description:
While in Chinatown, we wanted to have some Chinese food (of course) for dinner but out of the many restaurants to go to, we didn't know which one to try.  This was one of those times where we relied purely on the Yelp reviews and it everything turned out just fine.  My family of four had the vegetable fried rice, seafood chow mein, and string bean with beef in oyster sauce (mild).  The portions were very generous and the tastes were excellent!  We were pleasantly surprised at how much seafood the chow mein had!  It had scallops, squid, and shrimp.  I've never had string bean beef with oyster sauce but the tastes were reminiscent of beef and broccoli.  The string beans were cooked just right and still had a bit of crunch to them.  This is a dish I would definitely come back for.

Give this place a try because the reviews do this place justice...
author: Dan L.

description:
Save your time and money and go try one of the other places. Specially if you're here for Peking Duck (like we were). We ordered a full Peking duck and it arrived already carved, looking suspiciously smaller than a full duck, and definitely not enough for 4 people. On asking the servers (who were very nice) we were told they serve it almost boneless (which was true) so that's why it looks like it's less. The duck was fine, skin was crispy, but the sauce was just okay and it was served with tortilla instead of pancakes or buns. 
Because we (4 people) were no where near full,  also ordered sizzling chicken and the tai chin chicken which were also just about okay (I'd go with the Tai Chin chicken- the sauce and chicken were decent). Btw none of this was cheap. 
All in all, a very meh experience. You can find something much better in SF.
author: Sarmishtha S.

description:
Perhaps the most Americanized restaurant in Chinatown but still not my cup of hot tea. For starters, I'm not a fan of hot water and that was all that we got for about 5 minutes before our drink order was taken. On the drink subject, my water was never refilled but that's not too big of a deal. Pot stickers were absolutely delicious but the soup that you get automatically wasn't my favorite. Extremely sour and the spice grows on you pretty quickly. 

To the main course, my sweet and sour pork was flavorful and super tasty. However I will say that my dish came out something like 10 minutes before my lunch date's. If I'm completely honest, I was starving so I did start early but I would rather they hold my food in the back than bring it out that early?? Just my opinion, but it seemed a bit rude of them. The food wasn't overpriced and like I said, the place was pretty Americanized. Nice place for lunch just a couple hiccups in the service.
author: Cara H.

description: Amazing food and superb service-- Made us feel like family.
author: Paul D.

description:
Don't even look anywhere else. This place is out of this world! My boyfriend and I joke about flying to San Francisco just for this place. 
The chicken in spicy garlic sauce is our favorite. Check it out :)
author: Sarah W.

description: Excellent food, fresh & hot. My family and I ate here recently 10/28/18 and recommend it highly. We had 5 dishes, pot stickers as an appetizer plus sweet & sour chicken, broccoli beef, deep fried chicken wings, honey walnut prawns and chicken chow mein, we loved every dish and it came to the table piping hot & delicious. You won't be disappointed.
author: Julie S.

description:
Everything that I wanted in an Authentic Chinese Food!!! Perfectly seasoned.... and oh so yummy!!! 
I love the mango pudding that we were surprised with at the end of the meal!!! 
I think this is a Hidden Gem. We had the Sweet And Sour Chicken and Chicken Chow Mein!!! It was sooo good!!! 
Don't let the low stars fool you!! This place is amazing!!
author: Nicole C.

description:
XLB.   Very succulent and juicy indeed, be careful when you bite into it, it might burst.

Wonton soup.   Authentic flavor and the greens weren't bitter.

My only qualm is that they don't bring the food around the same time.   We would finish one dish then wait 5-10 minutes for the next.    It felt very spaced apart that I am able to write this review as we eat. 

The string beans with minced pork hit the spot with the shrimp fried rice.   The pork wasn't porky and could've easily been minced chicken.   FYI because I am not a fan of pork unless it is processed like bacon and sausage.   The shrimp fried rice was light and airy, with enough egg, peas and carrots in every bite.   Other than that it was a good meal and we would eat here again if in the area.
author: Roxana N.

description:
Looked up Chinese Food near me and this one came up. Run away fast! Got sick eating here. They cook there crab and scallop dishes with the guts and nasties still attached..eww 
Don't attempt to use the restroom you have to walk by the gross, disgusting tanks and the dirty filth in the hallway.
author: Gina G.

description:
Hunan Home has survived since forever. Having worked a block away, it was my go-to for large and small get-togethers in an informal setting.
One time I took my cousin there and was surprised by the expensive check. Oh well, San Francisco dollars has an unfortunate exchange rate. Anyway, the staff is so friendly, and remembers it's repeat customers. They have a large event space upstairs. 
So this happened: 
One time I ordered a combo dish ( chicken, beef, shrimp) and called the waiter over to ask why there was no shrimp. Answer: "chopped so fine you cannot see." 
Do you know the story of the candy wrappers?
It's a longtime tradition to buy a mint when you pay for your meal, then walk half a block north and stick the green wrappers in the same telephone pole. (see photo) It's a great found-object/ only-in-san francisco sculpture.
author: Lynn F.

description: If you are visiting San Francisco be sure to stop by this gem. The servings are generous and the food was delicious. We had the orange chicken, cashew chicken and beef and onion. The egg drop soup was soo good. We enjoyed our time in chinatown amd our dinner at Hunan Home's. I would defined stop by again when in town.
author: Mark A.

description:
I used to come here for lunch often when my office was located on clay. It's been a good 2 years the last time I was here and decided to come back and I even brought my new coworker. 

We sat and ordered; I got the beef brisket noodle soup. Our food came and we dug into the meal. As I bit into my noodle, I noticed this string like substance (I initially thought it was 'fat choy'/the black Chinese sea hair) and thought "Oh, this strand probably got crossed contaminated with another dish.." Then I found another and another and it was actually all over in my soup. I took a strand to inspect it further. Turns out, it's not what I thought it was (it looks like really long shrimp intestines). I even asked the manager what it was and he, 100%, didn't  know either and guessed it's a part of the meat. I was so grossed out, I lost my appetite.

I've had my fair share of beef brisket noodle and never have I seen this before, not even in the dirtiest of dirty restaurants.
author: Constance Y.

description:
Crispy orange chicken!

First time in San Francisco a day we landed here by accident. Well, we checked Yelp what's popular in the area we got lost in and we found ourselves here.

We weren't sure what to get so we asked the waiter the most popular order and he said the orange chicken and the hunan chicken. We chose the orange chicken and it was yummy! It was crispy and flavorful.

We also ordered shrimp fried rice and it's a smaller portion than what we're used to, but overall still yummy.

I'm not really sure what's the rave all about with this place. It was good, but nothing outstanding.

Would I recommend this place? Sure. I say if you are in this very area, it's worth going to... But that's about it.
author: Jane R.

description: very good chicken chao men. Good pi king duck. Great service
author: James L.

description:
Hunan is one of the mostly reviewed restaurants in San Francisco's Chinatown. So I decided to give this place a try.

Coming in there was already a wait and I noticed there were lots of tour groups inside dining in. There's only one table chair outside the entrance way, and after a few minutes we went inside their small wait area near the cashier booth. It was a Wednesday night, and it took about 15 minutes to finally get seated. 

We ordered the "Steamed Chicken" ($13.45). Its bone-in half chicken. You can't really get much taste out of these boiled pieces of meat, unless they provide a house sauce with it, but unfortunately we didn't get any. Other than its topped with shreds of onions and ginger, your left soy sauce on the table for added seasoning. Its not bad, but we've had better. "Chicken with Spicy Garlic Sauce" ($12.45). These deep fried orange chunks of chicken, tasted okay. It was mildly spicy and the glaze on the outside is sweet. The "Beef Fried Rice" ($9.95). I would pass up on these. There's not much to say about this fried rice, it's an easy make. It has a decent amount of beef and vegetables in it, but it tasted a little on the bland side. 

Overall, service was good and everyone here was friendly. However, the food quality is pretty much basic and average for the high prices. 

Hunan has good local ratings and its a favorite for tourist. If you're in for simple entrees and not so fancy mandarin meals, this place is for you.
author: Jon B.

description:
I have been to its south bay location so many times.  Last time I came to the SF one was decades ago.  Well, not much changed.  We Chinese knew exactly the difference between Hunan and Sichuan, yet restaurants need to cater to non-Chinese, so they all became generic over the years.

Here, I still found a sliver of Hunan.  Not much, sadly.

The classic one is the cured pork, I order that lunch special.  The waitress, understanding that I am a Chinese, asked if I want it extra spicy.  I declined.

The cured pork was well made.  Just the right smokiness and rendered tenderly.  The mixed veggie was reasonable.  The sauce is relatively standard and not bad.  I would have given it 4 star, except the rice was on the stale side.
author: Sin-Yaw W.

description: Wow amazing fast quick service. Food was delicious! After working around and everything smelling and looking good for what ever reason this one caught they eye. Price was just right.
author: Anthony H.

description:
On Labor Day 2017, when I was arriving in San Francisco, I visited to this Chinese restaurant located within Chinatown called, "Hunan Home's Restaurant." Hunan serves the customers of all ages to taste their sensational, eatable Chinese foods every day and night from Orange Chicken, Fried Rice, Chow Mein and many more! The atmosphere is very laid back and commonly active as I welcomed there. The concept is much similar and identical than any local Chinese restaurant across the U.S. although inside it's much original and classic for their interior with modest space floor.

The employees here from serves and cookers are doing a good job for making the customers like me a collective and remarkable service despite the busiest environment. No cons at all.

Now onto the food! Since there is no combination plates on the menu, I ordered my favorite Chinese food, Broccoli Beef with a side of a bowl of steamed Jasmine rice. As I ate it, the broccoli beef tasted alright although it tasted bitter as I thought. Kinda sourly after eating it constantly instead of being too savory of that entree. I wish they need to enhance the broccoli beef more savory and elegant next time without being to bitter. Also, on the other hand, the steamed white Jasmine rice did cooked perfectly! Fluffy and eatable without being too soft. Overall, not a bad meal for lunch.

Parking at Hunan Home's can be challenging to park. You can park at the nearby surface street parking nor the parking garage if it's available. You can also ride a bike, walk, carpool, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

All in all, Hunan Home's is the finest and closely averaged traditional Chinese restaurant that I've ever visited for the very first time. Hopefully, I'll be back again in the near future to try out their foods if it tasted better. A well visit indeed. My rating: 3 1/4 solid stars
author: William L.

description: Stopped in for lunch and got soup dumplings and fried rice. The soup dumplings were better then the ones in New York! So good! And fried rice was just as delicious, perfectly seasoned and not greasy!
author: Sarah H.

description:
Great service, the host who sat us was friendly and the waiter was a nice guy who helped us make our food selections.
Ordered the beef chow mein, orange peel chicken, and chicken in spicy garlic sauce.
Complimentary tea was piping hot and the food was great.
author: John D.

description:
Hard pass on this his place. Many more spectacular restaurants within close proximity, don't bother here. 
First off, the service is strange. No matter how big your party is, you will receive one menu for the table. This menu doesn't reflect what's online and the prices are written in. We ordered a number of items. These come out in random orders. Ingredients like shrimp were added without request. We got rice for the table - it was presented as a giant unshaped mound of rice and then the server threw the spoon into the top. Very strange. 
I also wanted to mention the latex gloves the server wore which made me think she was making the food in the back and then bringing it out. 
Overall, I would not be back even if it was free....but it's not, it's overpriced. One extra star because I liked the front windows.
author: Ryan G.

description:
Not a bad place, but also not truly spectacular. A solid 3 stars. Good service. I only tried the wanton's in hot chile sauce and one shredded pork dish which was really just sauteed in chile oil. No real sauce or spice to it. i would have to try more, to give it something more. 

The ambience is classic chinese with mirrors to expand the feel of the place. It is basically small with tired booths and big rounds.

Did see some chinese eating here, possibly even locals but overall it's in the heart of China Town and pulls in a lot of tourists.
author: Frank O.

description:
VERY good food.  We had Broccoli Beef, Chicken and String Beans (spicy!), Hunan Prawns, Sweet and Sour Chicken, and Pork Fried Rice.  Much fresher tasting than what I'm used to in MN.
Our waiter brought us complementary mango pudding!
author: Dan P.

description: Came back here for a second time and I am going to have to say that the service has gotten a lot better! We were attended to quick and the food was great! New spot for quality Chinese food while visiting San Francisco.
author: Kevin P.

description:
Maybe I'm just partial to East Coast Chinese food, because I honestly didn't like a single thing we ordered.  The Mongolian beef, which is a standard in my household, didn't even get finished.  We also had wonton soup, steamed dumplings, and peking duck.

The good part about being there was that it was during Chinese New Year, so some performers came in briefly and did a dragon dance.  That was cool.
author: Kisha M.

description:
While taking in the sights over in China Town, we realized that time was getting away form us. I was super hungry but I really wanted to indulge in some traditional/authentic food. Hunan Home's Restaurant came up in the Yelp search engine with some promising reviews. Therefore, we decided to check it out!

Hunan Home's Restaurant is located in the heart of China Town (San Francisco). It is on Jackson Street, between Grant Avenue and Kearny Street. A large sign outside of the restaurant displays its name in English and Chinese. You really can't miss it!

When we walked inside, we were greeted and seated right away. It's a lot larger inside than you would think. There are two levels, an upstairs dining room as well as a lower level. Tables are in close proximity to one another to maximize the number of customers that can be seated at any time.

We had a bit of a language barrier as we attempted to communicate with our waiter. I ended up ordering fried rice with just egg and shrimp. My husband ordered the combination plate. 

They asked us what we'd like to drink and I asked for a Coca Cola product. We sat at our table for a bit and my drink did not make it to our table. Soon after, our food was served but my Coke was still missing. We had to get our waiter's attention and let him know that I had my food but not my drink. I honestly started to eat my rice while we attempted to find the waiter. He was very busy so it was tough getting his attention.

My rice was ok but the shrimp did not taste that great. It had a strong fishy flavor. The shrimp didn't sit well with me so I focused more on the rice and egg . I just set the shrimp to the side and my husband helped me eat it. The food wasn't bad by any means but I felt that it was just okay. 

I love authentic restaurants because the Americanized version of ethnic food never does it any justice. Our experience at Hunan Home's Restaurant was interesting. I liked that their staff was friendly and that their patrons were of different ethnicities. In the end, I had mixed feelings about this place. The food was alright but service was off a bit.
author: Michelle T.

description:
I went on a trip to San Fran and was excited to get a meal in Chinatown. Because of our schedule, we knew we'd only have time for one meal in Chinatown, so we wanted to make it good. Of course, we turned to Yelp to see what sounded like a winner. We happened to be in close proximity to Hunan House and based on the reviews we gave it a try. 

I do have to say that this was BY FAR the best Chinese restaurant I've ever been to. However, the caveat is that we're from Ohio so the selections we have here are not that great (all of the chicken I've ever had from a Chinese restaurant tends to be questionable). AND I'm not the most adventurous, so I only ever get sweet & sour chicken. But I do have to say that this is the best sweet & sour chicken I've ever had and there's no way it could ever be topped. The chicken was excellent quality; all pure white meat with a crisp, flaky coating. Not anything drenched in coating like I've gotten at other places. The sauce was excellent as well. 

The interior is okay. I was actually very surprised at how big it is on the inside! There was a whole other downstairs seating area (which is where we were sat). I was a little disappointed because we were cold (we had just come from Golden Gate bridge and it was in March so kind of chilly) and the downstairs area of the restaurant was freezing! For whatever reason, we got sat right underneath a vent and it was blowing out cold air! Even when we asked to be re-seated, I still had to keep my jacket on the entire time. 

As for the service, it almost seemed we were an inconvenience. Our server did not smile once and I felt like he was very angry/unhappy. However, given the location, I can easily chalk this up as a cultural difference, perhaps?

All in all, it's a great stop for a bite to eat in Chinatown. Great food and I will definitely be back next time I'm in San Fran!
author: Chelsea E.

description:
While walking around and exploring SF Chinatown, my parents wanted some authentic Chinese food for dinner. Anddd that's how we found Hunan Home's on Yelp as it racked up quite a high rating. 

We were hopeful... however, food was just OK. Food wasn't terrible, but it wasn't exactly comparable to the ~4-star rating we saw and expected. There was also a line...but luckily we got our seats within about 5 minutes. One dish that came out great was the Moo shu pork!! I really liked how thin the ingredients were cut up. On top of that, our waitress helped us make wraps, which was a nice touch.

All in all, our experience was OK but nothing stand out. Next time my family's exploring Chinatown, we'll definitely visit another restaurant instead.
author: Franklin Z.

description:
This hidden gem is the place you need to go to if you are in Chinatown visiting. Just look out for the pink and blue overhang.

They have the best egg rolls I have ever had in my entire life. Wow. You can tell it is family owned and operated and the decor is great. 

We got the orange peel chicken and shrimp chow mein. Orange peel was sweet but spicy and shrimp chow mein was salty and savory. 

Awesome spot! Thank you for your hospitality!
author: Christie G.

description:
After living in the Bay Area close to 25 years now I've tried many Chinese restaurants up and down the Bay. This place has to be up there if not the best one I tried. As far as "authentic" I really don't care, this food was godamn excellent.

I ended up here because I was playing tour guide for relatives that came up for a Raider game.

BBQ pork appetizer
pot stickers
vegetarian egg roll
Mongolian beef
Orange Peel Chicken
Fried pork spare ribs

All of the food was super tasty and the portions were spot on. My favorites were  the Mongolian beef and spare ribs. Everything was fresh too and not overly sauced like most Chinese restaurants.

Our server was a real sweetheart too (I think her name was "Holly" or "Wendy") and she served us all with a smile even with my somewhat picky relatives.

Even though this is in Chinatown and it might seem touristy, I swear this is some of the best Chinese food around. This will be my main "go to" spot for Chinese in SF for sure.
author: Art O.

description: End up walking Chinatown that day search up a few spots luckily this one had no wait time . I guess for a 2 table is easy. The device was good. The food was good and they set a hot tea when u are seated. Prices were fair the food portions as well. Not much of a hassle to get your waitress they are all very attentive.
author: Manuel D.

description:
Oh my god the food here is not good and the service is so inattentive/slow!!!!

Lemon chicken: $11 ish and comes with 6 dry ass cubes. Tiny portion. Not to mention it was super bland! Panda Express trumps this junk.

Garlic pea sprouts: the pea sprouts were so old and dried out that we couldn't even swallow the stems. We could only eat the leafy bits. Sad. 

Walnut shrimp: the only decent thing here 

Hunan beef: minuscule portion. Literally 5 pieces of beef in the whole thing. And it wasn't even spicy when it was noted as spicy. Hunan food is supposed to be spicy!!! 
 
Fish in black bean sauce: Honestly flavorless LOL I cannot. 

Other notes: 
- Teapot was already at the table when we were seated so the tea was lukewarm. Wtf  
- First dish came 25 mins after placing the order 
- Three other dishes came 30 mins after placing order 
- They forgot one of the dishes and we had to remind them, and it came after we finished 80% of our food. L o l 
- Definitely not authentic Hunan food, or even Chinese food for that matter. You're better off at Panda Express tbh

But on the plus side they validate parking lol.
author: Marny N.

description: The orange peel chicken is basically candy. It's a delicious must-try for kids. I loved the Hunan string beans, which were super crisp and flavorful. Service was friendly and quick. Can't wait to come back.
author: Matthew R.

description: It was a decent chinese restaurant in the neighborhood, but to me who grew up eating a lot of chinese food, i thought it was ok. The stir-fry dishes we ordered was in a very gelly like texture, all of them, even though they have different sauce base. They do put a lot of beef or seafood in whatever dish you order so thats nice. It also looks a lot cleaner than most other chinese restaurants in the neighborhood. They gave us a free mango puree after dinner too and that was a nice surprise. I would have given it a 3,5 rating if I could.
author: Xi-Er D.

description:
Authentic Chinese food to its finest :) My girlfriend and I stumbled upon this place when we're visiting San Francisco's Chinatown. The ambiance of this restaurant is really crowded and have a long waiting line. From the outside, it looks like a random supermarket. The inside is still crowded, but hey we didn't mind at all. So if you are clusterphobic then godspeed to you :P... now the waiting game to get seated....

Luckily, we managed to be seated no longer than 10 minutes because we're just a party of two. Bizzarely, they asked us if we can be seated to a group since they have two seats available on that area.. yeap we did say yes because of starvation. It is pretty interesting to be seated with some local people and they were friendly. They said that this restaurant is one of the best. I was a little skeptical since the ambiance is not enthicing, but wow I was wrong.

The food is a killer.. No Panda Express or PF Chang here ladies and gents. They served the real deal Chinese cuisine. Of course, they have menus like orange chicken for tourist that is afraid to venture from their comfort zone, but my girl and I are nothing alike. I ordered their mushu beef, which I can described it as the Chinese food version of a burrito because they gave you rice wraps to blanket their delicious meaty beef. They gave you their sweet oyster sauce to enhanced the flavor as well. So good and unique to my taste.. sign me up! I like this dish. 

My girlfriend ordered their crispy fried chicken and shumai (pork meat dumplings). One of my awesome advise, if you're going to a Chinese restaurant is to order their fried chicken. It is a little salty than your average KFC, but Colonel Sanders will be jealous because if its crispiness and mouth watering flavor. The shumai on the other hand is always a great appetizer to start any Chinese meal. Overall, I like this place if you don't mind waiting :)

PS: Be open minded.. explore new food culture :)
author: Adrian A.

description:
It started to drizzle, cold outside even though it was May. It's unusual in Southern California where i was came from, sunshine always out there, people going surfing with almost naked. I took an Uber from Union Square where I went shopping both hands, wearing fur jackets. 

Located at the center of the China Town, where lots of red lanterns hanging overhead alongside the streets to celebrate the buddha's birthday, every corner remaining more than a hundred years of histories with Chinese traditional herbs, golds, produce, and many restaurants, this restaurant made people keep coming even though it's relatively smaller than its reputation.

This restaurant has lots of characters inside and outside, the signage with the golden Chinese letters, red decorations, Chinese speak waitstaffs clinking plates to bring fortunes, hot tea poured into the everyone's cup as I seated at the table, there's mingle Chinese and tourists, convivial, a home restaurant, I forgot the cold outside immediately.

I ordered sizzling rice soup, beef with veggies, and fried fish. Those were super delicious with sizzling sound on the killing hot plates, glowing radiant themselves under the dim lights, the jasmine tea made my throat smooth. I felt as though I were in China. But, i missed the mark that the dishes not big enough even though my friend and I shared three dishes and rice. 

By the way, I highly recommend this restaurant while you traveling SF.
author: Sun H.

description:
I came to this place after seeing great rating on yelp. The service is good and atmosphere is relatively quiet for a Hunan Chinese Restaurant.

We ordered: (in order of best dish to least favorite dish)

Hot spicy crispy chicken:
The chicken was cooked really well. The meat comes right off and the skin was crunchy.

Ma Po tofu:
The tofu was really soft and the minced pork was a great pairing to the dish.

Hunan string beans:
This was the dish that was probably the most salty out of the 3 we ordered. 


The reason I give this place a 3 is mostly because the food here is really salty. I believe this place is more salty than it is spicy. My friend kept ordering water!
author: Chloe C.

description: My husband& I agree that Hunan Home's has the best Chinese food that we have ever tasted !!!We will eat there every time we visit San Francisco.
author: 敬

description: This place isn't that bad. If your looking for some Chinese food I would recommend this place if you wanna get seated and food in 15 minutes. There wasn't any wait for us. As of the food is waa good just like any average Chinese restaurant. We were craving Dim Sum but the wait across from this restaurant was ridiculous. As of the menu if your looking for dishes with shrimp they call it Prawns compared to Chinese restaurants back home. Cleanliness of the bathroom was good there was only 2 stalls and it was downstairs. Service was average. But I would recommend going here if your craving chinese. Reminded me a little of Seafood Town in Torrance.
author: Veronique V.

description: First time here. Good place. Had sizzling rice soup and dumplings! Delish!! Hubby had chicken chow fun and it was the best I've had. Highly recommend
author: C.S P.

description:
We wanted to eat something in chinatown that was worth it. Looked up on yelp and saw that they had a lot of reviews so we decided to try it out to see what the hype was all about.

Pros:
- Wait time wasn't that long, when we came by there there a short long with a few people in front. Got in, in about 10ish minutes
- They have a downstairs area which is probably more spacious than the one in front. I didn't feel all squish together next to people
- Food came out fast
- A lot of food to choose from
- We got the yang chow fried rice, sweet and sour pork, egg flower soup, shredded jellyfish, and honey walnut prawns. 4 out of 5 was delish. The egg flower soup wasn't that great. The honey walnut prawns was really good, the prawns were large. The fried rice was good. The sweet and sour pork was the winner, it has a torchy taste to it (if you've has a sushi roll that was torched on top, it has that flavor) we both really enjoyed it.

Cons:
- Not sure why our tea was spilling when we were pouring it. It spilled all over the table, but since the workers were so busy, they weren't at the table long enough for us to even get their attention
- Chairs and tables needs to be updated

Overall,
I personally think the sweet and sour pork was the main reason for the 4 stars, it was delish :)
author: Vonnie T.

description: I can't believe I've never reviewed Hunan Homes.  EVERY trip to SFO I make sure HH is on the agenda - lunch, dinner, or both!  My first time in town I asked the staff at the Hyatt where the best place for good old Chinese food was in town.  Without hesitation, she sent me off to HH.  WOW!  EVERYTHING I've had here is fantastic.  The Mongolian Beef, spareribs, the fried rice, soups.  You can't go wrong here!  ENJOY!
author: Jim W.

description: Pretty good chinese food,  and i usually don't like chinese food but this place turned it around for me.
author: Kristine N.

description:
You can't trust my rating of Chinese restaurants. Most of my Chinese food has come from local restaurants in a city where only 0.61% of its residents are Chinese. But because it's a pet peeve to leave a check-in without a review, here I am.

Hunan Home's looks like its always closed. Open the door, its probably not. There are two levels for seating. The decor is what you'd expect, although getting into the outdated side of things.

Food

I went real Panda express in here. 

I ordered a chicken dish and some noodles. Both were amazing to me. The noodles had a softness that I had never experienced in my life. The flavor that the sauce accompanying the chicken had was epic. The spices used put it ahead. 

Service fed me respectfully and efficiently.

Hunan Home's was great for me. One of the most bothersome things is high ratings on foods that people have no business reviewing, so I can't be a hypocrite and give it a 5. My argument for a 4? "Yay! I'm a fan" is subjective while "Woohoo! As good as it gets" isn't.
author: Javier J.

description: SF Chinese is where it is at and I was not blown away by Hunan's food. I was strolling around china town and stumbled upon Hunan when looking for highly rated Chinese restaurants near by. I ordered chow mein hong kong style (of course) but unfortunately, it was the worst dish we ordered in my opinion. Sticky and lacked flavor. The other dishes we ordered were sweet and sour chicken, various vegetables, fried rice, and chow fun (the best dish I ordered). Overall, not that impressed for how well it was reviewed.
author: Ashley F.

description:
Wow! After leaving the city I was on the hunt for some Chinese food and again yelp delivered.

I walked down into this little gem tucked away next to many other Chinese restaurants.

I ordered sweet and sour pork, beef green beans, and house chow mein.

The green beans were killer! I sat in the back seat as I ate while my dad drove us back. The smell of garlic aroma filled the car and the flavor was even better. The chicken was SEASONED...you could tell! Sauce on it was great. I really liked the chow mein as well. Really fresh.

If I happen to be in SF again I wouldn't mind paying a visit here. Only reason it's not 5 star is because of the portion sizes of the to go containers.
author: Alexys E.

description: After researching the best place for Hunan Chinese food, I chose this spot.  There was a short line but the wait was worth it.  The food was excellent and for a very fair price.  Everything we ordered was delicious.  Go there on your next San Francisco trip.  You will love it
author: Cindy C.

description: This place was pretty good. First time in SF and had to try a Chinese restaurant. Came across this one and was highly satisfied. Im Korean so dont trust my rating on this one  but it was bomb!
author: Kevin H.

description:
Chinese Food the way I remember it!

Before I move to San Francisco I lived in New York and back there this was the kind of Chinese food to which I was originally introduced. Look, I know one has many fancy options in this beautiful city of ours, but if you ever want to experience what the previous generations in North America called "Chinese Food", you would get a pretty good idea here!

The service was good, the food was even better and our group enjoyed a nice meal together.
author: Afshin A.

description: If you like Caucasian Chinese Food this is the place to come.  If you are looking for really good "Chinese" food go somewhere else. Bland. I let my waiter order something his local customers would like. Garlic chicken. No garlic. Even the peppers where blah. Honey walnut shrimp? Really?
author: Alan G.

description: So good!  Sizzling rice soup and appetizers were delicious.  Very dramatic when they put the chicken with black bean sauce on the sizzling platter.  Amazing green beans, so tender and crisp, studded with little bits of pork and salty bits of preserved turnip.  Really good food!
author: Alex L.

description:
What the Yelp?!  I'm a big fan of Yelp and over time I've found that Yelpers get it right most of the time, but...  Wow!  No!  I cannot imagine how some of the other reviewers has such a different experience than we did.  The food was mediocre at best, the atmosphere is stale, the waiters are super not friendly and the service was terrible.  No need to ever return to this restaurant!

There were 6 of us and we ordered 5 dishes, Wonton Soup, Chow Fun, Shrimp in Lobster sauce, Chinese Broccoli and Beef and Moo Shu Pork...  If I was basing this review on the food only I'd probably give it 2.5 stars.  It wasn't terrible, just completely mediocre and unmemorable.  But when you factor in how bad the rest of it was...  Some food came, but we had to ask literally 4 or 5 times to get rice and by the time it arrived we'd eaten most of everything already.  Could not get them to bring the pancakes for the Moo Shu until the dish was cold...  

I rarely beat up waitstaff, because I know it can be a tough gig, but this guy was aggressively incompetent and just plain rude.

All I can tell you is that for me and everyone in my group it was unanimous...  Nope!
author: Christopher V.

description: Stopped in on a whim. I ordered sweet and sour chicken and hubby ordered chicken with orange peal. Some of the ingredients weren't listed on the menu, such as peppers, onions, etc. So be sure and ask if any of these are of concern to you. The rice was an additional charge of $1.25/meal which was a surprise. Flavor and serving size were good at a reasonable price.
author: Jerri D.

description: This is a very good Chinese restaurant for anyone who isn't looking for fancy. It's comfortable, well decorated and pretty big. Both of us had orange peel chicken and it was amazing. We also had a fun waiter. The staff work really efficiently and don't make you feel awkward at all. They are really friendly. I would highly recommend Hunans to anyone.
author: Evan H.

description:
Very few Asians eating here. Food was meh. Ordered Mongolian beef - flavor was good but the cuts of beef were fatty. Fried fish with black bean sauce - not great. Crispy fried noodles with seafood - disappointing. Pea vi es were ok. 

Would not come here again.
author: Toni T.

description:
We came here for dinner on our last vacation day in San Francisco.  The reviews and food photos looked really good so we decided to give it a go. 

Inside is a typical traditional asian restaurant setting with dated decor and old soundtrack dating to ancient china. 

The food however is another story. We ordered a wonton soup for 2 which was enough to fill 3 typical bowls with lots of wontons inside. It tasted great too that we ordered a second serving later. 

Mongolian beef was very tender and a bit spicy but tasted great. Also portions are fairly large so order a few different plates to share and try everything. 

We also ordered Hunan Chicken which was excellent as well. 

I'd return here next trip to SF.   

Also, they have a Large Tsing Tao (pint) so that made me very happy. 

they also accommodated my picky child who only eats plain noodles.
author: Eugene O.

description:
How this place is no 1 on YELP is a mystery to me?!!
Ask a local where to eat! 

It's a tiny hole in the wall dump! People go here because of the Yelp reviews only!

The food is mediocre at best! Tasteless slime slop is my description of this! Go elsewhere!! Trust me please! Service is crap also!

My first thought was OMGGGGG phone the health department to check this out!!! 
Why you ask ... It's filthy dirty!!!! I saw a filthy tile floor my feet stuck and black filth grout! I saw an old man asleep on a table on my way to the toilet! I saw the filthy kitchen!!! Yuckkkkkkk! Black mold line the sinks! The service unfriendly a 3/10!!! This place is hype!! I give it a minus 1/10!!!!!
author: S T.

description: Meh. We wanted to try Chinese in Chinatown. It was rated well and busy so we thought it was a safe bet. Host seemed unable to negotiate seating large parties and those waiting. First waiter walked up looked at us and walked away. Finally got waited on and food came pretty quickly. Food was just okay, nothing special. I'd recommend looking elsewhere or ask a local.
author: Sharon H.

description: Great food and generous portions. Looks can be deceiving because it looks smaller than it is. Loved the food and it's authentic because we saw Asians eating there as well.
author: T, P.

description:
I'm not sure why this place is so highly rated, the food was alright. There's way better food in the area for cheaper prices. 

The space was nice and clean though and they took credit card (even AMEX) so that's a plus. 

All the smoke pork dishes were subpart and I wouldn't recommend. The string beans were great but that's about it.
author: Ming Y.

description:
I was staying down town for a work conference and had a free lunch break so a colleague and I made our way to China Town. I was craving XLB and a Yelp search lead me to Hunan Home. 
The food and service were yummy and the price can't be beat! We shared a moo shu pork and an order of XLB. They brought out complimentary tea and sweet and sour soup (I didn't like this but I'm not holding this against them since it's not something I typically like and I didn't order it).
The XLB were wonderful - warm, silky, delicious. I could have just eaten these for my meal! The moo shu was also good. The pancakes were fresh and held up well and the waitress prepared our first wrap herself which was a nice touch. 
The meal was filling and added up to about $20 - you'd be hard pressed to find a better meal for 2 for that price in SF!
author: Bonnie D.

description: Portions were a little smaller than I expected for the price! usually at Chinese restaurants they serve very large portions but I think this place is a little skimpy on the meat. Also after living in China, most of the food here would be considered American style Chinese food so I was a little disappointed in the lack of authenticity. You would think one of the better restaurants in Chinatown would have good quality authentic food! Guess not. Anyway if you like your basic orange chicken (which is not even an actual Chinese dish lol) then they have it.
author: Craig L.

description: We used to come here all the time. My mom had been coming here for years. They used to have the best pot stickers. But they changed management and kept the same name. All the employees are new. The food is different and you can tell. It is ok but I miss the old management and food.
author: Michelle C.

description: This is a really decent Chinese place to eat in Chinatown if you are ever in the area. Just keep in mind that this place gets super busy so be prepared to wait a little.
author: Jay G.

description:
12 years I've been eating at Hunan Home's and today was the day I heard this classic Chinatown gem is no more. New management, new servers, same name; but definitely not the same food you've come to enjoy.

If you've been coming here for years... do yourself a favor and start looking for a new favorite restaurant.

RIP Hunan Home's... I'll be dreaming of those tasty Potstickers.
author: Tony R.

description: A friend and I were wondering around Chinatown and stumbled upon this place. The menu looked great and they had a lunch special that included soup, rice, tea, and an entree. If you want to be seated right away, you should probably arrive early. We came at a great time and was promptly seated. People started to pour in after us making the wait time around 20 minutes. The service was average. The guy came by to bring us our food and take our order. We tried to flag him down for some water, but he never came by. The food was outstanding though! I ordered the Mongolian beef. The beef was cooked perfectly and the sauce was the best I've ever had. I would for sure come back, but next time I hope the service is a little better! Give it a try!
author: Michelle H.

description: Pretty good food in a small venue. We got there right before the crowd so was seated immediately. The spicy crispy chicken was not spicy at all, and I don't care for a lot of spice. I will say their fried rice had an amazing flavor and the succulent bread was a surprise.  Loved it!  Nothing extraordinary but good food.
author: Peggy H.

description: Amazing egg rolls! But warning the chicken they use in the chow mien and fried rice has a weird texture and fishy  taste.
author: Kai Renee L.

description:
Yelp wins again! "Hmm what Chinese place should we go in Chinatown?" A hard question to be sure. With 4 stars and 1400 reviews, this seemed like a winner. And indeed it was!

I got the cashew prawns, which were super good. Honey walnut would probably be even better but isn't on the lunch menu. They also don't charge tons for seafood, which is awesome. Dad got the string bean prawns, which were also super tasty. Mom got the beef and broccoli, which is the best beef and broccoli I've ever had. It's probably loaded up with MSG given how savory it was, but even if it is, it's worth it. 

The xiao long bao is tasty though not the best in the city. Still worthwhile if you have a hankering :)
author: Chris S.

description:
This is one of the few places that I crave a least once a week. But since the line is long, I only come during week nights.

My Asian friends are almost always doubtful when I recommend Hunan home to them. Especially after they see the long line of non Asian folks, they usually begin to question my food cred. I guess a tell tale sign of authenticity is usually how many locals hit up these restaurants. In this respect Hunan home stands out, because of its popularity among the non Asian population. Despite of this, this place is still top on my list. 

The thing to get here is any of their sizzling hot plate dishes. They are to die for. You can't go wrong with any of the meat combination sizzling dishes. The beef ones are great and so is any of the seafood ones. Beef and scallops is also really good.

Sizzling hot plate dishes are usually a combination of meat, peppers, onions, cooked with some fermented bean paste sauce that is then sautéed right infront of you on a heated hot plate. It sizzles when the food touches the hot plate hence, the name. These dishes are usually super flavorful and goes extremely well with rice! I get at least one of these every time I go.

Remember to order at least one sizzling dish when you are here!
author: Sherica L.

description: Nice egg rolls, good soup, good quality meats and veg. The seafood was underwhelming. Nice clean interior, good service. I would come back.
author: Joni W.

description: I had dinner with my family here on a recent trip to San Francisco. It was such an enjoyable experience!   Dinner is served family style, and the food was both delicious and very reasonably priced.  The string beans were crisp and full of flavor, we ordered the orange chicken and modified it to non-spicy (for my nephew), and the moo shu pork was really good too. Our waitress, Ling, was the best. She was friendly, helpful, and funny! The location was convenient too with a parking structure just down the street (because finding parking on the main street was impossible), and the restaurant is  close to all of the shops in Chinatown.  We're definitely going to make a tradition out of visiting Hunan Home's every time we visit.
author: Jacquelyn Z.

description:
I'm still super impressed that over the period of four months the food had remained consistent here. I am able to order things to go and they are ready in a timely manner. Service is hit and miss but the quality of the food totally makes up for it. I look forward to returning here when my craving hits for Chinese food!

Review #4 of 2017
author: Stephanie G.

description: An Uber driver recommended this place, and it didn't disappoint. Above average flavor in all the dishes we ordered. The Garlic Eggplant with ground pork was off the hook!!
author: Mel B.

description:
It seems like there are always reviews coming in for this place. Last I checked, this place only had 3.5 stars, which surprised me. Stopped by for lunch on a busy Saturday afternoon and only had to wait 5 minutes before being seating. Our server was very sweet and gave us time to look through their extensive menu. In the mean time, she brought over waters (with 2 ice cubes), tea and plates/silverware. My boyfriend and I shared an order of their house fried rice, honey walnut shrimp, and pot-stickers as an appetizer. I have to say the pot-stickers were my least favorite. Growing up, I've always had them crispy with a mix of soy sauce and vinegar for dipping. They were very large and doughy which made them difficult to eat and a little tasteless, in my opinion. Because the dough was so thick and not enough meat, I felt like I had to soak it in the sauce for some extra flavor. HOWEVER, the fried rice and shrimp was perfect and so delicious. Reminded me of the good 'ol days when my mom used to make her home-cooked meals for me..
Highly recommend and can't wait to go back (:
author: Molly M.

description: New owners and basically a new restaurant. Probably shouldn't be listed as Hunan Home's it is not the same place in any way, and not for the good. Table and bench chairs dirty and sticky. The waitress barley greeted us. Didn't respond to anything we said or asked for was just silent. When our dinner entrees arrived at the table she just plunked then down and walked away, we decided it wasn't even worth trying to ask for plates. The dishes also had changed and recipes had clearly changed, Gone was the food we liked at this place. The only time she said anything was when she handed us $10 in ones as change, really with that service don't expect to get much...... food left us with a goofy tummy. Bathroom was also dirty, needles to say we won't be back. It's a shame because we liked the previous restaurant.
author: Michael B.

description:
Maybe it was the 10 mile walk along the water that put us in some sort of famished hunger mode, or maybe it was the menu choices we made, but this was the best meal we had during our three day visit to the city!

Prepare for a wait if you come around dinner time, but the wait moves pretty quickly or so it seemed. There were about 10 people in front of us, and the wait to get a table was only 5-10 minutes. Service is friendly enough, food came out fast and hot. We tried the dumplings, veggie egg rolls, orange peel chicken, Hunan green beans and the chicken chow mien. All gets a big thumbs up! The dumplings were  much larger than we expected and had great flavor! The orange peel chicken was great and not spicy as it indicates on the menu. The green beans were a little salty, so be aware, but they were delicious and worth a little extra salt if you ask me! 

They also greet your table with a pot of hot tea which was perfect to sip throughout the meal. Overall we had an excellent dining experience and will definitely be back, and will recommend to everyone we know who makes a visit to SF!
author: Kaitlin K.

description: Highly recommend this Chinese restaurant. So delicious soup. I am not a spicy fan, so I just order the  wonton soup. Wonton skin just perfect with the stuffing. Yummy yummy
author: Kelly C.

description:
The food was yummy. I guess I took more of a liking to the food since the bf's family is from Hunan province.

We ordered four dishes: sweet and sour soup, Hunan smoked pork, Hunan string beans, and kung pao sliced fish. 

---

Sweet and sour soup: Though the sweet and sour soup was thick and authentic, I didn't take a liking to it. Maybe it's because I'm so used to the diluted version. Lol. The flavors were full on in this soup for sure. 

Hunan smoked pork: This was the bf's pick. It was only okay imo as it was a tad to salty for my taste buds. 

Hunan string beans: This was my pick, and it was the best out of the dishes we ordered. I'm not a veggie loving girl, but this dish was simply divine. The string beans were tender and flavorful. 

Kung pao sliced fish: My friend loves fish, and this was his pick. The fish was tender and pretty tasteful.

---

The place was packed when we arrived during lunch time. There was a constant stream of both Asian and non-Asian people waiting to be seated. 

The bathroom, which is located down the stairway, was ... um ... well used. Just adding this little side note...
author: Andrea M.

description:
More than traditional  Chinese American food.  
Good service and loved the "Mango Flan/Custard" to cleanse the palate after your meal!
author: D. K. G.

description: Lots of choices on menu.  Lunch menu is limited.  Place is clean.  No gluten free choices.
author: Lauren T.

description: The service was nice and the place was clean. But the food was worse than a Chinese fast food takeout place. The flavor just wasn't there. All the non-Asian diners in the restaurant seemed to enjoy it. I was quite disappointed after following a blogger's recommendation. Wish I had more time to try out other places.
author: Ei N.

description: We waited outside for about 15 mins. Waiters were prompt. I had Hunan chicken it was a bit to oily. My husband
author: Ronnie w.

description:
Frist let me say I hate fish and anything fish flavored. My partner ordered the Seafood soup. I downed two bowls before being told this. That being said I love this place based on it's flavors and love they put into their food 

We  had: Seafood Soup With Fish Tripe Soup, Orange peel beef, Pork Fried Rice and Beef Chow Mien 

The pork in the fried rice was juicy and flavorful and sweet notes at the end. The noodles in the Chow Mien themselves had amazing like beef broth flavors. All the vegetables has a good crunch to them.

We came on Christmas day wait was under 20 minutes.
This place is my go to in SF when I want good, authenticate food.
author: Christopher S.

description:
Great authentic Chinese food. 
Excellent variety!  I ate like a fat pig.
Superb service and a great choice if you want to eat in Chinatown in San Francisco.
We had a large party of 7 and the circle turning piece on top of the table was perfect for us to share all the food.
Oh; great inexpensive prices!
author: Aaron D.

description: Every thing was excellent!! Great prices, good ambiance and amazing food!! Probably the best Chinese food I've ever had! Everything was fresh and the service was excellent!
author: Edward C.

description:
Yes, the Roast Pork with gravy over rice is the star here. Included soup and put sticker are pottery good too.

I've got a salty palate, so I add just a dash of salt to the Roast pork, but it's super tender and delicately flavored.

The interior is standard divey cafe, but they're friendly and the Roast pork is legit.

Now, this review is solely based on the Roast pork dish, which means I'll have to come back to try the curry stew, zha jiang mian, and other stuffs later. Will return and report.
author: J S.

description: Friendly service.  Was hoping for more from a recommended spot in Chinatown.  Chicken with orange peel is flavorful.
author: Jeff S.

description: Found this restaurant in Chinatown.  Good food & nice Service.  New place to get food next time when you visit Chinatown.
author: Linda T.

description:
In an area where there are countless restaurants it may become overwhelming to choose one. Well I'm here to help you my friend! Look no more and stop by this place. The service is amazing, the food is delicious and the prices are up to par.

Four of us stopped by and they seated us right away. I noticed that as soon as people leave they clean their tables and have them ready to go for whoever comes in. In fact the entire time we were there I never noticed anyone waiting longer than five minutes. Pretty impressive for such a small/medium restaurant. They handed us menus and hot tea. We ordered our drinks. The drinks came in soda cans and a cup with ice, different but neat. 

The food: we ordered egg rolls as an appetizer. They came out almost instantly and they were nice and warm and crispy. With a side of sweet sauce it was a great starter. For the main course we ordered orange Kung pao chicken, chicken orange peel, prawns with walnut, combo chow mein and white rice. 

The Kung pao chicken was the best I've had, nice and spicy and the chicken was delicious. Orange peel chicken was crispy and full of flavor. The prawns with walnut, taste like honey walnut shrimp but more scrumptious. The chow mein was also full of flavor and plenty of shrimp, chicken and pork meat. We each filled our plates and they had Chilli paste that was also so delicious. The perfect Chilli to top your rice and chow mein with. All that food was able to feed us not just once, but twice. Yes we all got seconds. We actually finished everything on the table and almost wished we had ordered more. 

The servers checked in on us every now and then and cleared plates we were done with instantly. 

To top it off the bill was the cheapest bill we had seen on our entire trip there. 

Definitely stop by this place if you're ever in Chinatown. You won't regret it.
author: Andrea A.

description:
Wow, I thought how good could it be but I'm a fan! We were told to expect a 25 minute wait but they were asking people if they were OK with sitting together at the bigger tables and we ended up sitting with a family of 4 so we waited 15 minutes ish only. We ordered decisively and quickly but the food came out SO quickly too, it was incredible (especially because we were starving).

We got the xiao long bao which are the soup dumplings, and I've had Din Tai Fung, I've had Mama Lu's all in LA/SGV area but this was pretty good. Not as good as Din Tai Fung but similar to Mama Lu's. It was under $7 for 6 of these and it was piping hot. What I didn't like about theirs was that the skin of the dumpling was too thick. We also got a small sizzing rice soup which was great, my preference is always the watery kind not the corn starch thickened and it was again, super quick. The timing was perfect, as soon as we ate the dumplings, the soup came out and just as we finished with our soup, our kung pao deluxe came out. The kung pao deluxe had a nice and spicy kick to it, came with large shrimp, pieces of beef, chicken and bell peppers. The prices were cheap to reasonable and I was impressed by the operations of this place, runs like a well oiled machine. Service was super prompt and we never waited for anything. The only thing that could've made this place better was if they had kimchi as my Korean palette-d husband said.

Oh and as we were finishing our meal the other family was getting their food and everything looked incredible. The Mu Shu, the fried dumplings, pan fried noodles all looked amazing, my husband and I should've extended the olive branch first and just shared our food lol.

This is a no frills straight up Chinese restaurant and I highly recommend this place!!
author: Amy K.

description: I had wonderful time with my best friends here.  Great food & atmosphere. Hot & Spicy, Delicious.  Sweet & Sour. Seafood !!
author: Victoria T.

description: Best hole in the wall Chinese food in SF's Chinatown. Cute atmosphere inside and AMAZING food. Expansive menu. Go there now.
author: Kristian H.

description: Excellent food and service. Big portions and we are from Texas so make sure you don't make our mistake and order too much food. Food was delicious one of our favs while in San Francisco. Definitely recommend!
author: Zuri P.

description: My husband and I were in the mood for Chinese and came across this place on yelp. Yelp did not disappoint, this place was very very good. We got the orange peel chicken and the combination noodles. The chicken was crispy and the right amount of sauce. The noodles O.M.G. The best I have had. We will definitely will be back when we are in town.
author: Claudia M.

description:
As someone who uses Yelp to make many of my restaurant decisions, I decided to try Hunan Home's Restaurant as one of the most Yelped Chinese food spots in Chinatown.

Pros:
-The bbq pork and wonton soup were really good. 
-Overall friendly service.

Cons:
-The food wasn't all served together. This made it hard to make a plate with all of the different items we ordered.
-The combo chow mein and broccoli beef both didn't have much flavor. 
-Portions were small.
- Dirty fish tank up front. While not food related, it is still the first thing you see when you walk into the restaurant.

Overall, this spot is not nothing special. Disappointing Chinese food in Chinatown. 3 stars.
author: Matt T.

description:
I visited here on a short notice coming up from Monterey. I had searched on Yelp for some good Chinese food around the SF area. I will give my rating in sectiona based on Food and the location/appearance of the restaurant.

The food was definitely a 5, no arguing. I came with family and we ordered Kung pao chicken, broccoli with beef, beef with baby corn, shrimp and pork fried rice and chicken chow mein. I could say I had a pretty good example of what most people would order if they came here. The menu was large and had a variety of different meats, in different styles. The actual food that I ordered was very tasty, flavorful and just damn delicious. I would like to warn you that the kung pao chicken is a bit spicy so if you can't handle the heat, you could probably tell them to do no spicy. Overall, all the food came out steaming hot.

Hunans is located in the heart of Chinatown and is surrounded by the usual hustle and bustle of people walking and many other store fronts. The store itself is quite easy to find but parking on the otherhand is a challenge. Although there is a structure nearby it can fill up easily and usually all the parking in front of the stores are taken depending on the time you visit. The restaurant itself is what you would expect of a store in Chinatown. Its a bit old and small but honestly I didn't care and I don't think it is a good reflection on the overall rating of this restaurant.
author: Troy Q.

description: The best Chinese cuisine in Chinatown! The Food and services very good. I like the pot stickers, hot and sour soup.
author: Helen Z.

description: Wonderful meal and service from Ling. Great value for the price. We went family style.
author: Dolores A.

description: Hot and sour soup? Sooo good! We also ordered the orange chicken and spicy garlic chicken dishes. Definitely winners. The chicken fried rice was lacking in flavor and the chicken itself, however. Otherwise, we loved the food and ambiance!
author: Amy R.

description: Solid spot right here. Food was pretty amazing although the tea was basically water. Enjoyed the soup appetizers and main dishes would recommend people to this place.
author: Wyatt R.

description: One of my favorite places tp go for dates. Romantic feel, great food, excellent service. Highly recommended
author: Justin K.

description: Oh my gosh. We just went here on a whim after looking at places in Chinatown on Yelp. I am so glad we stopped by!! We had the Potstickers, Cashew Chicken, Orange Chicken, Sweet & Sour Pork, and Vegetable Fried Rice! Every single plate was empty before we left. It was all so delicious and wasn't busy at all!
author: Cassidy R.

description: This is one of my favorite Chinese restaurants in SF, which its home made style Hunan dishes always taste good, price is acceptable and actually cheap.  I always order their egg soup and fried straight beans.  Definitely recommend people who love hunan style.
author: Ciel S.

description:
Atmosphere:
* Cramped tables close together
Staff:
* Medicore Service
Service:
* Normal speed of service
Food:
* Nothing too special for the food. There is a lot of hype but did not live up to it at all. Not bad though
Tips:
* Xiao Long Baos are pretty good. That's what they are apparently know for.
author: E Z.

description:
Stumbled on this place while hanging out in San Francisco today in Chinatown!!

What a great surprise!!

Will eat here again!!

Hunan chicken was amazing and Mongolian Beef was really really good!!
author: Maria V.

description:
San Francisco's Chinatown is so beautiful and cute. My mother and I walked down there from the scarlet Huntington this evening to take a stroll and go to dinner. We went to the Hunan home kitchen for dinner, and it was delicious!

We just arrived in San Francisco today and we are having a great time. There are so many cute stores and restaurants and boba places!

Seriously enjoying the food we are eating right now. We got wor Wonton soup, Combo chow mein, a Side of assorted veggies, and xiao long bao dumplings at Hunan Home Kitchen. DELISH! The food is so rich and the service was great. I have traveled to China several times, and the food at this restaurant is just as good if not better than the food in actual China.

I recommend the dumplings that we started off with because they are especially delicious. They even have a little bit of peanut butter in them! Wow! We then got boba down the street... Great walking!

I would definitely go back here. Everything we got was amazing and the service was superquick!
author: Amanda W.

description:
At first I didn't know what to make of Hunan Home's. I've never been here with my family and I can understand why. Most of the customers aren't Asian and it's catered more to non-Chinese because of it's location near North Beach. I was skeptical on whether or not this place had authentic Chinese food or Panda Express style food.

The decor of this place seems very Chinatown old school style (fish tank in the front, pink table cloths, green seats and decor). The staff here seems like they've worked here for a long time too. It sort of feels like I'm time traveling to back to the early 1900s (they actually opened in 1983). Or maybe even from that Chinese restaurant scene in Rush Hour. 

Compared to other Chinese restaurants, Hunan Home's food is more flavorful and they have more "entertaining foods" like showing you the sizzling effects of the beef/rice crackers in front of you.

-Peking Duck: Love the duck. The fattiest duck I've ever had. Almost tasted like butter. Seriously amazing.
-Sizzling Rice Soup: Pretty cool how they place the soup out first and then add the rice crackers, which instantly crackles in the hot soup! Pretty cool.
-Sizzling Beef: One of the few/only Chinese restaurants in the bay area I've been to that sizzles the beef right in front of you. I guess the sizzling trick is great entertainment for foreigners? haha.
-Dry-Fried Green Beans with Ground Pork: I thought it would be really spicy with the red chilies, but it's barely spicy. Not bad. 
-Xiao Long Bao: Not the best. Skin was thick, not enough broth, and meat was just okay. 
-Shrimp Fried Rice: Very flavorful and oily. Shrimp is fresh. Would recommend!
-Salt and Pepper Fish: Very delicious. I'm not really interested in fried foods but this was delicious. Very hot and fresh and crispy.

This place is very fascinating. I've never seen such a diverse mix of people inside a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown before. It's pretty interesting to just sit and watch everyone, actually. Haha.

I would absolutely come again. Definitely make a reservation because this place is packed. I highly recommend the peking duck, shrimp fried rice, and salt & pepper fish!
author: Vicki L.

description:
So THIS is Chinese food! I can't claim to be any kind of expert in Chinese food. My family loves it, but we don't have much choice coming from Santa Barbara. On a recent overnighter to SF, we made it a point to check out some "more real" Chinese. Found Hunan Home's Restaurant on Yelp and it did not disappoint! Located towards the north end of Chinatown, there was an understandable 10-15 minute wait for the 5 of us on a Saturday evening at 6:30pm, even after calling ahead (which we were told didn't guarantee a table anyway). The restaurant was cozy/homey and well staffed. Nothing fancy, but relatively clean and comfortable. We had some very basics: egg rolls, orange peel chicken, prawns with broccoli, combination chow mein and pork fried rice. All I can say is that it was like seeing in color after only seeing in B&W.

Egg rolls and filling were so hot and crisp they literally exploded with each bite. Chicken had a nice crunchy exterior and liberal amount of orange zest and spice to it. Prawns were huge and perfectly cooked. Chow Mein had a nice touch of crunchy cabbage mixed in and a wonderful texture to the noodles. Pork fried rice was light and fluffy - I almost didn't recognize it, compared to the heavy, grease-laden stuff I am used to.

Menu appeared quite extensive beyond what we had. Service was attentive and efficient, with perfect pacing of the dishes - portions were standard, and I didn't find the prices unreasonable. I can't make a testament to the more exotic fare, but in the category of basic, solid Chinese in America, Home's has got my vote. Will definitely be returning to explore more of the menu!
author: Kim R.

description: 25 years of eating here and not one average meal.  Wide variety of great dishes - String Bean A La Hunan (a must), any of the sizzling plates (great), and the Succulent Bread (fried) is a one-of-a-kind experience!  In my opinion it is the best Chinese restaurant in SF - and I have been to 30+ others.  Fresh, quality meat (for Chinatown), and quick efficient service.  2 decades of eating here and every time is A+.
author: James N.

description:
Pros: Very good food and EVERYONE loves it!!! My three fav dishes: Shanghai/Soup dumplings, Shrimp Fried Rice, and white rice w/ salt. Has enough space to navigate through tables and not very cramped. Seats are very comfy and r fine.

Cons: Has about 10 min to 1hr wait which is pretty bad for one of the best restaurants in Chinatown. Maybe they could get the lighting a little lighter. Also the bathroom floor is very sticky and has graffiti on the stalls. Also maybe serve full pitcher of water and ice in 95 degrees+. 

Overall very good restaurant and I hope it get at least a 4.3 rating in the future!!!!
author: Roddy S.

description:
This restaurant my best friend and I went to was called Hunan Home's Restaurant . It is located on 622 Jackson Street on the heart of San Francisco Chinatown. Hunan Homes have opened up for more than two decades as I know, the restaurant has become a very popular place to eat in San Francisco . The word Hunan comes from a name of a provenience in Southeast China. Hunan food is known for making their food very spicy. This restaurant has a nice size and ambiance, but the important thing about this place is that the food is excellent not just the way the place looks. You can't judge anything without trying it.

My friend and I went to this restaurant for lunch on a Saturday. The waitress came to take our order.  She seemed to know well about their menu and gave us quite a few recommendations. But, I ordered my usual dish Kung Pao Chicken with steamed rice which had to be extra spicy hot and my friend had ordered Hot and sour soup he also liked it very spicy. Both were delicious.  Price was reasonable.  The overall experience of dining there was excellent.  I would definitely come again and again!
author: Jansen K.

description: My favor Chinese food in Chinatown.I enjoyed having dinner here.Everytime i come i must order their  potsticker,i will come back again. :)
author: Dylan L.

description:
Awesome String Bean & Beef dish tonight! Nice and spicy, and the beef was probably filet mignon because it was so tender. I could only eat half (it's a very generous serving), so now I have the rest for lunch tomorrow!

I came here because the other Hunan place around the corner (Chong Qing) was packed with white folk / tourists and no Chinese. Here, it was the opposite, so that boded well.
author: Some Bozo ..

description:
Wow, I'm surprised that a place like this has such high ratings given the location. I can't imagine this place would even survive in more competitive Chinatowns like in Toronto or NYC. 

We came here because Z&Y had a wait and this place didn't. Now I understand why. 

The food here is really below average. I'd put it at Panda express quality and authenticity. In fact, I don't think that I would even be able to distinguish between this and Panda Express food in a blind taste test. 

Note also that it is NOT Hunan type food (as in spicy).
author: Angelo B.

description:
Had lunch at this place while roaming in Chinatown. Heard lot of good things about this restaurant, so obviously had really high expectations on the food. I had Hunan fish and fried wontons and shrimp. 
Each of these dishes are well made and tasted excellent. I would surely recommend this restaurant to anyone visiting San Fransisco.
author: Goutham K.

description:
First time here, and happy with their food and service. 

Very Authentic Chinese food
author: Joe L.

description:
Came for the Xiao Long Bao (XLB), someone's review said this place had the best XLBs they've had outside of Asia. They must be smoking crack! 

I left very disappointed. The skin on top was way to thick and tough and there was barely any juice inside. C- grade. 

Chicken and string beans - beans were undercooked and not fresh

Shrimp fried rice - best thing we had. Solid choice but nothing wow about it. 

Fried rice didn't come out until 15 minutes after the string beans. Seems like they forgot about it. 

Too many options nearby to ever eat here again.
author: Aaron O.

description: We oredered this chicken, it tasted so good! We loved it so much! Next time we will come back !
author: Kinh L T.

description: It's a good place. We often come to dinner... It is worth recommending to everybody, the decoration here gives a person a kind of comfortable feeling, especially master chef's specialty dish, definitely want to try...
author: Leehom C.

description: HANDS DOWN the BEST Chinese food I have ever had!!! This place is so authentic and delicious I had tears in my eyes tasting the beautiful traditional spices and flavors of china like I never had before. The restaurant is very cozy and comfortable! The staff is speedy and friendly! I highly recommend the hot and sour soup! They have perfected this soup in a way I can't even begin to explain, the only thing I can try to describe it as is melt your mouth and soul good! San Francisco, especially china town is filled with beautiful authentic Chinese food, but this place is honestly on a whole new level. They have the freshest ingredients and have found a way to perfect ALL of their dishes. The portions are big and the prices are extremely reasonable! I highly highly highly recommend this restaurant, and I can't wait to come back soon with my boo!!!i
author: Lisa S.

description: We try the jellyfish for the first time, it was perfectly tendered. We also ordered the orange chicken, it had a lot of chiles but it wasent spicy, it was really tasty.
author: Marta R.

description:
Originally wanted to try Z &Y across the street, but there was a 20-25 min wait on a weekday night?! Jesus. So we looked on Yelp, and found out this place had 4 stars and no wait, and right across the street. To be honest, I just wanted to try a Chinese restaurant NOT in the sunset or richmond district. I think I was craving Chinese food that wasn't Cantonese. 

It's a pretty homey Chinese restaurant. Still filthy, indicating its authenticity. However, there were tons of tourists - seemed like the whole place was packed with white people. Service was super slow, but there was one hilarious waiter that kept making small talk and jokes with everyone. 

Highlights:
-Hot & sour soup - spicy and sour, great taste. It really hit the spot. Super flavorful. It was $6 for a medium bowl that gave us 2-3 bowls for 2 people. 
-Green beans - crunchy and soft at the same time, and I loved the soy sauce flavor. This is a must too.

We also got a combo chow mein, which had scallops and shrimp in it, and it was just standard, not a huge deal. 

Not sure if I would come back, since I really need to try Z &Y next. But if you're in the same situation as me, Hunan home's is worth a try if you don't want to wait at Z & Y.
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Nice relaxing atmosphere.  Good food and good service.  Would recommend this restaurant to anyone that is wanting Chinese food.  Highly recommended.  Also if you were walking in the area you would not think of stopping.
author: Roxanne S.

description: I had dinner at Hunan Home's Restaurant for the very first time last night and I was very impressed.  Not only the food were delicious, customer service is excellent as well.   I love their house vegetable delight chow mein.  It was cooked to perfection, not too salty but yet still taste delicious!  I would definitely go back again'
author: Yoyo W.

description:
Got the ma po tofu lunch and was very happy. 

I used to come here 20 years ago and the place has only gotten bigger and better. 

Hot and sour soup to start is phenomenal. 

Ma po was super flavorful and just the right amount of heat. 

This place is cheap and a dive but the food is delicious.
author: Dave K.

description:
This was some classic Chinese-American food right in the heart of San Francisco's Chinatown. The dishes were served quickly, hot, and were great renditions of the favorites. Lunch was also served with some hot tea, which was great on the chilly and drizzly day we ate here.

I had the Mongolian beef lunch special, which was awesome. Where I live on the East Coast, Mongolian beef is not a common Chinese food option, so I like to grab it when I'm out West. Cheap, hot, tasty, friendly. It doesn't get any better than that!
author: Michael R.

description: Great little restaurant in China town. 5 minutes walk from union Square. Good food and good service. Try the Mongolian Beef!
author: Taj H.

description: I'm from Los Angeles and have visited the best Chinese Restaurants in Chinatown.  This place in San Francisco beats them all! Dined with friends from Moraga and we all agreed the that the food and service was first rate! - Try the Orange Peal Chicken!!!
author: Karl J.

description: Had a wait to get in but well worth it. Food came out hot and fresh, flavors were spot on. Some of the best Chinese I have had.
author: Johnny F.

description: Mushroom chicken at Hunan Homes taste like rubber. I think the chicken is sliced incorrectly and cooked too long. DARN!!! Just wasted almost $10 and I can't even eat it.
author: May W.

description:
We were in Chinatown and decided to try this place.  The first bad sign was that it took a long time to get seated.

There were a group of us.  We started with hot and sour soup that was really good.

Our dishes included Mongolian beef, fried rice, chow mein, and orange chicken.  We were kind of disappointed here.  The fried rice was OK, but other dishes were kind of bland and lacked much meat.  We eat at many Chinese places and did not meet our usual standard.
author: Edward S.

description: Visited for lunch today and gotta say, five stars. The staff were friendly and one step ahead. From the water refills, to rolling all my Mu Shu pork rolls, and the complimentary mango pudding. Food was great per usual.
author: Joey B.

description: A great Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. The service here is simply excellent and very vigilant. The food is amazing. Very fresh and tasteful. Loved my honey walnut prawns and will definitely be back to get more as this is a personal favorite. Their extensive menu leaves me wanting to come back and try more and more. Fair prices in such a simple establishment. Liked the non-disposable chopsticks too. An elegant feature!
author: Daniel M.

description: Excellent food, great service at a good price. We had a few different entrees to share in our group and everything tasted great!
author: Kim P.

description:
Started off with hit and sour that had 10X the black
Pepper it normally has. The meal went downhill from there.
author: Marc L.

description:
Got here right when it opened - 11:30, ordered right and received half our food 30 minutes later. HORRIBLE. I guess restaurants aren't ready when they open anymore? 

When we received our first plate (chicken) our Dumplings were no where to be seen and we kept asking about them an they said "vey long wait". when we asked our server how long she went away and never came back. We asked the other server and same thing. When the original server came back we asked to talk to the manager twice and everyone avoided us. 

We came in at the same time as another family and they were done eating a 2 course meal (soups and entree) before we even received anything.
