It's like they we're all avoiding us for asking about our 30 minute plates. Worst part was that we had to catch a plane back to our home town so it was not worth it
author: daniela d.

description:
Our Lunch Review 07-28-2017 -My comments are regarding the new cooks cooking style: Basically TOO GREASY!
String Beans Ala Hunan was supposed to braised/dry fried what we got was oily string beans.  Eggplant had an oil slick. Orange peel Beef was too greasy.
We've been attending this restaurant for the last 10 years and got very disappointed with the food. We understand that Hunan Homes is under new ownership and will miss the previous owners James & Vivian Yuan & their cooking staff. I'll update this again after our next lunch soon.
author: Charlie E.

description:
A-OK Chinese food. After so many good reviews decided to check this place out on a Sunday night. Still surprisingly busy at 8PM.

There is not wait list and have to just wait in line at the door (No matter how cold it is - the door is left open .___. ) 

Definitely recommend doing family style, but the taste and portion were fairly bland and small for us.

Ordered the Xiao Long Bao like others have recommended and to surprise were pretty good (4 out of 5 stars) Definitely not the best, but still pretty good.

Ordered the Honey Walnut Shrimp 16.25. (3 out of 5 stars)

Vegetable pot stickers (2 out of 5 stars)

Sharing dishes amongst our group each person paid around 26$ for group of 5.

For price I hoped that the food was better and bigger portions.
author: Stephen L.

description: OMG!! You have to try the XLB! They are very juicy and succulent!! I almost burned myself because I really want to put them inside my mouth! LOL be careful you guys. The juicy bursted out when you bited on it. I always come for the XLB!
author: Willem L.

description:
- Just amazing food! Period. Full stop.

(I can't stop there... )

Absolutely great food! The Hot and Sour soup was the best I've ever had in my entire life and the Double Mushroom, Prawns and Scallops was astoundingly good! 

I'd recommend ordering something that looks interesting, something you've never had before because I'd bet the farm that everything here is a magical culinary treat!

Go, stand in line (because there will almost certainly be a line) get inside, order and enjoy. You're welcome.
author: Robert W.

description: I ordered the string beans with pork. I could count the specks of ground pork with one hand. So basically, I spent 12 bucks on beans. The problem with a restaurant that lives off of tourist business is they don't cook for repeat business.
author: William B.

description:
Love their ...
* Shredded Pork with Spiced Bean Curd
* Hot Spiced Bean Curd
* Chicken with Orange Peel
* Chicken with Spicy Garlic Sauce
author: Mindy - Oishii Moments S.

description:
The food here is OK, americanized chinese food type of deal. We would have had a better experience if the service wasn't so meh. We ordered and were waiting for quite a loong time, only to see the table that got seated/ordered after us served far before us :/

Xiao Long Bao: They line the dumpling basket with cabbage but only with two dinky pieces, so the majority (4/6) dumplings were broken open making them soup dumplings with NO soup :( It was disappointing, and the dumplings themselves weren't so tasty.

Kung Pao Chicken: They trick you by including a small portion of chicken, and using similarly cut cubes of bamboo (or some other light colored vegetable) on a 1:1 ratio... so in the end you're not really getting that much meat. 

Yang Chow Fried Rice: Tasty with baby shrimps and chinese sausage bits. Probably best thing we ate overall

Meh wouldn't return or recommend, have been to better restaurants in the area. One positive here was the super sweet lady managing everything at the door and thanking all her customers personally!
author: Hana S.

description:
Orange chicken (OC) aka chicken with orange peel. Perhaps it's "basic," but I'm on the journey to find the best of the basics in SF across cuisines: OC, pad thai, and of course, chicken tikka marsala. 

My quest for the best in town brought me to Hunan. The OC here is delicious. Tender chicken fried to crispy perfection, with bits of cilantro for an even crispier finish. The sauce is good, but perhaps a bit too much on the sweet side and also lathered excessively. I recommend getting the OC with a side of their fluffy and delicious steamed white rice. 

Although this isn't the best OC in town, it'll satisfy that OC craving.
author: Behnam S.

description:
It breaks my heart to write this review. We've been going here for over twenty years. We knew the family and all of the staff.  About two weeks ago we went and realized we didn't recognize any of the servers, cooks, etc. I asked where the owner was and was told the restaurant had been sold but "everything was the same as before". It wasn't. It was generally tasteless, and, although the service was good, the food lacked flavor, the dish with black bean sauce lacked any sauce, the pot stickers came with a strange (bad) sauce and the other dish was just as tasteless. 
Time to find a new restaurant.
author: Judith B.

description:
Service was horrible! It took over 30 minutes after asking twice ...for water and tea to be brought to our table.  We ordered the fried wonton, and found a bug like object with legs in the sauce!  We brought it to the server's attention and was offered a new plate of sauce with no apology.

While other reviews seem okay..I also looked around and found that we were the only Asian looking patrons in the restaurant, this definitely isn't a restaurant geared toward those looking for authentic Hunan food.  And don't expect any form of service if you look Asian
author: Maggie L.

description:
If you want authentic Chinese food, don't come here. 

We ordered the xiao long bao- it came out cold.
Then we waited another 30 minutes for another one, but it was missing one xiao long bao.

The spicy spareribs came out edible, but that's not saying much. 

The tofu appetizer was decent.

The service was mediocre. 

We won't be back.
author: Nance H.

description: This place is the best! I love Hunan food! I tried the orange peel chicken and the sizzling soup because I saw a lot of people commented about these two, so I decided to try it out. And turns out!! It was amazing! Those are my new favorite food right now. I come here more often than ever just to eat the orange chicken! Big thumbs up!!!!!
author: Ivy Whywhy W.

description: We were looking for authentic Chinese food and this place gave us just that. The service was fast and attentive, then again it was 11am lol! Prices were good for the large portions. It quickly became packed. I do remember being cold inside, wish it would have been a little more cozier.
author: Anne S.

description: Food is soo good, service was perfect. Fast, food was hot and fresh. We ordered the Hunan string beans, magnolian Beef, vegetable chow menu and white rice. Food was okay priced right not expensive and worth every penny. They greet you well and sit you down with complimentary jasmine tea. :)
author: Estela O.

description: The chow mein is really good tried sweet and sour prawns which is really delicious and the orange pile chicken the service very good and the place is nice! Recommend
author: Theresa R.

description: Hunan style Chinese restaurant. I found this place on Yelp and decided to check it out one late evening. The place is open late on weekedays. I ordeded Sizzling Seafood Deluxe, which had jumbo shrimp, scallops, squid, mushrooms, asparagus, bamboo shoots, and carrots. The sizzling plate comes separate with four slices of onions, and the server plate the rest of the dish right in front of you when it is being served. The sizzing sound probably is the highlight of the dish. The sizzling plate is super hot with steam. Wait until it sizzles down a bit before eating. The server was probably one of the nicest server I had in Chinatown. She let me sit at a table of my choice, came by after serving the food and checked how I like the food, and also gave me a small cup of mago dessert as extra service :)
author: Lisa O.

description:
Seeing 4 stars on yelp and them serving the soup dumplings in their restaurant, I was excited to come and try their food. But I was mostly disappointed by everything here... 

FOOD
I ordered some seafood soup with rice crackers and it tasted really good! The only dish I really liked during my visit. 
We ordered soup dumplings (Xiao long bao) of course and.... The dumplings are just sad. They are small (but I'd say they are normal size). The worst parts are: 1) skin is very thick!! Soup dumplings supposed to have very thin skins! And because the skin is so thick they are not cooked throughly 2) there was not much soup inside the dumplings and that only shows these are not well made... 3) too much meat inside the dumplings and I think that's why there's not much room for the soup. 
We also ordered a beef with string bean dish. Was just okay. Super greasy.

SERVICE
We ordered a seafood soup with rice crackers, and when the server brought the soup to the table, he scooped the soup evenly (or he was trying to) into 3 smaller bowls for us. But here was doing it very impatiently and hastily that he was making a huge mess on our table! Lots of soup were spilled onto the table and the server just left without cleaning it or even feeling bad about it! What! Leaving us with a wet table. Not happy! 

Overall
Not impressed. Will not come back.
author: Miranda L.

description:
This used to be one of my favorite, inexpensive and local Chinese restaurants that was close to work. After a few times of visiting this place, it is clear that the ownership has changed.  The servers, cashier and other staff members are no longer around.  Their food doesn't have any flavor and is bland.  The original owners and wait staff were attentive and took your order timely.  At the end of your meal they gave oranges and a fortune cookie.  

I would not recommend this restaurant any longer to tourists much less locals.  I am truly disappointed.
author: O ..

description:
We ordered shrimp fried rice, combination chow mean, Kung Pao chicken and pork potstickers. Everything was delicious, but the Kung Pao chicken was awesome! One of the best I've had, cooked perfectly!

Place was clean and the service was super nice and cheerful.

Highly recommend.
author: Gicell S.

description: The food is so and here ordered pork with pepper something like that it's so salty. Worst food I ever ordered never come back again
author: Clancy Y.

description: When I first time came to this place, I saw many Americans were sitting there and talking about the foods from the menu. It sounds like pretty good, so I got in the restaurant with my friends. We ordered Fried rice, sweet&source chicken (orange chicken), and sizzling beef, wonton in a chili sauce. The wonton is pretty good, but I personally love their orange chicken because I love sweet and source. Additionally, theirs sizzling beef is very tender and little bit of spicy because of the black pepper. This is one of the most favorite restaurant in Chinatown after trying their food. Definitely will come again for trying the other food from them!!! :)
author: Cathy Z.

description:
Ordered: Hunan beef, beef fried rice, chow mein, kung pao chicken.

-when you order chow mein or fried rice, they use the same beef as Hunan beef.

-beef and the chicken tasted so chewy and so bland. It was hard to chew because it was so chewy.

- chow mein and fried rice just okay. 

- small corn that you see, was gross and so sweet. Definitely came from the can. 

Customer service was ehh

Price is reasonable 

Overall I had better Chinese food. Will I come back again? No. 

I had better authentic Chinese food from a hole in the wall Chinese restaurant owned by a Chinese.
author: Linda C.

description:
Food: We ordered 5 entrees and steamed rice for 5 college aged guys. We were not STUFFED as we left the place, but the portions were not small by any means. We ordered an assortment of foods - a seafood chow mein, pork fried rice, hunan chicken, kung pao deluxe, Mongolian beef. Overall, the dishes tasted authentic (or at least more authentic than any Chinese food I've ever had in America) with the exception of the fried rice, which was really just fried rice. They also gave us hot green tea instead of water, which we were fine with.

Service: Nothing extraordinary. Courteous, refilled tea when we finished it. Attentive, prompt, and ready. The food came out pretty quickly as well. 

Interior: There were some tables with the rotating platter in the middle for larger parties. Otherwise, plenty of room for smaller parties as well. I can imagine it gets pretty busy in here during peak hours on the weekends.

Parking: We parked in the California Garage that was located less than 2 blocks down from the restaurant. It was $12 for the 4ish hours we were in the area.

This place has some good Chinese food. Authentic, fast service, and parking nearby. I do anticipate it being pretty packed (and maybe even a wait) during peak hours, but I would love to come back here nonetheless.
author: Jacob R.

description: This is probably one of my favorite Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. Their service are attentive as well!!! I love their chow main, potsticker and orange chicken!!! Trust me and You won't regret it.
author: Niko L.

description:
My family and I were here for lunch yesterday. We spent the day in San Francisco. We came here because the reviews were good. I wasn't disappointed with the food we ordered except the wonton soup. It had no flavor. It was like bok choy and wontons floating in plain water. I took one bite and pushed it aside. We had lemon chicken, orange chicken, shrimp fried rice, chicken chow mein, asparagus beef and a appetizer combination plate. 

Now the downside. I had to go to the bathroom and to get to it, you have to go downstairs. Walking past the crab tanks, there is mold all over the pipes. When you get to the second set of stairs, which are made of metal, they are cracked on the side close to the wall. I could feel them giving way when stepping down. The locks on the stalls didn't work. Another thing I noticed was what sounded like an electric bug zapper going off every 30 seconds or so. It also stated parking was validated on orders over $45. Well you have to park at a specific garage during certain hours. When you're spending $110, they should validate no matter what.

I don't think we'll be returning to this restaurant. Also be sure to read the Current Health Inspection. It speaks volumes.
author: Kathy B.

description: My favorite Chinese food restaurant anywhere! Amazing salt n pepper fish, chicken fried rice, chow main, and many other great dishes to choose from. Their food is seasoned just right, and always fresh!
author: Kim H.

description: Food was all rather salty.  Service was very short and nasty.  Not nice at all.  Food was n9t worth waiting for.  Also very pricy. Disappointing
author: John C.

description: W-A-R-N-I-N-G:  I've been coming here for 20+ years. This has been my favorite  Chinese restaurant for most of my life, part of family celebrations and a must-visit spot for any friends visiting from out of town. Today I went here and didn't recognize a single staff member. When I ordered my favorite potstickers, I was stunned to see a plate of tiny, limp, frozen dough that resembled a Trader Joe's gyoza. I knew something was up. I asked the manager and turns out the original family sold the business and the new owners kept the name. Don't be fooled, this is NOT the same spot. All my favorite dishes are still on the menu, but lack any authenticity or flavor. Truly bummed and need to find a new Chinese spot in SF.  They should not be to keep the name if they can't uphold the quality.
author: Marta R.

description: EXCELLENT, EXCELLENT, EXCELLENT service but the food is just average. We had crispy garlic chicken, long beans with tofu, moo shu pork, and fried rice. Just meh...
author: Marti H.

description:
The bf and I came to this place because they're supposed to have some of the best soup dumplings and have some of the best Chinese food. Well, it's hard to tell when the soup dumplings come out busted or sticking to the lettuce so they break. 

The waitress was helpful, and she recommended the Kung pao mix for me. However, it was bland and vinegary. I couldn't finish it. The bf had sizzling beef and scallops. It was OK but nothing to write home about. They do charge extra for rice, so don't get it if you don't think you'll be eating much. We didn't know that, so we got hosed after only eating a few spoons of rice. 

Their chili sauce was on point, but our meal left a lot to be desired. We had high expectations based on a lot of the reviews that just weren't met.
author: Erica T.

description: Restaurant located heart of Chinatown.  When we walk in, it was so busy as usual.  We waited for 15 minutes and got our table to sit in.  We order spicy crab, and it was very delicious. Good food, good service. A restaurant I definitely will come back.
author: Bill l.

description: This is the best restaurant I went too so far in SF for four people and 9dishes under 100 dollars great pieces and awesome customer services and great food and awesome atmosphere I would recommend this place to anyone
author: Lionel K.

description: Times have changed at Hunan Home's. Just not good food. Came in based on high SF Eater and Yelp reviews, but were left disappointed by greasy, bland food and dirty bathrooms. If anyone in the dining room orders the sizzling plate, get ready to stop, drop, and roll as smoke fills the whole dining room and everyone starts coughing.
author: Mia B.

description:
Yum.  Been here a few times and it's always enjoyable.  Try to gauge your visit to avoid the lines because waiting is never fun.  Food is good. Service is acceptable and attentive.  Portions are sized right.  

If you want to avoid the zagat hype head here.
author: Sean C.

description:
I was in San Fransisco searching Chinatown for a place that was open to eat on Lunar New Year. Luckily yelp helped me find Hunan's Home which was open and busy. 

The restaurant's system was very much like trying to shop at a Chinatown bakery on a weekend morning. There is no take a number or put your name on a list, you need to stand in line in the small entrance and make sure no one cuts you. The server's didn't seem to care that they were there , but they were at least efficient. The one in charge (who I assume was the owner or manager) would scream in Cantonese across the restaurant anytime she needed to her staff.

So at this point you may wonder why a 4/5? The food was very good. We ordered the 
Hunan chicken and Fried rice with shrimp and pork. Both dishes were very well made and filling. I would definitely come back to try some more of the menu, but this is a place you come for a casual, satisfying meal.  This is not a place to come for a nice night out.
author: Doug P.

description:
Standing at the intersection of Kearny and Jackson the array of Chinese restaurants on offer is indecipherable.  There are simply too many from which to choose (which is not a complaint).  

I settled on Hunan Home's (sic) perhaps because the wildly creative placement of an apostrophe in "Home's" signaled that the kitchen would also turn out equally inspired creations.  In the end though, the kitchen turns out standard Chinese restaurant fare from a heaping big menu served piping hot.  The apostrophe is likely just an amusing error.

Two of us opted for Egg Rolls ($4.50), Mongolian Beef, Sizzling Platter Bean Curd, and rice.  One beer was ordered and the whole thing, pre-tip, clocked in at just under $40.  This is why we dine in Chinatown, no?  

The beef in the Mongolian was cut a bit thicker than usual (making it chewier than usual) and the portion size was a bit smaller than other restaurants serve up.  This Mongolian Beef was not my favorite version.  

The tofu was brought out along with a smoking hot cast iron platter and it did indeed sizzle madly when the waiter emptied pot onto platter.  As with the beef, the tofu was also presented in large chunks.  Someone in the kitchen prefers hunks of things to delicately presented offerings as well as portion sizes a tad smaller than you may find elsewhere.  

I really enjoyed the egg rolls.  

There's probably a million other places equally pleasing, possibly on the same block, but if someone again suggested Hunan Home's I'd say why not?  All in all, a hot and satisfying meal can be had here.  The best Chinese meal?  No, but a perfectly fine offering nonetheless.
author: Tracey A.

description: Great food, but only decent service. I'd come back. It was busy, but we only waited ten minutes.
author: Jeff D.

description: Appetizers, including fried bread, were pretty good. Entrees were unexceptional in both quality and variety, and the portions seemed relatively small. I can't imagine coming back with such a wide variety in the area
author: Fat O.

description:
Possibly the best Chinese food that I've ever had.

The Plate A is a good variety for a couple and quite filling.  Service was excellent too.
author: Ryan R.

description:
Cozy and gets the job done in Chinatown. It can be easy to pass by this place, it's pretty hidden. I think we ended up here because we were starving and barely noticed the door. 

Came here on an early Saturday afternoon. Not crowded at all so we got seated immediately. Ambiance is interesting. Kind of reminds me of a couple places in my hometown. Has the cliched fish tank that hasn't been cleaned in a decade and a lot of decorations all over the wall. Like a good Chinese restaurant, we were served tea instead of water, bless their hearts.

Portions are pretty generous- we had the BBQ pork, chicken chow mein, and a shrimp fried rice. Definitely easy to share the dishes. None of them were oh my goodness, this is amazing. All were definitely very solid and palatable. But you know, it's our fault for not ordering any traditional Hunan cuisine. I'm sure they make killer Southern Chinese food and if that's the reason you're here, go for it. 

Good place to stop by if you're in the area. Also, assuming by the people next to us, not a bad place to drink during dinner.
author: Arezou A.

description:
My dad and I went here based off the consistent reviews about their xiao long bao. This review only concerns them, not other dishes.

The first thing we noticed was the deal-breaker for any ethnic restaurant: it was full of white people. That being said, here are some notes about the food:
1. Dumpling wrapper was thick, and easily ripped, spilling the soup
2. The meat was tolerable, but not memorable
3. There was minimal soup, and no spoon was provided

Final Remarks: 
Disappointing, go two doors up to Bund Shanghai.
author: Lucy G.

description: Really Good Chinese food, just wish the portions were a little bigger. Other than that.... the won ton soup was the best!
author: Angelyne H.

description: Actually came here because of the reviews on Yelp. Very very busy and small. We probably waited in the crowded doorway for about 40 mins or more. But you walk in and the smell is insane. You can't wait to eat. They also have pictures of the food on the front window which is helpful to know if something is fried or not. Once seated we ordered some sake which was great. Nice and hot. They only had one kind. But at least is was good. We tried the gyoza, dumplings, Crispy outside and flavorful inside. Great sauce. I go the Hunan chicken which was supposed to be more spicy than the Pad thai sauce. It wasn't. It smelled like it was loaded with flavor but a bit light on it actually. We also had the beef broccoli which was incredible. I don't like meat very much but I would get this again in a heartbeat. Very good service even though they are crazy busy. I will come here whenever I am in the City again.
author: Valerie M.

description: Menu does not describe the items as you receive them. Random peppers showed up in my wife's dish. Servers were not super friendly and seemed to just want to crank through guests.
author: Chris W.

description: Good food. Veggie pot stickers and spinach soup are great  for starters and followed by a dish of cashew prawns with brown rice, perfect meal for two!
author: Rob P.

description:
Not sure what happened on my visit here because despite the reviews, this was one of the most disappointing experiences I've had in my culinary adventures.

First off, if you find yourself here, props to Thomas for the info that if you park at Portsmouth Square Garage and spend at least $45, you can validate 2 hours of parking (which comes to about $6). The garage is only a few blocks away, so this was a nice start.

Everything else... was just sad. It took about 15 minutes to get seated (despite having open tables... which they could have their own reasons so no harm done here). For Chinese, the food is really expensive ($12 per entree) and it. is. small. Based on average serving sizes at other restaurants, you can easily eat one and probably two entrees per person. This is the first time I've ever left a restaurant still hungry (as well as everyone else in my family.) 

Okay, so the portion size is small. But does it taste good? We got the Xiao Long Bao, the hot and sour soup, the mushroom scallops, the Mongolian beef, and the something pork. In short, the XLB was alright, the scallops were pretty good, the pork was pretty good but had a lot of gristle and fat, and the Mongolian beef, in my opinion, was very mediocre. The hot and sour soup was very interesting and actually like-able though, so there is that.

Since it's sometimes easier to understand by comparison, let's just say a typical Panda express 2-entree meal will have double the food (and more meat), taste a bit better, is $5-7 cheaper per person, and doesn't involve a wait. Yes, I said it.

As cool as it is to try something new, I was ultimately sad to waste our family's time here. Maybe this really is the best Chinese food in the area, but damn, it doesn't meet any standard to authentic nor Westernized style of Chinese to me.
author: Greg G.

description: Always the best Chinese Food around!!!  Wonder why this restaurant is always full of people, because they have the best food!! We have eaten here for the last 30 years, never a bad meal!
author: Robert L.

description: Food is overpriced for the quality and as far as health standards..it's a little suspect..I wouldn't go based off of the yelp reviews. Service was mediocre at best. You can better Chinese food in the hood. Overall not a great dining experience and wouldn't go back. I'll keep looking for a good Chinese restaurant in the area.
author: Justin B.

description: The food was alright but this place really lacks poor customer service especially when we asked the waiter to take off the nuts in the chicken since my boyfriend is allergic to it but he refused and still served it and he was so rude about it. So were not coming back lol
author: Mary H.

description: This place was excellent, we went here two years ago not knowing it was the same place. We walked in the workers were great the service is good the food was really good. I'm talking right now.
author: Roderick U.

description:
In town for 4 day's. We ate here 3 times!
Pot stickers are not doughy, they're crispy and meaty...best we've ever had!
Orange beef was perfect, crispy and light. Fried rice was fresh and light. Food comes fast and hot. Our waiter had the personality of a wet rag, but we weren't there to make friends, lol. Definitely worth a visit.
author: Ian N.

description:
This place is quality white people Chinese food. Which, in itself is fine. But I'd much rather go a few blocks to find some quality, more authentic Chinese food. 

We ordered the sizzling chicken, the house fried rice, the green beans, the mushu beef, and the Kung pao chicken. Everything was pretty average but the green beans were SUPER salty, almost to the point where I couldn't really taste anything but salt. 

Service was decent but it was obvious that they were trying to get us out of there because people were waiting which is understandable. Except for the fact that waiters kept trying to give us the check and take away our plates before we received all our food.
author: Sarah Y.

description:
Good food, good service and right in Chinatown. 

We had ginger beef and basil chicken and it was very good. I'd recommend this place for tourists looking for authentic Chinese with good prices
author: Scott H.

description: Decent food in downtown Chinatown. We came because of the high yelp score in comparison to other places in the area. The food is typical Americanized Chinese. There was nothing that completely amazed me but nothing that was bad.
author: Kristina K.

description: Meh.  Disappointing.  Nothing was bad.   Service was fast.  Price reasonable.  But the food was just not SanFrancisco quality. Relatively flavor less.  The hot dishes had no spice.  They rushed the food so soup overlapped appetizers overlapped entrees until our table was stacked up with food getting cold.  The sizzling beef did not sizzle because the pan was cold.  Neither did the sizzling rice soup make that dry sound when it hit the liquid.  Not my favorite.
author: David R.

description:
I've lived in the San Gabriel valley of Los Angeles for 15 years, where the population is +40% Chinese. I'm spoiled with great Chinese food and I know my Chinese food.
The food at Hunan Homes in San Fran's Chinatown is not good. The restaurant looks kind of dirty and the floor is gross. The soup came out room temp. The portions are small for a Chinese restaurant. The spicy chicken was dry, the combination chow mein is better at your local takeout place, like Panda Express. The service is slow and not very friendly. Totally disappointed, way over rated and over priced.
author: Mermski C.

description:
The first time I visited Hunan -- the original on Sansome or Kearny, I don't recall -- my mind was blown. It was in 1980-something, I think. I met Henry Chung, bought the cookbook, and Henry even signed it. 

Henry's gone now but I have been to Hunan-related restaurants since ( I can never tell which ones are Henry-Chung-related and which are copies) and all were good but none matched my memory. Until now. 

I don't think this place is Henry-related but no matter -- this visit reminded me of those days. The food was as good as I remembered and I thought, "why can't there be any Chinese food like this in the South Bay?" (There used to be but I don't see anything of this caliber anymore.) (But, I digress.)

The hot and sour soup was classic. Too often H&S soup has the hot, has the sour, but that's it. Without an underlying foundation, it comes up shallow and uninteresting. Not here -- this was meaty and big, complex and rich. I could make a meal of this.

Where are the onion pancakes I remember from the old Hunan? Missing, unfortunately. 

Hunan's headliner was always the Harvest Pork, made from slices of ham, smoked on-premise. This did not disappoint and was as I remembered it. Savory and smoky, not too salty and not too spicy (which I have experienced at other Hunan-y places). This was spot-on. 

Mongolian beef was well made though oddly did not have the classic rice noodles. No matter, it was great and not too spicy. 

Shrimp with walnuts -- a crowd pleaser and well executed: Crispy, saucy, crunchy. 

Several other dishes were all equally well prepared. 

Service was efficient and courteous. 

Winner, winner, stir-fried dinner!
author: Moe R.

description:
I would say that Hunan Home's Restaurant is simply a solid Chinese restaurant within Chinatown.

None of the dishes here have ever really disappointed me and none have ever really surprised me delightfully. They're all just solid Chinese food slightly above the average of Chinatown. I enjoy some of the dishes here including the Shanghai dumplings, green onion pancake, and potstickers. I also recall this place having a dessert bread with condensed milk for dipping, which is a fun dish to try if you've never had it before. I would recommend this restaurant for a simple, enjoyable Chinatown lunch experience.
author: Joshua M.

description:
Honestly feel horrible to say this but... every thing was bland! The only thing I enjoyed was the moo shu pork (actually yummy) and the beef and broccoli (it was just OK, but at least it had flavor!). 

We had: 
-Lobster Sauce Prawns (just had some bell pepper and onion and the eggy sauce but barely any flavor)
-Beef and broccoli (yummy-ish)
-chicken chow mein (annoying because we ordered pork and they gave us chicken which sucked because the chicken had no taste)
-chicken and string beans (just tasted like chili oil, nothing else)

Not worth the wait and that makes me sad because there were so many great reviews. There is normally a line, moved quick I guess. 

Nothing memorable about my experience and will not be back, sadly did NOT live up to the hype. Wonder what's going on here or if there is new owners?
author: Sierra B.

description:
I have to agree  that it was the best authentic Chinese restaurant in SF Chinatown. There was no wait and food arrived fast. It was 3 of us and we all ordered 2-3 different dishes. Everything was delicious. 
The restaurant ran by a family. The service was fast but luck of emotions. They weren't rude or anything like that. I live in Korea-town and it's know thing that if you  want service you don't go to Asian place. 
I will definitely go back once I'm in SF.
author: Daria P.

description: Wow!  We are so impressed with Hunan Home!  The restaurant is full of smiling San Franciscans, and they managed to seat us right away!  The food has layers of fragrant flavors I've never before tasted in a Chinese Food place.  They even managed to make my 6 year old son happy and he is the pickiest eater!  I am blown away by the delicious food and the amazing service!  I will be back to Hunan Home often because it is seriously the best Chinese food ever!
author: Gabrielle W.

description: Friendly staff/food was good but didn't stand out. Restaurant and restrooms were clean.
author: Lisa G.

description: Great Chinese food in Chinatown SF. Had the Mongolian beef lunch special. The hot and sour soup was amazing!
author: Ryan S.

description:
This duck!? This duck tho!!!

I called my momma and slapped her through the phone it was so good. 

The snow pea was as good as my wife would make it and she is freaking amazing with her culinary skills. 

This is one of those places that I will come back to and tell my friends to check out. 

Man that duck.... I'm going to dream about the duck for weeks.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Originally from Monterey Ca we were in the city for mom's 60th bday !Amazingly Fanny (waitress) did an awesome job getting us in coordinating a reservation for a party of 30 people! Whoooo we scored were calling many of places in china town who didn't take any reservations we were all so stoked because mom wanted to eat Chinese food in China Town and we made it happen for her special day! Food, service was great we all enjoyed it would highly recommend the chicken chow mein+chicken w/asparagus! They were also sweet in making us a mango pudding for dessert! Thanks again you guys are the best! 
PS shout out to Kenny (our waiter) for such great service and having great communication skills with everyone's order good job buddy!
author: Z M.

description: Stopped here for a late lunch/early dinner based on fellow yelp reviewers and had a decent meal. Not the best meal, but not bad. We shared Hunan string beans, lemon chicken, sweet and sour chicken, wonton soup and the xiao long bao. Highlights were the dumplings and the string beans. Flavors were subtle and not over the top.
author: Melissa F.

description:
We came here with high expectations - a benchmark of one of Chicago's best, if not the best, Chinese restaurants where we've been going weekly for over 20 years. Hunan Home's Restaurant did not come close and actually left us feeling ill.

We ordered:

Appetizers:
--Fried Bean Curd

Entrees:
-- Tea Leaf Duck
-- Steamed Chicken
-- Kung Pao Vegetables

A fair warning about the Steamed Chicken - this was supposed to be Hainan Chicken, but it comes drenched in oil and swimming in yet more oil. The dish was unbearable to eat but I was hungry and didn't want to be a pain. I was left with a violent stomach ache the entire day. The Kung Pao Vegetables didn't score very high marks, either. The Tea Leaf duck was probably the best thing we ordered.

Beyond the food, the rest was okay. The restaurant is tiny, but service is quick and prices are great (on par with the rest of ChinaTown).

Would not return.
author: Nic Z.

description:
Wait...what?! I swear I had a review for this place already. I must have just thought about what I would write a million times and never got around to it. Eep! This is one of my favorite Chinese restaurants to go to in Chinatown. Dee-lish! 

My favorite dishes are by far the string beans and xiao long bao (soup dumplings). I don't know what they do with those string beans, but I always try to save some as leftovers so I can eat them again the next day, yet never manage to do so because they are too yummy and I have no self control. Writing this makes me want some. Now. Even though I already ate dinner. They also have this delicious sauce for their soup dumplings. I almost wanted to ask for a to go container to take whatever was left home. Hahaha. 

This is pretty much my go to place for lunch whenever I'm in Chinatown. Give it a go!
author: Jennifer T.

description: Came here because of the high yelp rating and a waiting line outside of the restaurant. I'm a fan of Hunan cuisine so I decided to give it a try. The service was good, the ingredients were fresh, and the prices were decent. However, this is not authentic Hunan cuisine...................
author: J. L.

description:
Service was a bit slow didn't ask us for drinks
Chow mein was good 
Orange chicken was really good
author: Victor L.

description:
This restaurant was fine. My husband actually picked it, so I didn't have a say in where we went for lunch this day. It's right in Chinatown in San Francisco. 

We stopped in here for lunch while walking around. I was told to try some authentic dim sum, so I was really looking forward to trying some that was authentic. Unfortunately, they did not serve this. We were served some jasmine tea, which was delicious. We also received some egg drop soup, it was good, but nothing special. We ordered some egg rolls, yum, and a super authentic dish (sarcasm noted), sweet n sour pork. I had wanted to order something more adventurous, but husband is not as adventurous as me when it comes to food. Everything was good. Nothing stood out as amazing, but there were no bad experiences either.

It did take longer than expected to receive the check though, the server didn't come around very often.
author: Danielle M.

description: WARNING for my fellow food hunters: this resturant serves Americanized Chinese dishes. I would say if you don't mind that kind of dishes, just go to panda express. At least cheaper. This is terrible. Totally not authentic hunan Chinese restaurant. This is just expensive dirty restaurant.
author: Christine C.

description: Stopped by on a Tuesday afternoon, no wait for a table. Outside is deceiving and looks outdated - but the food was amazing! Would recommend the Xao Bao Ling (dumplings), chicken with orange peel, and shrimp chow mein. The beef and broccoli was also good. They provide complimentary hot tea and mango pudding - both decent. Only downside was service - not friendly, but not rude. Had to ask twice for water and the fortune cookies were stale. Would definitely come back for the food, though!!
author: Samantha H.

description: So, this just night be the place for you if you like good, normal, American Chinese food. Maybe I'm spoiled by where I grew up, but this was not the most authentic and best. It was good, for sure, but if you want the best in the area, I'm sure this isn't it. I think the evidence is that there were almost no Chinese speakers eating there. On the other hand, two tour groups of 20 or more people came in, so its obvious who their market is. Note that the servings are a good size, and the best sign of all... no forks in sight. So, this just night be the place for you if you like good, normal, American Chinese food.
author: Daniel N.

description: This is the best Chinese restaurant in town. Good food quality and the waitress are very friendly. Must try the hot and sour soup, orange peel chicken and xiao long bao
author: Choi C.

description:
Don't ask for vegetables with your entree, received 2 broccoli sprouts, asked for more and they snubbed me

I was still hungry after I left!
Spent over $90.00 not including the tip

We went to a pub later and spent another $50.00 because we were still hungry.
author: krista t.

description: I literally only had soup dumplings, but they weren't that good. The dumpling is a little thick for my liking and barely any soup. Plus I think the server forgot about me because it took 30 minutes for me to get one order. Thank goodness I didn't order two. Off to another spot in search of more traditional lighter soup dumplings.
author: Ariana F.

description: Wanted to find some Orange Chicken to eat while in China Town. I give this place 4 stars. I ordered Chicken Fried Rice/ Orange Chicken/Fried WongTon and EggRolls.
author: Yolie M.

description:
Saw the reviews on here,  thought hey! Let's give it a shot.. there was a long line of folks waiting outside to get in.  Hey must be good! Ordered potstickers (not to bad) mongolian beef,  (edible) hard to mess up that.  Beef chow mein I dunno wtf this was, tasted like fish and fuck. Wife ordered hunan beef 
And had no flavor at all . I'm not really going to talk about how bad the service was aside from saying they put two separate meals in front of us that someone else ordered,  and leave it aft that.  I'm really disappointed at how bad the whole experience was from start to finish. I almost feel like this place is the locals joke on tourists,  give it great reviews,  and watch at your fav rest across the street  laughing at all the suckers waiting in line for the nasty stuff oozing out of the horrible hunan kitchen. 

You have been warned. Perhaps you will have a better experience,  but I've had better food at our local greasy wok that people avoid like the plague.
author: Keith C.

description: Yummy food! We eat here every time we come to SF.  Enjoyed the orang chicken, beef broccoli, fried rice, spring rolls and more.
author: Linda H.

description: This is our second time at Hunan Home's. The first time was around this time a couple of years ago. I had some family from the UK in town and they didn't believe me about the best Chinese food being from SF. Hunan Home's did not disappoint. My cousin, a vegetarian was impressed by a wide variety of options he could actually consume, and boy did he. The eggplant was his favorite. My son has begged me to take him back, so today we ditched the whole Black Friday shopping thing and headed for Chinatown. It doesn't get much better than a couple of Tsingtaos and some Mushu Pork at Hunan Home's. We were seated right away and had food within ten minutes of sitting down. Once I work off the calories, it will be hard not to return. This is the place for Chinese if you find yourself in the City.
author: Dylan C.

description:
Seeking out a good Chinese or Cantonese spot in San Francisco is in some ways the definition of finding a needle in a haystack, and while there are some great options, Hunan is pretty much your typical option. You won't by any means be disappointed, but you won't be blown away either. 

Star 1: How were the service and atmosphere?

Even on a weekend evening the abundant seating at Hunan is such that you likely won't be waiting longer than 30 or so minutes, which is a rarity in the city. From there, while the ordering process and food delivery can take a bit of time it's not impossible to be in and out in an hour or so. Dumplings in particular come out quickly, so keep that in mind if you're hungry from the get go. Star Granted.

Star 2: How were the portions relative to the cost?

The benchmark by which all Xiao Long Bao are and should be compared is without question Din Tai Fung (http://www.yelp.com/biz/din-tai-fung-arcadia-5), which run $1.05 each. At $1.16 each, the XLB here at Hunan are a bit more expensive, but they're a bit larger in portion size as well. The other standard Chinese dishes run just above $10 and maybe a bit closer to $15 once you bring the necessary rice into the mix, which is in line with the market rate. Star Granted. 

Stars 3 and 4: How was the food?

My party of three enjoyed our meal here at Hunan, but nothing really blew us away. The Xiao Long Bao was fine, although lacked a bit in flavor, and my Kung Pao Chicken was a bit weak with nearly twice as many vegetables as chicken. The other two in my party opted for the Chicken Fried Rice, and while I'll credit the hefty portion size neither seemed overly thrilled and didn't end up finishing their dishes. Hunan is a bit of a jack of all trades, and while they don't shatter the competition with any one dish they do everything reasonably well. Single Star Granted. 

Star 5: Would you eat here every day if you could?

There's simply too much competition in the area for Hunan to really stand out in my opinion, but they're a jack of all trades that will satisfy just about any party. No Star Granted.
author: Paul V.

description: This restaurant was recommended by a fellow co-worker.  Stopped by to give it a try. Side note: parking is impossible.  If you drive in then expect to drive around for a spot on the street or pay a good amount for parking in a nearby structure.  It was somewhat crowded when we arrived and given the option to wait 30 minutes for a table or be seated right away but had to share with another family.  We really didn't want to wait so opted to share. At first it was awkward but, the family was really nice and we had a interesting conversation.  As for the food, I think it was decent and nothing to really rave about.  Plates range from 10 to 18 dollars.  Not cheap.  Overall, I don't think I will be back. It was worth a try but will try something else next time.
author: Ana O.

description: Delicious food, cheap and great service! Probably the best chicken fried rice I've ever had. The moo shu veggies were fantastic too.
author: Heidi G.

description:
Oh me oh my. What a great foodie experience. I love xiao long bao & that's what brought me here. The XLB was really delicious. Prefect amount of dough and meat. I'm used to the typical vinegar and ginger, but this places substitutes that for a sweet soy sauce scallion peanut sauce that is to die for. It really made the meal for me. Now my one and only complaint is that the XLB were steamed touching each other, so they burst open, juices flowing everywhere, before I could savor it.


The environment is something like a home living room. The decor is very Chinese, and I felt like I was at my grandmas house. The staff consisted of older women and gentlemen. They were friendly, although we had some trouble with language. But in the end we got our order and I was extremely satisfied.
author: Christine L.

description:
Food was incredibly mediocre. Service was bad. They brought our soup and left it on our table for about five minutes with no spoons or bowls. The other entrées we got came out way spaced apart and then I also had to flag someone down to ask for plates. The sizzling beef had very little flavor and the portion of lemon chicken was really small. 

I'm very confused about why this place was so busy but I am guessing it must be a tourist trap situation. Bummed out that I paid 50 bucks for such a sad little meal. 

The wonton soup was all right so I threw in an extra star.
author: Andi R.

description: Came for my favorite food-chao fan,yummy yummy Guess my other food's name, it also good and taste
author: Jeany D.

description:
Not sure what makes this place so popular. It is not the Wor Wonton soup. I am willing to come again and try something else. 

Three stars for Wor WonTon soup which was the only item I ordered. The BBQ meat in the spoon is all I got (see photo.) Very skimpy on the vegetables and I think one of the 3 small shrimp wasn't  cooked thru. Broth was good.

Staff were nice.
author: Paula H.

description: Took our family from Krakow (and a new friend/family member Maciej) for some authentic Chinese food. Ordered the combo for 6. We were not disappointed with the excellent food and service. However you do have to overlook the front of the restaurant  (please clean your windows where the menu is posted. Many customers would judge the food/service by the cleanliness of the exteriors)
author: Aunt J.

description: I never even received my food to try it. 45 minute wait and we decided to leave. Go up the street to Great Eastern restaurant
author: Jason J.

description:
Fried prawns were delicious. They came along with egg rolls and potstickers on the combo appetizer plate. The egg rolls were good but the potstickers were average. 

My wife had the orange chicken which was really delicious. I had the crispy chicken with spicy garlic sauce which wasn't terribly spicy or flavorful. 

The service was good and the price was decent. Overall it wasn't a bad experience but if I was in the area again I would probably try something different.
author: David R.

description: I've been here twice and both times completely underwhelmed.  I don't find anything special about this place.  I would much rather go to Hunan House on Washington.
author: Lillian M.

description:
Chinatown in San Francisco is as authentic as it gets. While visiting this beautiful city I searched all over yelp for the perfect Chinese restaurant. We didn't have a car San Francisco and we use the hop on hop off tour bus system where they drop you off at certain points. With that being said we had to walk about a mile to get here...and fatties and steep hills do not mix lol. 

 The food here was pretty good. But I have had better Chinese food in the Los Angeles area. The one thing that did surprises was the incredibly small portion sizes and pretty steep prices for what you are getting. For the same amount we pay in LA, you can get double maybe...even triple the portion size of what you get here. I guess because its in a tourist area? I dont know but that was kind of weird.
author: Rachel M.

description: Solid option in SF chianatown. Nothing earth shattering but best I have had in SF. Service is excellent and has a nice feel inside. I say go for it! Hot and sour soup normals and good. Pot stickers the same. kPC just ok
author: Brad M.

description: There seems to be lots of mixed reviews on this place! Admittedly, I hardly ever eat Chinese food, so in terms of the authenticity of the food I am probably not the best for advice there. However my boyfriend and I came in around 7 PM on a Saturday and got seated within 5 minutes. I have always wanted to sit at those round family style tables at Chinese restaurants and I was so happy that is what we got!! We were immediately served complimentary green tea and water. The service through out the meal was quite attentive and patient. To start we had the Wonton soup (small) which was plentiful for two and delicious! We also ordered the steamed bread which was honestly so addicting. I have never had that before and I was really digging it. For the mains we had sweet and sour pork and sizzling beef with scallops. The pork was way too greasy for my tastes. I wish we had chosen a different dish, but my boyfriend liked it enough. The sizzling beef and scallops were much better but some scallops were really wimpy and chopped up. IMO, the food was about 3 stars, but it was really fun to be in Chinatown and the service was good, therefore its deserving of 4.
author: Mary Kate R.

description: Walking through china town and decided to stop here! Very impressed! We ordered the egg rolls, which were very good. My family and I split the  chicken chow Mein and it was delicious!! Staff was super friendly; however did not get any water until we asked at the end of the meal, but overall would recommend.
author: Sarah F.

description:
This place was  horrible with customer service...they seemed annoyed cus we came in a group of 11..  we just separated tables cus we were like sardines in a can all crammed up in the corner round table...
The food was average ...chowmein was good we had both chicken and beef...
But wow when we ordered  2 full orders of sweet n sour pork & chicken  ...it's like they put 6 or 8 cubes of meat and tons of bellpepper, onion,  & pineapple chunks swimming in sweet & sour sauce....
So after bad service I didn't tip them..Hell No..specially after the younger lady asked me 2 wait outside...ok did you tell the group before us to wait outside, No she didnt..
So they get 2 stars ...shitty service
author: Ana G.

description: I really like spicy food. The restaurant has a lot of different dishes I love because it has fresh food and good service. It has authentic Hunan flavor, this is my favorite. Especially their dry pot pork, hot and sour soup, nine tower chicken, their taste will not be too salty, and spicy taste just right, and the price is reasonable.
author: Renee X.

description: I thought the food was really good at Hunan Home's. The hot and sour soup was outstanding. The kung pao chicken was tasty, and we also had some kind of pork dish with tofu. The various Henry's Hunan locations will always have my heart, but in Chinatown Hunan Home's is a darned good option.
author: Gwynnie P.

description: This resturant came highly recommended and did not disappoint! I highly recommend the succulent bread!
author: Tami H.

description: Hunan Home's was delicious and staff was very nice. I enjoyed a pleasant dinner with my family. We ordered Wonton Soup, Shrimp, Kung Pao Chicken, Fried Rice, and orange Chicken. Everything was very good.
author: Kimberly B.

description: Great Chinese spot.  There was a wait so we went across the road for a drink.  The staff was pretty funny.  The waitress shouted something in Chinese at another waitress but sounded like she was yelling at us.  The waiter/owner guy told us we could suck the peppers for flavor but don't eat them cause they were super spicy.
author: Nyla K.

description: Yelp review rating were pretty spot on, one of the best Chinese food places I have eaten. First of all it's a small restaurant, Service shouldn't be that difficult but it was. You literally had to flag the waiter down to order or get your bill and it took them a long time to pick up payment. Still, I have to say the orange chicken, Kung Pao Beef and the fried rice were really, really good! Wanton's were not the best they were ok. They don't take reservations and if there is a lot of people you will be waiting a long time. As usuall, parking in SF sucks but there is a parking garage down the street. Despite there being a moon festival we didn't have to wait a long time to be seated but 30 min after we arrived it started to get busy and some people left because they did not want to wait. They could use more staff.
author: Teresa I.

description:
One of the items on my San Francisco bucket list was to eat at a restaurant in Chinatown.  

In my search of authentic Chinese, of course I turned to Yelp.  Hunan's Home had over 800 positive reviews so I thought it had to be a sure thing.  

We walked there from The Embarcadero so we didn't have to worry about parking. There were meters on the street out front but I didn't see any available spaces.  The interior was what you might find in other Chinese restaurants:  a fish tank near the entrance, zodiac placemats and faux bamboo in the dining room.  It was lunchtime but we didn't have to wait for a table.  

Our server was ready to take our order before I even got a good look at the menu.  I don't think he was trying to rush us.  I think he was used to dealing with people who hurry to get in and out during their lunch hour and he was trying to be efficient.  He used Chinese characters to scribble our orders on a mint green notepad...loved that.

I got Egg Flower Soup and Moo Shu Chicken.  The soup was filled with clots of scrambled egg instead of light ribbons of egg.  It tasted fine but clearly someone in the kitchen didn't stir the soup properly.  It wasn't served with any crispy fried noodles either for some reason. 
 
For the Moo Shu they brought out two plates--one for the Chinese pancakes and plum sauce, another for the chicken and vegetable filling.  The vegetables were overcooked (with browned edges) and the flavors weren't interesting.  I ate less than half my order.  My dad just picked at his Fried Rice and my son was indifferent about his Chicken Lo Mein.

After our meal, the server brought out fortune cookies, orange slices and a pot of jasmine tea.  I didn't think I would like the tea since there wasn't any honey or sweetener to go with it but it had a nice floral flavor.  The oranges were the sweetest I've tasted in a long time.

None of us thought the food warranted so much acclaim from Yelpers.  Our entrées were so mediocre.  One star for helping me check the item off my list, another star for the service and one half star for the food.  2.5 stars.
author: Andrea T.

description: The tea smoked duck is a must try! Also the deep fried buns with condensed milk as dipping sauce is so good!
author: Huong T.

description:
We (Group of 7) went to Hunan Home's (on Saturday -June 25th) because of the yelp reviews "4 stars", and we looked at the pics. Totally misleading. I'll make this plain and simple (see below)
1. Ordered the chicken (fried)  - raw inside (pink flesh)
2. Ordered 3 plates of Mongolian beef - was charged for 4   
3. Ordered Prawns and scallops w/eggs over white rice - received Bay shrimp and fried rice
4. Asked for a glass of ice - got it, with black mold like particles "MAJOR HEALTH HAZARD"
"hygiene risk." what alarms me is that the likely culprit is the dirty ice machine, and while the presence of pathogens like E. coli in anything meant for ingestion is cause for alarm. It makes me wonder WHAT ELSE IS GOING ON at Hunan Home's Restaurant. EAT AT YOUR OWN RISK !!!!!
author: D R.

description:
The food was excellent and the service was even better.  Henry was one of the best servers I have come across in a very long time.  

I recommend that everyone try this restaurant .
author: Michael G.

description: Food is delicious  Had a variety of different stuff and the service was great. Parked at the parking structure 1 block away.
author: Jason C.

description:
We liked it.  We had

Won tons in spicy sauce (not very spicy but really good anyway
Shrimp chow mein (tiny portion but very good)
Eel on sizzling plate (huge portion and excellent)
Fried half chicken with bones (not spicy bit good)
Asparagus (wow, fantastic)

Everything was good, service was prompt, and were very sweet to make sure we knew the chicken had bones!
author: Foodlover B.

description: It wasn't a good experience, not very friendly or helpful with the extensive menu.  It's not worth going.
author: Isabel G.

description: I have gone to this restaurant on and off for around 5+ years. It was great food, love the steamed rice and the string bean chicken. The wonton soup is the best. Although a few months ago after being away for at least three years has changed. I believe under new ownership, found myself confused when there was a line out the door???? The most waiting would be inside the lobby area with a few ppl, I got a sit quickly during previous Christmas shopping weeks so this was odd. I did not recognize the person managing the front. The food was very bland and which was very odd, the food is usually very flavorful. Portions were not as large as I remembered.Service was a lot better, it would take forever to get servers attention, this time around I was able to catch them easily so that was a plus. I will probably try one more time to give them a chance.
author: Pamela M.

description:
Service first and foremost was incredible.  Very attentive, brought out hot tea right away on a cold rainy night.  Waiter came around right away to take our order and kept checking back, and our water glasses did not wait long to be filled.  

We didn't order Appetizers, looked like standard fare and I'm sure it was good.  We went right into the entrees expecting lots of food.

I ordered the Chicken and Prawn with Eggplant in a garlic sauce.  The portions were good, not over the top.  I thought they were large enough to share or enough for an individual.  The flavor was very good and the prawns were very large and there were probably about 5 to 6 large prawns mixed in with the chicken. However the chicken bits were all dark meat, I wish I would have known that.  They seemed a bit under done and chewy.  I didn't eat much of the chicken.  The Eggplant was plentiful in large stalks.  

My Fiancé ordered the Hunan chicken.  Good flavor in the sauce.   Lots of colorful vegetables, and crisp not mushy.  Chicken was all dark meat bits as well, good but a bit chewy.  One odd thing was that there were a few pieces of beef in the dish that shouldn't have been in there.  

This restaurant was recommended by the Hilton where we stayed and very close proximity to the hotel. The interior is very clean and very nicely decorated. We came for dinner at 8 p.m. and still lots of people here obviously a well-known and favorite for good Chinese food.
author: Anessa A.

description: We made reservations and our table was waiting for us despite the line. We ordered egg rolls, xiao long bao soup dumplings, wao wonton soup, beef with broccoli, prawns in lobster sauce, and pork fried rice. Tea was complimentary and we also ordered a Cabernet, Pinot noir and Tsingtao.  Everything was very good. My husband complained the egg rolls looked like spring rolls, but he ended up really liking them. He said the wonton soup was the best he ever had. I liked the beef with broccoli and thought the prawns were good, too.
author: Cathy O.

description: This place is awful. I have no idea how they have such good ratings but it sure is not due to their food or service. We waited almost 30 mins for our first appetizer, then our food came and it was nothing to brag about. I had the kung pao chicken and it was absolutely disgusting. The "chicken" was not edible, had to chew over and over then i just set it to the side. I am 36 and have eaten chicken all over the world and this was not chicken. I feel bad for whatever animal I may have eaten. Very suspicious. The service was terrible as well, we asked for water since we first got seated and we left about an hour and a half later without ever getting our water. Skip this place and chinatown completely since from what we have heard is the worst Chinese food you will ever have.
author: Bruce H.

description: Nice place to be! Extremely satisfying services and food! The meat is very fresh and yummy!
author: Francine L.

description:
This is my first time trying the Hunan food in Chinatown and it is fabulous~
They have great service and delicious food. I ordered the spicy pork and sweet sour fried fish~ Tate's very good and I will absolutely come back next time.
Next time I want to try the sour spicy soup and the fried wonton.
author: K L.

description: Best Chinese food I've had in a long time, maybe ever. Egg rolls were delicious as was the garlic sweet and sour chicken (I think that's what it is called). My husband loves hot and sour soup and this one did not disappoint. Nothing fancy, but great service and a good find in Chinatown. Also great value! Would definitely recommend!
author: Julia M.

description:
Ah if I'd only follow my own advice...

Meeting a friend in SF Chinatown and needed to find a place quickly because Chong Qing Xiao Mian closed. Saw the four stars and didn't think too much. Got to the restaurant and knew something was up when I saw that it was full but had no asians.

Also the whole place smelled Mike general tso's chicken or sweet and sour chicken or whatever dish that's covered in that deathly sweet mystery goo.

Too late to go anywhere else so sat down and tried to order the most Chinesey dishes there, hoping for the best. 

The dou miao flavor was ok but super super super tiny portions. Got a whole fish that was the most meh thing ever and the cured meat stir fry was really just full of what tasted like hillshire farm sausages or something.

Best thing there...the rice.

Sorry but this place is anything but authentic and the dishes definitely reflect that.
author: Michael C.

description:
A great start to a short San Francisco adventure!

My 16 year old and I are in San Francisco for a day or two and needed some lunch. Wait at well reviewed restaurant? Nope. Easy to find another well reviewed restaurant in Chinatown. That is how we ended up here.

Stated with some hot and sour soup and tea. Caffeine = always good. The hot and sour soup was relatively bland, but passable.

Next were vegetarian pot stickers. They were both fried and steamed and had great texture. The mix of veggies inside was tasty. Given that veggie pot stickers are hot or miss this is a hit!

My kid ordered the chicken curry. It was chicken with green pepper and carrots. He said it had great flavor, but it was not as spicy as he expected.

I ordered the string beans and prawns. It was a good size serving. It was supposed to be spicy and had a creeper spicy feel. Maybe I needed to ask for more spice on the front end. Either way it was very good.
author: Neal B.

description: This place was my go-to place in San Francisco for at least 15 years. No more validated parking. Have to hunt the streets for a while to get a extremely daunting task of squeezing a car into uphill or downhill space. Not a happy camper (car parker). Food is very good, but the usual dishes have gotten smaller. Not all restaurant owners realize that keeping your customers happy and satisfied with their food will entice future visits. My usual beef chow mien, pork fried rice, broccoli beef, are now fit for a group of small kids or little people.
author: Alex G.

description:
A little disorganized but a good meal. Forgot to make one of our entrees...forgot to bring water... the tea could have been a lot better...it was in a bag. The chicken and garlic sauce, xiao dumplings, and the hot and sour soup were superb. String beans in minced garlic was good but too salty.
And, the waiters and staff were all very cordial~
author: V V.

description: worst food i ve ever had in SF. Had so much hope for soup dumplings but they turned out to be so thick and no soup inside @.@ peking duck was super expensive and so bad...not sure why they are rated so high...
author: Hannah L.

description: So we went there for the soup dumplings- I'll get to that in a minute. We ordered fried dumplings which were pretty good- wrapper was a little thick but inside was flavorful. Then came the combination fried rice- it was good. Soup dumplings- I was really hoping for better but there was no soup in the SOUP dumpling. I've eaten a lot of soup dumplings but this is not the place to come for them. We finished with Hunan Succulent Bread- fried bread which came with some condensed milk which was really good. Overall I would come here for other meals but not when looking for soup dumplings.
author: Lori C.

description: Great food. One of the best restaurants to eat at in Chinatown. There are plenty of options here like most Chinese restaurants but they are all executed well. The Peking duck and ginger/scallion chicken stuck out as being particularly good here.
author: Austin L.

description: If it wasn't for yelp idk how we would have found this place, but after a long day hiking and exploring the city my authentic sweet and sour pork was so fulfilling. It was very scrumptious i give them a 10/10 for the experience service and food. Waiting line is interesting but i'll save the fun for you!
author: Ben C.

description: Best restaurant of my San Francisco trip! If you're looking for an authentic Chinatown restaurant - this is the #1 place to go. The set up is homey - there's two floors. If you have a big party, you'll be seated at a big table with a lazy Susan which was very useful. For appetizers we enjoyed egg rolls, potstickers and the wonton soup. The medium wonton soup is so big it fed 6 people! For entrees, we ordered the chicken chow mein, broccoli and beef, veggie fried rice, and mu shu pork. I recommend all of it!!!! The service was great and they split our meals for us and we didn't even ask! Only bad thing was our 20 minute wait turned into an hour wait and they definitely seated larger parties that came in after us. Make sure they don't forget you're waiting for a table!
author: Kelsey S.

description:
Not good anymore. Did ownership change? I'm not going to eat there ever again.

The meat is low quality, the wontons taste like liver. The chicken has the texture of rubber. 

It was my favorite Chinese food for 30 years. But today it was so bad I won't try it again.

So sad.
author: Michele S.

description: This was our first stop in the city for lunch and it did not disappoint.  The service was excellent and the food was delicious. We started with the bread and the pot stickers.  Both were amazing. Kung Paige beef, shrimp Lo mien and Hunan Shrimp were the entrees. All very tasty and fresh.  Mango pudding was dessert and was very good
author: Gus G.

description: From the hot tea to the chow me in, everything was delicious!!! We had great service, even the fortune cookies were fantastic!!! Great place to visit and have a meal.
author: Christina F.

description: First time came to this restaurant. Everythings good the Servers are nice. I love the spice pork and crab.
author: Melody L.

description:
Does  it get much better folks.

Crowded but the line moves quickly.

Food is always spot on wonderful.

Cheap eats served up fresh and hot.

What's not to like?
author: Walter M.

description:
Friendly greeting at the door, we were seated and immediately given a pot full of hot tea. We ordered Vegetable dumplings, Double Mushroom with shrimp and scallop and Mongolian Beef. The beef was soft and flavorful. Just enough spice. 
The double mushroom was bland and not appealing. Plenty of seafood in the dish but lacked in flavor.
My husband took some sauce from the Mongolian Beef and stirred it into his dish. Tasted pretty good.
Will return.
author: Barbara C.

description: Service was excellent but neither my husband or I were all that impressed with the food....although i loved my hot and sour soup! The other stuff we got was just ok. Very nice staff.
author: Shauna B.

description: We love this place. Egg flower soup is top shelf. Skip the salt and pepper squid but everything else is delicious and the service was fast. They took the squid off the bill and the orange chicken was delicious. The won tons have no meat in them as advertised.
author: Jake B.

description: Was there in 12/10/17 this place is horrible service the Man waiter body stinks underarms,Gigi woman  waitress keep blowing nose and seats smell no cushions was stain and have no padding also when we refused to give a tip they got very combative wanting there 20% and we gave them there tip but never will go there again! And I live in San Jose ca and go 2 week to sf but this time I wanted to try a different Chinese restaurant and got the recommendations from Yelp...,beware of this place from Chinese Hell hole place.
author: God J.

description: Great service, great price. The food was delicious. Had dumplings and some kung pao with shrimp and chicken. It wasn't the best I've ever had but I would definitely come back.
author: Emiliano A.

description:
A little disappointing. Went here on my trip into Chinatown based on the Yelp reviews. I might have been there on an off day, but I don't think so. 

The hot and sour soup was very tasty. Not very hot, but tasty. For entrees I had the cashew prawns and my wife had the Kung Pao chicken. Both were okay. Just okay. Neither was as good at what I get back home in Charlotte, which is not saying much. 

The waiter was attentive, but cold as ice. Generally, the place did feel friendly. 

Overall, I was let down. I had high hopes going in and only got average food. Surely there's better in the largest Chinatown outside of Asia.
author: Jim D.

description: Found this spot as a less busy but highly rated Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. Heard the other "higher rates" restaurants were not as great as they seemed. There was still a line outside we had to wait in even at 6pm but it went quickly. We were excited to try it out. Had the eggrolls and dim sum to start out. Both were great. Eggrolls were the skinny kind, less meat than normal, but still flavorful. The dim sum I liked. Very meaty, tasty, and fling. The outer "dough" did have some kind of floury aftertaste but wasn't bad. I had the hot and sour soup which was probably in my top 3 of all time. Then had the Mongolian beef. The sauce and vegetables in the Mongolian dish were great but wasn't a fan of how they cooked the meat. Rice was on point. Should have been crispy, which is just my personal preference. If it would have been , then I would be tempted to rate it a 5. Service was average but the best you could expect in Chinatown.
author: Sean C.

description:
First of, San Fran's china town is by far the best I've ever been too. Tops, Boston, NY and any other. 

Ok this spot. On my trip this wasn't on my list but in San Fran the best of the best spots are so crowded that I had no other choice but to have Chinese. In the end I'm glad I stopped by. Very good service. Very good soup and dumplings. The fried rice was delicious. And so were the spring rolls. And did I say very friendly and welcoming staff.
author: Giovanna H.

description:
Amazing little find in the sea of Chinatown restaurants!
We were greeted with kindness, waited just a few minutes for a table to be readied, and seated with complimentary hot tea.
We ordered:
Orange Peel Chicken-perfectly crispy and cooked, just the right amount of sauce. Not spicy, and our kids loved it. 
Beef Chow Mein-seasoned and cooked just right. 
Hunan chicken-real chicken breast pieces and a nice array of vegetables. Very spicy and flavorful.
Pot stickers-our kids are "pot sticker experts" and they loved them. I had one, it was cooked exactly right.
They also served complimentary spicy soup.
We were checked on several times with a smile, and service was prompt!
The bill for our entire meal was only $31 before tip! We normally can't eat in a big city for anywhere less than three times this. You won't be disappointed.
author: Jamie C.

description:
As other Yelpers have stated, I don't know what is so great about this restaurant.
To be honest, their service is pretty good compared to other Chinese restaurants and that's about it. 

Beyond that, food was mediocre.
And after we finished there were people outside waiting to be seated.

We ordered the:
-chow mein combination meat: pass. noodle was thinner
-mongolian beef: too much onion, need more meat.
-soup dumpling: Skin is too fat, and little soup
-Chinese broccoli in oyster sauce: no flavor

I should have known by looking at their customers.
There were too many people other than Chinese eating here....
author: Eunice K.

description:
Looking for a good Chinese restaurant in Chinatown?! EAT HERE! EAT HERE!!! Honestly, the food here is so good, I refuse to try any of the other hundreds of Chinese restaurants in Chinatown. (Which many are sketchy, so just come here ) 

The service is awesome and food is delicious. They even make something simple as pea shoots taste so good!  My favorite is the salt and pepper fish. They're like mini fish and chips (minus the chips) with a flavor explosion. It comes out steamy hot and so crispy! Another favorite is the family style bean curd. (Fried bean curd, mushrooms, snow peas, in spicy garlic sauce)
author: Chanel H.

description: Food was all very good and service was efficient. However, the ladies bathroom was dirty and had dead bugs on the floor. The back room by the restrooms is filled with food sitting out. Not sure if it was for restaurant use or personal use. Then I know I saw the busboy salvaging un-eaten oranges and something else off of a table. He was clearing the table, then stopped, picked up oranges off of other plates and put all on one platd, left the room. When he returned he proceeded to put the rest of the dirty dishes in a bis pan stacked on top of each other. Wouldn't have eaten here if I'd seen all this first.
author: Allie S.

description: When I brought my boyfriend here back in November it was his first time ever having xiao long bao and he loved them. Since then he has been on a mission and we get them at every Chinese restaurant we go to. We both agree that no one has been able to make them better than Hunan Home's! We even tried out Din Tai Fung in Costa Mesa the other day (look up their yelp page) which specializes in xiao long bao and still felt like they weren't as good. Next time we are in the city we will be coming back!
author: Connie S.

description:
Awesome service (James is the best!) we got the chow mein, chicken fried rice, tin sin chicken, won ton soup, and sweet and sour pork.

Wasn't a huge fan of the pork, but everything else was delicious and they brought the food out promptly. Amazing for the price too. With a few beers and all of the food the split was about $17 a person split evenly and we got to try a lot of great dishes. Will definitely be back!
author: Jackie G.

description: Egg rolls without taste, only oily. Fried rice too. Fried rice from Panda Express is better :)
author: Ramon R.

description:
Good food, reasonable price. Was busy and did not have to wait long. Staff were friendly. Complimentary green tea.

Would go again.
author: Luke S.

description: First time come to Chinatown try this Chinese restaurant. I really like the orange chicken and xiao long bao. Will come back next time
author: Hong H.

description: Good looking table settings.   Long menu.  Weak Jasmine tea brought to table before steeping.  Good egg rolls, but weak flavored plum sauce.  Similarly the food was meek.  No desert available.
author: David C.

description:
Came here with a friend and ordered the Chicken with orange peel and the House special crispy seafood chow mein.

My friend choose the Chicken with orange peel because of other reviews.  They were right, it was delicious, very light and crispy texture.  It was tasty but the portion was kind of small.

I wanted a noodle dish, i was hoping they had chow fun noodles, but they didn't, kind of odd to me, but maybe thats just the cuisine.  When it came out i thought it was kind of disappointing, the portion was small and there was very little seafood.  I liked the crispy noodles, i like when they are crispy then you let all the sauce soak into it all.  The sauce was kind of bland too, you could taste the seafood, but very subtle, i added soy sauce to it for a more bold flavor.  It was okay but i wished i ordered something different maybe the chicken and asparagus with black bean sauce.
