The prices are decent but the portions are on the smaller side, 1 entree per person + rice should be enough.  It wasn't bad, I'd order the orange peel chicken again.
author: Ryan M.

description: This place was an absolute gem. We arrived right before a large tour group having taken the recommendation of fellow yelpers. We waited about five minutes. No reservations and they make you stand in line. We ordered the wonton soup, potstickers and sizzling beef and scallops. The wonton soup was spicy with plenty of wontons. Definitely for two. The potstickers were huge and tasty. Beware of the sizzling beef and scallops. It came with a spicy black bean sauce. We didn't realize that it was spicy and my husband ate a green pepper and turned beet red. He needed a glass of water or two. It was so good we are trying to decide the cheapest way to get back there from our hotel at SFO.
author: Jocelyn B.

description: San Francisco has so much amazing Chinese Food.  After living in the city for 7 years this is the place I call home for the best hunan Cuisine.  Anytime a friend or family member would visit from out of town, i'd bring them here.  The sizzling platters will dance with each of your senses.  This is a no frills place, just solid delicious food at fair prices.
author: Luis J.

description: Great pot stickers, the mu shu was fabulous.  The orange chicken was light and spicy.  Everything was absolutely perfect.  Pricing was fair and wait staff was attentive.
author: Teresa C.

description:
There was a picture of Jeremy Lin with the owners. (First Asian American in the NBA) that says it all. Jk. 

I ordered potstickers, Hunan chicken and seafood Hong Kong style crispy noodles.

I don't come here for the service plain and simple but they are kind and courteous. It can take some time to get your food but why so anxious? Lol. It will get there. Chill out and admire the ambience. 

Food portions were plenty enough for 2. Good for at least 3 for what we had. 

Hunan chicken sauce though...I kept scraping up the sauce and mixing it in white rice even though I already unbuttoned by jeans and belt haha! It was that good or MSG perhaps ...who cares! 

Potstickers were hot,delightful and fatty and porky ....me like. Meaty and some veggies not too much veggies either...Major plus. Oh! And that chili sauce they have there...aka crack sauce. You Will  know as it sits on the table with a spoon. 

Noodles were crispy and seafood was soft and fresh not over cooked. Delicate morsels. Sauce was spot on and I was on cloud 9. 

Probably stoned...but it was 420 that day! 

If you are about the food, come here. If you are needy then this is not for you. 

They have high chairs for kids as well but if you have kids that cry easily maybe get some takeout but expect 45 min wait early on weekends. We went at 11am Sunday and beat the rush.
author: S. L.

description:
We got the sweet and sour chicken and the chicken lo mein. It was absolutely delicious. We didn't have to wait long either.  I asked for the check at the end, the waiter goes, "check not here, bill." Not sure what he was saying, but assuming he meant they only take cash, I asked again, "the check. We'll take it when you get a chance." Again, he repeated, "no check, just bill here." I started to smirk, because I thought he was screwing with me. "Okay...the check---" I say and interrupts me and goes "chuck went home for the night, just bill is here." 

He was totally screwing with me and making a joke. 

We all start laughing and he goes "I'll bring the check" as he cleared our table. 

Great service, funny and awesome. I would definitely recommend it and plan to go back.
author: Carmen C.

description: The food was just ok. I can't explain the meat in my "beef" with string beans...I really don't want to think about it!!! The servers were typical...not very friendly, at all!! But what I really can't explain was the music that was playing, rap music with all the really bad words. Totally inappropriate, especially with kids in the restaurant. We will not be returning!!!  Total fail in China Town!!
author: Alina F.

description:
Very spicy! Hot and sour soup is especially good. Other dishes are also very nice, such as beans, gong pao chicken, gong pao shrimp, mapo toufu. The service is also nice with both English and Mandarin ability.
Located in the heart of Chinatown, also convenient to reach when travel in downtown SF. Overall, this is 5 star experience.
author: Wenzhe L.

description: Second time here. Stopped in Chinatown just to eat here. Excellent food. Fresh ingredients.
author: Luci S.

description:
First the good - The food was tasty.  Good flavor and generous servings.  Also, our large party of 6 was seated very quickly considering the line out the front door at lunchtime.

Now the bad...
I seriously saw a mouse run from the kitchen to underneath a guest's table.  OMG.  Ok, so I put that in the back of my mind as I ate, chalking it up to being an old building in Chinatown - I get it.  But it just keeps going.  We all get our food as it comes available, so some people are practically done by the time the last person got served - but that wasn't the last person either - my son's order could not be made because they didn't have jellyfish at the time.  Why did we have to wait until all the food had been served to find this out??  So we ended up just sharing whatever we had left with him.  The service was sub-par - they hardly tended to us at all.  Then I went to the restroom.  Ok, I get that it's an old building but it smelled like mildew and one of the stalls didn't lock so I ended up opening the door on a very surprised lady.  On my way out my sons were looking at the live crab tank and by now I wasn't surprised to see all the gunk and dead shrimp carcasses on the outside of the tank.  At the door I made a point to look around for their Food Facility Inspection grade and couldn't find it anywhere inside or outside.  No surprise there.
author: Zazil A.

description: BAD. Xiao Long Bao had no broth in it, chow mein had no taste, same with fried shrimp, rice was old, beef was GREY?? Good to know as I am trying to find my go-to Chinese place and now I know it is not here.
author: Lynsea C.

description: I looked at the number of reviews and trusted it. The quality of food was mediocre at most.  We got Mongolian beef - meh, sizzling rice soup that had no flavor (you can't even compare to House Of Nanking-our favourite place in this neighborhood), spicy garlic chicken was ok, fish in salt pepper was whatever.  Not sure what happened.  Won't be back.
author: Viktoriya Z.

description:
Kung pao tofu was so mushy, not fried, not crispy.. just terrible. Succulent home bread was not succulent at all. The veggie chow mein was the only thing I found edible and my husbands orange crispy beef was not crispy and touch too sweet. 
We're from NYC and we know good Hunan and Szechuan food. This, unfortunately was definitely not it. 
The only reason we came here because we were in a rush and Z and Y wait was too long. Next time when in SF we'll definitely wait across the street for some quality food, hopefully that one wont disappoint!
author: Julia S.

description:
A classic Chinese restaurant that almost every city in America has. Hunan Home's fits that description to a "T." Stop #4 of our DIY chinatown food tour brought us to our first sit-down meal. My wife and I split the chicken fried rice and the chicken with spicy garlic sauce.The hot tea was a nice a treat as us Miamians were a little cold for our first day in San Fran. 

The chicken fried rice was amazing! The flavor was out of this world, but the chicken was a little fatty. The chicken with garlic sauce was deep fried chicken probably  better known as the  General Tsao's chicken at most Chinese food restaurants. The chicken was good and the garlic sauce had a nice kick, but wasn't overly spicy. 

The restaurant was supposed to take credit card, but the machine was conveniently down as we went to pay. Luckily we had cash on us. Tip: make sure you ask if the machine works prior to ordering. I would recommend this place, but if you're not from San Fran there is a good chance that your city has a restaurant just like this.
author: Josh K.

description: The food is good, I feel in love with the fried bread. It's delicious! The customer service is definitely not the best though. They made it difficult to split the bill in 3, she left saying "we can only split in two, figure it out" lol. If customer service is not high on the list I would recommend it. The food was good.
author: Anayancy O.

description:
First things first. My family and I made the trip to San Francisco to experience the thriving culture there. The experience was incredible so we decided to end it with some of the world class cuisine we've heard so much about. We chose Hunans.

Expect to pay for parking if you're arriving hungry -- trust me. The line was short so the wait wasn't long. The issues started occurring once we had to hail someone to take our order although people seated after us where helped before us. 

The wait for our food was long enough that the same people seated after were finishing up their dishes. Now one could say: "Maybe they couldnt see you". We were seated in the most trafficked area of the restaurant; in the middle of the restaurant.

FINALLY: We get our food... all except of our family members. Instantly the tiny portion sizes shocked us gravely. We dug in because we were hungry and the disappointment in our faces was blatant. BLAND.
author: Harold W.

description:
Read the review so we decided to walk and find it and give it a try.  The staff was friendly and we were seated quickly.
The hot and sour soup was ok.  We were trying to decide if we wanted the succulent bread or pot stickers.  The waiter recommended the pot stickers...good choice.
My wife ordered the orange chicken, she said it was one of the best she has ever had.  I even liked it and I'm not a big orange chicken fan.
author: Rowland A.

description: Sure, good vegetarian food and friendly staff. As many Chinese joints the ambience is a little lacking but the food makes up for it. We had luggage and they were accommodating as we were heading for the airport after.
author: Phillip D.

description:
We were in San Francisco for half a day and wanted to eat in Chinatown. Arrived around 6:30 and the place was packed. The hostess was a bit short and not very friendly - but it is a chinese restaurant (I don't expect great service at korean or chinese restaurants). 

Ordered wantons in hot sauce (I've been ordering this everywhere i go), string beans with pork, and chicken in garlic sauce. Everything was excellent! I overheard someone saying their bbq pork is amazing also. 
The wantons were great - my toddler ate almost 4 of them basically inhaling them. Considering it being an appetizer, the portion was generous. We weren't feeling soup dumplings, so we decided not to get those - plus we live in glendale/pasadena with din tai fung right around the corner. 

We put string beans over rice - was amazing. But I am a fan of chinese string beans - so take it with a grain of salt!
author: Sue K.

description:
We were in Chinatown trying to get in a popular Chinese restaurant up the street but the line was too long, so I remembered seeing Hunan Home's on "Check Please" and decided to give them a try. The restaurant was packed but we got a table right away. This place is a really American Chinese food. We ordered the following :

Mushu Pork 4 stars tasted good but stingy on the wraps (4)
Hot and Sour Soup 4 stars actually pretty good
Szchuan Scallops 2 stars penny sized scallops with hot sauce.
Orange Peel beef 1 stars deep fried sticky mess
Smoked ham with veggies 3 stars was ok

Originally ordered the tea smoked duck but after the soup came they told us they were out and we subbed out the smoke ham dish.

The place was packed and service was slow.
author: George F.

description:
Ok restaurant, didn't offer water when we sat down and kept pushing rice without saying it would be charged. Food was ok (chow mein, orange peel chicken, kung pao chicken) but not amazing...
Also, bathrooms aren't the greatest but relatively clean.
author: Gonzalo O.

description: Hunan home's is the best restaurant in the chinatown. People are very friendly. All plates are very big and realy delicious.
author: Ufuk Emre M.

description:
Very tasty food, chow mein delicious !!
Not disappointed at all. Very cozy and the music playing in the background is very hype!
author: Angel G.

description:
Yelp let us down :(  The reviews sounded pretty good, but it was so meh!

We were in San Fran for a couple days and were looking for some "authentic Chinese food" in China town.  This was literally just any old American Chinese food.  It wasn't bad, but it also wasn't that good.  I've had better Chinese food in upstate New York.  

On top of the mediocre food, the service was pretty rude and everything took a while to come out.  Our table's food also came out at different times (though, I understand food coming out at the same time might be an American thing) which made the lunch experience even more awkward.  

If you want American Chinese food, that's what you'll get here, but this place will not wow you, by any means.
author: Megan S.

description: This was the best, real Chinese food I have tasted! This place was great and with really good service! We ordered the prawns with honey walnuts and a spicy chicken entree, sooooo good!
author: Lizzie C.

description: Been going here for 5 years for lunch. Ownership changed in the few months and its horrible now. This is my second tine going since change in ownership, i thought the first time was a fluke. Will miss this place
author: Krista T.

description:
Yum! I dig this place quite a bit. A friend and I were looking for dinner somewhere where we wouldn't have to wait too long on a Friday night and since we got out of the office at 7pm... the options were pretty grim. That being said though, we called into Hunan Homes at literally 6pm and they said they would take us for a reservation which was great.

We got the green beans, salt and peppered pork, hot and sour soup, and seafood special chow mein. All in all... good stuff. I liked it. Pretty authentic Chinese food at a respectable price. The total was a little under $50 for two people which is not absurd for dinner in SF, but is definitely on the higher side for a Chinese restaurant. This place definitely feels like it caters more toward Americans... but I really did like the food and thought it tasted pretty good and definitely had my authentic Chinese food cravings filled. 

tldr; pretty good Chinese food at a bit of a higher price, but definitely delicious!
author: Jasmine X.

description: We (party of seven) just left the restaurant and it was such a disappointment.  The food was okay nothing to brag about.  The service was the worst I have ever experienced.  We only ordered six dishes and all the surrounding tables (with bigger parties and some had arrived after us) appeared to have ordered more dishes were getting them continuously without a huge gap in between.   We had to sometimes wait 20 minutes for our next dishes and had to ask several times for the status of our order.  We had to literally wait 45 minutes for the fried squid.  I would not recommend this place to anyone.
author: Cynthia M.

description: We came here on a Friday the food was delicious. The service kinda like they don't care. They don't have a kids menu . The egg rolls were delicious .!
author: Evelyn L.

description:
I was looking for a restaurant open on Christmas Day for lunch with the family while visiting my brother. I was a little worried about what might be open but then I remembered Supreme Court Justice Elena Kagan talking about the Jewish tradition of having Chinese food on Christmas. So off I was to search for a fabulous Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. Well, apparently, everyone else had the same idea -- most of the best restaurants were packed. Relying on Yelp, I found this place, the wait wasn't too long even though the restaurant was quite busy and the very nice hostess even offered to call me once our table was ready so we could wander around for a bit.

The food was very solid. We had the sizzling rice soup (quite good), the pork bao (which I didn't try since I don't eat pork but looked good), the Peking duck which was served moo shu style (also good and I usually don't like duck), the shrimp with lobster sauce (quite good although a bit salty) and the chicken with string beans (also good but a little salty). The one less than stellar part of our meal was the rice which was a little on the dry side. I wouldn't hesitate to return here!
author: Elena M.

description: The service was great. Very accommodating and attentive and sweet. I came here with 4 adults 3 toddlers and a newborn and we all loved the food. Ordered the BBQ pork chow main for the kids and the steamed small dumplings. They devoured it all. The adults had the salt and peppered crab, snowpea leafs (such yummy greens), clams in oyster sauce, honey walnut prawns (the walnuts were nice and crispy) and some ribs forgot the name... all these dishes were so tasty and didn't feel greasy. We also ordered the lemon tea roasted duck. This dish wasn't bad but I'd would had preferred the Pecking duck. Overall, it was all yummy as will w going back!
author: Ms C.

description: Really good restaurant! We had to wait in line outside which was an experience in itself. Loved this place though. Best Chinese in San Fran. MAKE SURE TO CHECK IT OUT!
author: Peter D.

description:
It was a little pricey (standard for SF but high for Chinatown) and I wasn't thrilled about my dishes (fish dish with chili peppers, rice; beef). On the salty side and just didn't seem particularly good. To be fair, was tastier after refrigeration.

Why was this the highest rated Chinatown restaurant on yelp?
author: Rona C.

description: Had really good Hunan style Chinese Food in San Francisco. Had the hot and sour soup that was maybe the best I've ever tasted. The Hunan Shrimp and Shrimp with green beans were very flavorful. The place is not very attractive and the wait staff are okay, but it's the real Chinese Food we came for. I live in South Florida where the Chinese food is just average, so it was a treat.
author: Arlene K.

description:
I am more than willing to deal with long waits, chaotic service, over priced food, dirty kitchens, dirty table cloths and bathrooms where you feel dirtier walking out of than when you first walked into -- if the food is gonna be great.  Hunan Home's food fails big time.  

This is some seriously bad food.  And the cigarette smoke from the staff hanging out in the alley was another gross touch. 

Save your time, money and taste buds.  

Oh, and heads up, they are about to change ownership.  I guess the current owners are grabbing a lifeboat before this Titanic goes down for good.
author: XManLA X.

description: We were in the city for the day, and wanted Chinese food. A yelp search led us here. I liked this place a lot. The duck was good, but a little dry. The bbq pork was awesome. My friend who is Chinese approved as well. Service was also great. I would definitely eat here again. :)
author: Kyle H.

description: we used to come here almost once a month, but about a year or so ago the quality definitely went down, and the amount of msg hit the ceiling.  you'll notice almost all reviews are from visitors.  they must be listed in the guidebooks or something.  the last time there i had a vegetarian kung pao with tofu and it looked and tasted like leftovers.  we're done with them.  good luck to the unsuspecting visitors.
author: Alexandria B.

description:
We have been going here for almost 20 years. This used to be a family run business but changed ownership in 2017 when the original owner's son decided to retire. Fortunately the new owner kept the original menu and signature recipes. Only very minor changes occurred in the recipes such as no longer serving whole red chilies in the Orange Peel Beef but instead they are finely sliced. This means they no longer impart as much of a smokey flavor to the dish and instead make it a little spicier. On the flip-side, they are now using more tender strips of beef in the dish. 

Though the familiar staff is no longer working there, the current staff is just as friendly and the prices have significantly increased either.  

In my opinion it is still among the best Hunan/Szechuan restaurants in China Town.
author: Jorge S.

description:
Don't let the long line scare you. It only takes about a half hour to get through. It's hard to find really good Chinese food, but I think they nailed it. Service was fairly quick. The XLB, while they could have been soupier, were very high in flavor. I ventured off from my norm and got the Hunan Prawns. They were delicious, having the perfect amount of spice and it was nice to not have them fried. The Hunan String Beans were also very tasty.

Now the only reason this is a 3 star and not a 4 or 5 is because I received a spoon covered in blue goo (I believe it may have been detergent). Because I was in autopilot mode I almost ate my rice after using it to serve. They replaced it and brought me new brown rice, but I think that cleanliness is something that every restaurant should pay close attention to. That being said, I will say that this place is still worth visiting, but in general I tend to use caution at most Chinese restaurants.
author: Carly H.

description: As a tourist I was looking for good Chinese food without going "too" far out of my comfort zone. They had all kinds of options for the adventurous and the not! Great service! Great food! Great experience!
author: Christine L.

description: Just left the restaurant. Food was mediocre and service was absolutely terrible!!!!!!! Do not recommend at all!! This is my first review because I just had to say something.
author: Kailyn C.

description:
Really wanted to like this place more because they are one of the only well-rated Chinatown restaurants to earn respectable health inspection scores.

However, I just didn't think the food was that good in the 2 times I ate there.

I tried Salt & Pepper squid (just OK), whole braised fish (bad), and hunan string beans (good) over my 2 meals.

This restaurant is mostly full of non-Asian customers so maybe that should have been a warning sign.
author: Daniel P.

description: We landed in Frisco and had to eat here immediately. Amazing service and food you can't get anywhere else. All ingredients are fresh and cooked nicely. The water tastes funky here in San Fran, but that's not the restaurants fault. Would eat here at least once a week if I had the chance.
author: Darrian G.

description: Decent American style Chinese. Wait was short and serving size was decent. Price was also very reasonable. Would come here again if in the mood for Chinese.
author: Mike H.

description: This place would get more stars from me if possible. The pot stickers were absolutely outstanding, the tea duck was perfectly cooked with crispy skin, the orange peel chicken, while a common Chinese food staple, was delicious and not overly sweet and lastly the pork chow mein's noodles tasted as if they were freshly made. Definitley coming back here on my next trip to San Fran!
author: San B.

description:
Good service and good food!

My family was in town celebrating a wedding and we were looking for a good place to have lunch with about 20 people without reservations.  Found this gem on Yelp and it didn't disappoint.  We got there about 15 minutes after opening, we were hoping with our group size it might be a wait for a walk-in.  We were surprised and pleased that we got seated in less than 10 minutes.  They brought us through the main restaurant and down some stairs to another dinner room that had larger round tables.  Good seating for larger groups.  On the main floor I noticed most tables could probably accommodate smaller groups.  Our group of 20 was split into 2 large tables. 

We ordered off their menu a selection of entrees... 1 for each table.  We ordered the Wor Wonton Soup, Orange Peel Chicken, Sweet & Sour Pork, a couple rice and noodle dishes, salted shrimp, a veggie plate, enough to please everyone's' taste buds.  I was hoping the dishes would be a little larger portions, but I wasn't too disappointed, I just order another entrée plate for each table.  

Everything was pretty solid, and everyone enjoyed our time there.  Looks like it's a popular place amongst tourist and locals.  I'd recommend for  groups looking for a place to eat that wouldn't hurt the wallet too much and they could expect pretty good Chinese food.
author: Tiffany A.

description: Best cheese food for lunch in SF. Excellent service! Loved it. Order the fish for sure.
author: Ruxana L.

description:
Wandering around Chinatown- saw a review on Yelp for this restaurant so I decided to check it out. Opted for a set menu option. 

The soup was excellent followed by a selection of egg rolls and three other dim sum items. Next course was an orange chicken dish. I usually enjoy orange chicken but this dish the chicken was almost a jerky consistency with a very strong bacon flavor- it didn't taste bad it was just an unusual flavor and hard glazed coating on the chicken.  

The last course was an almost flaming beef dish with onion and chili. I mistakenly ate what I thought was a green bean- nope it was a green chili that had my eyes tearing and nose running for 5 minutes!

All in all the food would get a perfect five except for the orange chicken- the bacon flavor was overwhelming and the hard glaze and jerky consistency was not my favorite. Despite the chicken dish the food was high quality and delicious.
author: A P.

description:
This review is solely about the xiao long bao. 

If you are looking for xiao long bao (soup dumplings) look no further! The XLB here is incredible. The soup inside is hot and one of the most flavorful broths I've had. They interestingly add a peanut butter to the broth, and oddly enough, it works! Not only does it work, but I think that unique touch makes these some of the best xiao long bao I've had.
author: Karina S.

description: The place is a little old and run down. Maybe even a little dirty. If you can get past that, give them a try. The Mongolian beef was fantastic and so were the egg rolls. I would return for sure
author: Angela H.

description: Food was delicious but the portions were way too small. They squeezed 11 of us including 2 kids into one table. Service isn't the best, so if you are expecting to get anything you pretty much have to be a bit pushy. We ordered 3 orders of lemon chicken, fried won-tons, hot and sour soup, fried rice, white rice, chow mein, shrimp dish and a 2 other plates I can't remember. Bill was just shy of $200. On a PLUS note they do validate (2-hours) at a parking lot near the restaurant.
author: Gabby D.

description:
Im giving this restaurant only 2 stars. I cant believe we sidestepped other restauants that had high ratings and total number of reviews. We didnt have that long a wait to be seated. We went during the week. My friend ordered the kung pao with shrimp and I ordered the wonton soup. His meal came out in less than 5 mins! leaving us to wonder if it was properly cooked. It was unremarkable and bland. The soda we ordered as well as my wonton soup seemed to have been lost. I had to get the waiters attention to inquire of its whereabouts. It wasnt worth the wait. The soup had no taste to it. We were too disappointed in the experience. As we were getting ready to leave the patrons who came and sat next ti us apparently ordered a kung pao and also had shock on their faces of how quickly it came to the table. The female diner had our same perplexed look and said that was under 5 mins. We even planned to stop at another restaurant for dumplings but the experience had us leaving chinatown as quickly as possible.
Would not recommend!
author: Racquel S.

description:
The food was excellent, we had sizzling rice soup, then egg rolls, followed by garlic chicken, greens with mushrooms and vegetables fried rice.  They don't take reservations or your name so you have form a line like you are going to a club. 

The garlic chicken though is the best and the mushrooms & greens add a nice vegetable side. I'm a fan.
author: Sam P.

description:
I heard great things about this place and was very excited to try my first SF Chinatown restaurant. Full disclosure: I'm not a huge fan of Chinese food, but when in Chinatown... I was ready with an open stomach. Here's what I ordered:

Yang Chow Fried Rice (with BBQ pork and shrimp) 3/5
The flavors were very subtle..maybe too subtle, but the bits of pork were tasty and when I got the perfect bite of rice, pork, and egg it was quite delicious

Combination Chow Mein 3/5
Good flavor in the chicken, beef and noodles, although the shrimp had hardly any flavor and the dish was pretty oily..noodles kept slipping through my chop sticks :(

Sweet and Sour Chicken. 5/5
This dish was probably the best Sweet and Sour Chicken I have tried from a Chinese joint. Super juicy and lightly fried chicken in a sauce that balances the sweet and sour just right. The vegetables and pineapple were yummy as well. 

Overall the food was A-OK. The flavors were just too delicate for my taste, but the owner/ hostess was super adorable, enthusiastic and very nice and food came out fast.:D I feel like they probably do have some really good dishes, so I'll be sure to stop by and try something else if I find myself in San Francisco again.
author: Stephanie G.

description: I love the waitresses nice and considerate. Louis the owner is a very out going young man plus very nice. The food from type b was delicious I couldn't stop eating.
author: Aaron G.

description: Outstanding restaurant in Chinatown! Extremely authentic!  The Dried Spiced Asparagus is a Must!  Also ask if they have Chow Fun, it is on a secret menu and absolutely delicious! We have to admit we went here twice on our 3 1/2 day vacation - we loved it so much!
author: Nanette M.

description: Best Chinese food I've EVER had. Might be one of my favorite meals in general that I've ever had. The pot stickers were life changing- so flavorful and perfect texture. The soup dumplings were incredible as well. For entrees we went with the lemon chicken and the sweet and sour chicken- both very great but enjoyed the lemon chicken most. The white rice comes in a large pot, fun for serving. The fresh tea is tasty as well. And again the pot stickers and dumplings were life changing. MUST go here!
author: Elle C.

description:
I've been to Hunan Home's now on a number of occasions. Here's the thing, though... I'm not a lover of Chinese food. But, Hunan Home's is getting a 5-star rating. WHAT?!

Lots of selection and the food is REALLY good. Better yet, it's right around the corner from LiPo - get yourself a Mai Tai and then come for a delicious dinner. I highly recommend the Peking Duck. The best part is, if you've never had Peking Duck before, your server will make the first few "burritos" for you so that you know how to finish things off!

Definitely give this place a try. You likely won't be disappointed (and if you are, go have a Mai Tai... you'll feel better).
author: Derrick S.

description:
LOVE this fantastic Chinese restaurant. Looking from the outside you might just walk right by as it is very unassuming. But come inside and the food is as good as it gets - you will not be disappointed. 

On our most recent trip we had hot & sour soup (OMG so good!), tai chin chicken (savory spicy), prawns with honey walnut (yummy perfection) and xiao long bao and every dish was nothing short of delicious and the standard by which all other restaurants should be measured. I am getting hungry just writing this review. The service was very friendly. It is not a fancy restaurant but the food is EXCELLENT.
author: Joe B.

description: Good food with very fair prices for being in the city. Orange chicken was very tasty and kid friendly.
author: Candace B.

description:
I was so surprised by how clean this restaurant was, with hole-in-the-wall prices! And the quality was top notch. I would happy come back!!!!

It was Friday at 8pm. My boyfriend and I were quickly seated. 

WHAT WE ORDERED:

-Xiaolongbao. The soupy innard was so flavorful. My boyfriend thought it wasn't as good as the ones from Din Tai Fung (we're too partial to the thin skinned dumplings) but this was a close second! 

-Steamed wontons. YUMMY!!! I would totally order this again. I loved the spicy garlic soysauce that came with it.

-Fried wontons. Only ordered this because my bf loves fried wontons. It was good but honestly I am not a big fan of them as a food item. I would not order this again. 

-Hot & sour soup. I'm definitely ordering this again!!! Inexpensive comfort food!  

-Garlic prawns with green beans. It was tasty but at this point we were SO full that we had to take it home

-Side of rice (need to order it separately)

--
Clean, chic decor; prompt and friendly service (not to be expected from all Chinese restaurants!); delicious food; affordable price point. I'll be back!
author: Min Ju L.

description: I have driven straight from Seattle to make it to SF in time to eat here for dinner. Today I drove from San Diego to eat here on my way to Napa. It is a must stop for me.  Love the streets of Chinatown and this restaurant that I originally found as it was recommended to me by the concierge desk at the Fairmont SF in Union Square.  I love this town and I love to eat great food at a good price and Hunans delivers both. So as the song goes. now I'd walk  100 miles and I'd walk 1000 more just to be that person that walks 1000 miles to show up at your door.....O. O
author: Tish D.

description:
Went here for Chinese New Year dinner with a large group (10 people). 

When we got there, there was a line up of at least 15 people in front of us, which was expected considering everyone was out on the look out for good dim sum to celebrate. We were seated after an hour, which was surprising to me considering how large our party was. They even managed to put all of us together.

The place itself looks like your traditional restaurant in the heart of Chinatown. Very casual and busy vibe. We let our stomachs order a frenzy of menu items including the Xiao long Bao, Sizzling Chicken, Sizzling Shrimp, Mongolian Beef, Yang Chow Fried Rice, and Pork Chow Mein.

The food. was. on. POINT. The flavours were rich and complemented each other. My favourites were the Xiao long Bao, Sizzling Chicken/Shrimp, and the yang chow fried rice. It was a good dinner combination, getting the warm savoury soup dumpling, with the smoky flavour of the sizzling plates, and the subtlety of the fried rice. Considering how much we ordered, the price was wasn't bad at all.

I'd definitely come back here again to try the other menu items.
author: Aldrich W.

description: Food was less than mediocre and the service was some of the very worst I've ever experienced anywhere.
author: Felix P.

description:
It's really hard to believe that this restaurant currently has a 4 star average. I decided to come here while visiting San Francisco Chinatown and searched "Chinese food" based on current location while standing in the middle of Chinatown.

While reading the menu outside the door, I noticed that they had limited vegetarian options and the options they did offer seemed rather boring. I was with two other friends though and we were all hungry so we decided to check it out anyways.

I ordered the vegetarian potstickers and the fried tofu off the appetizer menu and both were just okay and did not come with any good dipping sauces. My friends ordered a curry chicken dish and chicken chow fun and thought their food was just average as well.

What makes this a 2 star review rather than 3 though is that the service was super rude! It took about 10-15 minutes after we were seated for the waitress to take our order. Then when we tried to ask her for water for our table or hot sauce she acted extremely annoyed to be even talking to us.

I've had way better Chinese food elsewhere, so please do yourself a favor and go someplace else!
author: Regina W.

description:
Yikes, this was a bit of a misstep. I didn't have enough time to properly research where to eat in this area and we ended up here. We just got the xioa long bao and another type of dumpling (I forget).

Then we saw a woman who looked like Paula Deen walk in, accompanied by her farmer-like husband wearing suspenders, and she says to the waiter, "This place has the best Chinese food!" in a loud, midwestern-y voice. Oh no.

It was then we realized almost everyone dining there was white.

The dumplings were nothing to write home about. I was hoping to find something better than the lackluster dumplings we have in San Diego, but I didn't find it here. They weren't terrible, but I was sad I wasted a meal during my short trip to SF here.
author: Kelly O.

description: must try！traditional Hunan cuisine, I like xiao long bao the most in this restaurants.
author: Mingfei C.

description: While enjoying my  stay here in San Fran ... on our first day we decided to get some Chinese and ended up here ... well I wish they could have told me the portions were going to be small because  although the food was good the portion size wasn't ... it was like feeding a group of 4 with a single entree ... never again ... but you live and you learn
author: Judy D.

description: We had several different dishes and all the food was pretty good. I can't say it was the mind blowing experience others have experienced. My expectations of coming to San Francisco and eating in a "Chinatown" restaurant with some sense of flair were not really fulfilled, that being said it was good food reasonably priced and accommodating.
author: Chris B.

description:
While the food was very good, we encountered the rudest server we have ever had!

We waited in line for over an hour, which we expected and we didn't mind doing because we were very much looking forward to our dinner there. We hadn't eaten all day, it was after 9 when we were seated and our family of 4 adults were very hungry!

We ordered appetizers, one entree each, steamed rice, fried rice, and when I tried to order chow mein, we were ALL shocked and embarrased when he said "No! That is too much!"  I said "What?"  And he said it again... "No chow mein, too much, you already have 2 rice!"

Never in all our years has a waiter told us we could not order what we wanted!

We knew we might not finish it all, but we wanted to sample both the rice AND the chow mein!  We planned to take our leftovers back to our hotel and heat them in our microwave for lunch the next day.  What right does he have to tell us what to order and what we can't have?

He shouldn't be doing that to customers.  We didn't get his name, as we were so upset by him, we ended up moving to a table upstairs and having our food brought by a very nice woman instead.  He was an older man, probably the oldest waiter there, not sure how else to describe him.  He never once smiled or said anything nice to us.
author: D M.

description: Thank you Yelp for helping us pick a restaurant.  Absolutely excellent.  The vegetables were cooked perfectly and the fish and chicken were seasoned to make my taste buds dance.
author: Wendy K.

description:
There were so many tasty looking restaurants in Chinatown, I wish I would've picked another.

The hot tea was cold and lacked flavor, but luckily it's complimentary.  Service was "abrupt" if I could describe it in one word.  But that parts not really important I guess because I don't imagine other restaurants in China town being any different.

My boyfriend ordered the orange peel chicken based on the photos on Yelp but when it came out it looked very different from the pictures we saw.  I tried some and in my opinion it was pretty disappointing.  I got the sweet and sour which was actually pretty good.

Luckily steamed rice for the table was $1 per person so that was nice.  

Ultimately an "eh" experience
author: Nikki R.

description: Another place found through fellow yelpers. We were starving and it was our first ever experience in Chinatown. We wanted to eat at a memorable place. This place was so busy so I knew it must be good. There was another place across the street that was busy but I took the opinions of my fellow yelpers. We didn't wait to long because there was only 2 of us. Our waiter was funny and service was quick. Highly recommended.
author: Chris D.

description: Great find!  Delicious chow mein, orange peel chicken and egg rolls!  Definitely making another stop here before leaving the city.  Service was good as well.
author: Hanna L.

description:
My mom, aunt and I were in Chinatown for the day and were looking for a place for lunch. Thanks to Yelp we found this restaurant. There was no wait time and we were immediately seated at a large table. The restaurant was pretty full which is a good sign. We were greeted right away and our waiter took our drink order. 

Their menu is quite large but we all ordered off of the lunch combo menu. Each entree came with a cup of hot and sour soup and a rice (.50 extra for brown rice). The soup was spicy and delicious! We ordered the kung pao chicken, broccoli beef and mongolian beef. The sauce on the broccoli beef was delicious. My mom's kung pao chicken was good, but not at all spicy. My aunt's mongolian beef was good but she said it wasn't the best she's had. The combo prices were more than reasonable and the portion sizes were more than fair.

The service was great, the food was good and the prices were reasonable. I would recommend this place. I didn't rate it higher because it was just average Chinese food, in my opinion.
author: Nicole B.

description:
Old-school Chinese food joint in chinatown

The decor and atmosphere very much reminded me of how old chinatown must feel like back in the day, with an old (but clean!) fresh tank near the entrance, large chinese paintings on the walls, and waitstaff who look like they have been faithfully serving the establishment for a long, long time.

The food, in general, is geared towards Americanized chinese food, with items like "kung pao", "moo shu", "general tsao" etc. But if you look deeper, the menu actually consists of mostly traditional chinese food, and a lot of non-Americanized items. Once I ordered the food, I realized the food quality is actually very, very authentic. The whole place feels like it's being run by cooks who learned the authentic craft, but started adding Americanized items to cater to more customers.

The juicy pork buns were ok, but were quite large and had a nice presentation. The eggplant in garlic sauce was sizzling when served, and cooked with the right amount of sauce to give it a real "kick" of spiciness. The sweet ribs were also cooked very well--you can taste the "smoky", "wok" flavor in the meat underneath the sweet sauce on the outside.

We went on Friday night, and a group of 5 tables were there for a group celebration of their friend who just published a book. Different members of the group raised their glasses and gave toasts to the author, and at the end everyone yelled "mazel tov!" together. Some even toasted the chefs. Definitely one of the rare moments in life where different cultures co-exist in such a small, densely packed restaurant.

Not a bad place to go back to once every so often.
author: Henry L.

description: We were visiting Chinatown for the first time and wanted to get some really good Chinese food. We hit the jackpot with this place! We ordered the orange peel chicken, the mushu pork, and the fried wontons. They serve jasmine tea with your meal and the tea is really good! Everything we ordered was amazing. I'm not sure I would order the fried wontons again because I prefer steamed wontons  (and the fried ones were so fried they were like chips), but I was so hungry that I enjoyed them anyway. I would definitely come back here (if I lived in San Francisco).
author: Lauren D.

description: Delicious! Husband and I both agree it was some of the best Chinese food we've had.
author: Kimberly B.

description: Thanks to my fellow Yelpers we stopped by here for dinner with the kids while in town.  We ordered a smattering of apps like dumplings and dim sum, hot and sour soup cause I have to have it, and veggie chow mein.  Everything was fresh, delicious, and exactly what we were craving.  Prices very reasonable.  They wouldn't accept reservations for 4 so we chose to eat an early dinner in order to avoid lines- which worked out perfectly.  I would definitely eat here again next time we're in town either with or without the kids.
author: Sarah P.

description: Must try the Xiao long bao and hot and sour soup. The staff are very friendly and very good service.
author: Ya Ling L.

description: Food was no better than I've had at a dozen Chinese restaurants around the US.  Indifferent service.  Nothing special.
author: Paul K.

description: I was very excited to try this place because it had good reviews and it was Christmas Eve in Chinatown. When we arrived we were told it was a 10 minute wait and we had to stand outside. We were eventually seated at a nice big table in the middle of the restaurant. They brought us menus and we were served our drinks and tea. Then as we were ordering they asked us to move to a different table. We were shoved into a small booth next the front door so every time the door opened the cold wind blew in on you. You also get the pleasure of having people standing at your table with their butts in you face as they wait to be seated or pickup to go orders. The booth was so small only on leg fit under the table. Our original table was given to another party of four which really made no sense. We finally ordered, the food arrived, portions were small, and the quality is that of a food court at a shopping mall. This place is not worth the hassle.
author: James W.

description:
They had Xiao Long Bao and it was poorly made. The skin was dry and thick. The dumpling must have been reheated because it was barely warm.  These should have come out steaming hot. 

We had their flower soup, fried string bean and hunan pork.  All very Americanized flavors.

I guess a chinese restaurant in Chinatown SF is not that authentic anymore.
author: Luke T.

description: Food was decent but service was the worst. They messed up one of our orders and took forever to fix it. The people next to us who came after got their food, finished it and paid by the time they brought us one of the corrected dishes. Also we asked for water from the beginning and never received it.
author: Linda S.

description:
It's been 4 years since I've back to Hunan Homes, and (sadly) a few things have changed .. No more warm buns with the (half) order of Peking duck. They come with white tortilla wraps instead. Also, the half order really seemed more like 1/4 of an order. Luckily we ordered other things so we left satisfied. 

The xiao long bao, on the other hand - was the best! I don't know what aspect the peanut butter was included, but it was delicious! This is the best xiao long bao I've had thus far (even beating some very popular Chinese places in NY and Boston). 

Their potstickers are legit too! Enjoy!
author: Beverly E.

description:
This restaurant is ok. The food is not authentic Hunan cuisines and neither are their staff. Many dishes were made with the same sauce.  Quite disappointed. 

Waited 40 minutes between after we asked for the check and when we finally left the restaurant.
author: Earl C.

description:
I've been here twice. Food here is not reflective of true Hunan cuisine as all, not to my surprise since it is situated near busy financial district. Dishes here are typical Americanized Chinese food, such as sweet and sour pork, orange chicken, etc... If you think of this not as Chinese food, but as American asian food, this place is quite acceptable.

What I did love about this place is the braised beef wonton noodle soup. WOW... it was so flavorful! I will be back just for that.
author: Betty T.

description: Been coming here for years. Can't believe I have never written a review. Excellent dumplings. Large traditional menu. Orange chicken, mu shu, tofu and Cantonese chicken stand out dishes. Sizzling rice soup always delicious. Good value. Large portions. Will keep coming back. One of the better places in Chinatown.
author: Steph G.

description: This was okay for me. I read a review after going there that said something around that the flavors are catered to the mild palate. I agree.
author: Dixi S.

description: We have enjoyed Hunan Homes for twenty years, but something has changed.  Soup portions are different, pot stickers are tiny, nothing up to the same standards.  Food quality has declined.  Our waitress last week was pretty inept.  None of the staff was the same. Turns out there is new ownership and all new staff.  We are so disappointed.
author: Susan T.

description: We really like the potstickers! First in line when they opened! 10min in 4 tables full. Chow main looks as good as it taste. The Chinese bronchi beef taste pretty good to. Not over the top with sauces so you can taste the food.
author: Thomas P.

description: I thoroughly enjoyed my visit to Hunan Home's.  The food was delicious and the service impeccable and friendly.  The decor is far from modern but it has an endearing quality that reminds you that you're in China Town, which as a tourist added value.
author: Michael P.

description: If they had 10 stars I'd give it that. As close to authentic as you're gonna get outside of China. The service was good, the chefs were Chinese which i knew i was in good hands and the bathrooms were actually clean,impressive. Kind of pricey but i didn't mind because it was so darn delicious. Definitely a must go if you want authentic Chinese food
author: Deanna D.

description: Wow! We had a party of nine and made a reservation. The table was ready when we arrived. We ordered the $17.95/person dinner and it was exceptional! Every dish including the vegetables was great. We loved this place!!!
author: Ron E.

description:
Good food and service! 
I ordered war wonton soup, combination fried rice, and Mongolian beef. Delicious.
author: B P.

description: Hands down super delicious! Ordered the crispy rice soup, broccoli chicken, orange peel chicken, chow mein & sizzling seafood! Left full and satisfied! Staff was super helpful & courteous!
author: Hungry H.

description: On a weekend trip to san francisco, was really craving chinese food so took a trip to china town. We visited this place and it was delicious. Sweet and sour pork is highly recommended.
author: Samantha S.

description: We had an excellent experience at Hunan Homes. I made a reservation for 21 people a week ago and I coordinated with the manager everyone's order. When we arrived, the meal was ready for us within 15 minutes and we were in and out within an hour. Great food, and service!
author: Meghan B.

description: Tiny portions for the prices they charge. Service is very slow during busy hours. I wouldn't come back especially if you're hungry. Even though there's a line out the door.
author: Yvonne M.

description: If you're coming to San Francisco in search of authentic Chinese food, don't bother. Food isn't bad but tastes pretty much like any ordinary greasy take out. If you can't handle spicy food and prefer things bland, maybe you'll enjoy this. If you're looking for something with more flavor or spice, you'll be disappointed.
author: Another H.

description: The scenery is lovely it feels like you're in a traditional painting, if you're lucky, there might be a musician outside playing a traditional Chinese instrument it is so so so cool! The food is so savory and sweet, even the tea feels fresh. Its a great restaurant for when in SF!
author: Alice M.

description: Amazing food and service. Free endless green hot tea and great hot and sour soup. I had the orange chicken and it was great.
author: Melissa M.

description: So so so good!  First time here and absolutely amazing Chinese food!  My husband and I had the xiao long bao, sizzling eel with shredded pork, and the Peking duck!  All so good!!!! We were amazed that they had an actual eel to serve!  That is so rare to find and a must try!!! My hubby loves eel and we were just so pleased to find such a gem . If we ever come back to SF, We'll be sure to come back for more and try their other dishes!
author: Nathalie M.

description:
I was extremely disappointed with this place, considering all the great reviews it got. Before even looking at the menu I noticed my plate was dirty. A new one was brought to me, and it too was dirty. 

I ordered the King Pao Chicken, and they added an extra ingredient that I had no idea what it was. It wasn't something that was listed on the menu. I couldn't tell what was chicken and what was the mystery ingredient. I had to pick around it and the taste was super weird. The amount of chicken in the dish was lacking, and it was super soft chicken. It kinda freaked me out how soft it was when I ate it. - almost like it was undercooked. Must have been fine because I haven't gotten sick yet. 

My friend ordered Orange Chicken and loved it. Also ordered egg rolls - but they were extremely greasy. Almost dripping grease and overlooked/soggy. 

Definitely would not come back or recommend this place. Gave 2 star because my friends dish was ok.
author: Andrea T.

description: Horrible food. Pork fried rice was not with BBQ pork but with boiled looking pork strips. Cashew chicken was the most "uncashew" we've ever eaten. Not sure why this place got so many good reviews.
author: Brandy W.

description: Amazing food... Tried 6 different things and each one of them was outstanding. Don't go to this place for it's ambience... If you're looking for some good Chinese food, look no further
author: Avinash S.

description: After seeing all of the good reviews on yelp, my coworker and I decided to give this place a shot. It's definitely a bit divey, but I guess that's what you should expect in Chinatown. The service is OK but the food is subpar. Dinner didn't sit well with either my coworker or me.. Not sure if what we ate was bad or what.. Won't be returning
author: Bianca H.

description: This place is legit. This is probably the best Chinese food I've had in a long time. The orange beef was so good. It was sweet and crispy. I highly recommended this dish. My sister had the waitress take back the chicken green bean, based on the fact that the pieces of meet looked like bacon bits (I think it was the chicken green bean dish or it might have been beef...it was definitely some type of meat). The waitress told us that that is how the plate comes. My sister told her that she wanted more meat. They brought back the plate with a lot more bacon bits on top. It was good nonetheless whatever type of meat was on it.
author: Tara S.

description: This is my favorite place in China town. Food are delicious and my favorite food is Mu shu, it is a pancake,vegetable and some sauce!! Taste so good
author: Sitong L.

description:
Pleasantly surprised by this place and more surprised that I have never heard of nor eaten here before. The photos of the dishes posted in the window helped draw us in. Figured if the food was as good as it looked in the photos, we'd be in for a treat. 

After we sat down we noticed that we were the only Asian customers in the place, which worried us (as far as food being good/authentic) but then some other Asian customers came in later. LOL. 

Stumbled upon this place after we learned the place we were headed to is now closed, & we were up for something new.

Ordered curry chicken and spicy green beans...more than 'not bad', both were quite good. They serve brown rice if you ask. Got a takeout order of cashew chicken for roomie & feedback was positive. 

Will be back to try other dishes!
author: D L.

description:
The beef and green bean dish was superb. Very flavorful. Nice tender beef. 

Wor won ton soup. Packed with seafood and wontons.  

Orange zest chicken.  Waiter recommendation.  

Good service.  Typical ran Chinese restaurant with a woman running the show and barking orders.  Great to watch.  Our waiter had a great dry sense of humor.
author: Dan C.

description: Came with a group and we ordered the Chicken Fried Rice,Orange Chicken,Fried Won Ton and EggRolls.We were the first customers,it started to get busy pretty quick upon opening.The food was so amazing and flavorful!!The next time we visit SF we are coming here and ordering a lot more food!We can't wait. A must try if you're in SF.
author: Jessica N.

description: It was our first time eating Chinese food out side of the typical American/Chinese restaurant. We were blown away by how different the food tasted! No thick gravy overwhelming the food, just great tasting quality food! We ordered the egg rolls (no thick doughy shell) They are more like a spring roll. My wife ordered Hunan Chicken and I ordered Mongolian Beef and the portions were more than enough for lunch but again the quality was top notch! I would highly recommend going to Hunan Home's !
author: Nick P.

description: Delicious chicken basil has fresh leaves of basil in it hot n sour soup one of the best wish we lived closer highly recommend
author: Nan M.

description:
To paraphrase the Fresh Prince of Bel Air, "Yo Hunan Homes, smell ya' later!"

This restaurant was packed ... even though there didn't seem to be one Chinese or Asian person eating there. We figured we'd trust the high Yelp rating and give Hunan Homes a try for an "exotic" lunch with my mom. 

Olivia (from Shanghai) gave it 1 star ... She might be right, but I've had worse Chinese food ... barely. 

 * Wonton Soup ($5.95) with Pork Wontons and Tender Greens in a Chicken Broth. This simple soup seemed like a safe way to start our lunch ... and it was. (3 stars) 

 * Xiao Long Bao ($6.25) with Chicken and Pork is a classic dish famous in Olivia's home town of Shanghai. These dumplings were shriveled sacks of disappointment. (2 stars)

 * Hot Spiced Bean Curd ($8.95) with Ground Pork in a "Spicy" Sauce Garlic Sauce to flavor the Tofu; however, it wasn't very spicy or flavorful at all. (2 stars)

 * Fried Fish Fillet with Spicy Salt ($12.50) promised deep-fried Fish with Salt & Pepper, but was more like Fried Salt with Fish Fillet Stuffing. Really disgusting. (1 star)

Speaking of disgusting, the dishes may have been forgettable except for the sodium, but the food did leave me with a fierce case of Hunan Homes Revenge ... and singin' like the Fresh Prince ...

   I rushed to the lavatory times 7 or 8
      And I yelped to the flabby, 'Yo Hunan Homes smell ya later."
   Looked at my symptoms, I got the runs there
      To visit my throne as the Prince of Diarrhea.
author: Michael S.

description: Wow - what a nice surprise!  The concierge at the Westin directed my friend and I to Hunan Home's for lunch yesterday and he definitely sent us to the right place.  The decor isn't much to look at, but the food sure is good!  We started with some steamed dumplings and pan fried potstickers...holy yummy!  I had the chicken with string beans for my entree and absolutely loved it - the chicken was melt in your mouth tender, the string beans were cooked to perfection and the spice level was just right.  Make sure to enjoy the pot of tea too...I think I drank 5-6 cups myself.  This is a must visit in Chinatown!
author: Jennifer S.

description: The rolls and the wontons are excellent and the sweet and sour pork great also. Good service and worth the price
author: Gina A.

description: We thought the food was a bit overrated. The soup dumplings here were definitely average - if not below average. The hit and sour soup and Mongolian beef were pretty good, but their prawns and walnut were our favorite dish (hard to mess this up though). Also a bit biased to the food in NYC Chinatown so take the review for what it's worth. Cheers!
author: Patrick C.

description:
Mediocre and almost broaching on ghetto Chinese food here. Get your usual Americanized Chinese dishes here like orange chicken and potstickers. Nothing special and if anything the prices are a bit high for the neighborhood but I guess they take credit card if you must. 

One notable item is the in house fried bread they have so if you must try it out, but if you really want a savory dessert just go up the street for some egg tarts and the GG bakery and wait for it. 

Cheers and pass on this Chinatown spot.
author: Joseph L.

description: Pretty good Chinese food, I have been here twice. I have ordered the honey walnut prawns, beef broccoli and the chicken chow mein. All these food items were delicious, I would say the beef broccoli could have had a little bit more flavor. All in all, it was fast service for a Wednesday night. Next time, I will try more items on the menu.
author: Clarisse R.

description: If this is the top Chinese restaurant in SF then I am very disappointed. The small Chinese fast food in my small town serves better food. The service was pushy and the food was meh.
author: Spock N.

description:
Hunan Home's is now my go-to dim sum place in Chinatown. Not the best I've ever had, but convenient and consistent enough.

I didn't even realize there was dim sum here until my roommate directed me to their appetizers section, and now I skip over the Americanized section of the menu. I really like the xiao long bao -- always served tasty, hot, and soupy! The fried dumplings are usually yummy, but always oily. The wonton soup is pretty great, exactly what I need for the colder days. I occasionally try some of the other dishes, and they're not as consistently satisfying.

Both floors are nearly always full when I stop by, and service can be quite slow and inattentive at times. I usually only come with 1-3 other people, but generally will experience a 15-minute wait or so, especially in tourist season.
author: Kimberly Y.

description: Still a little expensive for lunch pricing in CT. I did like their free hot and sour soup. That was pretty good. The chicken, pawns, and egg plant rice plate fell short. Chicken were almost diced in cubes... the pawns were frozen of course. The best part was the fresh egg plant. The spicy sauce was meh. Rice is low grade.
author: Ann L.

description: I strongly recommend the Paking duck it is AMAZING. Service is great I also like that you share tables with other people so you can meet locals and or tourist. Good for big parties. Had to wait a little bit, the line was out the door. Totally worth the wait.
author: Erin S.

description: Amazing Hunan Scallops, perfect spice and the scallops melted in your mouth! We also loved the hot and sour soup along with the bbq pork/shrimp fried rice.
author: Kristi G.

description: Food is reasonable. Service is absolutely terrible!! The staff has no idea how they should treat their customers.
author: Manish G.

description: Everything was great and fresh. Kung pao chicken is perfect balance of heat and flavor.
author: Christian B.

description: Classic Chinese food!! We were there 2 weeks ago when most of downtown San Fran was without power so boy were we glad to have walked deep enough into Chinatown to find this gem!  We live in a small resort town with no good Chinese food, so it's been 13+ years without Chinese food for us.  The food was ALL wonderful.  There were 6 of us and we each ordered a different dish and shared all the way around.  Fabulous!!
author: Shelley C.

description:
After an 8 hour drive to San Francisco from LA, I was looking for some good Asian food to start out my stay as a first timer. Came across this place on Yelp and decided to give it a shot. Loved in the interior designing, as it's something you don't see very much in NYC at Chinese restaurants. 

I ordered a pork and mushroom dish off the chef recommendations menu and felt very unsatisfied. It was uncomfortably spicy and the lack of pork made it seem like you were just eating peppers.

The tea and service was good though.. And I think there's wifi.
author: Dan T.

description: When in Chinatown this place is great. Way better then the bigger Resturant's in the area by a long shot. The Tea Smoked Duck is awesome.
author: Ryan I.

description: I've been coming here for years bringing my coworkers, friends and family.  I knew the owner - her used to come out and say hello. Rumor is that they're under new owner/management AND most likely new cook!  The menu prices have gone up, the usually dish that I order for lunch - Hunan Beef.  It was so tasteless and beef was so chewy, I had to spit them out! Then they give you the bill without the usual dessert of oranges and fortune cookie. We were so disappointed and will wipe this place off my favorite place... I can see why they had plenty of space during the height of lunch time rush hour at 12:30. It was always hard to get a table but we are regulars and they used to always get me a table fast!  This time - we sat right away with lots of empty tables around us! I was surprised to see that and something didn't look quite right.  You can tell that the regulars don't go there anymore.. Too bad - another restaurant bites the dust! Bring back the old owner and cook...PLEASE!
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
Great food and service. Our waiter had quite the sense of humor - which went over great with our group.

I split one of the meal for two options that consisted of egg rolls and fried prawn appetizers, sizzling rice soup, orange peel chicken and a beef dish that I can't remember the name of. It was all delicious!  My favorites being the soup and the orange peel chicken!! One guy with us had this soup with these amazing little dumplings in it, and those too were just awesome!  

My only complaint is that they only allow 2 credit cards per table - which normally isn't a problem except we were in town on business and all needed to use our separate cards.  We made it work, but it wasn't the most convenient.

If I ever find myself in the area again I will definitely be coming here for another great meal!
author: Andi P.

description: Very savory food! I would definitely come here again. Fried rice is delicious! Chicken entrees were a bit greasy but tasted yummy.
author: G G.

description: Service was horrible. The server didn't look to happy serving us. She brought out extra bowls and pretty much threw it on the table. We also ordered extra dishes and she seem annoyed and gave us an attitude. This will be my first and last time here. Food was alright, nothing amazing.
author: Diana P.

description: New management , mediocre fare , weak tea ,very dirty toilets, staff was good. Definitely  not the same place.
author: Cranky P.

description:
Extremely Average food, below average customer service. 

I considered a 2 or 2.5 ranking, but the biggest problem is that the place doesn't live up to hype or its current ranking.

My family and I waited over 30 minutes to be seated, 15 minutes to be greeted after getting the table.

We ordered egg rolls  (deep fried cabbage and vegetables ) not great; sampler appetizer (ok); kung pao chicken (ok), beef and broccoli  ( below average); combination chow mein  (not great).

Overall average.   Very disappointing,  better food closer to home and much better service.
author: Dante G.

description: The best place in Sf Chinatown for Chinese food, owners & waitress was very nice,I love a spice & sour soup that so......... good, and a sweet and sour chicken is so good too, and they are very reasonable prices
author: Fanny L.

description: The service was great! The guy working at the front desk is super nice and so conversational. The food is also really good. I'm not a big fan of Chinese but I like going to this place.
author: Erina S.

description:
I came here after the yelp event. I was a bit tipsy and needed some more foooood!

Tried the jellyfish, salt and pepper calamari, house chow mein, a chicken dish, and others tried the bbq pork. 

The jellyfish had good flavor and I loved the calamari. The other dishes were just average. 

Service was mediocre. We had to practically flag down the wait staff to get their attention even though we were in the middle of the room. When we wanted to order more they told us the kitchen was closed. Don't you usually say last call to your customers before shutting it down? Service just rubbed me the wrong way so it left a bad taste in my mouth.

Pass.
author: Noelle H.

description: Went there for lunch on sunday. The dishes taste good just smaller portion compare what I used to get in Los angeles. A bowl of Brown rice costs 2 but overall is great for sf standard.
author: Scott L.

description: Most Chinese food out in San Fran is pricey but this place is affordable because of the family combos. If your traveling in a group order that dinner C for four and it pretty much has their best plates in one combo. Staff was friendly
author: Robert G.

description: This is my favorite Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. I love their deep fired chicken.  it was very tasty and juicy. Also, the spring roll was so delious. I will bring my family over next time. :)
author: Pak C.

description:
Not very ideal, food amount is far from average food size in South Bay.
Thanks to its prime location in Chinatown, lots of tourists stop and eat here.
author: Steve S.

description: Delicious. Hot and sour soup, pot stickers, sautéed string beans and Hunan chicken!!  Service was good. There was a line out the door which is always a good sign.  Only had to wait 30 minutes.
author: Kyle M.

description: We got the lunch special. The lady at the door was really rude and they never gave us the fruit at the end of our meal. Plus, our waiter wasn't the nicest person in the world either. However, the food was homemade and tasted great. I even saw the ladies that were hand making the dim sums downstairs. They just need to improve their service and the manners of the staff.
author: Claudia G.

description: Delicious food and great prices!!! The lunch specials are a great deal. We tried the green bean beef and orange peel chicken, they came with rice and hot & sour soup. I'd highly recommend this place for good food at a great price.
author: Ryan C.

description: I had family from out of town from Houston. They requested Chinese food for lunch. Hunan Home's Restaurant had good reviews so decided to come here and try it out. We had a party of 9 and we were able to get seated right away. Our server Gigi was very attentive. We had broccoli beef, steamed rice, combination appetizer, honey walnut prawns, Hunan pork, Chinese broccoli, war wonton soup and pan fried noodles. Food was excellent and we were all satisfied. We will most likely come here again!
author: Dee S.

description:
Stylized Chinese. Staff dressed in crisp white shirts, black slacks and vests with red bow ties. All male staff wore a sour face, while the hostess greeted us with a contagious smile the staff seemed immune. 

Food? Delicious. We ordered cashew chicken and combination (shrimp, chicken,  beef) chow mein to share.
We were served, complimentary,  a small bowl of delightful sweet and sour soup, Jasmine tea, and fortune cookies with sweet orange slices for dessert.

I began my meal with chopsticks but soon switched to a fork since my husband was enjoying his fair portion of our agreed upon share with a voracious rapidity.  As usual, he negotated an extra large portion of the must try cashew chicken. It was good enough that there were zero leftovers.

Across the street is P.R. Chinese. President Obama ate here. We originally decided to skip Hunan and eat where the President dined.  What.  A. Dive.  Sorry, Mr.President.
They stuck is in the crowded, sketchy, cafeteria downstairs,  handed us a picture menu and carbon copy paper we were to fill out our choices and give a copy to waiter...we guess. We snuck out and crossed the street, thank goodness,  to Hunan.
author: Kyle T.

description:
Went here based on the reviews and wasn't too impressed. We got seated quite fast since we came after lunch hour. I've eaten much better Chinese food in other places, wished I tried the place around the corner or the ones with the line in front. 
Overall good food, but I've eaten better for less money.
author: Rita S.

description:
Most Chinese places lost their Authentic touch these days and I find Hunan still lives up to it. Food was delicious and their Veal dish is top-notch. Just perfectly cooked.

A good place for dinner in Chinatown
author: Sharan N.

description:
Tip #1  Make a reservation--the line at 7:30pm was out the door.

Tip #2  Park at the Portsmouth Square Gararge.  Hunan Homes will validate 2 hours of parking if you spend at least $45.00

The Xiao Long Bao were very moist and served with a dipping sauce.  I've read a lot about this dish on YELP and noticed that it was hit or miss for a lot of people.  We really liked everything about them tonight--taste AND texture.

The barbecued pork was honey glazed and virtually fat-free.  The thin slices were substantial and very juicy.  The owner asked if we wanted to try their hot mustard and we gladly accepted.  He stopped by frequently and joked around with us insisting that we ordered hot dogs and wondering if they came out yet.  

The pork fried rice was moist too--very flavorful and not skimpy on the meat.

I had the sliced chicken with snow peas served with a white sauce.  The meat was of very good quality--all white meat--and sliced thinly.  The white sauce was excellent.

The sizzling platter of beef, scallops, green pepper, and onion in a black bean sauce was excellent.  It had a kick to it too--quite a blast of heat.

Service was excellent.  Some people may interpret it as brusque, but the owner definitely made up for it.  He visited every table with a smile.
author: Thomas D.

description:
Hot and sour soup
Wantons in hot sauce 
Potstickers 
Mushu pork
Orange beef
All amazing!

Other things less good but looking forward to trying a few new things each time as I am sure there are many gems on the somewhat over large menu.
We came on a Monday this time so didn't have much seafood...
For heavens sake book a table, can't believe all the whining about the wait, yes it's busy so what, it's good and tiny what do you expect?
author: Bertil N.

description: Been here twice and not disappointed. First time we [my husband and I] came for dinner and shared a prawn chow fun and a soup. Next time we came for lunch with another friend and tried the prawns & string beans in garlic sauce which was really good, orange chicken which was the best thing we have tried so far, egg fried rice which was good and cashew chicken which was very nice as well. Thumbs up! Service was quick and efficient and lady also tried to crack some jokes while she was running back and forth as it was really busy day. Enjoyed and will be back again to try other items on the menu.
author: Heliana M.

description: Very quick service; food was out less than a couple of minutes after ordering. Staff knew how to speak good English and the bathrooms were impeccably clean (as were the tables and utensils). Most of all, the food was great and plentiful.
author: Jeric F.

description: Friends and I were visiting Chinatown for the first time in years. Came across this gem recommended by a fellow Yelper/friend. We really enjoyed our time here. Affordable food with quick service. All three of us ordered and shared the "Sizzling Rice Soup", Wontons, "Combination Fried Rice and the spicy "Kung Pao Deluxe". Their dishes are good for two people even though we had three, we were still satisfied. It seemed like a popular place for a Monday evening. They were still able to get us in pretty quickly. Good choice if you're new to Chinatown :-)
author: Bria S.

description: It was really nice! I had an appetizer of xiao long bao and the chicken with orange peel. The service was great, it was clean and delicious! Thank you!
author: Jefferson S.

description: Very good Chinese food! The Mongolian beef was excellent. You have to ask for steamed rice. I found this odd considering how many entrees we ordered that the rice didn't automatically come with it. The only bad thing about this place is that it is quite small and we had to wait over an hour to be seated. You really can't wait inside because the place is a bit cramped as it is, but the good thing is there are many shops nearby to visit while you wait.
author: Raquel R.

description:
When in Chinatown, eat Chinese food! My little brother is within walking distance of Chinatown so after a very long drive from Southern California, we decided to have some food here. The restaurant wasn't too crowded which made for some quick and efficient service. They refilled our teapot without any questions and made sure our plates were cleared right away. I do believe that they are on the pricier side, but I am under the general idea that everything in the city is a bit overpriced. 

Between the five of us, we ordered a variety of different dishes and steamed rice. We started with the hot and sour soup. I thought that this was way too salty and I actually poured some of my water into it. It did have a nice tang to it though. Honey walnut shrimp was super tasty. I liked how the shrimp they used were large and the walnuts made for a nice texture. We also ordered their Orange Peel Chicken which was just okay. I think I actually prefer the orange chicken from Panda Express. Mongolian Beef was another dish that could have been great but was ruined by too much salt. For our vegetables, we ordered the Hunan String Beans which was so addicting but once again, so overwhelmingly salty. I mean it felt like the restaurant was trying to kill us with a sodium overdose or something. 

Overall, the food was fine but I think I was expecting more for the price. Or maybe I'm just spoiled by Chinese food from San Gabriel Valley. One thing for sure, I think that the chef of this restaurant needs to lighten up on the salt because it is preventing some of his dishes from shining. Not the best but it works for a quick and hot meal but I will probably keep walking to another restaurant next time. 3/5
author: Michelle L.

description: Came here for lunch because of all the positive reviews but left feeling unsatisfied. The soup dumplings had no soup in them, defeats the purpose there. Our lunch entrees didn't come out for 45 minutes. We sat when the restaurant was still empty and placed our order before the lunch rush. Somehow, everyone after us got their food, finished eating, and even paid before we got ours. Pretty sure they forgot our order. When reminded, we were told "it's coming." I'm sure it's coming... I'm asking when. The portions were big but the quality was subpar. Tofu (bean curd) in mapo tofu tasted old and hard and the beef in Kung Pao Beef tasted chewy.
author: Thao T.

description:
I am pleased to say the concierge at the Hilton said to skip the Garden Cafe and done here instead. Her recommendation was not misplaced at all. Lols like a popular favorite place with many coming and going. 

I had the Spicy Squid and it was perfectly cooked with a light battered hand and yummy medley of orange, red and green jalapeño peppers. The tea pot was excellent as well and complimented the palate very well.

Take a chance and you won't be disappointed.
author: Travis K.

description:
