I am a local but was playing tourist one weekend and decided to check out Hunan Home's Restaurant in China Town because of its relatively high reviews.

Hunan Home has AVERAGE Chinese food. The interior of the restaurant needs some work, and the fish tank at the front of the restaurant needs to be cleaned badly. It seemed outdated (in a bad way, not a hip way) as well as dirty. Only positives were that this place has many menu options to choose from and is in the middle of interesting China Town.

I will forever feel content ordering Take-Out Chinese food from somewhere else, because it will taste the same if not better!
author: Kendall F.

description: Do not try this place if you're allergic to great Chinese food. Pot Stickers are the real deal. Wonton soup is perfectly seasoned and the orange peel chicken is straight out of Momma's kitchen.
author: Brad P.

description:
Sometimes you gotta call a spade a spade and this establishment surely fits the bill for run of the mill Chinese fare. 

From the pictures I knew I was not walking into a fine dining restaurant but the I expected a higher level of quality than my local Colorado takeout joint. I have never been to China, only eaten a ton of said takeout, so perhaps my vision of a multitude of flavors is not really a part of the cuisine. Waitress delivered all items requested but there were no free smiles. 

Also, hate to say it, but when 100% of the clientele is Caucasian, this isn't exactly local fare. That being said, I WOULDN'T make this a MUST visit.
author: Lauren B.

description: This is the meal I was hoping for when we came to Chinatown.  Amazing food.  Cute little restaurant.  Good service.  Just perfect.
author: Maxine K.

description: Ok so we been to sf and china town for about 20 times.  We saw this restaurant on yelp with 4.5 stars and close to 2000 reviews so we thought give it a try they all cannot be wrong.  We walked in and our first thought was oh no.  Asian restaurant in china town but only 10% Asian which is not a good sign.  Food came out and was  it great as everyone say it was.  Believe us we are Asian so we know Asian food.  Food was a notch below ok.  We asked what is the best soup and were told hot and sour soup.  Seriously ? That is more American Chinese.  So sorry y'all believe an Asian that this is not that good and there are much better ones in china town sf.
author: Michael M.

description:
My husband & I LOVE this place. Any time we are in the city around lunch or dinner, we find ourselves craving it. 

The orange chicken is an absolute must. They're an incredible combination of crunchy & tender. And the orange sauce isn't too orangey or too sweet. 

Also really love their broccoli with oyster sauce.

If you go at dinner time, there might be a wait, but it will be well worth it!
author: Michelle H.

description: Food was fantastic. Place was busy but we put our name in and within 15 minutes we were in. We actually shared a table with another party of 4 and it turned out to be an incredible time. Staff was exceptionally friendly and helpful with the menu. Service is super quick and food came out really fast. Portions are big, but totally handleable. Food was amazing.
author: Nathan B.

description:
I have been coming to Hunan Homes for 15 years and have hosted many dinners and many of my life-changing events (wedding rehearsal dinner, birthdays, graduations) here.  It is with great sadness that I found out that James (the owner) recently sold the business.

I really hope the new owners will be able to hold on to the traditions, excellent food and great service that made Hunan Homes so special in SF.  James, his family and his staff will be missed both at Hunan Homes and my family's life.
author: Alex O.

description:
Really enjoyed the food here!  Would give it 5...but there is ALWAYS room for improvement..!

Not "Heavy" like some Chinese food, just right!  Portions are good sized, not "too much".
author: Korgie W.

description:
I dig the extensive lunch menu here. Decent-sized portions of a large variety of stir-fry dishes served with rice and hot & sour soup for around $7-9. Pretty much everything I've had has been good, with the sliced fish with vegetables being my current favorite dish.

Also good is the fact that it's almost always possible to get a table, even during the busy lunch hour. (Not because this place isn't popular; rather, simply because it's huge.)
author: Zain K.

description:
I visited the Hunan Home because it was featured on a local SF foodie blog.

1) the food came out a little fast 
2) my dishes that I ordered were prepared okay and was nothing spectacular 
3) service was good, my waiter was fast but he didn't anticipate any of my little extras

All and all, I could've ate better Chinese cooking around the corner.
author: Charlie B.

description: This place is busyyy!!  Came here on a Sunday night and it's a good thing that we came before 6pm and only had to wait 40 minutes.  When we left at around 8:30pm, I counted more than 40+ people waiting at the entrance.  The food is good - they serve spicy Hunan cuisine with lots of flavor and spice.  The owner recommended the spicy Hunan pork which I thought was quite good.  The best thing about this place is actually their service, which I know shouldn't be the case for a Chinese restaurant (esp. in Chinatown SF), but the service is outstanding and the people working here are all happy and attentive.  A great experience for me overall at Hunan Home's.
author: Ken S.

description: Nice Chinese place! We chose it cause it has one of the highest yelp ratings in Chinatown. My friends and I ordered the fried wontons, chicken chow mein, shrimp fried rice, orange chicken, and honey walnut pawns. The serving sizes are just a tad smaller than what you might expect our be used to, but it was perfect for us. We were thinking we'd have some left over, but we ate everything and were perfectly satiated afterwards. Was it better than any other Chinese pave I've been to? No, not particularly. But service was good and fast. My friends, both who are from out of state, really enjoyed it. They tried some dishes here they've never tried before, and they liked it all.
author: Angela H.

description: This place is gross...literally dirty. The food doesn't make up for it. The 1/2 Peking duck was more like a quarter and was awful. There is far better in SF's Chinatown!
author: John B.

description:
It's not a good sign when you're in Chinatown and see almost no Asian people except for the waitstaff.  The food tastes like something you'd get at Panda Express.  We ordered snow pea shoots which was good, but the beef with green onions and chicken with cashews and water chestnuts was coated with sauces so thick you couldn't taste the meat or veggies.  After we placed our order, except to ask for our check, the waiter never came back.  It seems like everyone delivers food.  

I was attending a show next door at the Landmark Theater and was checking reviews for something in the area.  Normally I find reviews to be pretty accurate, but felt let down in choosing this place based upon the reviews.
author: Scott S.

description:
We just got into town and after a tour of China Town went here to eat. OMG! This was the best Chinese food I have ever had. Period. I thought my favorite place in New Orleans was good but after eating here I wanted to go back and burn it down. (Joking.). 
We had the pot stickers, fried succulent bread, lemon chicken and cashew chicken (yes, it was a bit too much). The quality was top notch, as was the preparation. 
I can unreservedly recommend the food and will come back whenever I get within striking distance of San Francisco.
author: Michael P.

description: So to make up for my dad's experience at Mission Chinese food, he wanted to eat "real" Chinese dishes, so off to Chinatown we went.  There were a lot of people eating at the restaurant, so that was a good sign.  We ordered fried rice, beef, sweet and sour pork, chow mein and potstickers.  The food was good, not too greasy and most importantly, my dad approved, however it took a long time to get the potstickers.  I think they gave it to another table who sat down after us. The LO was waiting for the potstickers, so poor thing was grumpy with hunger.  We didn't get them until we were done with our meal. They didn't charge us, which is good, but we waited longer than we should.  So I have to give them 2 stars.
author: Rochelle R.

description:
We stopped here on a Sunday evening about an hour before closing, looking for our Chinatown Chinese food experience.

The meal started off with complimentary hot tea, we ordered (to share): orange peel chicken, sweet and sour pork, steamed rice, and vegetable lo mein. We loved all of these dishes - and have no complaints! The meal was finished off with what seemed to be fresher than most fortune cookies. 

Would recommend!
author: Dana E.

description: This is my first time coming here. We ordered a lot of food but what is good was the lobster and the hot and sour soup
author: Melinda W.

description: The food was ok. With the reviews I read, I had hoped for something different than I would get at an Americanized Chinese restaurant. Not so much. It wasn't bad, but not what I had hoped given it's location in the middle of Chinatown.
author: Deedra E.

description:
The quick scoop is that this place is tasty and caters to the American palette for Chinese food: sweet, sour, and spicy (but-actually-not-spicy-at-all). The food is delicious (but the portions are SMALL) and I had a good time with the quick and friendly service.

I don't agree that this restaurant is cheap on a standalone basis; compared to non-Asian restaurants, fine, Hunan Home is cheap; but when you consider portions and ingredients, it's not really that much of a value-play. I'm going to call Hunan Home out and say that its Orange Peel "Chicken" is not really chicken and should be called orange peel BREADING instead. It's delicious, but it certainly shouldn't be called chicken when the breading is over 60% of a piece.

That said, if you have a large group and are eating on a budget, come right along. As far as eating authentic Chinese food goes, you will have better luck elsewhere because Hunan Home isn't it.

P.S. If you think their xiao long bao is good, you obviously haven't had authentic ones. Their XLB is dry, its fillings are measly, and the skin is too thick. It's an abomination really.
author: Lee T.

description: Delicious orange chicken, good egg drop soup and amazing dumplings! The waiter was a lot of fun, and gave good customer service. I would recommend coming here when in Chinatown.
author: Ellie B.

description: Really loved the veggie egg rolls!! The plum wine was amazing! I got the veggie fried rice and it was good. The service was pretty decent and my boyfriend and I had a nice night here.
author: Elizabeth L.

description: Great food and quick service! Stopped here for lunch when I was touring China town. I was pleasantly surprised by how good the food was and was in and out quickly.
author: Michael D.

description:
Caters to more American palate than authentic Chinese. The food is above average, but a little bland for my taste and not good enough to justify the lines. It is often very busy.

Their Won Ton soup was average.
Hons Won Ton House is way better.

Their Xia Long Bao's are bland. 
Bund Shanghai up the street has much better XLB's.
author: David T.

description: Good service. Great food. The sweet and sour pork was amazing. We also had the cashew chicken, pot stickers, egg rolls, spicy garlic chicken and wonton soup. All were delicious! We will definitely be back.
author: Amanda P.

description:
This Chinese food really hit the spot.
Like, really hit it. 
Like with fists.
The spot didn't see it coming.
It was a surprise attack; 
the spot got cold clocked.
Knocked right out.
You might say it got hit by the anthropomorphized concept of Chinese food.
One of the main characteristics attributed to Chinese food was big, strong fists.
The better to really wallop the spot.

In other words, it really hit the spot.
author: James I.

description:
Will not go again.

Been here on 3 occasions and every time I'm hoping for more. Soup dumplings are average at best; too doughy in texture. 

Signature orange peel chicken: nice viscous sauce but lacks any real amount of chicken when you pull back the deep fried exoskeleton. 

Hunan beef is goopy, a decent amount of veggies but loaded with msg unsure if I will be able to finish this review...
author: Soroosh P.

description: We came to this restaurant with all of our out of town family for the holidays.  Little did we know coming here would lead to a trip to the emergency room at Kaiser SF.  Hunan Home's serve their Xiao Long Bao with peanut butter?!  Why?!  We've had XLB in other restaurants in the Bay Area, Taiwan, Hangzhou and Shanghai..NO BODY puts peanut butter in XLB!!!  Never,ever are we waking in to this restaurant again.
author: Nancy D.

description: I am not sure this considers as a traditional Chinese food.   With the relatively small size of the dish and the price they charge, this one goes to the bottom of my list.   Food generally lacks flavor.  It is not worth of the price.
author: J D.

description: Delicious food and the prices were amazing for San Fran ($10-$12) a plate.  I work in the city often and am amazed I haven't been here before, I will be back!
author: Justin B.

description: Came here on vacation, food was great and service was great:) we didn't have to wait very long and food came out pretty quick. Everything we got was good, my favorites were the egg drop soup, green beans and kung pao shrimp. The fried rice was just mediocre, but I would definitely still come again!
author: Meryll H.

description:
UGH!! This WAS our family favorite restaurant in China Town until last night. 30 minute wait on a Saturday night, that's no problem. A 15 minute wait JUST FOR menus after being seated, 30 minutes between each appetizer (3 of them), and another 30 minutes between each entrée (3 of them) is completely unacceptable and was deliberate. Did I mention we were never checked on? Or that we had to flag someone down repeatedly for water, and tea? Never once offered anything else to drink. We were sitting RIGHT in the middle of the restaurant and every time a waiter or waitress zoomed by, they refused to make eye contact. Our party of 6 was extremely patient and honestly we should have walked out. We watched every single party seated after us receive their food and leave before we got all of our food. The food that was brought out was warm, leading me to believe it had just been sitting downstairs in the kitchen. Why? 

Extremely disappointed, and they have lost our business.
author: Liana H.

description: Shot in here for some dim sum and how delicious it was! I just had egg rolls and potstickers but they were pretty good. Tea in a lil silver pot is served when you sit and there are small white cups and plates waiting at your table when you sit. Super busy street but I'd come again if I'm ever in the area!
author: Tamara F.

description: Made reservations for 7 with my wife on a Thursday. Pre-ordered the Peking Duck because I am a Peking Duck addict and what better place than Chinatown! Started with the Spicy wontons and the Xiao bin Dao- amazing. Had a Taiwan beer and a couple Tsing Tao to wash it down. The Peking duck came and was fantastic- crispy and meaty with scallions and plum sauce. Finished with their spicy prawns with green beans- my wife loved it. Service was quick and friendly. All this came to just under $100- I was stunned. Authentic Chinese? I'm a white guy so what do I know but I think it's a good sign that over half the patrons were Asian. Check this place out.
author: Robert L.

description: I'm very surprised why this bland, tasteless, boring Chinese food is appreciated. Everything tastes the same. Waiters are rude (but this happens in other Chinese restaurants as well sometimes).
author: Jeroen D.

description: Very tasty place that we visited in Chinatown on our visit to San Fran. It was super yummy. We had Egg Rolls, Vegetable Fried Rice, Kung Pao Prawns and Chicken with Spicy Garlic Sauce. It isn't a fancy restaurant but the food was delicious and the service was good.
author: Lianne S.

description: Came here around 11ish for lunch on a Saturday. We sat immediately as we entered, which was a big plus. Food was very tasty in my opinion. Overall good experience minus the issue with having to get up and search for our waiter to ask for our bill. Other than that, things were good.
author: Julio V.

description: Came here for Chinese New Year and was quite disappointed. The service was really bad and the food wasn't as good as I remembered it. There are so many restaurants in Chinatown I will not return.
author: Jane H.

description: On the plus side, very affordable and friendly. The food though is just a bit better than ordinary. The soup dumplings were a big miss. Half we're torn so they were soupless. Pretty sure they were frozen. They used chicken stock rather than pork which means they don't have that luscious flavor and texture. They also include peanut butter. Why?
author: I. V.

description:
Yelp rarely lets me down so hard.

I wandered all around Chinatown and after a few hours I decided to eat. I passed places full of Asian customers, places with interesting menus (some I couldn't read because they weren't in English), bizarre meats hanging in windows, etc. I was so pumped for good, authentic Chinese.

I checked yelp and this place has great reviews, so I headed over.

The fact that literally every customer in here was white should have been a warning sign. The menu, which is standard Chinese takeout food, should have been a warning sign. The waiter's dismissive and barely courteous demeanor should have been a warning sign.

But I trusted in yelp! So I ordered a seafood deluxe sizzling plate.

How disappointing. It was so very basic. Unexciting. The kind of food you'd get at any takeout place anywhere.

I blew my chance to eat authentic Chinese in San Francisco. Bummer. I now have massive regret and a belly full of standard Americanized Chinese food.
author: Ashley J.

description: We are visiting from NYC and I have to say that food was great. We had the pot stickers which were pan fried to perfection. We decided to split the orange peel chicken and the chicken chow mein. The orange chicken was barely spicy it was nice and crispy. It was a delicious meal overall. The one reason why I would not give them 5 stars it's because of the service.  They do the bare minimum and rushed us out without us even finishing our food, they brought the check. I mean c'mon at least let me finish my plate. Besides that we didn't have any other issues.
author: Carol G.

description:
The food is disappointing. I had the chicken with orange peel and seafood deluxe sizzler plate. The chicken with orange peel was mediocre. It was very sweet with hardly any spice to it. The orange chicken in Panda Express tastes better! The seafood sizzle was average; the spice was non existent. 
Tl;dr: tastes worse than Panda Express but costs twice as much.
author: Sandeep S.

description: The food is delicious and James (the owner is the best!). I feel like family here and love them!
author: Stephanie Y.

description: Roaches!!!! Fucking roaches everywhere, I didn't even sit as a rod h was on my chair and the guy just slapped it off the seat. I walked in and walked right out
author: Luis M.

description: Saw the reviews and thought to go there - in SF from Miami and wanted a nice meal. Bad idea. Slooooow service would be an improvement from what we received. We ordered the wontons which were fairly good. We ordered saki which was a refilled wine bottle recapped incorrectly!! We had to flag down servers five times to place our orders and get water......the main course of Kung pao shrimp was average at best.  The Mongolian beef was soggy and uninspired. As I write this I'm still awaiting our check after 30 minutes..... STOP THE MADNESS!! Avoid this restaurant.
author: Teri A.

description: I'm from out of town and I rarely eat authentic Chinese, but let me tell you, it doesn't take a Chinese food expert to tell you this is some of the best Chinese in the city! The Snow Pea Leave were my favorite thing we ordered, but the Hot and Sour soup was DEFINITELY the best I've ever had. I really don't think you could go wrong getting anything on this menu. Great food, fast service, and low prices. If you're in San Francisco and want good Chinese, this is for sure your place!
author: Morgan B.

description: Good food, typical Chinatown atmosphere, clean visible kitchen and so-so service.  Fine for a casual dinner, but not a place I would seek out.  The eggplant and garlic was tasty, the seafood hotplate was a bit bland, and the hot and sour soup was fine .
author: Howard G.

description: Found this on Yelp and it lived up to our expectation of good food in Chinatown! Had the string bean chicken and my husband had the Mongolian beef, it was a little spicy for me but the right temp for him. Also, the tea was excellent. Highly recommend this restaurant as part of your Chinatown experience.
author: FT B.

description: My boyfriend and I dined in and shared potstickers for our appetizer. My boyfriend enjoyed them. He got the beef with Chinese broccoli dish and I got the Hunan chicken. We tried a little of each other's dish and enjoyed both even though we've had better. I like that they serve rice in a communal bowl - provides a family-like atmosphere.
author: Chenda H.

description: Writing a review to balance out this overly optimistic yelp place... I sense something fishy.  There are tons of good restaurants in San Francisco, wasting your money on Chinese food that's as good as what you can get in any suburb in America isn't a good move.  By all means, check out Chinatown.  But don't waste your money eating here.  Rude service, and you can tell that they're just loving the fact that everyone pays 100% more than they did a few short years ago.  Nothing special, I had Orange Chicken.
author: Buddy G.

description: Been here a bunch of times and love it! These traditional Chinese restaurants where by you really don't know what time of day or night it is after they seat you are always the best.The garlic sauce dishes and oyster sauce based vegetable dishes are best.The beef here is also good but for me the urban oriental environment that is what really does it.I love the San Francisco Chinatown and this is a staple of the neighborhood! The cheap soups are good as are various sizzling plates they offer of stir fried favorites.
author: Brian D.

description: Nice food,  a little bit greasy but very good taste.  The restaurant is small but comfortable.  A little bit of cleaning at the place could make a difference.
author: Allan Ernesto R.

description: Exactly what I hoped for in a China Town restaurant.   Pot stickers were fried and a little larger than standard fare.  Mo sho Beef came with wraps and a delicious dark sauce that was almost like a mole sauce.  My wife's sweet and sour chicken came in a lighter sauce that was so much better than our Dallas TX fare.  Decor is traditional, a little dark and wonderfully out of date.  Place was busy with a nice mix of locals.
author: Chris K.

description:
Visited San Fran Chinatown, because comeon, any big city, you have to check out their respective Chinatown! Coming from the east coast, and having pretty good xiao long baos, I had some high expectations coming in here to see how good their xiao long baos were.

I came in hungry, with a huge cravings for xiao long bao. I left still craving them...
My experience here wasn't too great. The xiao long bao did come a bit presentable, but the dumpling itself... was... dry.....Expected some sort of delicious broth in there, but no. There was very little, and it came out luke warm. Was highly disappointed that there was very little broth in each dumpling, to the point where you can't even call them soup dumplings.

Also had an order of orange peel chicken. But had no chicken... it was mostly fried breading, and i really tried hard to find some chicken in these, but i honestly could not. The sauce is decent and has the right amount on them. But please dont call it orange chicken if there is no chicken in there....

Not too good of an experience, and would not recommend going here for xiao long bao.
author: Jun W.

description: The look of the place and the neighborhood was not nice so I was a little skeptical if the restaurant would be what I was looking for. But I was wrong. Food was great and so was the service and no wonder why this place was crowded and we had to wait 45 minutes to be seated.
author: Dr. Kay S.

description: We ordered the Xiao Lin Bao appetizer and our waiter James showed us how to mix the jalapeños in the sauce to make it spicier.  We also ordered the Short Ribs with spicy salt and the deluxe Kung Pao bc it included beef, chicken, and seafood. The price wasn't bad for the Xiao Lin Bao, 2 entrees, pork fried rice and 2 Sapporos $50. Easily can recommend this place and I will definitely be back.
author: Art W.

description: Loved it. Vegetable mu shu and sizzling shrimp and egg rolls. All deeply flavorful and freshly prepared. Brisk, professional service. Awesome.
author: kevin m.

description: everything was not tasty. chop sticks were plactic. we tryed sweet and sour and gung bao chicken. only sapporo beer were ok..highly not recommending to eat here. waste of money and time
author: Air F.

description: we had:  beer, tea, kung pao, sweet chicken, white and brown rice. bear was not bad, but chicken was disgusting.
author: Roman P.

description: We were so excited to try this place out but as soon as we walked in we saw the sign... food score of 78!!! That is NOT good! According to the department of public health it means "needs improvement; multiple violations observed; typically several high risk violations" and high risk violations mean "High Risk: Violations that directly relate to the transmission of food borne illnesses, the adulteration of food products and the contamination of food-contact"
author: Maryann Y.

description: Excellent food and good sized portions.  What very busy because of Chinese New Year but service was quick just a little unfriendly from what I am use to normally
author: Henry F.

description:
This place is meh... 

Right when you walk in and get seated, you feel like you're being rushed to go in and out. Like, I go to Chinatown LA and unless you are a regular, they're usually rude but their food is fire so it cancels it out. So I understand since we we're not regulars here that the service might be kinda off, which it was, but the food was just alright. 

I've been to other Hunan restaurants in LA and one in Rowland Heights. Don't know if its a chain or maybe just different or even if its a socal or norcal thing. It was definitely not the race issue because I got slants too. But definitely if I were to base it off solely on customer service socal Hunan would win, and for food portion and taste socal would win again. 

I usually order the Salt & Pepper Calamari, Salt & Pepper Pork Chops, House Special Shrimp, Fried Fish w/ the brown sauce and HK pan-fried noodles with beef and etc... I would say you can clearly see a difference in the portion size and the taste factor is a couple notches under from what I'm used to. I guess I am a little spoiled in that sense. 

Oh well i guess give it a try, maybe I caught them on an off day. 

P.S. parking sucks, but i bet you already knew that if you're in Chinatown SF.
author: Matt T.

description:
This has sort of become my go-to SF Chinatown restaurant. I started coming to Hunan Home's a few years ago when I was in town for work and I have just kept coming back. Chinatown can be overwhelming, and in situations like this I like to find something that works and stick with it. They've always had tables available, but they're also always fairly busy with a wide diversity of customers. You hear a lot of English being spoken at tables, but a lot of Mandarin as well. 

The menu seems to lean a little bit (not entirely) toward "Americanized" Chinese (which is fine with me, because I reject the notion that "authentic is always better." Americanized Chinese food is dang tasty. Who cares if it's not what you get when you go to Beijing?). At the same time, their specials do include a number of more authentic offerings like you would find elsewhere in Chinatown. 

My favorite set of dishes at Hunan Home's are the sizzling platters. I've had three of them (chicken, beef, and shrimp) and all were excellent. Highly recommended overall.
author: Benjamin G.

description:
First timer. Had the cashew chicken and orange peel and chicken chow mein. All delicious. This place was excellent. I went on a Monday and there was a 10-15 minute wait at 7p. 

I gave this place 4 of 5 because they lack in service, I would have given 3 but I think the owner or manager greeted us and spoke to us during our meal which enhanced the service experience. Servers and hostess were very dry.

I haven't been to another Chinese restaurant in SF but the food here was delish.
author: Salto T.

description: Great food but parking is hard to find but that's besides the point the food is awesome I had fried rice and peel garlic spicy chicken. The service was excellent and fast and got seated quick. I would definitely be coming back here when I come back. If your in the mood for Chinese food and want fast service come here! They have excellent Chinese food!
author: Jesse V.

description:
IT'S JUST A HYPE. What a disappointment... Earlier this week me and my family went to Hunan Homes because of all the hype it has been getting on Yelp. 4 stars and over 1000 reviews? Sounds promising. When we first attempted to come to Hunan Home's (without a reservation) it clearly didn't work. The wait was 40 minutes to 1 hour. A few days later we called and made a reservation. I was so excited to finally try this place!

Walking in, the atmosphere is friendly and kind. The restaurant is pretty loud due to all the customers it gets. The decor is kind of old school but I like it. So far so good... Until we get the food. Everything on the menu seems so good and we ordered our food. We ordered: Sizzling rice soup, Orange chicken, Bread (steamed), sizzling seafood, and the chicken and snow peas. 

SIZZLING RICE SOUP: Absoutley disgusting. It tasted like old leftovers dumped into a metallic broth mixed with loads of oil

ORANGE CHICKEN: This was ok, but not the best I've had. I didn't like how fried it was. I feel like without the batter it would be horrible

CHINESE BREAD (STEAMED): This was ok too, the bread smelt very strongly of yeast. It was soft and fluffy and came with condensed milk to dip it in (??lol??)

SIZZLING SEAFOOD: Probably the best thing we got. It was mediocre and nothing special at all. Chinese takeout level! 

CHICKEN & SNOW PEAS: Looked like actual vomit, would not even order this one. 

ALL IN ALL, Hunan Home's is seriously nothing special at all. Please do not read these 5 star reviews and think this is the holy grail of Chinese food in SF, because it's far from that. I would not come back. Service was friendly and prompt, prices were reasonable.
author: Emmanuella Z.

description: Good food and very nice people.  Busy place we had a little wait but everything is good. We will comeback.
author: Bella S.

description: So so...small portions.  Ordered the Mongolian beef.  Tough and very little of it.  Ordered the honey walnut shrimp and it had some sweet mayonaise tasting sauce poured over it.  I didn't finish either one.   The pot stickers were only cooked on 1 side.  The other side was still frozen.  The waiter was fine.
author: Marissa G.

description:
Went to Hunan Home for the first time on New Years Eve. Everything we ordered was AMAZING ( hot and sour soup, fried dumplings and Kung pao beef). The owner was funny, helpful and so nice! 

Highly recommend! Will definitely be heading back next time we are in San Francisco!
author: Stephanie R.

description: Terrible food!!! This is a tourist trap as most of the customers are out of towers and non-Chinese propping the review star.  I am not sure what cuisine this establishment serves, as it is not Hunan.  My advice is to hit up Henry's as the food over there is 3 stars better.
author: E M.

description:
A few friends and I were looking for some simple Chinese food on a Sunday night, so we decided to give Hunan Home's a try since it was 4 stars with 1174 reviews at the time. After eating here, I honestly have no idea how this place has 4 stars...

To start, we were probably 1 of max 3 tables that were actually Chinese or Asian here...and not to sound racist or whatever you wanna call it, but that's not a great sign for a Chinese restaurant haha

Food-wise, very plain and not that satisfying. For some reason none of our food was that hot, and was more lukewarm, which wasn't very appealing. We got:

1) Pea shoots, which were actually ok and had some good garlic in there
2) The standard sizzling chicken, which didn't sizzle at all (literally), and the chicken meat texture didn't feel and taste right
3) Fish sauce shredded pork or sometihng of the sort, again, lukewarm dish, not much substance to the meat, and just not very satisfying
4) A mediocre bowl of brown rice

Altogether ~$20 a person, so not a huge deal, but overall, pretty disappointed and probably not coming back. Also, I'm not asking for much on the interior of the place, but the booth seating was worn out and uncomfortable, and the inside of the restaurant wasn't very well lit either. Given it was our first time here, we asked our ~50 year old male waiter for some suggestions, and he wasn't helpful to say the least. They definitely use MSG here, too.
author: Gore S.

description: The food was great, but service was subpar. We were seated right away, but no one came to take our order for like 15-20 minutes. The fried rice we ordered came at the end of the meal, so my spicy Hunan chicken was too hot to eat. Overall, could not understand why this place had 4 stars... not recommended.
author: Ralitza M.

description: Went here last week and had an excellent dinner. Pleased to say that the quality of food and service here remains very good. Highly recommended.
author: IQuack D.

description:
Don't believe the hype: for the long wait to enter this establishment, you're better off going somewhere else in Chinatown. 

Sure, the Hot and Sour soup is great. But the blandness of the pork fried rice brings tears to one's eyes. Coupled with the aloofness of the waiters, and the endless wait for your food, Hunan Home is overrated and not worth your money.
author: Yaniv K.

description: Food was undercooked. Sent back chicken Bc it tasted slimy. Came back the second time the same. Yuck
author: Daniel L.

description: Walked in sat down found bugs on the chop sticks. With an attitude the server took them. She said something in her language giving us a dirty look. Didn't even say sorry or anything. Then other bugs appeared. We left. Not coming back. They can eat there bugs.
author: Juan P.

description: I don't understand why this place has such high rating and a Zagat review. The place is dark and depressing; the service was poor. When we asked the server what their signature dishes were, he just told us they are all on the menu and they have not change the menu in 50 years. What kind of service was this? We were simply asking for suggestions and there was none as if the server didn't even know what their signature dishes were. The food was mediocre and overcharged. Very disappointing and don't wanna come back again.
author: Sharon M.

description:
I'm a huge fan of family-style Chinese restaurants.  Hunan makes my list for so many reasons.

Our first impression of the restaurant was set by the friendly and sassy waitress, who is an older woman.  She made us feel welcome - brought us tea, a bit of chit chat, and served us sweet and sour soup. There were lots of families (mostly white American... where do the Asian people go?) laughing and eating together. The decor is modest and what you'd expect for a hole-in-the wall type. This place is not in the slightest bit pretentious. 

I had the sauteed pea pod leaves (a childhood favorite!) while the BF had a beef dish and the sweet & sour soup.  The prices are right and the portions are generous.
author: Victoria C.

description:
Only went to this place because it seems to be a highly rated Chinese restaurant near SF Chinatown. The price is cheaper ($7-8) than what you'd normally pay for a main dish but the portion size is much smaller too.... Ended up ordering more food so the final bill wasn't cheaper anyway.

The food was subpar: the egg rolls we ordered only had shredded cabbage in it which was very disappointing, I was expecting more (i.e. a variety of vegetables). The orange chicken was just soft and gooey (expected some bite to it from the fried chicken pieces). The shrimps in fried rice were not devain (already pretty grossed out at this point). The most disgusting part was finding a piece of metal scrub in the food......REALLY REALLY REALLY DISGUSTED BY IT! I know it was an honest mistake and the manager took the dish off the bill. But it still couldn't save the experience.

The food really wasn't good, edible is how I'd describe it and the portion size is too small for sharing. The service was good. Definitely would NOT come back again unfortunately.
author: Ping L.

description:
It's a rip-off!

I order 2 plates that cost $25.

But I was forced to pay $35 when checkout.

That was horrible experience in US.
author: Tim T.

description: Don't under stand how this place has 4 stars in town for 4 days wanted to try so Chinese food ordered the dumplings they where ok no complains then I had Mongolia beef was super spicy burned my mouth the bad chicken and pork fried rice super bland no taste what so ever do not recommend!!!
author: Edward L.

description: Yup. Just what I remember from great Bay Area Chinese. Good food, relatively fast, and reasonably priced.
author: Karen K.

description: The most flavorless Chinese food I have eaten since I could remember. I'm Asian raised in the heart of socal Asia :) (alhambra/San Gabriel/Monterey park) I had Peking duck with tortilla it's a no no, wonton soup was bland, soup dumplings were dried, stir fried veggie noodle was boring, and Chinese broccoli.  One positive note the waiter was funny and quick.
author: pony b.

description: Good food, clean venue, but the service could be a little better.  Definitely worth trying!
author: Omar C.

description: Overrated. Tourist trap. Did not see any locals in this place. We had the beef with green peppers, the mapo tofu and the sizzling beef.  The two beef dishes tasted exactly the same. Very bland with no flavor. Tasted like they boiled the meat and layered it with watered down sauce. The tofu also had no taste.
author: Al W.

description:
This is a tough one for me, because I have never given a bad review & I really try to keep my yelps positive...however the moment an insect shows up in my food - I have to mention it. 

I'm pretty lenient with Chinatown restaurants when it comes to ambiance & overall cleanliness because after living abroad in China...the most authentic ones in the states don't come packaged up like a Panda Express. 

The food was good, enough. But not good enough for a house fly, the size of a nickel to be tossed into my Tai Chin Chicken. 

I was with my supervisor on a work trip & did not want to make a scene or ruin his appetite so I shoved the fly under my plate & just continued drinking. 

Still paid for my experience but must let fellow yelpers know to look down at your chopsticks before shoveling into your mouth.
author: Amber N.

description:
Very neat that this restaurant makes use of its downstairs area to serve more customers and even establish their restroom. I came here with some friends on a Saturday evening, and we were seated immediately. There was nothing too special about the experience, and I'm not a huge fan of Hunan food so I'll try my best not to be biased. The tea was bland, so I would have asked for a different variety next time (if there is a next time) but anyways this is what we ordered:

* Hot and Sour Soup ($8.50 for medium size) - Served with pork, bean curd, mushroom, bamboo shoots, and eggflower, this hot and sour soup did not satisfy my craving for it. There was something off about the flavor. It tasted very beefy (or porky) and not spicy at all.

* Beef Chow Mein ($7.95) - The beef was a little undercooked in this chow mein, and the noodles were soggier than ideal. It was okay, not too bad.

* Hunan String Beans ($8.95) - These string beans are dry stir-fried with garlic and minced pork. Not a fan of the flavor. They are more on the softer than cruncy side as far as string beans go, as a note in case you have a preference.

* Hunan Spicy Garlic Chicken ($10.75) - Saving the best for last in my review, I actually really enjoyed this dish. The chicken is sauteed with snow peas, baby corn, celery, and mushrooms. You can really taste the spice and Hunan flavors. Goes well with steamed rice. 

These dishes came out to a total of around $44 for four people, and we still had a bit of leftovers. I would probably not opt to come back here again but it was not too expensive, so if you're looking for a basic Hunan restaurant to satisfy some cravings, this may be for you.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
This is exactly what you expect from a quality Chinese food restaurant:

Excellent food
Terrible, dated and rundown decor
Awful but efficient service 
Full of ethnic Chinese (always a good sign)
Clearly serve you last if you are white. 

Would absolutely return here again as the food was incredible.  Just be sure to have realistic expectations of everything else. 

P.s. Another appropriately ironic sign pointing to the quality of this restaurant is that it was recommended to me by my business partner, who is Jewish, and ate here for Christmas two years ago.  The stereotypes just keep coming...

So why five stars? It was perfect for what it was. We loved it!
author: Steve G.

description: This is THE best restaurant in Chinatown that we have eaten at. everything is fresh and homemade! We are locals, so this discovery is a real find.
author: Pat H.

description:
When I was visiting San Fran I wanted some good Chinese food. Came across this place on Yelp and thought I give it a try. 

I ordered some Mongolian beef, orange peel chicken, wonton soup, fried wonton and some fried rice. Everything was delicious. 

The staff was very busy even though it was a Monday. They tried their best and still gave us great service. 

You want some good Chinese food, this is the spot. Variety and decent pricing.
author: Hugo M.

description: Very disappointing, after reading the reviews I expected something great.  The food wasn't anything special and the service was bad.  Visited in Sep. 2016 around 1--there wasn't any line and the restaurant was about 1/2 full maybe
author: Cynthia L.

description: It was quick for a sit down restaurant. The potstickers were awesome as was the combo chow mein. The Mongolian beef was rubbey. Service was good!
author: Jennifer S.

description: Better choices, go elsewhere. Not much to look at outside, should have been a warning. Other helpers rated high because it was OK. the food was merely acceptable. I expect better from takeout Chinese places. Service was poor even though we were there at 5pm. The servings were small and the tea was very weak. I am disappointed with Yelp on this one. I will be more cautious in the future.
author: Walter A.

description: Best veggies at a Chinese restaurant ever! My friends and I really enjoyed our lunch.
author: E S P.

description: Staying in Chinatown, naturally I had a hankering for Chinese. The Hilton recommended this place to me, and boy am I glad they did! The pan fried dumplings were fantastic! I really liked the way they served the wonton soup in a single large serving bowl; enough for my friend and I to split. Finally, the Kung Pao chicken was terrific. The decor is a little dated, but don't let that stop you from coming in.
author: Pat B.

description:
I came for lunch on Sunday around 1:30, and our party of 4 was seated within 15 minutes. We ordered the sizzling beef, roast duck, salt and pepper pork, gai lan (chinese broccoli) with oyster sauce, and brown and white rice. Our food came out quickly, and everything was really good! 

My favorites were the duck, which had perfectly crisp skin. It was pretty fatty though, but that made it even better. The fried salt and pepper pork was super flavorful, and the batter wasn't greasy at all. My bf liked the sizzling beef the most, which literally came out on a sizzling hot plate.

Service was surprisingly good! I dont expect much from places in Chinatown, but the servers were like friendly Chinese parents haha. 

I'd definitely come back to try some of their other dishes!
author: Abby S.

description: Super super super good. Came here when I was visiting San Francisco and fell in love with this place. Highly recommend the XlB and orange chicken.
author: Div L.

description:
The dinner in itself wasn't really bad: we were 3 people and we took 2 starters (Eggplant with Spicy Garlic Sauce and Chinese Broccoli with Oyster Sauce) and the Peking duck.

For the 2 starters nothing to say, they were really good. The Peking duck was really cold and the service was cold and unkind, we didn't feel the welcome there.
author: Viviana D.

description: AHHHHHH! I need this in Orange County! Something that I definitely crave. They have one of best wontons in chili oil that I have ever had, rivaling Din Tai Fung. My friend who cannot eat spicy food, ate it and loved it! The orange peel chicken is probably the best orange chicken I've had. The service was a bit slow, but the waiter was nice and the food definitely made up for it. My friends and I were so impressed with it, we decided to have it twice in one day. This would be a go to spot if I had cravings for good Chinese. If I ever visit SF again, this will be on the to-do list.
author: Quy P.

description:
Got the fried bean curd and xiao long bao for appetizer and Mongolian beef and sizzling seafood platter as main dishes. 

The food was solid but I did not love the xiao long bao. The skin was thicker than is usual for xiao long bao and the soup inside was lukewarm. They added peanut butter which tasted a bit odd. 

Both the Mongolian beef and seafood platter were delicious. Portions are smaller than most Chinatown places but prices are very reasonable. Rice is an extra $1/person. 

I have no complaints about service. The servers worked together to make sure the food came on time, cleared our plates quickly, and refilled water.
author: Kathleen W.

description:
My first yelp! 

This spot is awesome. Great food and service. My girl and I flew up to San Fran and stopped in on the way to Napa and it was so good we ate here again before we flew back to San Diego.

We had the Mongolian beef and the prawns with string beans. We shared the spare ribs for an app. 

I'll go back any time I'm in San Francisco!
author: Collin K.

description:
Our expectations were high because of tons of reviews on yelp, tripadvisor, 10best, etc. There was nothing wrong and everything was fine, can't say it lived up to hype.

Appetizer portions were all big so we assumed entrees would be as well so we ordered fewer. Entrees were surprisingly small and we were nervous about having enough food

Assorted vegetable entree was our favorite. Orange peel chicken was recommended which was ok but especially small for a Chinese food entree.

Service was average. Our food took longer than all other tables which I'm willing to chalk up as a fluke. Our server had a dry sarcastic humor which was funny until I thought he was actually annoyed at us. My dining-mates didn't find it rude. He wasn't thrilled about all the questions we asked. He did give us a good tip to suck the sauce off of the chilis though.
author: Laura G.

description:
We've been here twice now, and have had a great experience every time. The Orange Peel chicken is by far our favorite. The dumplings were also delicious, even for a non-dumpling fan.
Don't expect overly enthusiastic service, but they get the job done. We'll bring guests here, for sure.
author: Dani T.

description: Clams and wine sauce. Stopped in for a quick meal. Had some dumplings. They warned me it would take a while but it was fast. Too gooey for me. The clams were delicious, very fresh. It was a strange atmosphere. Not sure I enjoyed it or not. At one point about 8 guys ran in and all ran upstairs to do something. Curious but never checked. I had to prompt for everything  . Service was ok.
author: Kim N.

description:
This place has a lot of options with a friendly (but awkward) wait staff and the stereotypical fish tank.

The pork dumplings, vegetable potstickers, clams with black bean sauce, orange peel beef, fried bean curd and succulent bread were really good.

We also ordered string beans and fried rice which were pretty mediocre and didn't taste fresh.

It was okay, but I'd suggest you opt for House of Nanking or Hang Ah Tea Room.
author: Molly M.

description:
Seriously? I can't believe that this place deserves 4 stars. Don't be misled by the 4 starts on Yelp. 

This place has good service. But we are not there for the service. Food quality matters. And the price it charges just does not match the quality of Chinese food it serves. To be frank, its quality of food is the worst I have ever had in California. I and my friend regret that we did not simply go to Panda Express, which obviously beats this place.  It's overrated. And this is the first time I feel that Yelp review is so misleading!
author: Jason K.

description: Dined there 11/4 with my wife. Great experience. Our waiter was very attentive and the food was very tasty. This place is a keeper.
author: Ray C.

description:
I was with my family in Chinatown looking for some Chinese food and we found this place with four stars on Yelp. We ordered tai chin chicken. We finally got our food and my daughter took a bite and said it tasted very mild and like bbq sauce. So, we ordered hunan chicken but it tasted almost the same.

I guess their struggle is they are in a heavy tourist traffic area and have to make food to cater to the non-Chinese as well. The result is generic food in generic sauces. DISAPPOINTED.
author: Puneet G.

description: Best service. Would come back when in town.My parents had a lot of fun and our server had the best personality.
author: Candy B.

description:
You know its a bad sign when you're the only Asian customers in a Chinese restaurant.

Came here because of the high ratings on yelp. It was around 7pm on a weekday. The restaurant was pretty full but we were lucky enough to be seated immediately. It wasn't until after we ordered that we realized we were the only Asian customers and started getting nervous. :/

We ordered:
-Mapo Tofu: I LOVE tofu...but for once in my life there were leftovers. They don't use silken tofu and it tasted a little sour. Not a horrible dish, but also not the best.
-String beans: Nice and crunchy but a little too soy saucy for me.
- Orange peel chicken: The best dish out of what we ordered. But my boyfriend said Panda Express orange chicken was better.

Overall, its overpriced Chinese food catered to non-Asians. The food is not bad if you like American style Chinese food. If it were cheaper, we would probably come back but for the price and what you get, better to just go to Panda Express.
author: Crishyashi T.

description: Another solid eat in San Fran. Food was solid and delicious. Establishment was nice and service was friendly and quick.
author: Justin T.

description: Good not great. Some of the reviews are correct about the food being a little bland (hunan chicken & egg rolls in particular). The potstickers were good though.
author: David B.

description: Went with a group of 7 on a Friday evening around 7:30  line out the door, but it moved pretty well. When we got close to entrance and told hostess we were a party of 7, we were taken in immediately - the restaurant is much more spacious then it appears from outside, and they have several tables specifically for groups of up to 8. We made good use of the lazy Susan for our potstickers (very tasty), BBQ pork, moo shoo pork, Hunan scallops, Mongolian beef, spicy chicken, vegetable fried rice, and Hunan green beans. All items were good. The beans were the big standout. Everyone really liked them a lot. Good prices.
author: Gary R.

description:
Ordered a chicken dish that tasted like left over food kept in a refrigerator for days. Ended up eating most of the rice as I was hungry.

Not sure if I picked up the wrong item or it is just a poor quality restaurant. 

Restrooms downstairs are poorly maintained; they are very close to the kitchen. 

Not a place to go again...
author: Ed W.

description: Best Chinese food I've ever had, hands down. We had the Bao Xong dumplings, Pork Chow Mein and Orange Chicken. It will be hard to ever eat Chinese anywhere else after this experience!
author: Mike L.

description: We're giving Hunan Home's 5 stars because we've been coming here for many years and they stay consistently good in both food quality and customer service which is very hard to come by in Chinese restaurants. Hunan Home's is one that you'll surprisingly see tables full of both Chinese families as well as white people. They are able to cater to both taste buds and have delicious spicy and non-spicy dishes that are not oily or too salty. My husband says they are the ONLY Chinese restaurant that brings you water the first time you ask and will freely re-fill your glasses throughout dinner. For those of you who eat at "real" Chinese restaurants, you know this is not the case nor would we normally order water because we grew up only drinking tea or hot water. Their Xiao Long Baos are not that good which isn't surprising as they aren't a Taiwanese or Mandarin restaurant but they are still tasty. Their dishes are on the smaller side but are hot and fresh. Try their Pot Stickers (juicy and homemade tasting), Hunan Home's Smoked Pork, Peking Duck (served with pancakes vs buns), Mu Shu Chicken, Kung Pao Chicken, Sizzling Seafood Deluxe, and Shrimp with Gai Lan. The restaurant is clean and they have tidy restrooms.
author: Jen L.

description:
Ehhh... I came here solely based on Yelp, and I was not a big fan.  It was crowded (which I like) and there were people who didn't seem like tourists (like us!  haha) which is a good thing.  

The problem was that the servers were grumpy!!!  We didn't linger at ALL, and were very non-needy with our orders, but I still felt like I was inconveniencing them!

The food was just as I expected... no frills, nothing different than standard Chinese food which was fine with me... I would not come back, especially since there are so many restaurants in Chinatown to choose from.
author: Laura C.

description:
I decided to visit this restaurant after reading the reviews on yelp. I have to say, it's air conditioned and clean. After walking up the steep hills of San Francisco with the sun burning your face, sitting down in a cool restaurant is nice.  

The service is subpar but I do wonder why the waiter never asked what drinks we wanted. I didn't see a drink portion on the menu but maybe I didn't look hard enough. 

The food, sadly, was very salty. I ordered fried rice with the sweet and sour chicken. The chicken was average and something that I would eat again but the rice was unbearably salty. The rice sent me on a coughing attack.  I would not recommended this restaurant if you are unable to eat large amounts of salt.
author: May S.

description: Good food, mediocre service. Was in the city and read the reviews on their orange peel chicken and Mongolian beef. Both were pretty good and didn't mess up my stomach like most Chinese food places do, so that's a plus :)
author: Nima F.

description:
Had a great lunch here with my grandparents and the rest of my family. We had good food and good service. 

The xiao long bao was perfect. It had just enough soup so that it didn't explode and had enough meat to make it have something to cut the fat. We also had cheung you bang which was great. The dish was a plate of crispy onion pancakes. They were nice and crispy and had a great selection of sauces to use with them. 

The place was great, it had good food and great service. There's always the problem of the language barrier though. These guys though can understand English pretty we'll though, so the barrier isn't much of problem. Now if I'm ever in San Francisco Chinatown I will come back here for a meal.
author: Gabriel L.

description: Accommodating in getting us seated as quickly as possible. Dumplings were excellent. The service is on another level here folks. Our server's knowledge of the menu was spot on and his low key, dry sense of humor had us in stitches. There's a dedicated water server. Let me repeat: there's a person whose sole job is to ensure that you stay hydrated. I'm a fast water drinker and I never even got to see the bottom of my glass. I secretly tried to do it but I think he was onto me and kept a close look. Could have used a few more ice cubes but I won't hold it against him because he made up for it in volume and agility (busy house).
author: Zach S.

description:
We ordered takeout and were glad we did, since we avoided a massive line at 8 pm on a Sunday night. People waiting outside were complaining about the (lack of) service to get on the wait list & be seated, but I feel like bad service is to be expected at most hole in the wall Chinese restaurants (including in China)... just my experience. Didn't affect our rating.

Honestly, after reading the reviews, I expected a lot more. The asparagus was very well done - my favorite part. The sauces were light. But the sizzling seafood & the prawns with asparagus (minus the asparagus) were both just okay. The eggflower soup wasn't that good (the egg almost seemed overcooked). Maybe we picked the wrong things, or maybe eating Chinese food in China has spoiled me, but this really wasn't as good as I expected a highly reviewed restaurant in San Francisco's Chinatown.
author: Courtney R.

description:
The food was ok. Ordered appetizers and entrees everything came out on time but nothing special. 
The one thing for sure that made this place extremely unpleasant was the service. Our server was extremely rude and disrespectful. Every time we asked a question he would roll his eyes and look away. Everything he brought out he would slam it on out tables and then walk away speaking in his native tongue. It does not matter how good or how great of a reputation you have, a customer just be treated with respect. I would never eat here or would recommend anyone to this location.
author: Freddy C.

description: The food was hot, very tasty and the quantity of food was good. The ground hot peppers on the table was convenient. The cost was very reasonable.
author: John C.

description: Restaurant was packed when we entered at 8 PM in a weekday. Appetizer order ( Fried Prawn) was not well cooked and tasted ok. Void was filled by the entree order (Hot spicy crispy chicken). chicken was well cooked and sauce was in right amount for mixing with rice and had the right taste of spicy and sweet.
author: Karthikeyan T.

description:
Chinatown is a place you must experience in San Francisco and then you must experience the food.  Hunan Home's came recommended from a friend who is always here.  Love how its traditional but still new age a bit.
Staff is friendly and we each had different dishes.  I had orange chicken which was not made like normal chinese american places you find,.  The chicken had good flavor and was excellent.
I will def. be back here.
If you are in this area try Hunan Home's.
author: Matt S.

description:
What do you do in San Fran? Well venture to Chinatown for lunch of course! And what do you do when you get there? Search yelp for the best spot around, of course! 

I was overwhelmed with all the options being thrown at my face to eat that I simplified it down to wanting the best, and this is where the yelp world turned me to. And boy am I glad it did! 

We got here in perfect lunch time and I anticipated a wait. I wasn't sure how long or what not, but we got a table no problem! They seem to do a lot of larger parties, which is cool! 

The orange peel chicken was delicious!! And the pot stickers were wonderful on the taste buds as well. 

It seems with the amount of service they could get they could clean the place up a little, but that was my only turn off about this place. 

The wait staff was amazingly nice. One of the guys even helped us by showing me how to eat the peppers that came in the chicken. Suck them, and than eat an orange slice! 

Definitely an awesome little spot.
author: Melanie R.

description: This place wasn't good at all. I went here based on reviews and became very disappointed. I even got the orange peel chicken which was awful. The egg drop soup wasn't good. This place was also expensive, save your money and try a different place.
author: Sarah R.

description: We found this through Yelp and I have to say it was amazing!  The pot stickers were very popular as many tables had orders.  We also ordered Hunan Beef which was OK but the Orange Chicken and Chicken Fried Rice were fresh, homemade and tasted great!  We also had the Wonton soup which was fresh and tasty too.  If you want authentic Chinese food in Chinatown, this is a safe bet.
author: Amy C.

description: The staff here are sooooo friendly and nice!!!!!!!! Just kidding.... They're awful but the food is pretty good and for Chinatown, pretty clean facility. They have bathrooms! Tourists and locals alike so you know it's gotta be good food.
author: Sierra N.

description: Terrible service. Terrible food. Terrible atmosphere. Why would you come here? Turn away, better places are waiting.
author: Vibhore S.

description: My boyfriend and I came to Chinatown and we were very impressed with our first encounter here. The food was delicious! I ordered the egg flower soup and beef broccoli. Although it did state that it was spicy, (it had a red chili on the side) I ordered it to be mild. But it came out spicy! I told the waiter that it was too spicy for me to eat and he was kind enough to take my plate back to the kitchen and have them remake me a non-spicy dish. Although the waiter seemed kind of annoyed that I kept calling him, but he was mostly around & attentive. So good job! I would definitely come back here for the food
author: Ericka S.

description:
Was sat quickly and seating was not too squished. Restaurant looked very clean.

I work 9-5PM in the area and I am always looking for a good lunch special. This place is a thumbs up! Deep fried pork is always my choice of entree and places are a hit or miss with how they fry their pork. This place was a hit. Not too oily and a lot of meat. They also give you broccoli on the side. Soup and tea is included.

The portions are generous and this means a lot because I am also a student and love good deals. I recommend this place through and through!
author: Melissa V.

description: Been waiting 9 years to come back to San Francisco, partly to eat at this restaurant. It was just as good as it was then. We had the combination plate as an appetizer then the chicken with orange peel and the Mongolian beef- all awesome!
author: Amanda B.

description: Just ate here and ordered sizzling beef, xiao long bao, and seeet and sour soup. Food was probably 3 star but rating it 2 cuz both my bf and I have insane stomach cramps now
author: Annie W.

description:
It's always an awesome experience when you get to eat REAL AUTHENTIC CHINESE FOOD!
I'm from LA and the Chinatown here doesn't feel as authentic as the one in Frisco, food/culture etc etc.. but now to the food!

1. Hot n Sour Soup - the bidness 10/10  one of them soups u talk about how good it is after each bite till u notice u said the same thing like 100 times haha (u have to get this I swear to god)

2. Walnut Shrimp - 9/10 really really good

3. Mongolian Beef - 10/10 I just remember the beef being very very tender and seasoned perfectly.

This place was as good as it gets.  If your looking for some Chinese food in Frisco this is one of the best spots IMO!
author: Andrew J.

description:
The food was good. It wasn't OUTSTANDING, but it was pretty good. 

The service, however, was worth giving this place five stars. Not only did they seat us (a party of 9) quickly in a relatively busy restaurant, but they checked on us repeatedly. In fact, it wasn't just our waiter who was responsible for us. The manager ALSO took part in waiting on our table and making sure we got what we needed. He also took the time to joke with us and gave us a ton of good laughs. I had a really good experience of service at this place that I can say was matched anywhere else I've been to.
author: Jason G.

description:
I'll start with the positive: nice staff, great xiao long bao.

The negative? It was so stinking spicy that it over-powered the taste of the food. We ordered the hot and sour soup, Hunan beef and Kung pao prawns. Unclear why this place is so popular.
author: S C.

description: Food was really good. Service was quick, we were seated right away and our order was taken quickly. We waited a while for food, but likely due to a larger group who had come in front of us. Portions were a little small. Sweet and sour chicken had only 6-7 smallish pieces of actual chicken and the rest was peppers and carrots.
author: Arlando L.

description: I ate like a glutton here. Everything was good. Definitely go either the Hunan Smoked Pork, if it's one of your flavors. Staff was great, food was pretty prompt, and we had a great visit to Chinatown.
author: Jordan B.

description: A completely unsatisfactory dining experience. Server was rude and unhelpful, and disrespectful to my dining companions. Food was mediocre at best, bland and greasy. At the end of the meal, the hostess refused to validate parking. Zero ambience. I will never go back and strongly urge all to avoid this dump.
author: Arugula F.

description:
On the filight in, a San Francisco native suggested either R&G Lounge or Hunan Home.  The wait was an hour and a half at R&G, and that sounds like the norm.  As luck would have it, there was one open table at Hunan Home.

Very high quality Americanized Chinese.  No complaints - everything was just fine.  We each got one of the price fixe options.  Plenty to share - plenty left over.
author: Randall R.

description:
So, you know when you tell someone, if a place is packed with their 'own', it's probably worthwhile to go in?  I tell people this all the time, but didnt listen to myself. I passed by a place, packed with a lunch special and people. But decided to come here based on the stellar reviews. 

Food was good, not great. A little more americanised then I wanted.  I wanted more traditional chinese food. And this place was more expensive, not costly tho at about $10-12 pp.  

Up to you if you wanna utilize the high reviews or use your gut.  I recommend going with your gut
author: Justin C.

description:
Yes look at non publisher reviews 
Safe all look angry and sad 
Wontons had no meat in them 
My husband got his entree 15?minutes before I got mine 
My spare ribs looked like chicken wings 
Sweet and sour had no flavor 

Not a hit for us
author: Jennifer S.

description: Love their family style menu. The hot and sour soup is great. I wish I could remember the spicy sauce they served with the wontons, it was amazing! Service is great but not super friendly, then again I'm from Texas. Delicious hot jasmine tea and they'll send you out with a to-go cup.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
The first time I have a pleasant experience at a Chinese restaurant. Kudos to Hunan Homes.
This place well deserve 5 stars compared to the many other Chinese restaurants Ive been to in the bay area.
The staff was very friendly (unlike other restaurants). The lady who waited our table is funny as hell.
-You must have the Hot and Sour soup. I promise it won't be too sour. For once in my life I could finish the whole bowl of Chinese hot and sour soup.
Regarding other dishes, they all have a rustic feel in terms of taste and smell. It doesnt strike you with a strong smell of preservatives or pre-made sauces. The food seems rather fresh and light, which is what I always expect dining at an Asian restaurant.
author: Alan T.

description: The service here wasn't great, it took us 5 minutes to be seated, 30 minutes to have our order taken, and about 20 minutes to be served, and it wasn't a busy day either. The food is average, and it is nothing special, despite other glowing reviews. The menu has everything that your average Chinese Restaurant and Asian Cafe has on it.
author: R T.

description:
My aunt and uncle (SF locals) highly reccomended this place with specific menu items--they are not wrong! The food was great. We ordered green beans, mu-shu pork and some boiled pot stickers. Typical Chinese interiors --nothing special there!

We had an early dinner so the place wasn't too full. Waitress wasn't that great but we were pretty relaxed and in no hurry so it didn't bother us. Had we been In a rush and picky about servers coming to check on us, this place wouldve pissed us off. 

I loved seeing the back table in the restaruant being used to pop the ends of the fresh green beans. I know it sounds silly but seeing fresh food was well...refreshing!
author: Emily S.

description: Service is fast and accurate. The owner/manager is right there to make sure every need to looked after promptly.  The wait staff can be a little acerbic, but are helpful if asked.  Food was excellent, good serving size and price was reasonable. Sizzling rice soup was great.
author: Dan E.

description:
Dined here on the recommendation of a tour guide. It's decorated like every other Chinese place I've been to and it's clean and unassuming. 

We arrived at dinner time and were still promptly greeted and seated. Tea arrived while we browsed the menu. The waiter made his best attempts to be friendly. We decided to order hot sour soup, Chicken with orange peel, Chicken with pea pods and vegetable fried rice. 

The soup arrived first in a large bowl and the waiter ladled it up into individual bowls and served us. It was a nice touch. The soup itself was hearty and full of flavor but not as hot or sour as I prefer. 

Next out food arrived, it looked really appetizing but the portions were a bit on the small side. The entrees are not really big enough to split so order one per diner. The food made it to our table piping hot although the fried rice was a bit late it was hot as well.  It was all very good. 

The chicken with orange peel while advertised as a spicy dish was not spicy at all, that said had a great smokey sweet flavor. If you like it spicy as I do I'd recommend asking for it extra spicy. 

Overall this place is a solid 4 star experience. Good food, good service and it's in Chinatown baby..
author: Jim B.

description:
I would have never thought to go to one of the largest Chinatowns outside of China and stumble upon this place in SF only to find all white folks eating here.  Not that I have anything against that - but from an Asian perspective when we see this we typically assume that the food is prepared more towards the eastern culture taste buds.

To my surprise the food was good! On point and authentic tasting.  We had the fried fish, garlic spicy green beans, salt and pepper pork chops, and mongolian beef..

The wait staff was very professional and unlike traditional chinese restaurants, they tended to our every need.  Also I'm assuming she was the owner (the lady counting money at the end of the night) was very energetic and friendly and we engaged in some conversation as well.
author: Nam N.

description: Went back last week just to see if my other early experience was a fluke.  It wasn't.  Portions were poor; no meat in the Mongolian beef; appetizers came after the main items.  Bland; rubbery chicken.  Loss of atmosphere.  My Dad, who has eaten here several times with me summed it up well: "Don't take me there again."
author: Davey B.

description:
My boyfriend and I are huge fans of Asian cuisine and wanted to try something authentic while visiting SF. This place had good ratings for the most part, so we decided to come here.

We tried the fried wontons, kung pao chicken, shrimp fried rice and beef mushu.

The fried wontons were a little well done and there was hardly any kung pao chicken served on the plate. The shrimp fried rice had great flavor, but nothing was done with the baby shrimp that was added to the fried rice. Also, the beef mushu could have been cooked a little longer.

Despite the minor mishaps, we ate pretty much everything, as we came with a big appetite. 

The hostess that seated us was very friendly, but not so much the servers. Very uncomfortable. Service should always be with a smile.

I don't think we would come here again. :(
author: April T.

description: If you can find the invisible line and get over the sophisticated rude hostess, this restaurant is worth it. Waiting time for dinner is about 30-45 minutes. Price is reasonable, $$ overall and the serving sizes are decent. Approx $15-20 per person for dinner.
author: DJ N.

description: If you're looking for good Chinese food in San Francisco, then look no further.  My fiance and I came here for dinner and had the kung pao with shrimp and the deep fried shrimp in the sweet sauce with honey walnuts.  The kung pao was some of the best that we've ever had, but the honey shrimp was too sweet.  Maybe that was because of the kung pao, but nonetheless it was still good.  Highly recommend this place if you're in the financial district/Chinatown and are looking for a good Chinese restaurant.
author: Matthew V.

description: Only been here a couple times, but so far, this place has not failed to impress. I've come here with people who've been to China 20 times, and they say it's delicious. The service is also mostly friendly, and the food came relatively quickly given that the restaurant was rather full. It was furthermore nearly full on just a random Tuesday night, which I took as an indicator of its popularity and quality. Price wise, it's a bit above average for Chinese food, and I food it a bit unusual that they made one pay for white steamed rice- normally complimentary in Chinese restaurants.  With regards to accessibility, the restaurant is easily accessed from the street, but the bathroom is down a flight of stairs. Odd then that they have a wheelchair accessible bathroom.
author: Alexei S.

description: Food was good, wish the chicken was sliced thinner and that they used big shrimp and not the mini ones. The plates were proportioned perfectly for 2 and the hot and sour soup was delicious!
author: Ruby G.

description:
Probably the best hot and sour soup I've ever had. 

Other than that, everything else is pretty standard. Delicious, but nothing out of the ordinary.
author: Sophie L.

description: Beef and prawns with bell peppers was not flavorful. The serving size was smaller than I had expected. Service was very fast that the meal for myself arrived quickly in 10 minutes or less. It's an expensive yet small meal .
author: Susan T.

description: Had the hot and sour soup and the pot stickers. Both were really good. I was seated very quickly and the staff were on to it. Very responsive and quick to serve. The space is nice and has a nice vibe. Pot stickers were DELISH but hot and sour was a little too peppery.
author: Tommy B.

description: As I was wondering through the city on a Sunday afternoon, I was hungry had this craving for soup dumplings. As I searched through all the soup dumplings (the highest rated one being closed) I opted for Hunan's, and I am so happy I did! I walked in, ordered TWO orders of xiaolongbao (because that's how much I was craving it), again best decision I ever made. They came out with this sauce made of (my best guess) jalapenos, green onions, rice vinegar, soy sauce, cilantro and garlic. Although I usually eat my xiaolongbao with vinegar, this was even better! The spice and flavors paired well with the xiaolongbao's flavorful broth. The texture of the dumpling was perfectly prepared and the mixture inside was delicious! I have yet to try their other dishes, but this will not be my last time here!
author: Nhi N.

description: This is a great place for a group or kids.   Service is fast, food is delicious and reasonably priced.  The moo shu chicken and Mongolian beef are great.
author: Scott P.

description:
Opposite to to other reviews, I would say:
Food- 10 Stars
Service- 3 Stars

Food was amazing! It was very flavorful, and I couldn't stop filling my bowl with more!

However, service was really lacking.  The people were more interested in watching sports and playing candy crush instead of serving their customers.

The interior is REALLY cheesy, but they own HUGE real estate.  I was shocked at how large this place was.  You can really hold a wedding or banquet here easily!

They validate for the Golden Gateway Garage but didn't really seem very happy about give it out. 

Hot and Sour Soup:
Not REAL Chinese food, but I still crave for it.  This gave me my fix. A small is more than enough for 3-5 people.  Drinking too much of this will make you throw up, literally!

Cashew Shrimp:
This is the ONLY dish where I thought it was bang for my money.  Shrimp were fresh and fat and the plate had a bunch of them.  Cashews were roasted and infused with Chinese spices.  LOVED IT!
This place is the only place I know that does this dish right.
My nephews hate celery, and they ate all of theirs cause the flavors were so well infused.  It hid the sour/bitter taste of it. 

Orange Peel Chicken:
I think Panda Express' is better but they put REAL orange peel in this which is a treat and not cheap when you buy it outside. 

Broccoli with Beef:
Be careful.  There are TWO broccoli with beef dishes.  The "Chinese" broccoli they list is "jie lan" which is the long green vegetable.   The one we usually eat is considered "Western broccoli".  
This dish was good, but seriously, paying over 10 bucks for this is SUCH a rip off.
This is something you can easily make it off.

Rice is $1/person, and they only give you a little bit...
They should have offered a free refill considering how many dishes we ordered and how we paid double the prices as compared to any other place.

The bill for 3 dishes and a soup came out to be about 60 bucks. OUCH! But it's Chinatown SF, I guess...

Would I come back?  Probably not.  Maybe just to order a shrimp dish to go.
author: David W.

description:
With time to kill before our movie at the Embarcadero, Boyfriend and I wandered into Chinatown to grab some dinner. We ended up at Hunan Homes based on an earlier Yelp search. Based on its ratings (and its proximity to Golden Gate Bakery which, sadly, we didn't make it to), we decided to eat here.

I was a little worried that this would be a more "touristy" kind of Chinese restaurant (a la P.F.
