Chang's -- especially since, racist as this sounds, there weren't very many Chinese people in the restaurant), but I was pleasantly surprised by the food nonetheless. True, the food was a bit more on the "gimmicky" side, but there were a number of more authentic dishes sprinkled throughout the menu.

Seating was immediately available, as was a pot of tea, though over the course of our meal, the restaurant quickly filled up and got very busy. We chose to get the pot stickers, the hot and sour soup, tea smoked duck, black mushroom with tender greens and some white rice for both of us to share.

Don't tell my mom, but I liked Hunan's potstickers more than her homemade ones. There were 6 of them and I was starting to worry that I would get full simply on the potstickers after having 2 of them. I was also pretty impressed by their hot and sour soup. I didn't develop a taste for this dish until I started getting older, but now that I have, I can't get enough. It was very flavorful but not overwhelmingly hot -- but after two bowls, I was starting to sweat just the tiniest bit and my taste buds were tingling a bit. There was enough that both Boyfriend and I managed to have 3 small bowls of soup each.

The tea smoked duck was REALLY good -- better than any duck I've had anywhere else, actually. It was prepared differently than what I'm normally used to (it being fried instead of, say, steamed or roasted), and the meat was a reddish color (like the skin of char siu) which was also different. But the duck was very succulent and the flavors were full. Some of the pieces were pretty bony, but you can't expect EVERY piece to be chock full of meat. The black mushroom with tender green ('tender green" meaning bak choy...) was meh. Out of all the dishes we had, that one was the least tasty and I wouldn't order it again.

We ended up with a lot of food to take home as leftovers (rice included), so I'm pretty pleased. After tip, I paid $40 -- and considering that I'm technically getting TWO meals out of it, I'm not complaining at all.
author: Anna W.

description:
We were staying around the corner at the Hilton and looking forward to having an authentic Chinese dinner, (the kind of Chinese food I enjoyed as a kid.  :) 

I was not disappointed! We ordered the Shrimp w walnuts, chow mien, and fried rice! The food was great, the service quick and friendly.  They have an extensive menu and we hope to enjoy a few more dishes before we leave SF.  

The prices were good. A great place to bring the family.
author: Cynthia R.

description: Great and authentic food, there was a waiting on Wednesday but it was worth it, great soups and tea. They are quick on service, not the greatest service but they don't care since they are always busy.
author: Custo A.

description: The soup dumplings literally had no soup. We asked them for another batch and the 2nd batch was soupless as well. .  The two stars were given for pretty good service and the other dishes were pretty tasty.
author: Odom S.

description: Had to only wait a few minutes to get seated.  Tried the kung pao chicken and the green beans.  Both had very good flavor and some heat.  Also enjoyed the green tea that they give you with the meal. Service was adequate.
author: Darlene O.

description:
Delicious food. Great Service. 
Recommendations if your in a large party to make reservations.
author: Kourtney J.

description: Great Chinese food! Chinese is my favorite and I was very pleased with all the food I tried. I recommend the duck and the orange chicken. The restaurant  may have a wait or even a line out the door but it is very short and the service is very friendly and quick.
author: Regan B.

description: Excellent Food! Food was hot and delicious! Had Chicken Nut and Kung Pau Chicken with White Rice. However they need more staff assisting with waiting on customers! Young girl was hostess, taking phone calls for take out food orders and waiting tables but all with a smile! Highly Recommend!
author: Linda D.

description:
First time at this restaurant and so far is ok but I feel sorry about the guy that took our order as he is the only one working the floor then to get the food he has to walk downstairs, after we talked to him he said that from 2 to 5 he is the only one working, all and all, he was a good guy.
We had the hot and sour soup and it was good, my son likes the pot stickers which were really good.
The spicy garlic chicken was also good, spices they use are really good.
The prices here were not that expensive for a Chinatown restaurant.
We will sure come back and try something different next time.
Enjoy.
author: Rich M.

description:
Place is decent. Service is typical for a Chinese Asian restaurant. At least our waiter said welcome when we say thank you. Got seated quick and food came out quick. The best part of our meal was soup dumplings and pan fried dumplings. Would come back just for that! The rest, we've had better. Shrimp fried rice didn't have much flavor, hot and sour soup was okay. Wonton in chili oil, not the best. Hunan string bean was interesting and very salty. Sweet and sour fish was okay... Was crispy but have had better. Only recommendation is xiao long Bao and pan fried dumplings. However their oranges were super sweet and juicy.
With the many reviews and stars it has, was a little disappointing, but not the worse.
author: Sarah N.

description: Takes 5ever to get food, but it was alright. I recommend the Kung Pao chicken and the Mongolian beef! The portions were kinda small for a family style type deal, but what can you do. Lowkey too expensive for me, but that's just SF man.
author: Melany T.

description: The food was not good.  Service was not good.  Who is the Hunan character anyways?  I find it odd that this restaurant has 1300+ yelp reviews yet none of the round eyes waiting for a table near us had ever been there to validate the high rating.  I have a suspicious feeling that the yelp ratings are padded...touché Hunan
author: Chet L.

description:
Chinese food on Christmas? Heck yeah!! 

I tried Hunan Homes with my parents and boyfriend for dinner on Christmas day and I was BLOWN AWAY by how awesome it was. Granted there was a long line of hungry customers when we arrived at 4 PM but it was totally worth the wait (30-40 minutes... not that bad!) We were seated in a nice comfy booth and started to check out the menu which was daunting since there were so many options.

Here's what we decided on:

Wor Wonton Soup: 4/5 - I love starting off with soup and this one had so many ingredients. Shrimp, mushrooms, meat, bamboo, veggies, it was all there! Add a splash of the spicy chili oil and bam it's delicious.

BBQ Spareribs: 3/5 - these are my dad's favorite but I'm not too fond of them. However, they do have a lot of meat on the bones and were pretty tasty.

Eggplant in spicy garlic sauce: 5/5+ - this dish was like crack. Seriously people I had to restrain myself from licking the plate of delicious sauce because it was THAT GOOD. The eggplant was tender and the sauce was an excellent combination of spicy, savor, sweet goodness that I couldn't stop eating this dish even though I was full. This one will blow your mind.

Mapo Tofu: 4/5 - a good rendition of mapo tofu but not the best I've had. Still the sauce was yummy and the tofu was cooked well so I'd order it again!

Asparagus Beef: 4/5 - I've never had this dish before but it was yummy! The asparagus was perfectly cooked and the beef was nice and tender, making it a deliciously balanced addition to our feast.

Sizzling Oyster: 3/5 - I wasn't super excited for this dish but my dad and boyfriend were! Anyway the whole show of adding the food to the sizzling plate was pretty cool and the oysters were GIANT so we definitely got a good deal on this one.

Combo Chow Mein: 4/5 - the noodles were awesome, not too chewy but perfect! Hunan Homes definitely knows how to make a great noodle dish.

Kung Pao Chicken: 5/5 - another must order =) Definitely a bit spicy but it's a good kick, not a lip numbing painful ordeal. The chicken was great and the peanuts add a nice crunch.

In the end I CAN'T WAIT TO COME BACK! Our waiter was also really nice and made sure we had everything we needed even though the restaurant was super busy. Can't wait to return!
author: Sam F.

description:
The thing about tChinatown, is that there are countless places to get chinese food. the only downside in the majority of these places is that whatever you order, it seems to all taste the same. That is not the case for Hunan Home's Restaurant. 

Four of us stopped in for a late dinner and the place was bumping. We were hungry so we ordered quite a few different things off of the menu which I am so glad because Each plate had its very own flavor. 

We probably one of every type of meat they offered: chicken, beef, fish, squid, duck, chowmein with shrimp..Just to name a few. Everything was so amazing and the server who I believe was the manager was hilarious and so helpful! 

My new go to for Chinese for sure!
author: Christian G.

description: We stopped in for dinner on the recommendation of some nice people on the street. The food was delicious- I give it four stars for the lovely, savory, flavorful hot and sour soup and the yummy mu shu beef with pancakes. The fried dumplings were delicious as well. The vegetable fried rice was tasty, but I just missed the meat (we should have ordered it!). The seafood crispy chow mein was also good. I give the last star for the service, however! Our server was very attentive and professional, an all-around excellent server. The atmosphere was pleasant and clean; we were seated quickly after 5 minutes, even though the place was already pretty full by the time we got there around 6 pm. Definitely worth stopping by if you are in Chinatown.
author: Maria T.

description:
Chinatown has a clear divide between real "authentic" Chinese restaurant, and ones that are cater to non-Chinese community.  Saw this place on Check Please, and had to go and check it out.

Walking into this place you can NOT find a single Asian.  Go around the corner and you will find ones that are packed with Asians.  I asked the hostess, is this authentic Chinese restaurant.  She clearly stated that this is for caucasian tourist community.

The food was OK consistent with chain places like PF Chang.  If thats your thing, you will love this place.  If you want real authentic Chinese flavors, you should open your horizons.
author: David H.

description:
It's hard to decide amongst the wide selection of restaurants in Chinatown, but based on reviews, I decided on Hunan's Home for some friends visiting from out of town. I was most hoping their XLB came close to my favorite (Shanghai Dumpling King in Outer Richmond). While it did not, it was still pretty good and the rest of the food was great.

I ordered the prawns with garlic sauce and it was one of my favorite Chinese restaurant dishes ever. The potstickers were great, as was my friend's chicken with snow peas. I would happily return again for more delicious food!
author: David B.

description: Delicious. Spicy. Fresh. Can't find enough words to describe how wonderful the food here is. Service is reasonable and fast.
author: Ash N.

description:
If really good Chinese food is what you are looking for than Hunan Home's Restaurant is just for you! 

We started our meal with the wonton in hot sauce, that was absolutely delicious! 

We then shared a plate of chicken with spicy garlic sauce, so tasty and so juicy! The chicken was very moist and fried perfectly.

The Mu-shu pork is the best thing I have had in a while. A sort of pancake with pork and plum sauce. Trust me you will love it! 

The food here is super tasty. Every dish was more delicious than its previous. The service is relatively fast and the staff is friendly.
 
Can't wait to come here again!
author: Tamara S.

description: Wonderful food in the heart of Chinatown! I've come here on two separate occasions for munch and it's been wonderful both times. Food is delivered fresh, hot and fast. Im not the most adventurous eater, so no mind-blowing tips today. Just go there. You'll enjoy it!
author: Chad L.

description: This place is amazing!! We got the sizzling shrimp, orange peel chicken, wonton soup, and hot and sour soup. IT WAS SUPERCALIFRAGILISTICEXPIALIDOCIOUS!!! I have zero complaints! All of the food was delicious. I highly recommend going here for wonderful, authentic chinese food! :)
author: Aly M.

description:
I've been coming to human homes for 20 years and have never had a meal that wasn't fantastic.  

Highly recommended.

No msg

Great vegitian food.
author: Dennis W.

description: Have you ever been to a restaurant where your waiter doesn't talk nor respond to you? If you want to experience it go to this restaurant. Came here after reading some good reviews, stood in line for about 20-30 min and when got seated got the worst service ever. Yes, the food was good cant complain about that, but zero costumer service. There were 2 servers on the floor doing it all at once and barely handling tables. As we were leaving, the line was probably about an hour wait so there must be something special about this place. I would suggest them adding at least a bus boy to help out on the floor. Not even mentioning a hostess who picks up the phone that doesn't stop ringing.
author: Yana M.

description:
I ordered a sizzling seafood deluxe. The seafood was fresh, and the sauce was decent. Service was reasonably quick.

3.5 stars
author: Tony J.

description:
Good for a traditional (American-) Chinese restaurant in the middle of Chinatown.

I was suppressing my hunger while beaming with joy at City Lights Bookstore. Stepped outside and was famish. Decided to eat in the heart of Chinatown since it's around the corner and Hunan is the first recommendation from Yelp.

It's funny how eating the same type of Chinese food in San Francisco feels different than when I'm eating it in Los Angeles. Maybe all the walking and being fatigue makes the food taste better. Either way, the food was good (and the bookstore even better).
author: Caroline J.

description:
I've been eating at this establishment for close to 35 years.  They have the best pot stickers bar none.  Many of their dishes set the bar for good Chinese food in general.  I enjoy their versions of won ton soup, hot and sour soup, crab in ginger and green onion sauce, honey walnut shrimp, salt and pepper squid, orange sauce beef, and xiao long bao just to name a few.
What's so fantastic about this place is the consistency.  It is so reliable I never hesitate to refer people there.  If your going to be in the Bay area this the one restaurant you won't want to miss.
author: Charles L.

description: Very delicious! Our table got a range of food and it was all good. The only disappointing dish was the duck because there was too much fat - the flavoring was good but there didn't seem to be enough meat in the dish. Great service too! There was only one waiter during the day but he managed every table flawlessly
author: Stephanie W.

description: Went on a Tuesday night. It was really busy but we were seated in about 15 mins. The servers and kitchen could barely keep up with the number of customers. Our appetizer was actually the last dish to come to the table. No one checked on our food but thankfully we didn't need much attention. The food was better than average but I wasn't blown away by it.
author: Matt M.

description: We came here late night during the last trip to San Francisco. Primarily because that was one place that was open that late. Good solid Chinese food!
author: Vladimir E.

description: It was ok. Staff was friendly enough. The deep fried prawns were the best and the beef with string beans was yummy.
author: Brett M.

description: We always order the same dishes whenever we want to compare tastes between restaurants. For Hunan, we ordered their clam in oyster sauce, hot and sour soup, spicy tofu, spicy shrimps, and seafoods with vegetables. First of all, the hot and sour soup is leaning towards the sour side. Tastes like it had too much vinegar. I'm not sure if this is the standards in San Francisco, but it was a little too sour for me and my wife. Sad to say, it went downward slope from there on. Even the tofu didn't taste that good as well as the shrimps. I feel bad since I'm not really choosy when it comes to Chinese food, but I can't help it. We were really disappointed with the tastes of their dishes. Maybe we never really ordered their recommended dish or what they're famous with. I normally give restaurants second chance but in our case we can't since we're just visiting SFO.
author: Eduard L.

description:
Honestly these reviews of 4-5 stars make no sense, maybe yelps rating system is on a curve, go figure.

1. Seating was fast
2. Cleanness mediocre to poor 
2. Wait time from order to serve was long
3. Food quality was mediocre to poor
4. Food quantity average
5. Cost to value, this place is over priced.

Again I can't figure out the high ratings, but I being neither a food critic nor chef I can say for the 2 appetizers and 2 entree's + steamed white
Rice @ nearly $60 with tip I was sorely disappointed and left with a bad taste in my mouth never to return.
author: Philip T.

description: I'm not by any means trying to downgrade. But the food is almost generic. I try my best to look on the bright side of things and try to give this place a four but I just couldn't bring myself to it. I won't be coming back.
author: Jonathan L.

description: I really don't see how this restaurant has 4 stars. The chicken with orange peel had almost no actual chicken in it. It was like eating crispy batter covered in sauce. Naturally, the cheapskates don't include rice in the charge of the dish. Fine, but imagine my shock when I see that my side of rice cost me $9.50! For a $12 dish.. right. Don't waste your money here.
author: Leonie H.

description: My wife and I meet some friends here for lunch.  The restaurant was very clean and more roomy then it looked from the outside. The waiter took our drink orders right away and our meal order also.  It took the food a long time to arrive after ordering.  The food was very good and we had plenty to eat.  It's a god restaurant to visit in a busy Chinatown.
author: Jeffrey G.

description:
The best Chinese food in SF! Hands down. The service can vary but the food makes up for it. 

They use real pieces of chicken breast which in my experience isn't always the case with Chinese food. Having traveled to China I can truly say this is authentic Chinese but catered to Americans just the right amount. 

My go to are the Kung Pao chicken and dumplings in spicy sauce.
author: H K.

description:
Traditional Chinese restaurant. Love their whole crab! Served in nice precut pieces (but still in the shell), they were flavorful and succulent.
They have a pretty extensive menu and lots of great vegetable options as well. 
Good place to come with a big group as they have upstairs and downstairs seating, filled with nice round tables equipped with lazy susans. 

Con: service was poor and super slow.
author: Nancy Z.

description: The hubby and I are from Reno, so we really were in the mood for just some bomb ass Chinese food, the kind of stuff you can't even pronounce, just point at the picture. Of course I went to Yelp, to see where and what. This one stuck out to me, a bunch of good reviews. Off to find a parking spot in Chinatown. Hunan Home is just what we were looking for, a short wait, a packed house and waiters dashing from table to kitchen. The staff were all very nice, quick but with class. I had the tea smoked duck, I really loved this dish. Reno doesn't really have any good duck that I found, so I was happy with it's very light tea smoked flavor, juicy meat and crispy skin. I tore apart that dish like it as nothing. Just wish I didn't have to sort through the bones, but thats the lazy side of me. Hubby ordered orange chicken, we shared pork chow mien & an order of egg rolls. Orange chicken was pretty good. It had awesome crunch covered in a sweet and tangy orange sauce with little pieces of orange skin. Chow mien noodles were very fresh, flavor was on point. Good sized pork and veggie pieces.  Egg rolls were crispy, veggies inside still had their crunch and the sweet and sour tasted home made. We helped these dishes along with some cold as hell Asahi beer which is always a favorite. Reasonably priced, not too long of a wait, fast and friendly staff. When back into the city, we will come back to try other dishes.
author: Maea B.

description:
If you are wanting authentic Chinese food this isn't the place. This place is definitely a tourist spot. Hence while we sat down a tour bus stop in front and at least 30 people came through the door and the lady at the front (owner?) escorted them to the other dining area. On a wall near the register is a picture of the owners with Jeremy Lin which was pretty cool.
 
We had the Hunan Pork, Kung Pao Chicken, Shrimp & Scallop fried rice and Sizzling Eel. Everything tasted as if I was at PF Changs or Panda Express except the Sizzling Eel, which was good. 

Shrimp & Scallop fried rice - bland and didn't really see much scallops but there was an abundance of shrimp which was good. I could make better fried rice!

Hunan Pork & Kung Pao Chicken - both were alright but seem to lack something.

Sizzling Eel - the sauce was definitely good but wasn't spicy either (again my spicy level is probably much higher then the average person). The eel was still firm and the sauce definitely compliment it. It has this smoky and tangy taste with a kick. The guy owner came over to talk to us and told us to not eat the pepper but to suck on it to taste the sauce. When I had chomp down and swallow 2-3 peppers in front of him he had called me crazy guy haha.

Overall this place isn't bad but it wasn't great either.
author: Thommy V.

description:
I'm giving them 5 stars for two reasons:
1. They sat us quickly during the Chinese New Year weekend on a Sunday.
2. The food was excellent! Nothing to complain from what we ordered.

So it was Sunday of Chinese New Year weekend. After walking around for a few, we wanted to have lunch at Great Eastern Restaurant because we've eaten here before and the food was really good. We walk up and there's a crowd outside as well as inside. I over hear people outside saying it's 20-30 minutes, but WE go inside & they tell us 1hr - 1 1/2 hr wait. Makes me wonder who they were giving the true time to.

So we looked around for something else... Yelp comes up with Hunan Homes and it's 4 stars! Plus recent reviews have been very good. Once inside, it looks small, just a small room in front & then you see the kitchen. Several booths line the walls with some tables in the middle for bigger groups.

Inside there was only one other group of 4 in front of us. Then comes another group of 4 and a group of 2. Looking inside the restaurant it was all full except for a big table that could seat about 8 - 10 people. We all stood there for about 5-10 min. Then the woman asks us all to follow her. She walks us passed the front room, passed the kitchen & down some stairs. We joked whispering, "Are we eating in the storage room?" (HAHAHA) All of a sudden walking passed the kitchen we come to another dining room!!! Well played Hunan with your hidden extra space!

All of us there felt like it was kind of our own private room. Even though we didn't know each other, we got the vibe from one another that we were in a little more "intimate" space. The room was just as big as the front room with just as many tables.

Our waiter, an older man, comes rushing in to give us all menus. He was the only one working with all of us in this back room. I give him credit because he didn't skip a beat! First going table to table giving waters, then tea & cups. Then after a few minutes (enough for us to look at the menu) he comes back out & systematically goes from table to table asking if we're ready to order. A couple of the tables weren't ready but he politely moved to the next table.

To start we ordered: Xia Long Bao & Potstickers
Main entrees: Cashew Chicken & Crispy Chicken w/ Hot Chili Sauce

Xia Long Bao (Photo): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hunan-homes-restaurant-san-francisco?select=qxP_d4DcSiVBMkii4S77hw#qxP_d4DcSiVBMkii4S77hw

Xia Long Bao - I didn't know at first that these were "broth" filled dumplings, until the server came out with two large spoons. I know from experience that with "broth" filled dumplings you need to eat them in the spoon so that you don't loose any of that delicious broth. Served with a soy, ginger, green onion sauce. I try one with it first. The dumpling was tender and the broth was great. I was surprised at how much broth came out because looking at them you couldn't tell. With the soy it was even better. And of course for me, with a little chili oil it was excellent!

Potstickers (Photo): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hunan-homes-restaurant-san-francisco?select=qxP_d4DcSiVBMkii4S77hw#KyrsXrqLOZcXC-0K925gMg

Potstickers - I've always been told that a good potsticker has that crispy pan fried side with the tender skin on the other & a nice juicy filling. Well these did not disappoint. Take that first bite & it's nice & crisp! The filling was tender, juicy & flavorful.

Cashew Chicken (Photo): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hunan-homes-restaurant-san-francisco?select=qxP_d4DcSiVBMkii4S77hw#nBA_Iai_L11ju5ketXLrPQ

Cashew Chicken - I thought this had great flavor to it. It wasn't too salty. In other words no "MSG" kind of taste to it. The flavors were light, complimenting each other. But once you add just a bit of soy sauce it tasted like it brought out a lot more flavor to the whole dish. I didn't get that "salty" after taste like from some bad Chinese fast food chain.

Crispy Chicken w/ Chili Sauce (Photo): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hunan-homes-restaurant-san-francisco?select=qxP_d4DcSiVBMkii4S77hw#RgmGqNPZwto9OxRHvjZdSw

Crispy Chicken - Loved this dish! The chicken was so tender! So you're talking about a "fried" chicken that's been topped with a chili sauce. Now I know that crispy skin is eventually going to get soggy, which it was, BUT the saving grace was that I actually bit into quite a few pieces of skin that were nice & crispy! Overall, the flavor was great, the chicken was juicy and I added more chili oil just for the extra spice for me.

It's great to know that there's a back a plan in case Great Eastern is full again. But I have a feeling we'll be coming back here to Hunan House first before Great Eastern again. And it's right across the street too.

Eat it... Love it?... Yelp it!!!
author: Joel R.

description: Great food. Good service. But the bathrooms could use a facelift. Either way I would still recommend!
author: Emily M.

description: So freaking good! My boyfriend and are in SF and really wanted soup dumplings, so we decided to come here. We ordered two portions of the dumplings and vegetable moo shu to split, and we devoured every last bite. The dumplings were the perfect size to pop in your mouth. The broth was rich, nourishing, and warmed us on the cold SF night. My BF said that they were one of the best he ever had outside of China. The veggie moo shu was really good too. Everything was very fresh and was worth the wait. Great service too!
author: J P.

description: The service was horrible, our waiter was so rude we would ask him a question and he would ether barely answer or not answer at all. Everyone in my party felt uncomfortable, server was just rushing with everything trying to get rid of us. I personally enjoyed my chow mein but most of my friends did not enjoy their food. It was an okay experience, given that there weren't many places to go to in China town.
author: Jennifer F.

description:
A good choice in Chinatown!

Almost no wait even though the restaurant was bustling-- apparently they have a whole hidden dining room in the back!  The man working the front was super friendly and hilarious.  Maybe he'd adopt me and cook me lots of Hunan food?

They brought us hot tea but we had to ask (twice) for water.  But the food is the meat of the review (pun intended)...

For appetizers, we got vegetarian potstickers and succulent bread.  The potstickers were only okay, and were extremely ginger-y.  I really hate ginger, so that was not my thang.  Other people at the table with less of a vendetta against ginger found them only okay as well.  But the succulent bread was FANTASTIC.  You wouldn't expect it, but it was totally can't-miss.  We took home the very little extra that was left, and had it for breakfast the next day with jam.  Like sufganiyot! Amazing.  It's like a really light and barely-sweet donut, but words don't do it justice.

For entrees, we got the prawns with honey walnuts, eggplant in garlic sauce (but specially prepared without the pork-- props for being accommodating to vegetarians!), squid with spicy salt, and sizzling oysters.  I didn't try the oysters, but my mom hated them.  We really liked everything else!  The squid was salty, true to name, but also had a lot of other complex flavors.  Really light and almost flaky.  The eggplant was good too, very savory and soft... Great even without the pork!

But the prawns were the real hit... Everyone at the table LOVED those.  The sauce they're in is absolutely wonderful, and all the flavors work together perfectly.  Thanks for the recommendation, yelp!
author: Allison M.

description: I got the mushu pork. It was the best I've ever had. Great service. Would definitely visit again!
author: Maria W.

description: I haven't been to San Francisco for 11 years but I knew this is one of only a couple restaurants I wanted to hit.  It did not disappoint.  The hot and sour soup is fantastic here the lemon chicken was pretty good but the Mongolian Beef was far better.  If you are looking for a yummy meal in Chinatown this place is great.
author: Stephen H.

description: Some of the best Chinese food I've ever had. Was visiting from New York and actually went twice it was so good!
author: Foodie B.

description: I really loved this place! My boyfriend and I had egg rolls, wonton soup, sweet and sour pork, and prawns with broccoli. Everything was really great! We did wait outside for maybe 15-20 minutes but I thought it was worth it. Their service was awesome as well, our waitress was really kind and attentive. I highly recommend this place to anyone looking for bomb Chinese food in SF.
author: Fernanda O.

description: You win some and you lose some. Subpar food, subpar service. The reviews totally misled us. I wish we had gone somewhere else. The food was edible but nothing great about it. We went for lunch and prices were ok. I usually give good reviews but I have nothing exciting to say about this place.
author: Damaris Z.

description: Literally the worst place in San Francisco. So dirty, horrible service from the manager to the waiter, disguising food. This is coming from a huge foodie. Avoid this place like the Black Plague! My family was seated after another party came in after us, we were not served any water, received no acknowledgment when I politely asked for another bowl, and had to wait an extra fifteen minutes because the manager forgot to give us back our change. Just terrible. I was in shock at how careless the management was, and no one ever provided us with an apology. What a waste of my time and money.
author: Vivian N.

description: Came on a Saturday on a day they had a party of 90(literally) they weren't taking any walk ins or reservations for later that night so we went outside and talked about where else to go the owner came out and talked to us for a bit saying she was sorry asked where we were from and all that. Pointed out a few good restaurants around the area well we decided we would wait till a table opened up...yes it's that good. She literally was able to get us seated in 20 minutes if we took less than an hour, a great compromise. The customer service never lacked the food was delicious as always! Thank you to the owner for going above and beyond! We will continue to visit anytime we come to the bay
author: Diana B.

description: Pretty standard chinese food here, nothing that's out of this world delicious. Despite this restaurant having a ton of reviews on yelp, it's not much better than some of the other less reviewed, less popular chinese restaurants in chinatown. If you're just hungry and in the area, you'll probably enjoy this place. If you're looking for something that'll blow you away, a place that you can tell all your friends is the best chinese food in the city, then I'd say keep looking. This definitely is not that place.
author: Derrick W.

description:
I wandered in and was greeted by nobody, so I kind of stood around idly for a couple of minutes, awkwardly looking around for some sort of recognition and, getting none, stole some mints from the front desk and seated myself. 

Eventually, a super clean-cut, older Chinese server came over, grunted hello, and passed us the menus. He promptly brought us water and tea, and asked if we were ready to order--I got the sweet and sour chicken ("oh, how original, Helena"--you say) and Alex got the beef with broccoli. 

It came very promptly and for the sake of brevity, here, I'll just say it was delicious. I would have liked if the serving was a tiny bit larger, to be honest. The tea was fantastic, and the server was on fleek (not just the eyebrows, all of him).

I would absolutely recommend this place. Small note: maybe it's a family joint, because there were lots of kids around when we popped by. That said, whatever. They're entertaining. One of the children was particularly monstrous and I had the time of my life watching her try to use a fork to eat a piece of chicken. Eventually she gave up on the fork, but used it to wedge the piece of chicken between her tiny teeth, and then used her right hand to shove the whole chunk into her mouth. After chewing perfunctorily for about a minute or so, she seemed to get tired of the whole "chicken" taste, so she just regurgitated it all out of her mouth and proceeded to let it drip down her chin--until her poor mother noticed, and wiped it off. 

But I mean, kids, amirite?

Loved this place. Wouldn't have it any other way.
author: Helena B.

description:
To be honest, I didn't have high expectations of this place. It came highly recommended from a coworker here in San Fran as her favorite Dim Sum place in town, but I was skeptical. I'm so glad that they proved my disbelief to be wrong!

We had a large variety of food to try- hot and sour soup, pot stickers, Peking duck, steamed snow pea leaves, general tso's chicken, and about 5 other meat dishes that i didn't catch the name for. The only dish I didn't care for was the Peking duck, but I don't believe I've eaten duck before so I may just not like the flavor. It was nice and crispy on the outside and flavorful inside, but I'm not a fan of duck. 

Service was spot-on, and the waiter was very attentive and quick with the water and tea refills. The food came in waves, which each course coming at exactly the right time after we finished the previous course. The food was delicious! All the dishes were cooked perfectly, and full of flavor. The meat wasn't over cooked and tough, like some places, but was moist and juicy. I can't wait to come back!
author: Melinda R.

description:
Very good Chinese restaurant! Located at the heart of Chinatown it has very local climate and great taste. Far from being upscale restaurant it offers best quality Chinese food I had in the us so far.

Everything we tasted was delicious, from appetizers plate to share, followed by hot&sour soup to all kind of pork, beef, chicken and seafood. Freshly prepared, timely served. So definitely strong recommendation for all chines food fans!

Hint: kitchen closes at 22:00. 
Hint: you might expect queue for the table in the evening.
author: Mike D.

description: The xiao long bao was good, but that was about it. Orange beef left you saying "where's the beef" and the green beans were okay. I would come back only for the soup dumplings.
author: Thuy H.

description:
The sweet & sour is outstanding. We also had a great orange beef and minced pork beans.
Service was great, and made changes to the dishes to our request.
Great experience overall.
author: Pedro G.

description:
TOURISTS GALORE!

It's ok tho, I suppose it is fun to play tourist sometimes :)

Hubster and I found this place after getting spa treatments at Tru.

The food was pretty bomb! The Hot & Sour soup was one of the best we've ever had. 

Prices were decent and service was quick.

They're open late night! We will be keeping this place in mind after nights out in the City.
author: Earlene C.

description:
Quintessential  old school San Francisco Chinatown atmosphere.  I love it!

Food

Spicy sour soup- so good!
Must try.

Orange peeled Beef- excellent. The best I had.

spare Ribs with Salt - it's ok

hunan Scallop- the best 

Service: good so far, quick and super fast  and the manager named James is super friendly and nice dude.

ambiance: old school Fu Man Chu San Francisco feeling.
author: Chowder K.

description: It's been YEARS since I ate here.  However, I want to give them props.  The place has been around for at least 25 (and probably more) years since I was a kid.  Back when I was younger, my parents and I would come to Chinatown on the weekends.  We'd grab lunch at Hunan Home and either go watch a movie in Chinatown or go walk around.  It was a nearly a weekly ritual.  I loved potstickers and chow mein and stuck with that just about every week.  The waiters all knew the family and it was cool to stop by.  At some point, we stopped coming to Hunan Home (and to Chinatown as much overall).  But I'm happy to see the place still open.  I may stop by again to see how the food is though!
author: Donald L.

description: I eat here for lunch all the time..quick service with delicious food.  They serve free hot and sour soup during lunch!!
author: Tung Sheng H.

description: No visit is complete in San Francisco without some authentic Chinese food.  Tried this place based on it's Yelp recommendation and enjoyed our meal.  Will definitely come back again.
author: Rainbow T.

description: This place was the bomb loved the soup. I will defiantly come back. The service was great the waiter was funny made us feel very welcome.
author: Sherrie R.

description:
FYI- they have no wait list system, you literally wait out side and a lady comes out and screams we have a table for 2!! And you raise your hand lol
Starter: fried wontons- SO good but for sure wish there was more meat packed in.. 
Main- orange peeled chicken holy crap this was the best orange chicken I've ever had (not spicy though even though it says it is) the chow main is regular chow main but they also give you complementary tea at your table- very delicious!
author: Sam B.

description:
I enjoyed every morsel of food here! 
Chicken and corn soup was lacking a tad bit of flavor, but add a bit of S&P and
Vinegar and you've got yourself gold! 
Pot stickers were amazing. ORANGE CHICKEN WAS EPIC! 

Best. Chinese. Food. Ever. 

PS it was late valentine's day  and the wait was only 20min!  

Will def come by any chance I get!
author: Maggie A.

description: Try the cashew chicken, kungpow deluxe, and sweet and sour chicken!
author: Joshua C.

description: Seated quickly, delivered refreshments promptly, about 12-15 min wait for our order or vegetable chow mein, honey walnut prawns, and Hunan chicken. Everything was delicious and fresh!
author: Mariah R.

description: Great prices, fast service and awesome tasting food! Would highly recommend this place!
author: Victoria K.

description: This is a crowded, no-nonsense Hunan restaurant. I was there with two of my best friends and none of us were too impressed with the food. Service is quick though, portions are huge and the pricing is not that bad. They are very considerate when asking how hot you want your dish - which is a good thing when trying certain type of food for the first time. Not overly-friendly staff, but efficient and polite. Bathrooms are very clean which is always a plus in a busy restaurant located in downtown SF.
author: Maria N.

description: Try the won ton soup! YUMMMMMMMM! And all their pork dishes are terrific, too. Go! It's delish!
author: lisa c.

description: My favorite restaurant in china town. Very cost effective. I usually order combination chow men or basil chicken.
author: Machiruda Y.

description: Typical American-Chinese food. It may not blow your mind but it's pretty good considering the price and location at the heart of Chinatown.
author: Max H.

description: Nice semi casual Chinese place in Chinatown with good food and low prices, large menu so ou can choose whatever, great appetizers
author: James F.

description:
** This food is so good it ruined me for other Chinese restaurants. **

OH MY GOD! This was an amazing experience. We got in at the right time, when they were not super busy, but I can see why the January 3rd reviewer complained. The place filled up fast after we got there. A friend was in from Chicago and I wanted to show him Chinatown. I asked Siri for a Chinese restaurant near me and this came up on a list and it had great reviews and two "$" out of four -- so not too expensive. We had to walk almost a mile but it was more than worth it. The staff is very friendly, the food has a delicate but full flavor, and the food came quickly (something like 8-12 minutes after our order). They even charged my iPhone (which had just died) so that I could take a picture. 

The place is small but clean, and I got a chance to go downstairs a few times and peek around the back a bit (they don't know this yet). It is very clean downstairs and well organized, but packed with fresh vegetables. I *highly recommend* anything on a sizzling skillet. The presentation is far beyond anything I have ever seen. They bring a super-heated iron skillet and place it down and immediately place "mostly cooked" food on it (99% cooked) and when the food his the skillet it sizzles and steams (for about 20 seconds) enough to fog your glasses. Everything was good, but I preferred the beef and chicken - both "softly flavored," not overly seasoned, but saturated with flavor, and extremely tender. Best of all it is off of the trolley (cable car) lines, so it is easy to get to. This will be my go to spot whenever I am in SF. I don't think they take reservations. You may call to find out.
author: Dusty W.

description: We ordered peking duck and we're very disappointed. We basically got less than half a duck with mostly skin and no meat! The other things we ordered - spicy string beans and spicy eggplant were pretty good and are the only reason why I am not giving them one star. (Also service was basically absent)
author: Ana N.

description: We ventured to Chinatown and stopped by for dinner. There was a line out the door and for good reasons - it was a great restaurant. We started with Hot and Sour Soup for two. This was a great starter and certainly plentiful for 2-3 adults. We then were served Pork Potstickers for an appetizer. Definitely homemade and delicious. For our main course, we went with the Orange-Peel Beef which was interestingly deep fried and had great flavor and King Pao Beef which was just okay. Not much flavor and beef pieces were chewy. All and all highly recommend for an organic experience. Cheers!
author: Samantha M.

description:
I was a bit skeptical walking in since there weren't many Chinese people there but it was a full house. After asking the waiter in Chinese what's good and hearing "there isn't anything traditional," I further demoralized. 

What redeemed the place was it's fried specialty bread (or "zha mon tau"). I think it was #5 on the menu. Their preparation of this dish was excellent and it came with some sweet condensed milk.

The potstickers were also pretty solid. The pea shoot leaves were done as well as most authentic Chinese places as well as the sautéed string beans. 

The kung pao chicken didn't have much of a kick and wasn't prepared in the traditional manner. The whole braised fish was only okay too.

So, as far as really good authentic Chinese food goes... it isn't amazing but as far as Westernized Chinese food gooes, I thought it was actually an okay choice. Nothing was bad, but nothing was mind blowing either.
author: Victor W.

description:
We came here during lunch hour, and only waited 10 minutes at most. Service was fast, with great food. Check out the lunch specials... comes with a lot of rice. The Orange Peel Chicken was delicious!

All of our food was very spicy, so be sure to get something besides the quickly served tea. Lemonade and sodas, etc. come from the can.

Fortune cookies and oranges are served at the end of your meal. My cookie tasted a little burnt, but that may have been my mouth still on fire.
author: Samuel T.

description:
After a long day of sightseeing we decided to get Chinese to take back to the hotel. I don't want to call it take out because this is a restaurant and it was packed! 
The food was good. But I gave it an overall 4 stars for several reasons. First, the place is so small that we had to wait on the street while the food was prepared. And maybe it wouldn't have been too bad if it wasn't trash day. Also, they were quite slow at seating people. We were told it would be about 15 min for our food to be ready...no big deal. However, when we went to check if it was ready we had to wait 10 min to get into the restaurant because two parties were waiting to be seated (a total of 5 people). There was no room to move.
Second, none of the dishes come with rice. You have to order it separately. Which is fine if you want white rice. That comes in a side dish size but fried rice only comes as a meal which wasn't explained to us. 
And finally, they didn't give us any fortune cookies. I know it isn't a big deal but it would have been nice to have. 
The serving sizes were good and we were full. My friend ordered the potstickers and cashew chicken with white rice and I ordered the egg rolls and lemon chicken with fried rice (which I explained came as meal size). And the price was reasonable.
author: Manuela D.

description:
This was my first Chinatown San Francisco experience and it was very tasty. Won ton soup was excellent as was the appetizer sampler. The sauce that comes with the sampler is to die for. 

Only negative was that we got a duplicate fortune with two identical fortune cookies...
author: Danielle U.

description: Did not seem authentic at all. Some of the least unique Chinese food I've tried, and I've lived in China for three years.
author: Suhel S.

description:
Super friendly! Feel very welcome here. 
We have now found a Restaurant that we will keep on coming back to as a family.
author: Sergio M.

description: I wife and I were here in February 2015 for lunch.  I had the Hunan beef and she had the cashew chicken.   We also had potstickers for an appetizer.  Good food, however, not the best Chinese I've ever had.
author: Two H.

description:
Decided to give this place a try based on this being one of the places reviewed on an episode of Check Please Bay Area.

On the basis of atmosphere, it's your what you'd expect from a good Chinese place, no frills but straight and to the point - the interior and fixtures probably have never been renovated (adding to the charm), it's quite busy, and the food comes comes out quickly and piping hot. I wouldn't say the service is "nice", but they are very efficient... accommodating your requests in good time despite the place being busy.

In comparison to other Chinese restaurants, their fare is a little more expensive (usually $2-3 more per entree than you'd find at some other places) but I don't mind this since the food is quality here. 

We were a party of 6 folks and were able to get a good sampling of some of their dishes: Mongolian Beef, Sweet & Sour Fish, Vegetable Fried Rice, Hot & Sour Soup, Orange Peel Beef, and Salt & Pepper Pork Spare Ribs. All were really tasty. The food was prepared well, the veggies tasted fresh, and wasn't overly oily or greasy.

We even needed some vegetarian accommodations, which they were more than happy to prepare for us. 

It's a pretty extensive menu (natch for a lot of Chinese places in general) so I'm sure if I return I'll probably get to have a meal without ordering anything I've already tried.

If I'm ever in Chinatown area again, I'll definitely come here for another visit.
author: Jeffrey J.

description: Everything we ordered was delicious and fresh tasting!  We had hot and sour soup, egg rolls, pot stickers, orange peel chicken, Hunan beef, and Bbq pork with shrimp fried rice!! We also found parking right across the st, free after 6pm!!
author: San M.

description:
Quite bad - we were really disappointed.  

We had the String Beans with Chicken and Honey Walnut Prawns.  Neither were fresh. The shrimp had not been cleaned (sandy, stringy, etc.), the chicken was chewy with little bone pieces and gristle throughout, and the overall flavor was "off"--as in spoiled. Their health score should have kept us away.

After enjoying many meals at their Mountain View location, we were expecting our dinner to be at least satisfying, but we could not eat it. 

In the future we'll opt for the tried and true; Z & Y Restaurant, Little Szechuan, or Henry's Hunan.  Even delivery from Wok Shop Cafe satisfies.  Even Panda Express.  We are just looking for some quality please.
author: Courtney D.

description: Best Chinese food!!  Not great Devore, but who cares when the food is so good. Totally worth it!!
author: Kathryn A.

description: The wait took a little longer than expected but well worth the wait. Food was very flavorful and delicious. Enjoyed everything we ordered. A little crowded inside could use expansion but hey sometimes the smaller places are the best ones .:)
author: misty o.

description: In the heart of China Town, this little spot is great across options for date night to large group gatherings. The options are plentiful, and the overall quality of food is tasty and fresh! The service is prompt and efficient. Portions are great for sharing and I would highly suggest choosing this spot for tasty Chinese food.
author: Rebecky L.

description: The hostess for the restaurant was incredibly direct. When you enter she immediately directs her eyes towards you and says "there!" A bit rude but I can deal with that. I ordered the egg drop soup and it was a twist from what I'm used to. I really enjoyed it and would give it an 8/10. The Mapo tofu I ordered for my entree on the other hand was very synthetic and tasted unnatural. Without the rice I probably wouldn't have been able to finish the dish.
author: David N.

description: Don't understand the hype. Tastes like the same sysco-nese food I can get anywhere.
author: Nick S.

description: Not sure how this place has 4 out of 5 stars. Wasn't impressed at all. Would compare food quality to that of Panda Express. Food was very salty and not fresh. Used the restrooms downstairs and kitchen was filthy dirty as were the restrooms. Steer clear of the mongolian beef and assorted vegetables. The sweet and sour chicken was decent at best. Wouldn't recommend this place to anyone.
author: Drew A.

description: The good is absolutely delicious, and the service was great and quick! Well be my go to spot every time I come to SF!
author: Adriana M.

description: The service was terrible . The waiter asked once what we wanted to eat , and didnt let me have a chance to order a drink. He didn't show up again until he gave us the check. I would rate the food from 1-10 a 5. The kung pao chicken is not spicy and flavorless. The beef chowmein was not fully cooked. The only employee i saw with a smile was the cashier everyone else had an attitude. First and last time i eat there!!
author: Michael A.

description: When we arrived there was a wait outside.  We waited 30 minutes, just like we were told.  Service was fast and friendly.  Food was tasty and arrived quick. Good portions! More than you can eat!
author: Martha P.

description: Other than the dumplings, the meal was disappointing. Pretty flavorless. We expected a lot better for such a highly rated restaurant in Chinatown in San Francisco. Wasn't even worth taking the leftovers to go.
author: Amelia C.

description:
These people are lucky that I am giving them one star. The service was soooo horrible. The host was rude and one waiter was picking on his pimple as he was serving without washing his hand. Ewww!!!
We had to ask for water and he didn't even acknowledge us. All the staffs looked miserable and looked like they didn't want to be working. 
As per food, prices were somewhat high and the portions were very small. Super Americanized Chinese food. Not GOOD AT ALL. Coming to San francisco's Chinatown, I had high expectations but I totally felt ripped off. 
I really don't understand why this place has 4 stars?!?!?!
AWFUL PLACE TO EAT. DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY GOING HERE!!!!
author: Judy T.

description: Service was pretty bad. My family's originally from hunan, so we thought we could get some authentic chinese food here, but when my mom asked our waiter if there was any authentic food, he curtly replied with a "no" and left. The food was kind of pricey and not too great either, and everyone was really rushed
author: Alan L.

description:
While visiting the city, we did a quick search and found this place. The reviews were good so we decided to chance it. 

One word - AMAZING! 

We ordered the egg flower soup, chicken fried rice, chicken with spicy garlic sauce and shrimp with honey walnut. 

The egg flower soup was probably the best we've ever had. It was full of flavor but simply done - no corn or other things. It was just really, really egg flower soup. 

The chicken fried rice was also the best we've had. It was deceptively bland-looking but the first bite was loaded with flavor. And it didn't get greasy as the meal went on. I could have been satisfied with just the soup and rice!

The chicken with spicy garlic was also fantastic. It was the right amount of flavoring and it wasn't really "spicy". But I like my food spicy so it might be spicy to others. 

I've already recommended this place to my family. And I'm hoping to stop back in before I leave the city. Truly amazing!!
author: Grace M.

description:
There's a fish tank upon walking through the door featuring may exotic fish. Above the fish tank are printouts describing the fish along with how big a tank they require. Ironically, the tank is not big enough for any of them, let along all of them. Strike one.

The ambience is that of a standard hole-in-the-wall, 'fancy' Chinatown restaurant; fluorescent lights dominate. The fare is also standard, with the exception of the Hunan Chicken - I do not know what happened, but this dish was devoid of flavor except for a vague smoky taste. The price also seemed just a little steep. Not a lot, but enough to notice.

And again, that fish tank...
author: Patrick O.

description: Came here for the Peking duck because of the Yelp ratings for this place. Front of the house service was pathetic. Couldn't care less apparently to serve customers. Waitstaff same lackluster quality. Peking duck can't be ordered without placing an advance order with the restaurant. Two stars is generous.
author: Jeff A.

description: The worst Chinese food I had here.  This is not Hunan food at all.  It can't be called Chinese food.  I'm a Chinese, I never have had this kind of food in China, special use a local province as a restaurant name, but it's not Hunan food! Ridiculous!
author: Littlehouse F.

description: From what I've had so far, this is definitely one of the better Chinese restaurants out here. Food flavor is really good. I haven't tried a lot of their dishes, but definitely crave the hot and sour and the spicy garlic chicken. Just looking at the pics on yelp for this place is making me hungry and wanting to pay a visit.
author: Ali H.

description: We were waiting in line for an hour and found out that they actually had at least five empty tables in the restaurant. They just don't let customers in. Very inconsiderate.
author: Jin J.

description: The service was terrible which in my mind ruins a dinner. Our waiter never bused our table which was a small,one for two.  Our plates from appetizers and soup just piled up.  We had to put a beer bottle on the floor.  Our waiter was bored and acted like he was doing us a favor.  Such a different experience from other dinners where we have had great service. Based on that we would not return as there are many choices.  R & G was a better time.
author: Karen H.

description: Don't be fooled by their rating. They drown their food is sauces, msg and not to mention that much of their meat tastes funky. We had a table for 5 and all orders were grossly undercooked and it seems like they mask it with sauce.
author: Pavel N.

description: Found this on Yelp and decided to try it. Turned out to be a good choice. We ordered Wor wonton Soup, Hot Spice Crispy Chicken, Fried Rice, Xiao Long Bao. Hot Spice Crispy Chicken was great. A twist on the regular fried chicken but better. A must try. I like the crunchiness and the spiciness of the chicken. It was juicy to the bite. Xiao Long Bao was not as great as I was hoping for. It came a bit cold. I've tasted better. Wor Wonton Soup was good. The small size was good enough for three and it was a good starter. I'll still return and try the other items on their menu. It's a good find.
author: L D.

description:
Came here for lunch, definitely enjoyed the meal. Enjoyed the complimentary tea very much, very hot! Ordered the Chicken Chow Mein, and although it was a little bland, adding some sauce from the table flavored it up nicely. The hot and sour soup which came with lunch was also delicious. The egg rolls: delicious.

Prices were very reasonable. One soft drink, egg roll appetizer, and the bill for three people was under $35, not including tip. One hint: soft drinks do not appear to come with free refills, as they bring out a can and a glass of ice.
author: Tim S.

description: We got duped into thinking this was 4 stars. The xiaolong bao was not cooked properly... The skin was raw and there was barely any broth. We ordered other dishes but they were greasy and didn't have any flavors u would expect. The menu was a typical americanized Chinese menu...Sd have listened to my gut when I saw that and walk away
author: N K.

description: We decided to give this place a try after reading the reviews on yelp.  We were excited to try some authentic Chinese food in Chinatown, we were very disappointed.  We can get better Chinese food in our small town in Oregon.  Unfriendly staff and bad food made this an unpleasant experience.
author: Wendy F.

description: Absolutely suck food! I travelled across United States with my bf this summer. This was the worst restaurant I dining. Their food was disappointing and expensive, bad service as well.
author: Yanyan F.

description: Great Chinese food! Portions were a little on the small side, and service was not the greatest, but the FLAVOR was amazing. Would definitely go back here for dinner...also great for large groups!
author: Elise K.

description:
green tea to begin was awesome!


I started with Won Ton soup was outstanding and then went on to have Mongolian Beef which is one of my favorites. It was so good. Great texture and flavor.

I also ate some of my neighbors orange chicken which was also very good but not as good as my Mongolian Beef!

Enjoy. You really cant go wrong here.
author: Steven W.

description: Wonderful service, calm, quiet lunch environment and the food was delicious and plentiful.  This is my first time and I brought out of town guests...I will do it again.
author: Maura C.

description:
I just got out of a meeting and didn't really enjoy my tacos so my buddy and I decided to meet up for some late night grub.  Unfortunately much of the good stuff in SOMA was already closed so we decided to walk the 2 miles to Chinatown to find some of the good stuff.  We stumbled upon Hunan Homes and my buddy heard some good stuff so we dropped in for some yumminess.

They've got a huge menu here but we ended up deciding to order the honey walnut prawns and orange peel chicken.  The prices were a little above average for Chinatown and the portion sizes were tiny for just about anywhere, but the flavors were there.  Service was pretty good but I think they might have wanted to close up because they pulled my plate away before I was done eating.  Definitely wasn't cool with that move and affected their otherwise good tip.

The package was decent here but nothing I'd want over 2 miles in each direction for in the future.  The restaurant is completely pink and just felt kinda weird to eat in.  The food is the best part about this place but wasn't up to the standards of places like the clay pot restaurant down the street.  I'd probably find something more interesting for the money next time.

Food: 7/10

Service: 6/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 6/10
author: Joe M.

description: Generous servings. Multiple  tasty lunch special choices.  Clean   Nice decor. Tables spaced so business lunches can be heard and quiet discussions can be private. Happened in to this place while visiting the city- had heard that locals like it.  Prices were moderate and the portion sizes were generous .
author: Jay S.

description: Yum!  We wandered around Chinatown for a bit and one shop looked a lot like another.  For some reason, my wife picked this one.  She had the Hunan scallops and I had the Hunan chicken.  Great choice for dinner.
author: Rick H.

description:
So far this place has hot & sour soup ever! Having lived in Miami for the last few years my taste buds may be slightly off and less judgmental given the lack of good Chinese food in that area, but this one was PERFECT. My search for that is enough to give 5 stars! 
We also had the Mu Shu pork which was delicious and the chicken with black mushroom. Both are highly recommended. I also greatly enjoyed the service.
author: Marina B.

description: Excellent Potstickers, succulent beef with onions and bell pepper, tasty and fresh seafood chow mein. Overall, great service and price is reasonable
author: Inda C.

description: Found this place on Yelp while in Chinatown in San Francisco.  This place is fabulous. Food was awesome.  I ordered the Mongolian Beef and Honey Walnut Prawns with white rice and it was all fresh and tasted amazing.
author: Brooklyn R.

description: After reading the great reviews here on Yelp, I had to come try this place for myself.  I was hoping for super rad Szechuan-like kung pao chicken, but this was just ok.  The best things about this place was the ice cold Tsing-Dao served in an official Tsing-Dao glass and the complimentary soup that came before the meal.   Well that, and the cheap lunch prices.  While Hunan Home's was not as great as I was hoping for, it was still pretty good.  I'm kind of a Kung Pao chicken snob, what can I say?
author: Jason G.

description: Amazing food, great service.  Even my kids (who are extremely picky) loved it!  Lots of choices here in Chinatown, but this spot lived up to the hype.
author: Reece K.

description:
Living in Miami we have horrible Chinese food, thus when travelling especially in SF or NYC I'm on a quest to find good asian cuisines. I found this place via Yelp, and I really enjoy hot and sour, along with very spicy foods. This fit the bill.

I went solo after flying for many hours, and was quickly seated for dinner. I ended up ordering a bowl (they are really for 2) of hot and sour soup. The soup was awesome with a good amount of spiciness, and lots of tang, along the lines of citrus, it was very tasty. I also ordered some mongolian beef as that sounded good, it was pretty good as well, decent amount of heat (I still added a lot of hot sauce) and good taste. It was not to sweet. Overall it was a great meal, and I give this my stamp of approval!
author: Jonah K.

description:
I love Hunan style food and these guys serve it up right! The best hot and sour soup I have ever had outside of my kitchen, great kung pao chicken, and spicy chicken with green beans. A special dish was the spicy sauce wontons which were just damn good, loved the sauce!

Spicy, tasty good eats, my new fav in SF Chinatown.
author: Christopher Steven O.

description: It's ok chinese food.  I've been here several times and I'm always satisfied, but not very impressed.  They've got lots of variety but don't do anything particularly well.  Their xiao long bao have fairly thick dough and were dried out a bit when we got them and other meat and veggie dishes were quite pricey at over $10 each.  Try to go across the street to Z&Y, which I like much better.
author: Phil D.

description: The spicy won ton soup was AMAZING! The rest of the food was pretty good as well....the service...left much to be desired. I left 4 stars because the food was tasty and NOT because anyone that worked there seemed remotely like they like people. We would go back expecting to be treated like they don't want any customers but their food tells a different story, lol.
author: Nicolle S.

description: This place is now one of my favorite Chinese restaurants in San Francisco. Prior to this, I've tried many Chinese restaurants in Chinatown and in the inner Richmond area (aka. Second Chinatown in San Francisco), but have not been impressed by too many. I've seen people lined up to get into this restaurant but I never had the desire to wait in line when there are so many other options on the same street.  Last weekend, it was pouring outside and we were in Chinatown looking for a place to eat at 5pm.  I was in the mood to have some Taiwanese food, so I searched on Yelp for options. This place popped up with the highest rating, and the photos looked enticing, so we decided to give it a shot. Luckily, at 5pm, there was no line, but still busy- we managed to get the last available table when we arrived. They did not have Taiwan beer (sad...) even though it was on the drink menu, but that was really the only disappointment. The waiter was efficient but not super friendly, probably because they are always busy and wanted to customers in and out quickly. We ordered the hot and sour soup (highly recommend by other Yelpers), and my husband said it was the best H&S soup he has ever had! We also ordered the soup dumplings (aka. Xiao Long Bao), also one of the best I have ever tried outside of Asia. I ordered Tai Chin chicken for my main course, which was delicious with a spicy kick. Overall, it was a five-star dining experience for us! The only downside is that it's not ideal for a nice leisurely meal because it's so popular, that there's a small pressure to eat quickly and get out quickly, so others waiting in line can get in and enjoy the delicious food too.
author: Sarah W.

description: I felt happier when I was hungry. Genuinely upset. Absolutely everything tasted really bad. Painful for the palate. If you value your happiness, don't go there.
author: Shulin T.

description:
We got seated and had menus in hand in less than one minutes after entering the door. Hot tea served in three minutes. The waiter took our order in less than five and seven minutes after entering the door, hot soup was on the table. The friendly staff got right to the business of serving hot, fresh and certainly tasty Chinese foods. Sweet and sour chicken was awesome.
MooSoo pork, server assembled first two pancakes. Lunch specials come with huge scoop of white rice.  Fried rice needed soy sauce for my taste, so I added. Pop came in cans. Check comes with fortune coockies and sliced oranges.
author: Brandon L.

description: Food was amazing an reasonably priced. Service was friendly. My only complaint was service was a little slow, but I'd wholeheartedly recommend checking it out.
author: Dan G.

description: The food tasted like it would appeal to an American crowd. I was raised in a Chinese household with very legitimate Chinese dishes and I was fairly disappointed with my meal. The price is decent, but I wouldn't come back for the food.
author: Connie S.

description: The food was amazing.. The best Chinese food I have ever had in my live and all my party of 7 said the same .. One comment: the waiter was very rude.
author: Aboud J.

description: Food was ok, it tasted like any other chinese restaurant. But the waiters are what made me give 2 star, specially the lady (wish i got her name). She was rude from the begining. Everytine i asked for something she would respond with an attitude and her demeanor towards us was awful. I felt we were not wanted there, it may have been because we had our children with us but they were so well behaved. I felt rushed. Couldnt wait to eat my food and get the heck out of there
author: Zoey E.

description: The Sweet and Sour soup, the Wonton soup and mushu pork was amazing! Will definitely be back!
author: Miki O.

description:
Hot and sour soup. This was really tasty. 
Orange peel chicken. Kinda plain and the orange peel was a slice of orange and thats it. 
Soup dumplings. Good but meh. 

Price was decent and right next to Hilton hotel.
author: Eric S.

description: Really loved the cashew chicken, very moist chicken and wonderful vegy, just right! Our son devoured the full plate of chicken fried rice. Sweet and sour pork was very good - not full of fried batter - just a perfect light coating that did not interfere with the pork. Fabulous staff. Will definitely eat here again  next time in SF.
author: Janette N.

description:
We went here on Christmas day and it took about 20 minutes to get a table.  Not a bad wait!  We ordered the combo patter for the appetizer.  It was good.  

We had the hot and sour soup.  It was very peppery.  Be prepared.  

Our entrees were sweet and sour chicken - very good; kung pao squid - good; shrimp fried rice - good; mongolian beef - not good at all.  The mongolian been was not your typical mongolian beef - it was very spicy and hot, not sweet like I have always had.  I ordered a different dish because it was so bad.  So I ordered the orange chicken and it completely redeemed the night.  That dish is amazing!  Order the orange chicken if you go to this place.

The service was great.  The manager (or owner maybe?) was really nice and happy to help us since it was busy.  

We will definitely go back.

Oh - the bathrooms are very, very gross.  Beware.
author: Yvonne M.

description: We had an incredible meal here on a rainy Saturday night wandering through Chinatown. The sizzling shrimp is one of the best Chinese dishes I've ever had, and the green beans with minced pork was also incredible. It will be hard to eat anywhere else the next time we're in Chinatown.
author: Andrew S.

description: Very good food and our waiter was so much fun! All of the food was served with panache, I really appreciated our servers sense of humor. It's a popular place on a Friday night so be sure to make a reservation.
author: Kathleen K.

description: One of our longtime favorites to visit when coming to San Francisco. Peking duck - an absolute must, but must be preordered a day in advance. Delicious, friendly, in midst of China town. A jewel we became aware of by shear coincidence a couple years ago when asking locals for recommendations.
author: Andreas K.

description:
My husband and I got egg rolls and pot stickers, a small wonton soup, rice,  chicken with garlic sauce and kun paw deluxe, and some hot sake. We paid $52 before tip, which I consider a very good price. They also serve you tea (can't tell if it was jasmine or green). I would definitely go back for the delicious pot stickers and the garlic chicken. Also wonton soup was very decent. The kun paw deluxe was such a disappointment. I could just taste old frying oil in it! The stairs and the corners are a little dirty too. At the table next to ours an older lady was receiving what I hoped was an ear massage from another woman for about 15 minutes, which I just didn't want to see during my meal.
I wish I could give them 5 stars for the prices and the food, but that kun paw deluxe was a total bummer.
author: Tajka W.

description: Good place to have Chinese food. Not very traditional but American style. I like the crispy duck, tasty.
author: Shuo Y.

description: We came up from Los Angeles for a weekend trip in San Francisco. We had to visit Chinatown at least once. This place had good reviews on yelp. We have lots of good Chinese food in Los Angeles. In particular we like the dumplings at Din Tai Fung.  We were looking for good dumplings for dinner.  This place did not disappoint.  We had the pork dumplings which were great. We also had their beef chow mein, orange peel chicken, Kung pau shrimp, potstickers and the hot and sour soup.  Everything was fantastic.  Parking is crazy here so you're better off coming by Uber.  The male hostess was also very funny and welcoming.  Would definitely come back the next time we return to this town.
author: Robert L.

description:
So after we did the hellacious hike from Fisherman's Wharf to Lombard St. then back we had worked up another appetite... PLEASE did you ever doubt we would??? =}

Toya was on a quest for Custard Egg Tarts from Golden Gate Bakery http://www.yelp.com/biz/golden-gate-bakery-san-francisco#query:egg%20custart%20tarts unbeknowst to us (and about 4 other people we ran into) they were closed for Vacation. That was our main reason for waltzing through Chinatown LOL but not to be thwarted we decided to have dinner here before heading back to Cambria.

Food was pretty good. I ordered BBQ Spareribs 
WHAT? yea I know... I'm black SO WHAT? it's not like I asked for Watemelon to go along side of it HA! tehehehehe they were prepared with a honey glaze that was most scrumptious. The Wonton Soup, Potstickers, Xiao Long Bao, fried rice and the Jasmine Tea were all winners. Service was nice and friendly.

BTW they do not allow more than 2 credit cards on a seperate check transaction so KNOW this ahead of time and plan accordingly when arriiving with a large party.

Respectfully Reviewed
author: Pam S.

description:
After reading Yelp reviews and asking at hotel we came here. While didn't have reservation we were seated in 5 minutes. The service initially was a tad slow but then it picked up and was good. 

Kung Pao shrimp really good as was wonton soup. Sizzling shrimp is great too. Would come back.
author: Jeff N.

description: Delicious Chinese food for reasonable price but don't expect great service our waiter was very rude and almost like bothered to serve us
author: Viri L.

description:
Hunan Homes is a typical Chinese restaurant for tourists.  I came here because of the reviews .  I went against my first rule of eating...go where the locals go.  If you go here,  look around... No locals.

Food:  Like I said if you like Main Street USA Chinese food, this is the place for you.

Here is what we ordered:

Hot and sour soup- it tastes pretty good but is loaded with MSG.  I mean arms tingling head rush quantities.

Pot stickers - very good

Pork fried rice - ok

Sesame chicken an sweet and sour chicken - if you like loads of sticky sweet sauce, you will like this

Hunan scallops - they were over cooked 

Crab in black bean sauce - very tasty (it does cost $35)

Beef chow mein - very good

Orange peel beef - good

Service - I see some of the reviewers mention the humor and personality of their waiter.  My experience was different.  My waiter took our order with a total poker face.  No welcome, no recommendations, nothing.    To be fair he was bussing tables, washing glasses, and waiting tables.  He barely had time to breathe.  He was set up to not be able to provide good service.  

Would I go back?  Probably not.  As I walked around Chinatown I saw a couple of restaurants with lines of locals.  Those are the places I will go to next time.
author: Scot D.

description:
I have never been steered wrong by yelp....until now.  I was surprised by the quantity of high reviews for this restaurant. Even though I am a vegetarian (who does eat chicken broth with no chicken), I love Chinese food.  I have many favorite tasty and delicious Chinese restaurants that I frequent in the Chicago area. At Hunan Home's Restaurant, we ordered the following:

Egg Flower Soup- The soup was a thin broth that has a very pungent chicken taste-- too chickeny for my taste.

Hunan Tofu Veggie Dish- Blah. Not tasty in the least bit. Even though it was under the vegetable section, the sauce tasted like pork without the pork. The tofu was bland and the veggies were not anything special. 

Vegetable Fried Rice- Bland with no taste.

White Rice- Starchy and dry 

Overall, I was turned off by the experience.
author: Debbie M.

description: We were seated promptly upon arrival by courteous staff. The menu had good variety and the kitchen was able to cook my meal in something other than oyster sauce due to an allergy. The food was served quickly and was delicious. Our waiting staff was attentive and hospitable.
author: Erin J.

description: The orange peel beef is so good!! I'm on my lunch break and it took them about 5 minutes get it ready. Very friendly fast service.
author: Ericka C.

description: Hidden gem of Chinatown.  Had lunch there with in laws, everyone in our party enjoyed the food especially the orange peel chicken.  The owner came by to offer us a few tips on the red hot chili peppers, you'll have to ask him--definitely worth finding out.  The lady who took out order was nice and polite.  I'd definitely bring my out of town guests back ...
author: Rob D.

description: I had the sweet and sour chicken and it was the best I have ever had. The chicken is great quality. I tried the chinese beer and thought it was like bud light. The place was busy on a Sunday night but we did not have a problem getting a table when we walked in. I would go back here again.
author: Laura N.

description: Very very good food. I have tried the orange chicken. A bit of a wait to get a table (5pm - around 15-20minutes). Not extremely friendly the waitress which would be my only negative point. You can take home whatever you have not finished. Very easy to find. They don't take reservations.
author: Mara C.

description: It was ok, acceptable service, small portions for sure. Flavor was ok, but nothing special. Fairly clean place. With all the other options available, I have no interest in going back.
author: Cory G.

description: Everything was delicious and so filling. We got chicken with orange peel, shrimp fried rice, chicken with spicy garlic sauce, egg flower soup, and egg rolls, all super tasty. The owner/manager was also really funny, which we enjoyed.
author: Kayla P.

description: Got the curry chicken... didnt have curry flavor, it was just some thick, yellow sauce. Felt sick afterwards, spent like 15 minutes in the bathroom to clear out my poor stomach.
author: Simon C.

description: Went here last week after I took a trip to alcatraz. It was around a 20 minute walk from the pier. The food was unreal!!! Kind of small portions for family style but flavor made up for it and more. We got the orange peel chicken, deluxe kung pao, and pork chow mein.
