All were probably the best renditions of those dishes ive had. The hot and sour soup was amazing too! The waiter was hilarious but in a subtle way that made you believe he was almost serious. Gotta appreciate that. He was very accommodating and found a place to charge my cell phone. Will be coming back next time I'm in the area!
author: Dean C.

description: Mongolian beef made with quality pieces of meat. Non greasy, fresh veggies in all dishes. Food came out fast and service was great. No complaints
author: Erik A.

description: Great hunan pork! Spicy just like I asked. Place was filled with Asians so I knew it had to be good!
author: Mike M.

description: Straight up good and tasty Chinese food.  Not the hottest, not the most expensive, but absolutely delicious.  I am a repeat customer and have reccomended this to many friends who always have good experiences.
author: Maxwell R.

description: What a nice place!!! While visiting San Francisco we knew we wanted Chinese food in Chinatown and we just stumbled upon this little gem based on the good reviews. The service was so nice and either the manager or owner kept coming to our table checking up on us, telling us what everything was and even cracking some jokes. They have amazing specials on the menu based on how many people are in your party. They give you just enough food (actually more than we could handle--we had some doggie bags) for low prices. Pretty, cozy ambience too. Would love to return.
author: Gina A.

description: This is the best sweet n sour chicken I've ever had! The outside is only lightly coated so it was still nice and crispy and not too doughy . The hot and sour soup was very good and chunky with the perfect amount of spice. The other dishes were wonderful and the pot stickers! Yummy I definitely recommend this place. The owner or manager is a little abrasive at first but everything was quick and once she stopped for a second to talk she was nice good entertainment! I will be back here for sure!
author: Karli S.

description: It was our first time visiting this place. We went there based on the yelp ratings. XLB - was just okay, same for the chicken fried rice. Chicken and orange peel, as well as their hot and sour soup were good. The vegetable pot sticker was underwhelming. Service was a combination of okay at the beginning and rude towards the end where they started rushing us to leave and took away some of the dishes which we were still having - since there were more ppl dropping in. I wouldn't go back.
author: I Love Good Foo D.

description: Stopped in here for dinner, it was crowded but got seated with in 5 minutes. I had the won ton soup which was delicious, the broth wasn't to salt and the wonton was nice and tender. For my entree, I had the crispy spicy chicken, it was a generous portion I ended up wrapping half of it up. Some of the chicken is left on the bone, I'd prefer it all boneless but it was nice and tender, the sauce wasn't extremely spicy it had some heat but not mouth scorching. The price was pretty good $12 for the entree and about $5 for the soup that is split between 2-3 people.
author: Amanda C.

description: I have to give this restaurant a 2 star rating just on the experience alone. I looked to Yelp to find a good place in Chinatown and came to Hunan. Recommendation: make a reservation if you want to eat here. The hostess did not even write my name down on the waiting list - just told me 1 hour wait and walked away. She proceeded to have a yelling match with another employee in front of me- so we just left. The guests waiting outside told me they all had reservations. We walked across the street and had an excellent meal that was greated with a smile.
author: Janina M.

description:
Came here looking for authentic spicy Chinese food, and got a tasty meal but nothing spectacular. We ordered Orange Peel Beef, but it was very breaded and kind of reminiscent of Americanized Orange Chicken (compared to a more authentic version we've had at another restaurant). The Four Seasons String Beans we ordered were flavorful with a hint of spiciness, so those were good. But was slightly disappointed that they used firm tofu for their MaPo Tofu, because usually the tofu is supposed to be softer/silkier.

Nevertheless, the service and prices were good!
author: Audrey G.

description: We had a great experience. We went on Tuesday night and had to wait about 20 minutes for a table. Buy, it was definitely worth the wait. We had Sweet and sour soup to start, served family style. Pot stickers, Chicken and Orange Peel, Mu Shu Shrimp and fried rice.  The service was quick and the Beer was cold. Everything was excellent.
author: Rob F.

description:
Went at 2:15 on a Friday and the place was packed but only had to wait about 5 minutes for a table for two. 
We had the Hunan String Beans and the Orange Chicken. The beans were excellent and the orange chicken was good too.
I wanted to take an order of the beans to go they were so good but definitely order a protein as well as the mined pork is really just for flavor. My husband and I shared the two meals and it was perfect.
The service was good and the food was relatively quick. 
When we left there was a line out the sidewalk at 2:40!
I would definitely recommend this to anyone venturing into Chinatown and I hope to find the Hunan beans back in Florida!
author: Jaclyn T.

description:
This is my go-to Chinese place in San Francisco. I was feeling very underwhelmed by the places I tried in Chinatown until I was introduced to Hunan Homes and I will no longer go anywhere else. Everything I have ordered is always absolutely delicious and I'm never disappointed.
 
I always start with the fried dumplings, but make sure the guy gives you the sauce beforehand. The best dishes are the garlic eggplant, shrimp and string beans, and sizzling beef or chicken. I also sometimes get the mushu, kungpao chicken, lemon chicken, and beef fried rice. Honestly - you can't go wrong.

.... I think I'm going to go for dinner tonight!
author: Marcy M.

description: Always on lookout for good Wonton noodle soup.  This seems like a place that would have authentic chinese food but the soup was disappointing.
author: Lianna T.

description: We were visiting San Francisco and looking for some good Chinese food.  Hunan Home's did not disappoint. All our food was fresh and delicious. The service was great as well!
author: Steve R.

description:
If you're wondering why I gave four stars, see the bottom. 

I came with my parents and my brother on vacation. We got the Kung Pao and Hunan chicken and a beef dish whose name I can't remember (it came out on a sizzling plate with onions). Everything was perfectly cooked yet tender, and it had the right amount of spice in it. The won ton soup was nice, too. 

If you live in SF, I don't know how it compares to some of the other places, but if you're from out of town and looking for good food in Chinatown, this is the place, especially if you're coming from a place where it's hard to get Chinese that isn't super greasy or undercooked. (It's got a great location, too, if you're staying in an area like Union Square.)

Four stars because we sat in the basement and at one point, a staff member went to go smoke, but he either didn't step far enough outside or didn't go outside at all, because the whole room smelled like cigarettes for a few minutes.
author: Peter C.

description: I've been to the place only once so far. Ordered sizzling beef and it was really great. Probably will be there again.
author: Koutcherouk H.

description: Not impressed at all!  Barely greeted at the door. Left to wait to sit in spite of several open tables.  Took 10 minutes for a server to make contact and she was rude and dismissive.  When our food finally came, they served half the table, forgetting two of the main entrées. We had to ask before anyone even realized and table mates were completely finished eating before the missing entrées arrived. No compensation!
author: Dee H.

description:
I set up a lunch for my boyfriend and our families here. We arrived early - around 11:20am to ensure we'd get a table for 10. One of the hostesses was very accommodating and asked if we'd like to wait inside while everyone showed up. I appreciated the gesture however I thought she could've been a little bit more warm and welcoming.

It took a few calls to the waiter to get our orders placed. We tried several dishes; the hot and sour soup, hunan chicken, mongolian beef, honey walnut shrimp, etc. I thought the food was tasty but for the price, I thought the portions could've been bigger. 

Overall, our experience was decent and we left with full stomachs. The reason I give this place only 3 stars is due to the mediocre service and portions.
author: Jamie B.

description:
It just shows to go you, you can't trust Yelp for Chinese food recs.  I think if you're far from a Chinatown, this place might seem like a treat- steamed fish, dou miao, xiao long bao.  

But around here? Not so impressive.  

Things weren't really that fresh- the Chinese broccoli was a bit long in the tooth, the shrimp had been flown from Thailand after a detour to Australia, said steamed fish spent too much time in the spa.

Nice wait staff tho'!  And toddler-friendly.  

Tourist fare.  Sigh.
author: T W.

description: Love Hunan Homes. Dearly wish that the local one (Mountain View) delivered (whimper).
author: nora r.

description:
Smells clean as soon as you walk in. There is a welcoming feeling, with tons of options to eat!
Highly recommended to anyone looking for true Asian western cuisine
author: Jason W.

description: Will definitely be back here next time I'm in San Francisco. Eating here was an experience and the food was out of this world!
author: Jeanne A.

description:
- Reasonable prices for a lot of food. Plan to share. Tea  and water are served when you sit down. Of the bean curd and beef that I tasted, I doubt anything here is mind-blowing, but it's alls pretty enjoyable.

- Service is friendly. I appreciated that our server wore a tux and bow tie even if it's kind of kitschy.

- Decor could be improved. It looks your are outside in a Chinese neighborhood due to a roof decoration. Large mirrors just beneath create the illusion of a lot of space. Glass chandeliers hang from the ceiling. Seats are a mix of large tables, small tables, and diner booths.

- Chopsticks are plastic and surprisingly difficult to wield, which is frustrating.

- There are multiple bathrooms for men and women in the back.
author: Ceasar B.

description: Wow, wow, wow! We walked into this place after getting tired of waiting to get some dim sum and I think this was the best choice we have made all day. We had the xiao long bao as an appetizer which went quick. Then we all shared a Peking duck, which was excellent. Crispy, soft, and flavorful! We used their "pancakes" which is like a tortilla to eat the duck. They didn't have bao's here. The sweet and sour spare ribs were delicious, and so was our fried rice. We will definitely be recommending this to all of our friends.
author: Tyler C.

description: great food great service. i recommend going with a group and trying a. inch of stuff. the owners are very nice and accommodating. very authentic and a great find.
author: Erica R.

description: Possibly the most average Chinese food I have ever had. You won't find anything on the menu here you can't get at your local Chinese place. I have no idea why the reviews are good here. The fried rice was lacking any flavor and the Hunan chicken was surrounded by cheap vegetables you could barely find the chicken. The service is also terrible. They are cold and inattentive unless you are ready to leave. The interior of the restaurant needs an update. It is old and gross. I've seen many clearer floors in my life.
author: Mara T.

description: My boyfriend and I recently took a trip to San Francisco, and we decided to explore Chinatown. We wanted dinner, and so we found this place on Yelp and thought we'd give it a try due to its pretty awesome reviews. We got the food to go and ate it back at the hotel. Unfortunately, the food was far from awesome. The orange chicken was dry, my boyfriend was not happy with the duck, and we found a hair that was DEFINITELY not ours in the fried rice. I'd think twice about going to this place if I were you.
author: Sarah Y.

description: Food was great and was quick out of the kitchen. Highly recommend the orange peel chicken. Will definitely return next trip to San Francisco.
author: Michael H.

description:
Very good chinese food with a family-friendly atmosphere.  The mushroom soup and pork pot stickers were both very well done.  The mongolian beef stuck out for being particularly flavorful, and the shrimp in the shrimp fried rice tasted very fresh (a very welcome surprise and departure from most popcorn-shrimp served elsewhere with rice).  

The owner was very friendly and came by twice to tell a couple jokes and make sure we were doing ok.  The atmosphere could use some individualizing as it's pretty generic right now, but overall, a good place that I would go back to.
author: Jesse F.

description: The food was great! No problems with that.  However, the service is terrible. Very rude and not planning on dealing with this restaurant again
author: Jon O.

description: Some of the best Chinese food I've ever had. Their soup dumplings and orange chicken were like flavor explosions in your mouth. I would absolutely recommend to anyone in the San Francisco area. Great prices too. Me and my 2 friends got a few things and split them. Left raving about how good everything was and so stuffed.
author: Andi P.

description:
Chinatown is just full of little surprises like Hunan Home's Restaurant. I stopped by after a long day biking through the city, and was hoping to find some authentic Chinese food, free from too much western influence. 

The waitress was friendly, and had great suggestions when we found out that the fish we wanted was unavailable. We ended up ordering the Xiao Long Bao, sizzling beef, Hunan sauteed Pork and rice.

The Xiao Long Bao were amazing - the skin was just the right thickness and the dumpling was filled with hot juice. It takes some real skill to cook these dumplings correctly to get the right richness of flavor, and Hunan Home's got it spot on.

The sizzling beef and the pork were equally great, and the rice had a fluffiness that reminded me of home. The entire meal ended up only costing ~$20 each! For that much food, I expected a lot more.

Bookmarked. Will be back.
author: Dennis R.

description: Old school. Best Hot N Sour I have ever had. In the belly of the China-Town beast. Friendly staff with great recommendations of house specialties.
author: Chad B.

description: Great Chinese in the heart of Chinatown, but not fancy. So if you're looking for "chef" Chinese go elsewhere. But food and service were very good relative to value. We'll definitely go back
author: Scott K.

description:
MSG in their hot and sour soup. I'm quite reactive to MSG, as in my cheeks start feeling inflamed. Not a pleasant feeling. No Chinese restaurant that uses MSG deserves four stars on Yelp. 

The other dishes we ordered included: 
:: Shanghai dumplings (XLB) - one of the highlights that Yelpers mentioned, this was quite a disappointment. There was nothing special about these dumplings. The skin was quite thick, and there wasn't that much soup inside. They were also served a bit lukewarm. The only fancy part was that the waiter gave us clean plates specifically for the dumplings and served us the first ones (maybe so inexperienced customers don't break the skin upon picking them up). They take their Shanghai dumplings seriously! 
:: Pan fried noodles - they use a white noodle that's not as flavorful as the yellow egg noodle. Young's Cafe on Kearny and Sacramento as more legit pan fried noodle. Hunan Homes also uses a whiter gravy sauce that's more slimy and not as flavorful. When the dish cools down, it's like eating slime on your food
:: Chicken and green beans over rice - This was not your traditional dry fried green beans, but instead a spicy garlic sauce sauteed with chicken and green beans. The flavor was not bad, but the chicken could've been better quality. There were definitely bits of skin and fat that did not need to be included.

Overall, there are other more worthwhile restaurants to try in Chinatown, so skip this one.
author: Audrey L.

description: Chinese food in Chinatown is a must and this is the place to go. The service was fantastic! And the food was even better. If you find your way to Chinatown, you have to give this place a try.
author: Marlyn S.

description: The wait staff at this restaurant are all about business. They get you seated and plop down a hot pot of jasmine tea right away. Nice tea! They brought us forks as soon as we asked for sweet and low. The wan tons were great, fried prawns were crispy, and the sweat and sour soup was savory. The restrooms were clean and a fun way to see the back of the restaurant and you get to pass by the tank of crabs waiting for dinner (sorry PETA fans). We got a parking spot out front so that made it super exciting and enjoyed reading our fortunes afterward that all came true. I would definitely go back again.
author: Chris h.

description:
Love this place!! I was recommended this restaurant and since I tried it, it is now my favorite Chinese Restaurant! 

Kim is such a friendly server and very attentive! My glass of water never went past half empty.  Kim was even kind enough to let us know the "last call" to order before the kitchen closed.

Anything you order is great!!! Food is fresh and light! Nothing is greasy.  

I never feel nasty, heavy or guilty after a full meal here!  Great Quality Food and Service!! 

Always a Happy Experience at Hunan Homes!
author: Candice V.

description:
The service was spectacular. It is rare to find this level of service in a casual restaurant. The empty plates were whisked away at an alarming rate. The food was delivered with appropriate timing. The manager was jovial, telling jokes and conversing with the customers. 

The xiao long bao and egg rolls were very good. Sizzling rice soup had great flavor. I would pass on the chow mein. Normally I avoid fried rice in Chinese restaurants, but I saw a few plates pass my table and will def order some next time.

Best of all, the chili oil on the table actually resembled oil. Not a mashed up, reused and recycled glob of leftovers.
author: Robert B.

description:
After enjoying an afternoon in Chinatown during our first day in SF, we decided to opt for a late lunch/early dinner and stopped in at this restaurant.  For our entire stay of seven days we couldn't stop referring people to enjoy lunch or dinner at Hunan Home's.  We chose a combination of pot-stickers and the XLB to accompany an entree of the honey, walnut shrimp to share.  From the very first bite until we finished our meal we couldn't stop talking about how wonderful the food was.  The restaurant is not too small but not at all large.  Since we were there around 4PM you're not sure if the service will be up to their normal meal time standards but it was perfect!

The next time we're in Chinatown, we'll definitely put this wonderful restaurant on our must visit list.
author: John M.

description: Egg rolls were great and liked the hot tea on seating us. However the Kung pao beef was mystery meat with an odd texture. Couldn't eat it. Won't ever go back.
author: Jon H.

description:
湖南又一村 is the Chinese name for this place, and I came with two native Taiwanese who did the ordering. We had five dishes including the Orange Peel Beef, Mao Po Tofu, Fried Won Ton, and the Sweet and Sour Soup. 

The verdict? Excellent! However, this place has authentic Chinese flavors that may be too strong for some Westerners. In other words, the spicy is spicier, and the sweet and sour are stronger. 

The location is beautifully unassuming, resting on the verge of Columbus Street. Don't be fooled: 湖南又一村 is the real deal!
author: Kris F.

description:
I don't care what anyone says :D this is the BEST AUTHENTIC food in Chinatown!
We always start with the 
MU SHU (Mu Shu Ingredients: stir-fry with eggs, mushrooms, cabbage, bamboo shoots) and they always grab a pancake and make our first one for us :)

I try all different items and I have loved them allllllllll Black Mushroom with Tender Greens sauteed with garlic, Crab with Ginger and Green Onion, Shredded Jelly Fish Marinated with shredded cucumber and turnip........it's alllllllll yummy

but my hubby sticks with CHICKEN CHOW MEIN
Chow Mein Ingredients: egg noodles, bean sprouts, carrots, cabbage, and scallions

typing this is making my mouth water.....YUMMMMMMMMMMMM

PS. their other location...the food tastes different and service is...different...
I guess I'll save that for another review ;D
author: Elizabeth B.

description: Delicious soup dumplings!!! Yummy hunan string beans. Love that they give you hot tea as you sit down. Great service!
author: Lindsay P.

description:
This was my second time coming to Hunan Homes and the food was still delicious. We started out with an order of the veggie potstickers. They were deliciously fresh and the dipping sauce that accompanied them made the postickers a lot more flavorful. We shared our main dishes which consisted of the veggie chow mein and the family style bean curd. The chow mein was a little bland, and it could have been made better with a little extra hot sauce. The family style bean curd was a good mix of tofu and vegetables with a subtle garlic taste. It was a nice Chinese comfort meal.

They're usually pretty busy on the weekends and the staff is running around like crazy trying to get everyone seated and served so they don't have the best service that I've seen. But I still always enjoy a Chinese restaurant that has a variety of vegetarian options.
author: Malika R.

description: Loved their string beans!!! They were delicious! Also loved their tea. Definitely a must try!
author: Janine S.

description: Really good food.  It's small inside so get there early. We arrived around 430 and was able to sit down right away.   We probably waited about 20 min for food. We got 5 dishes and three appetizers for about $70ish.  We had a little left over that we all shared.   We had a party of 6. Oh...man food was BOMB!
author: Noelle V.

description: If you like eating in Chinatown and do not mind that the only people in the restaurant that are of Asian descent are the workers, you will love this place. I ordered the broccoli and prawns. Delicious
author: Leslie S.

description:
My favorite Chinese spot in San Francisco! Great experience from the food to the ambiance. The hot and sour soup is the best I've ever had! It's a must on each visit. Beef curry is also a stand out! 

Come hungry, leave happy.
author: Sarah M.

description:
We returned to Hunan Homes on our most recent visit to San Francisco, having had a good experience there a year and a half ago.  Unfortunately, this time things were different.  Our kids had orange peel chicken and beef chow mein, which they both enjoyed.  My wife and I had the hot and sour soup, which she liked but I found a little bitter (not sour).  We also had mu shu pork and kung pao beef.  The mu shu was okay, but we've had better at home, and it was mostly vegetables.  The kung pao had bell peppers and bamboo chunks (not julienned shoots), which I didn't particularly enjoy.  Personally, I don't think bell peppers belong in this dish, and the large pieces of bamboo tasted overwhelming and unpleasant.  The coup de grace was later that night when my wife got sick.  I'm not sure whether it was the soup or the mu shu, but something was obviously not right with the food.  

The service was good with one exception - they brought out the mu shu long before the other dishes, and it wasn't very hot to begin with, so my wife had to start eating before the rest of us.  This just shouldn't happen.

Next time, we will try someplace else.
author: Kevin O.

description:
This is a very mediorcre Americanized Chinese food place with all that you can expect, except that it's not a hunan restaurant but a general cantonese restaurant. The customers are all Americans. It's old style Chinese food inside chinatown. 

We got a banquet style with 13 courses: scallop stirred fried with green pepper, fried fish, shrimp walnut, sweet and sour pork, string beans, fried rice, peking duck, shrimp veggie clear soup, spring rolls, fried potstickers, fried tempura, orange and fortune cookies. Shrimp walnut and sweet & sour pork are the best dishes among these. Peking duck is not bad, but I don't like the wrap itself. Too much deep fried stuff, which I don't like.

A lot of food, we are very full. I ate the most out of my table and they called me "food lover".....We still have a lot of takeout to go in the end.
author: Ashley C.

description:
The woman who handed me my pick up was very nice but the food... It was supposed to be Broccoli Beef. I am not entirely sure what animal that was.
I will not be heading there again
author: Susan W.

description: We were on vacation and decided to come here because of the yelp reviews. Pretty good Chinese food, I don't know if it's the best I've ever had. But still quick service, right portion sizes, and we didn't have to wait to be seated! But again the food is okay~
author: Joyce H.

description: Great food but noticed they only rinse the water glasses by the sink upstairs (they are not washed)- not very sanitary.
author: Rich G.

description: First off, very delicious green tea before the meal even came. Probably had 5 cups right off. The egg rolls were fresh and delicious. Ordered the Mongolian Beef and let me tell you, best I've had in a while. Not the typical salty taste you get with chain restaurants. This place makes it fresh and makes it well. Definite go to in Chinatown at a decent price!!
author: Quintin W.

description:
We came here with a party of 8 (without reservations) on a Sunday night and were fortunate to get a table. We had intended to go to House of Nanking but should have known better than to show up there without reservations, lol.

We ordered six dishes: Sizzling Seafood Deluxe, Eggplant with Chicken and Prawns, Chinese Broccoli with Oyster Sauce, Combination Chow Mein, and Hunan Beef. The food came surprisingly fast but was also surprisingly small in portions. Our entire table ended up finishing all the dishes, though. If you come with a large group, do not compromise on the number of dishes you order!!!

Food was average. Not too oily, but the flavors were nothing out of the ordinary; the sauce for the Hunan Beef and Eggplant/prawns/chicken tasted quite similar. I did think the Chinese Broccoli was perfectly al dente (better than other restaurants) because it wasn't too soggy and not too hard. 

I don't think this restaurant was anything out of the ordinary among the plethora of "authentic" Chinese restaurants that populate this street. The meal DID come for under $100 which was a pleasant surprise. Overall grade: B.
author: Arushi S.

description:
The eight of us split 6 entrees plus chow mein and white rice. We had the Hunan beef, sizzling seafood plate, green beans, Chinese broccoli, eggplant with chicken and shrimp, and combination chow mein. The food came out so quickly! We placed our order and had everything out within ten minutes. I liked the Hunan beef, but it could have been spicier. Hunan food is supposed to be spicy, so I was pretty surprised by the lack of heat. It seemed as if most of the dishes came loaded with chili peppers but didn't actually taste spicy. 

Overall, I think the food was decent but not outstanding. Service was fast and efficient, which was a huge plus. 

Side note: this place only takes a max of two cards.
author: Anna N.

description: Not authentic at all, bad attitude. It's totally impossible that such a Chinese restaurant has four stars and more than 1000 reviews.
author: Liang F.

description:
Love it. Great food. Friendly service and a good place to take kids. 

Recommend the tea smoked duck
author: Ashley D.

description:
Food: 3
Decor: 2
Service: 3

Came here on a Sat night since I was craving some Chinese food, and this place was in walking distance.

1. Chicken with Orange Peel*, 11
Deep-fried chicken breast with special sauce.
~Mediocre. Ordered this Americanized dish since it's the most popular dish, but it was okay. I'll probably get the green beans next time if I visit again.

Service was okay.
author: David L.

description: We just left there it's 1/1/17 12:45pm and we didn't even eat there. They took us downstairs to the dining area and as I was about to sit down there was a cockroach sitting on the chair. I stood there for a good 30 seconds and the waiter walked over and just swiped it with his hand. Yea we walked out.
author: Maria M.

description:
I have visited this restaurant two times, and am happy to report that both experiences were great (:

Pros: Good service, and friendly waiters. Our waiter was particularly sassy (in a good way!) Ask what their recommendations are- sometimes things offered that are not listed on the menu. 

Thing to note: If you order the duck, it's served with a 'pancake', not a steamed bun. Not bad, just don't expect a bun to come out. 

Enjoy!
author: Christine M.

description: Hot and spicy soup was excellent!  Came here for Lori's birthday 2016 (and Mom's family celebration). Had beef with broccoli, lemon chicken, sweet and sour pork, Kung pow chicken, cashew chicken. All of them were delicious, but I liked the lemon chicken least. My favorite was beef with broccoli and the other spicy dishes.
author: Nate G.

description: Excellent lunch! Best hot and sour soup I've ever had anywhere. Very interesting dishes and excellent spice level.
author: Gretchen P.

description:
Probably the best fried rice I've ever had. If you like lots of egg in your fried rice, this is your place! 

I also got the Orange Chicken and Spring Rolls....chicken was great, tasty, plentiful, and crispy. Rolls were good, but they cooked them slightly too long. Our server was nice and attentive. Whenever I make it back to San Francisco, I will definitely be back!! I'm going to drool over their fried rice in the meantime....
author: Jackie H.

description: Omg. So good!  We decided to try 5 different dishes and they were all so very good. We had the yang chow fried rice (excellent), orange peel chicken (so very yummy), smoked pork Hunan (yes and yes), basil chicken (tasty tasty), and pork chow mien (scrumptious). If you're wondering how many were in my party, I'm not ashamed to share that there was only two of us and we cleaned the plates. Yummy spot and seems to be a local favorite. A must try!
author: Anita A.

description: The concierge at our hotel recommended Hunan Homes and it was fantastic!  We would have never picked this place on our own but it was great!  It is much larger than it looks, with a huge room in the back.  The Chicken with Spicy Garlic Sauce was the best.  I ordered the Kung Pao chicken, which was good but the Chicken with Spicy Garlic Sauce was far superior and I had order envy.  The service was very quick and efficient, but the server did not come by often and we definitely needed water.
author: Kristen F.

description:
We stopped in for a late lunch/early dinner as it's got a ton of great reviews.  It's nothing fancy or special-looking, but in its well-worn state has a cozy quality about it. 

The egg rolls were delicious. More of a spring roll to my eyes and mouth, but equally yummy! My husband had Hunan Beef and absolutely loved it. I had the chicken with snow peas which I felt was both a bit bland and a bit salty. Not bad at all, but not particularly exciting. I was hoping for a real "wow" in Chinatown, but in the end, it was a just a fairly decent meal on my side. The service was very good and the complimentary tea was delicious.
author: Laura Kate S.

description: Wow!  What a meal!  I had the Mongolian Chicken and the Honey Walnut Prawns.  The lunch special came with their signature Hot and Sour soup and nothing disappointed.  One of the better Chinese food establishments in the city!  And the prices were fairly reasonable, especially for the quality of food!
author: Raj G.

description:
We came here because it was among the highest-rated Chinese restaurants in Chinatown on Yelp.  We weren't disappointed by it, but it was average in every way.  The food was okay, but nothing special.  I remember being in San Francisco last summer and having lunch in some little hole-in-the-wall type places, and they were all the same quality food, if not better.  Not that Hunan Home had bad food, it was just decent and forgettable.  It was clean but not decorated.  The prices were not expensive or cheap.  

If you want to go here, you will enjoy it.  But if you are looking for Chinese food, don't bother going out of your way to come to this place specifically.  It's no better (or worse) than anywhere else in Chinatown.
author: Michael F.

description: Great food, very tasty!  A few hiccups on customer service, mostly language barrier stuff...  Would eat here again any time!!!
author: Dorel D.

description: My family over hyped this place so I was looking forward to this. Long story short the food was bland and really expensive for the amount you get, luckily I won't be visiting San Francisco anytime soon.
author: Kriz O.

description: Wonton soup was good and so was the pork soup dumplings. The main dish we had was Kung pao chicken which was not very good. Flavors we're nice, but the chicken itself was rubbery. The menu also says the lunch includes rice, which we were charged for. The best part of the meal may have been the oranges they served at the end.
author: Elana K.

description: Great place for classic recipes -- they do have a heavy hand with the sauce, but the cooking is really well done and the ingredients are fresh. Reliable.
author: Dave G.

description: So delish, my family and I thought it was yummy. Though the restaurant didn't seem full, we had to wait 40 minutes for a table. No worries, we were able to bounce around the many shops around. At exactly 40 minutes, our table is ready. We sat down, and the bus boy kinda just slapped the menus on the table. We ordered and our food came quickly. The portions were kinda small and we had to order more rice. Other than that, I enjoyed our dinner.
author: Arcenia K.

description: We get their wonton soup, Orange chicken and assorted veggies with black bean sauce. All taste good!! They validate parking after 5pm if you park at the Owensmouth parking structure, which is a short walk to the restaurant. But, you have to spent $45, which is easy these days. This place is always busy and it is your typical chinese restaurant vibe, quick service, but not warm.
author: Karen Z.

description:
We went to Hunan Homes on a random Thursday since I had a cousin in town. I tend to stick to chinese places in the richmond but thought I should try this one out. Got there around 6:30 and we were able to find parking quite easily. After almost entering the wrong Hunan place, we managed to find our way here. It was not particularly crowded so we pushed ourselves into a booth and started reviewing the menu. 

My cousin and his buddy ordered a tsingtao which arrived promptly. We also ordered the veggie pot stickers, egg rolls, veggie fried rice, hunan beef, sizzling chicken and the combination chow mein. 

The pot stickers were decent but I did not find them particularly special. The big downer for me was the chicken. It felt rubbery and lacking flavor. I did not scream "wow, i need to come back here again". 

Before we paid the check, my cousin tried the restroom which had a backed up toilet. Not cool! 

Overall, the dinner left me very unimpressed.
author: Rahul H.

description:
There are literally hundreds of Chinese restaurants in San Francisco so why stop looking after you've eaten here?  I'll tell you why!  They've been at this location for over twenty years and must be doing something right.  And once you've had their crispy orange peel chicken and an order of their green bean a la Hunan, you will be hooked too!  Order some mantou or soup while you wait and you will be hooked, I promise.

Yeah yeah yeah... there might be cheaper or better places but my heart belongs to this place festooned in pink tablecloths with three separate dining areas.  It's massive if you've never kept going past the first room with the aquarium.

The service can be brusque but it's always been good.  I've never had to ask for another pot of tea or a water refill, it's just done quickly.  Bathrooms are kept clean and the tables bused quickly once patrons depart.  

Another perk of this place is the free parking if you spend $20.00 at the restaurant.  Park at the Hilton Hotel or Portsmouth Square Garage from 5:00pm - 9:00pm and take your ticket to the restaurant with you!  They will validate.  The walk isn't too taxing and you'll appreciate the stroll back to the car after your belly is full of tasty food.

PS.  I said they were wheelchair accessible but I believe only for the first dining area, if memory serves the other areas (and bathroom) are accessed by stairs.
author: Kristine H.

description:
Friend and I ate here for lunch today. No wait, and service was reasonably fast but they took more than 15min to bring out the Xiao Long Baos. 

Food: not memorable. not the best I've ever had, and very americanized. the wonton soup was bland, the rice plate had too much rice, and the xiao long baos were too dry and thick-skinned. even the fortune cookies were hard and stale.
Decor: old and stuffy, tacky.

Basically this place draws tourists and non-Chinese people.
Oh and my friend got major food poisoning right afterwards. AVOID.
author: Alice L.

description:
My friends and I went here and waited 15 minutes in line. My one friend has a seafood allergy and when she told the waitress about this, she was told, "Don't eat here. A seafood allergy can kill you and we will not serve you." 

My friends and I decided to eat here and the price was very reasonable and the food was good. After the meal, the owner came and asked how everything was. We told him about the food allergy and he explained the situation more clearly and was very nice. 

However, if you have a seafood allergy, I suggest you do not eat here.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Hm, what's the hype?

In all honesty, the food tasted like Panda Express food.. maybe slightly better.  For a Chinese restaurant that is right smack in the middle of Chinatown, I was not that impressed.  Surprisingly, there are still a decent amount of people that come here during lunch time.  

Prices are very decent, but the quality of food.. ehh not so much.  The hot and sour soup was anything but..... it was not hot (temperature and spice level wise).. but I guess it was sour?

We also ordered seafood panfried noodles.  There was way too much starch in the sauce - totally masked the flavors of the noodles and the seafood.  

The Chicken with Orange Peels was really sweet.  Totally something you'd find at a Panda Express (I think i actually like Panda Express's more....).  Again, wasn't a huge fan.

The Hunan Spiced Garlic Prawns was decent.  However, it could use a tad bit more flavor.  

According to my aunt, this restaurant used to be THE spot back in the day when she used to work in the area.  Apparently, ownership/management has changed since then, and it went down hill from there.
author: Cecilia S.

description:
Ordinary, usually bland, but sometimes flavorless. The main reason for this place's popularity is it's close to Columbus Avenue and downtown, it's cheap and it's been around forever.

You get what you pay for. If you want flavorful, go to Clement Street. Chinatown is so old-school they forgot how to make food taste good.
author: Kevin P.

description:
It's way overrated here on Yelp. Go there, try it but expect only an average Chinese restaurant with mediocre food.
I wouldn't go there again.
author: Jan S.

description: Awesome tea leaf smoked duck. And orange peel beef was well made. Very busy spot with 90s decor of pinks and blues; outside looks like I would never walk in here. Huge seating area. The owner came to our table and told us that smoked duck is not a regular dish ordered by most people that visit his place, and that we were in for a treat. He was right. No sauce came with it and none needed. The duck here is so flavorful; he was kind of insulted when I asked upon arrival of the dish if it came with sauce. Price was more than fair and food is great
author: Rachel A.

description: My husband & I were looking for an authentic Chinese food place to have dinner at. I came across a review of a restaurant that was near by our hotel & walahhhh... this place was amazing. Great people working here as well.
author: Jenny A.

description:
I was in SF to visit friends Superbowl weekend and needed to get in some Chinese before the game.  I searched Yelp for an option near our hotel in Union Square and knew I had to try this place out.  

It's great! The green beens were yummy and the gyoza was also very tasty.  All in all a solid stop for Chinese in China town.  The staff was friendly too which is always nice.
author: Jennifer A.

description: The food was really good I enjoyed it Alot! It was a 12min wait not bad and the service was fast & nice!!
author: Alaysha G.

description: Good Hunan cooking style. ..everything we ordered was very good & not pricey. .authentic Chinese taste unlike others which tastes the same sauce. ..
author: Arthur B.

description:
DEAR TOURISTS: please stop giving this place 5/5 stars or even 4/5 stars. Unless...

You enjoy waiting to be seated with no dinner or lunch rush and zero other parties waiting behind or before your modest party of three. If you're into standing around and watching others eat their food in slow motion, about to pass out from low blood sugar from not having eaten all day and then being completely shunned at the door because they know you aren't tourists, then by all means, come right in and wait around. 

You enjoy being finally seated and then waiting another 10 minutes for a waiter to give a flying-f about you. We were literally sitting right where the waiters bar was and we could see/hear them passing us around like no one wanted to serve us. So, again, if you like being outcasted and denied quality service by second rate servers, by all means, come here to eat, or not eat, because that's what we did. 

You enjoy asking for waters from a skew of different waiters and instead of getting too many waters, receiving ZERO. We were there only half an hour and on multiple occasions, one of the lazy waiters could have passed us a dirty glass of water at any time, since you know, the sink and cups and waiters doing nothing were situated literally an arm's length away from us. 

AND LASTLY, unless you enjoy being swindled from by the restaurant you're already paying good money to to get the worse possible service, please please come here. We asked for the check, when it came, I knew better than to trust them. I checked my orders and recalculated everything, which seemed to match up. So, I paid for my $35 meal with a $100 bill. I received less than $50. I then politely asked for the waiter to come double check and even asked if tip was already included. He said no. So I asked why they already decided I'd want to even tip them over $10 for the piece of crap service I got. He called over the supervisor who seemed to be pissed at me that his people messed up my bill and tried to steal my money. They're lucky I even bothered tipping after all those heinous ordeals. 

On a last note, about the food, it wasn't anything spectacular or noteworthy. I ordered three dishes, a meat dish, a seafood dish, and a vegetable dish. Pretty basic stuff, but it wasn't memorable. Nothing you couldn't get right next door or from any other restaurant in the Chinatown vicinity, who probably wouldn't have tried stealing my money and give me terrible service. If I could, this place would get zero stars.
author: Han P.

description:
Major disappointment.  Part of the problem was that is was so hyped by a friend of mine that when I finally made it to the location I was simply overwhelmed by its mediocrity and general suckiness.  

There is simply nothing special or remarkable about it, only that the service is detached and seemingly uninterested in being friendly or helpful (but that is excusable if the food is amaze balls!)  Instead, it was just boring poorly cooked overly sweet and tangy Americanized Chinese food all served on beds of vinegary cabbage. 

Part of the reason it is so over hyped is partially because no nothing tourists from far away lands, have no idea what good or even authentic Chinese food should taste like.  Considering that the concentration and sheer number of choices for absolutely fantastic and hardy Chinese food in Chinatown and the Bay Area surpasses pretty much anywhere in the United States, this is a poor representative of what SF has to offer for Chinese cuisine.

If you want better Chinese food, just close your eyes and randomly place your finger somewhere on a map of Chinatown and go to the nearest restaurant.  Guaranteed probably to be better use of your money.
author: Joshua H.

description:
Called on a Saturday night and was told they don't take reservations, and we were already in S.F. we thought if we were to do that than we could show up and just walk in and have a table ready...but that didn't work out. So we showed up at around 7 pm and put our name down and was told it will be a 20-30 minute wait.
There were 4 of us, and after we put our name down, 3 of us decided to walk around the corner to "Golden Gate Bakery" to swoop up some egg tarts. The line was pretty long and we in line for maybe 5 mins or so. Anyways...we get a call from the other person at Hunan and he said they just called our name. 

Awesome! They said 20-30 minutes and we get called maybe 5-10 minutes later!!

The service was pretty good, they have this guy working who has a sense of humor but you can't tell by his facial expressions. 2 of us asked for forks because we don't know how to use chopsticks(....I'm sorry! Give me a break....) And the guy tells us he has to go down the street to get forks because they don't have any there and that it will be a $5 add on to the bill. Which I thought was pretty funny. 

When the food was ready they brought one, and once that was done...the next one came out and so on and so on. The thing I liked the most was, we ordered the mu shu chicken and when that was ready the waitress brought that out and set up our plates and put the little pancakes on each plate and put the chicken in each pancake...then what got me was she rolled it up for us!! I was like, "awesome service!" Usually I just put the chicken on the pancake and eat it like a soft taco of sorts.

Pot stickers are good, mu shu chicken was good, the spare ribs were amazing, and then we ordered duck! The duck was bomb.com! It's on the greasy side but it's really good! The skin is crispy and is the best part. There is also a lot of fat on it that I didn't really care for much but the meat and the skin are off the chain!

The food was really good, and the service was pretty good as well!

I highly recommend coming here!
author: Jason D.

description: Bad food quality, service and price. I won't come again. I barely can't trust Yelp anymore which make me so sad.
author: Yunru C.

description: Service left SO MUCH to be desired, not friendly at all, practically demanded our order. Walked to bathroom and there was a waitress standing in the doorway literally eating her dinner--YUCK! She saw me standing there clearly waiting to go in yet still did not move until I asked her if it was alright for me to go in. Food was alright, wouldn't complain about it... but the service alone was enough to ensure myself and my date will NEVER return.
author: Brandon F.

description: Food wasnt that good...waited 40 minutes for what we figured would be a great experience based on the reviews. Unfortunately the food was pretty average but it was the AWFUL AND RUDE service that really sucked. Nobody working there smiled and when my dad asked a waiter for a fork and spoon he gave the " talk to the hand gesture" and said later. He asked a second waiter who obliged but gave a serving spoon which wasn't much help.... Only go to this place if your happy to be rushed and to receive rude, abrupt service and attitude. My advice...go elsewhere !
author: Andrea P.

description: Excellent food. The service was fast and efficient, but not personable. We had the hot and sour soup and egg rolls to start. Then the sautéed asparagus and the Hunan smoked pork as our entrees. Everything was great.
author: Nicole W.

description:
Got some good reviews so I thought I would try it. We like the pot stickers and the hot and sour soup was memorable. The Hunan chicken had sauted chicken, not fried...but the chicken was kind of rubbery, like it was processed.
The fried won ton looked good. I think the chicken needs some attention because I saw a post about the chicken like mine.
author: Jim S.

description: Writing this review after just walking out their restaurant. Service was absolutely absent today. Never got the waters we asked for. Our appetizer came 10 minutes after our entrees. The Mongolian Beef was alright. The potstickers had potential if they weren't cold by the time we got them.
author: Darius A.

description: We wanted to find an authentic, great Chinese food place in China Town, so decided to go here after seeing so many good reviews.  The food was great!!  And you get a lot for the price, too.  Enough for leftovers for both of us the next night, and a little bit left after that even.  Beware, if you're an invalid like me with chopsticks, you're going to be in a bind.  They don't offer any other utensils, and when I (totally embarrassed) finally broke down and asked our waiter for a fork, he seemed to understand, but his English was so scarce I don't think he did, since a fork never arrived.  I ended up resorting to using the big serving spoon that came with my entree.  It was better than having to eat with my hands.  But that's NO fault of the restaurant ... that's all on me.  Food was fantastic, and I would highly recommend.
author: R F.

description: Had high expectations given the reviews, but food didn't really live up to it.  It wasn't bad by any stretch, but wasn't anything special.
author: Matt E.

description: Excellent service and great lunch specials around $8-$10 that include soup, rice and entree.
author: Lauren H.

description:
How could a place with Pepto Bismol colored tablecloths, old teal carpet and matching teal banquet chairs completely blow my mind?  We waited only a few minutes for a table for four and just hung out observing the fish in the fish tank (they seemed happy.) 

We went family style and just ordered a bunch of stuff to share.  I was getting anxious because people ordered things I usually don't like (xiao long bao and hot and sour soup), and then the mind-blowing happened.  The xia long bao were perfect: thin, delicate skin, but hefty enough not to break when picked up.  The vinegar that came with it was just right -- no weird medicinal aftertaste like I'd had before.  And I have no idea what they did to the hot and sour soup or how I miraculously inhaled my portion of it, but damn it was good.  It wasn't thick and goopy with cornstarch and didn't skew sour like so many do.  

The Hunan scallops were crazy good, too.  Cooked really nicely -- not chewy or stringy at all -- and just spicy enough.  From this, I deduce anything that has the word "Hunan" in the title is going to be delicious.  

Service was speedy -- no gratuitous niceties, they just handled it!  Everything was just right.  The tea.  The soup.  The dumplings.  And not just because I was already drunk.... I don't think.
author: Yelena K.

description: Good basic Chinese food. Nothing extraordinary, but solid. Busy atmosphere, slow service.
author: P S.

description: Absolutely delicious fresh food.  Had the Vegetable Chow Fun.  Superb, unforgettable!  I want to go back soon for some more!
author: Sue T.

description: So delicious!! Best Chinese I've ever had. There was an hour wait and we almost didn't wait. SO GLAD WE DID!!! And James is excellent waiter!!
author: Rachel G.

description: Mediocre Chinese food. I expected a lot better for a well-rated restaurant in Chinatown, but even ordering some of their more traditional dishes, everything was quite disappointing. Main complaints: sloppy preparation (clear overuse of corn starch to thicken, over/underseasoning) and low quality ingredients (fish was cheap & falling apart. poor cuts of beef & pork were used).
author: Alan Y.

description: We were excited to finally be in a city with good Chinese food looking at yelp we decided here, it was decent food, a little bland, nothing special really, which was a disappointment because we were so looking forward to great Chinese food in SF.
author: Morgan M.

description:
First time at this restaurant and it was amazing! We got the fried prawns, hot and sour soup, orange slice chicken, chow mien, shrimp fried rice and the green beans.  

The fried rice, chow mien and prawns were really good! Not super oily and the flavors were good for everything.

I absolutely LOVED the hot and sour soup.  Seriously the best hot and sour soup I've had.  Incredible.  The green beans were also fantastic.  The chicken was really tasty too, but the one thing I can say in criticism is the chicken plate was kind of on the smallish side.

That being said, all that food fed 7 women for $60.  If that isn't a good deal, I don't know what is!  I am definitely going back!
author: Amanda E.

description: We had a large group, 10+, which they accommodated well. The service on a busy weekend night could have been better, but I'm giving them 4 stars for the Mu Shu Pork and Mu Shu Chicken, which was probably the best of my life. After several courses and drinks, our meal came to approx $29 per person, with tip! I will return for the Mu Shu, the Hot and Sour Soup and the Gai Lan.
author: Jennifer J.

description: I was really excited to try the beef brisket noodle soup per another yelper's suggestion; though they didn't have it that day. I did try the pot sticker appetizer and they were really tasty-- hot hot hot inside recommend poking or cutting in half the first few when they come out. Their spicy string beans were really spicy (recommend requesting some rice to mix in with). I also had their hot and sour soup which was great... I think I'm starting to turn around on my previous hns-soup prejudices! I would come back to eat in again!
author: Alexander T.

description:
The waitresses in here are SUPER RUDE. 
No check-ins or anything.
The waitress grabbed the menu so forcely. 
Also when paying, they said " this is tip, you have to give tip" like we were supposed to give tips. They didn't even service us good.
author: Kay D.

description: I thought it would be more authentic.  We got the orange beef as others suggested and it was good - gooey, thick, sweet sauce on quick fried beef.  The best of the three dishes we got.  Kung Pao Prawns were a bit bland and boring.  Smoked Pork was like a ham cooked in a smoker.  None of us liked that one.  Dumplings were good.
author: Michelle S.

description:
Me and the bf usually come here when were around the area and get a to-go order of Hot and Sour soup, which in my opinion is one of the best Hot and Sour soups in the city.

I have not experienced the horrible service everyone raves about, but I also not have not dined in nor tried their other dishes.
author: Oriel F.

description:
I was so excited to try this place out. We had a short wait to be seated. The two women that greeted us were great and fun, however, our served was rude, and appeared to be in a bad mood.

The food was either drenched in sauce so you couldn't taste anything but the sauce or had no flavor at all. 

We will not be returning.
author: Maria F.

description: We were visiting San Fran and fell in love with this place!! Sizzling beef , Mongolian beef and they are one of the few restaurants that have the soup wontons ( bite into wonton and your mouth folks with broth ) the owners were so friendly and the place was packed!!!
author: Laurie B.

description:
Very good service! 1) Fast delivery of food. 2) dishes not too big not small either - just appropriate. 3) Manners and courtesy of waiters. 4) Not expensive - 9 person 8 dishes for $105. 5) Easy to find and park around, good place for gathering.

Although people say it's not super delicious, but it's totally OK. I don't expect to get super fine dishes here, but for this price, I'm already very satisfied. I'll definitely come again for future gatherings.

,,,(9105),!
author: Jasmine W.

description: Had a group dinner here with 10 people.  The food was excellent... probably the best Mu Shu pork that I have ever had.  We ate a ridiculous amount of food and drank a fair amount and the bill came out to about $30 per person... great value for the money.
author: Brad B.

description:
I'm not sure what the hype is about. We had the following dishes and were not that impressed:

Combination chow mein - bland, relatively little flavor
Mongolian beef - way too lunch ginger, also lacking flavor
Sizzling rice soup - this was actually pretty decent 

I got the order to go so I can't really comment on the service, but the lady at the register seemed pretty nice. I don't think I'll be ordering from here again. We just moved to the city and haven't found a decent Chinese place yet!
author: Jeff J.

description: Not worth four stars. Mediocre Chinese food. Kung Pao did not have much flavor. The only flavorful thing was the egg rolls.
author: Kimberly R.

description: My boyfriend and I are from New York and what a dinner we had our first night in California! The Chinese food was extremely delicious and left us more than satisfying. The staff were very attentive and kept asking us if we wanted anything else. The complimentary tea was a first for us at any restaurant. Very nice touch! We love the authenticity. Definitely coming back on our second trip back to Cali!
author: Kathy V.

description:
Was visiting SF and looking for a good restaurant in Chinatown. The choices can be overwhelming but turned to Yelp and found this place. I was definitely not disappointed with the choice.

To me, it's a typical Chinese restaurant in back. We went there for an early dinner, greeted quickly but the front area was packed and thought we would have to wait. However, we were quickly taken to the large back dining area downstairs and seated immediately.

Wife and I ordered the lemon chicken and the beef with orange peel and both were amazing. The lemon chicken was all white meat pieces cooked to perfection. It was not your usual heavy breaded, hard as a rock chicken you normally see. Very tender and juicy with just the right amount of breading. The sauce was light, tangy and added just the right amount of flavor. It wasn't your typical yellow lemon ketchup product you would see at other places. Thick enough to stick to the chicken but not enough to overpower the flavors.

The beef with orange peel was lightly fried and tender. The orange flavor was subtle but enough to compliment the beef. I still can't believe how amazingly tender and flavorful the beef was. It literally would melt in your mouth.

Prices were on par with other Chinese restaurants. I will absolutely visit this place again on my next visit and would recommend to anyone. You won't be disappointed.
author: Brian W.

description: Best Chinese in SF!  We live in San Diego where there is very little good Chinese, whenever we come to SF we go here!  The Mu Shu is delicious.  The hot and sour soup is really great.  Everything is hot and quick.  If there's a wait to get in it usually goes pretty quick.  Definitely worth the hassle of parking and the crowds.  It's on the edge of Chinatown so not as crazy.
author: Beth K.

description: I've never rated a restaurant I haven't eaten at, but I tried to go for lunch on Christmas, and when I asked the hostess what the wait time would be, since I was with a child, I was rudely told that the line was outside, and that I should just go out. Needless to say I won't be going back. Good food does not excuse bad behavior.
author: Diya P.

description: The 50 minute wait today was worth it!  We had sweet and sour soup, garlic chicken with green beans, and the kung po deluxe. It was very flavorful.  Would recommend this restaurant with no hesitation!
author: Dianne S.

description: It was just Ok-ish place. I would say that I was thrilled with the food they served. It was hard to get in and we waited 20 min across the street at the bar, as the matter of fact that place had better food lol... Shrimp was tough and overcooked. There was a lot of chaos running around, which was quite disturbing.
author: Yuliya S.

description: By far my favorite restaurant in SF.  Very friendly staff, relatively inexpensive, great food.  As far as authentic Chinese food goes, not sure how to comment on that, but I will say it's my favorite, better than what Chicago's Chinatown has to offer.  Orange Peel Beef and Honey Walnut Shrimp was AMAZING.  I would highly recommend to anyone in in the area!
author: Allison P.

description:
I agree with Marcia K, my experience here was OK, not better.   My colleague had the pork ribs to start, and we shared Hunan Spicy Chicken and Sizzling Mixed Seafood.

I expected more flavor sensations, and considered both dishes good, but not excellent.  Service was very good.

I would return if I was in the neighborhood, but would not go out of my way to revisit.
author: Thomas E.

description:
One of my favorite Chinese restaurants in Chinatown.  Food is always solid.  Everything here has been great, but my guy and I like to order the following:

Start off with the sizzling rice soup, and for meat we get the orange peel chicken (we like them to make it spicy), and for some veggies we get the sauteed green beans.  That leaves room for us to get some boba elsewhere after dinner. 

The owner is a real character with true charisma.  It's fun conversing with him, and is another reason we keep coming back.
author: Jenn L.

description: Have been here with friends for a city outing, the food was good here. We didn't had a reservation so had to wait for the table for about 15 min, food is 3.5/5, service is good here.
author: Sandeep L.

description:
It's not the cheapest Chinese restaurant you can find, but whenever someone ask me about a recommended Chinese restaurant - I tell them Hunan Homes (since I am Chinese and pretty picky with Chinese food)

They got spicy and none spicy. They have all kinds of food and pretty much every dish we have there is quality.  My favorites are
- hot and sour soup (surprisingly hard to make right - most restaurants suck at it)
- West lake soup
- sizzling fish dish
- beef scallions
- garlic stir fry "doe miao" - chinese bean leave veggie
- sizzling prawns
- salt and pepper prawns

we also get restaurant.com coupons to use here which make it more affordable.  If you google restaurant.com coupons, you can buy a $25 off coupons for $2-4 sometimes.
author: Lei H.

description: Read so many good reviews about this place so decided to have it for lunch. I got the beef with string beans lunch special which comes with hot and sour soup and rice. I think the food is just ok. I'm from NYC and I'm Chinese so it was just ok to me. It taste like any Americanized Chinese food. Would I come back?  Prob not but it's not to say it's not good, just I have different standards for Chinese food
author: Tammy W.

description: Great service food came quick good presentation but the table was wobbly . I got the sesame chicken which was decent. Steamed rice was good. My total was around 12.00 . Not bad
author: Cynthia R.

description:
Every year I come here for Chinese New Year. Every year they remember me and are gracious and welcoming to me and my friends. Our party is anywhere from six to 15 people strong, and they never bat an eye at last-minute changes to the reservation.

I love the food here, we almost always end up ordering more potstickers at the end of the meal because we each just want one more. 

Beef and broccoli, tea-smoked duck, all of your favorite Chinese dishes, done right. Service is quick. Going tonight, and can't believe I hadn't written a review yet in five years of going to Hunan Home's (the apostrophe is theirs, not mine).
author: Amani Ellen L.

description: Nothing authentic about their food, just plain average American Chinese food. I don't understand why yelpers have raved about this place so much. We ordered takeouts from here while visiting SFO. Service was prompt though.
author: Debolina B.

description: Came here with my father and my niece for dinner.  Had the honey walnut shrimp, the orange chicken, sautéed asparagus, and fried rice. Portions looked a bit small so we were worried that we didn't order enough at first but it ended up filling our tummies perfectly with nothing leftover (by the way, our portions were smaller than most of the pictures.  For example, our orange chicken mostly had dried orange peels and only 5 pieces of chicken).  I usually prefer stir fried over deep fried Chinese food but chose the orange chicken and honey walnut shrimp because of high yelp reviews.  Everything tasted very good except the fried rice which was a disappointment (boring and similar to Panda Express).  I wouldn't mind eating here again but will probably prefer trying the other places in the area in hopes of finding a better fit.
author: Linda H.

description: Absolutely amazing!!! Probably the best Chinese food I've ever eaten ! And one of the best dishes was the green beans!! I mean wow!!! The only thing I didn't like about the place is that they light too much I incense and it's a little over powering to be in a restaurant but other than that just amazing!!!!
author: Brianna L.

description:
Visiting from Atlanta, saw the reviews and decided to check it out. The food was just ok, expected great with all the hype. Nothing that tasted better than items I could have gotten back home. 

Ambience: 3 - not a big deal, wasn't expecting anything fancy. 
Service: 3 - once we were seated it took at least 10 mins before anyone came to our table. After we got a waiter service was pretty good. *manager or owner up front...wouldn't hurt to smile and be nice to your customers. Don't make it seem like a burden to take our reservations. 
Food: 3 - average, nothing stood out. I had the sizzling beef, sizzling rice soup and a few apps. My girlfriend got orange chicken. Egg rolls were not good, dumplings were good, and fried "prawn"...really just regular shrimp weren't good. Sizzling beef was good but nothing special. The same goes for the chicken. 
Price: 3 

I wouldn't rush back anytime soon, I'd check out other restaurants in Chinatown.
author: George R.

description: We stumbled into this little gem thanks to Yelp. The food was amazing. It was definetly one of the highlights of our San Francisco trip.
author: Ryan H.

description: Super tasty. Best pot stickers I've had in a long time. Chow mien was delicious.
author: Seth T.

description: The food is not bad, the dining room is ok. Service could have been better, but this restaurant mostly lost stars for their cleanliness.  They have fish tanks in several places that are nasty.  The bathrooms are down stairs and both were flooded.  I would cut them some slack but the smell and water lines along the bottom of the wall suggest that they've had this problem for some time now and just put down rubber mats to step on top of it. Gross.
author: Toni M.

description: I came here with a friend who is a regular, so the service was very attentive. The food arrived quickly and was very fresh and flavorful. I typically do not go to Chinese restaurants in Chinatown because I feel many are geared toward tourists, I would come back to this one though as it felt very authentic.
author: Infodiva B.

description: Good when you want to eat Chinese food, but it is catering more to the non Chinese palate.
author: Faryal Z.

description:
This was the perfect old school style family Chinese restaurant we used to have back in the day in the NY area.
I found it while in SF through Yelp, of course and am so glad I did.
Friendliest service.  
Best hot and sour soup I think I have ever had.
Best moo-shu pork dish and chicken with vegetables.  
Seriously you can't get better Chinese food than this.

If only they weren't 3,000 miles away.
author: Alexandra C.

description:
I got the curry chicken. Soooo good!
If you like chicken, you absolutely must try the curry chicken.

Weirdly even at 4PM on a Saturday afternoon, there was a 10-15 minute wait. 
An old man walked by us and told us that the wait would be worth it. It indeed was!
author: Nakul J.

description: Visiting from Los Angeles for the weekend and we ended up in Chinatown of San Francisco in the pouring rain. Hopped on Yelp to find some near by Chinese food and Hunan's popped up so here we are. The service is great, extremely friendly and very attentive. Our order was taken within minutes and now we wait for the delicious entrees. This hot tea will do just fine until then.
author: Jade J.

description: This is totally average chinese food.  I was expecting something special due to all the good reviews but -- no.  Just average.  Ordered veggie potstickers (which btw take 15 mins to cook) and vegetable moo sho - just average. The service was pretty charmless as well.
author: Sasha A.

description: Very insulting and racist behavior. Never coming here again. Me and my friends were insulted multiple times. Poor service.
author: Sia M.

description:
Best chinese food I have ever had anywhere. Infact any chinese food I have now is being compared to hunan homes and falling short so might as well stop going anywhere else. 

Love the place, love how fast the food makes it to the table and how delicious it is. Pretty cheap too. Their corn and chicken soup is a must and everything on the menu is equally tasty.
author: Nora B.

description: Loved everything about this place from the super friendly family orientated atmosphere to the scrumptious and flavorful cuisine. The female host was SO sweet that she taught my niece mandarin and made sure we were well taken care of. Also this place is very vegetarian friendly. This will now be our go-to Chinese restaurant!
author: Ruwanie B.

description:
I don't understand how this place gets the positive reviews it does! I've tried it a couple times to give it the benefit of the doubt, but it's a no-go in my book.

I feel as though it's a factory for non-Chinese ppl - come in, order from a picture menu, eat, open a fortune cookie, leave.

We had a few apps (soup/rolls/dumplings) and kung pao chicken for the entrée. The rolls were manageable, but everything else was tasteless. Kung pao had no flavor, and the chicken was rubbery. I've made better from a box kit from Safeway.

It's too bad there are restaurants like this in Chinatown that give Chinese food a bad name. San Francisco has something like the 4th largest Chinatown in the world, can't we do better??
author: Anna C.

description: THE BEST CHINESE FOOD IN CHINA TOWN!!!!!  1. The service is great and friendly and so well dressed ! 2. It's CHEAP! Me and 2 friends ate and were stuffed for $23! Way better deal than anywhere close to my house, I love eating here with my dad. We found this place on yelp and your lucky that you did too because it's bomb :)
author: Grace S.

description:
Hunan Homes is a great Chinese resturant that caters to tourists. It has a safe-for-the-non-Chinese diner atmosphere and the waiters are friendly and willing to take the time to explain the ingredients in the dishes if you inquire.

Since I'm Chinese, they don't pay attention to me. 

The food is mostly classic American Chinese food (sweet & sour ____, mu shu____, pot stickers, chow mein, etc....). It's not the best or the worst; it just is. Either way, you won't get much value here since it mainly caters to out of town dollars of tourists. Ordering a la carte will prove fatal to your wallet ($13 pea shoots). If you want to splurge, there are better options in the area (R&G or Great Eastern). After trying the dinner once, now I stick to the lunch menu. It's a perfectly fine place for a rice plate (about $10 out the door). Service is fast if you're just ordering that and nothing else.

Bathrooms in the basement are decently maintained. They are unisex so you have a choice of the left one or the right one. 

Overall, a great place for tourists. I've seen many of them enjoy their experience there. But if you're a native San Franciscan and this is your go-to place for Chinese food, then we need to have a nice long talk.
author: Stevey K.

description:
5 stars for the food.  4 stars for service. 
Hot and sour soup is some of the best I have had in quite some time. BBQ pork nicely seasoned.  Kung pao chicken and sesame garlic chicken were both full of flavor, the right amount of heat/spice, and quality meat.  Highly recommend.
author: Alan N.

description:
I was staying in the Financial District on a business trip and felt like having lunch in Chinatown.  This place seemed to be one of the higher-rated restaurants.  One of the reviews mentioned they had the best Hot & Sour soup on town...

It was ok, but definitely not the best hot & sour soup I've had.  More like average, perfectly fine hot & sour soup.

The lunch portion was a decent size for the price.

I had to chuckle when they offered my dish (Mongolian Beef) in either medium or very spicy.  I guess "not spicy" was not an option!

The food was very tasty, but definitely did not blow me out of the water.

The service was ok, but my waiter was a little short and I felt like he wanted to get me out of there as quickly as possible.

It was ok, but I'm not sure I would pick this place again on my next trip to San Francisco.
author: Jana S.

description:
I think it's fair to say this is one of the best Chinese meals I've ever had. My girlfriend and I started with Egg Rolls and Won Ton Soup.  The Egg Rolls were so-so but the soup for was really flavorful.  For our entrees, we had the Tai Chin Chicken and the Hunan Smoked Pork.  Both were delicious.  Just the right amount of spice to keep sweat on my brow without burning me too badly. I like it hot. 

The decor wasn't anything to write home about but the food spoke for itself.
author: RJ D.

description: We were visiting Chinatown on Thursday September 3rd, 2015.  We wanted to eat at a restaurant since everyone always talks about how good the food in Chinatown is.  Well after much research we came to this restaurant.  Wowwww!!! I could of just stayed in my hometown and eaten better food!!! Very very very disappointed with the food and prices.  I found the food to be very bland and tasteless.  Please go somewhere else!!!!!!!
author: Alice K.

description:
We had a table of 7...everything we ordered was fresh and flavorful!!! Fast service.. Would go back for sure yummy

The only reason I did not give it 5 stars, was that I wanted a brown rice choice and more vegetarian dishes ( tempeh maybe), and they only had 2 choices. Nevertheless, the flavor of what we ordered was really good!!
author: Suzanne A.

description: The food was great but lacked protein! Beef chowmein had about 5-6 pieces of beef and the sweet & sour chicken had about 10 pieces of chicken. Customer service is a bit lacking and since there is a slight language barrier it's difficult to get any suggestions when ordering.
author: Sarah J.

description: Small restaurant. Food was amazing. The best Chinese food I have ever eaten. Unfortunately the service was subpar.
author: Victor M.

description: Fast service, coz y location. As soon as we sat down we got our hot tea - which makes me happy. We got the mu shou pork and the peaking duck for three people and had more than we could eat. The duck was not greasy and had a lovely crisp skin. No complaints!
author: Nicole S.

description: We came here for the high yelp ratings but were disappointed. The environment is nice but the waiters were cold and not very welcoming. We were served with ditry chop sticks and plates and asked for new ones and the waiter grabbed them in an upset manner and gave us replacements with no sorry or explanation. We ordered just appetizers and the wait was long for two small dishes. The food was somewhat bland, nothing special and seemed to be catered to the American tastes.
author: Paul F.

description:
OMG! Thank you Yelpers who have gone before me, as that is how I chose Hunan Homes.  

I LOVE THIS PLACE!!! 

I love that they do not skimp on the rice.  Suzanne A. is correct, they could have more rice choices, yet that notwithstanding, you get a very generous portion of rice.  It feeds two persons easily.

We enjoyed the Chicken with Spicy Garlic Sauce and the Beef with Orange Peel.  The serving of Chicken was small, yet the beef serving was large, so it worked that we were sharing, otherwise one of us would have had too little and the other too much.  The spicy garlic sauce was delicious! 

Lipton iced tea was on the menu and I ordered it.  I did not get that brand, however what I got tasted exactly the same (I am a Lipton tea freak). 

The hot tea was good.  It was also very strong with hints of rose.

The staff took their break while we were there and they has a plate of beautiful greens.  I asked for the name of the dish so I could get it nest time and I was told it was Chef Greens, but they only make it for themselves, it's not a menu item. Darn! 

Being new to S.F., I'm  still getting used to businesses existing on multiple levels that are not department stores.  I got kinda freaked out when they took us down a level to an additional dining area.
author: Artemis X.

description:
Great hot and sour soup
Best potstickers and we usually go to Frank fats Chinese bistro
Orange chicken is zesty with chiles, way beyond normal orang chicken which I normally don't like because of sweetness
author: Angela C.

description:
First, I am not much of a Chinese food fan, simply because of the extra pounds that show up on the scale the next morning. That said my husband and I and our cousins from overseas were doing the tourist thing a few days ago and had lunch here...5 of us. We ordered several dishes. 

orange chicken: in a word yum-a-licious. Think lemon chicken, but orange: perfectly crunchy, and spicier than its lemon counterpart. 

won ton soup:  broth for me was a 3 1/2, but the won tons themselves were great. Delicate and tasty.

Sizzling fish (flounder) was great. Excellent texture to the fish and well spiced

Moo Shoo Shrimp: Excellent, perhaps the best ever. To their credit, the shrimp were cooked perfectly...tender to the point of a swoon. And the wraps were delicate and way better than the standard ones that are kind of cardboardish.

Mongolian Beef: Good, say 4. Not the very best I've had.

Hunan smoked pork: I didn't try it but it was a hit with the others.

The overall experience was such that I'm giving them a solid 5 star review, and it is now my go to in the bay area for Chinese.
author: Barbara S.
