description: After reading yelp reviews we went here. Can't tell you what we ordered.. Don't remember. (Damn yelpers who let too much time go by!!) But I can tell you it was similar to what I remember Chinese food being like in Chinatown in Manhattan. Almost everyone eating here was Asian which is a good sign in my book. The Waiter was extremely friendly, I do remember him telling me to suck my chili while he watched. Does that sound weird? It should, it felt weird, but when in Rome I guess.. We loved the hot and sour soup I do remember raving about it. I don't remember the food besides that which is why I can't do 5 stars. But was a memorable enough experience!
author: Gina J.

description: Get the honey shrimp, jesus sweet mary and joseph those are good.
author: Kyle H.

description: Excellent food at a great price! Would highly recommend and return whenever I visit San Francisco again.
author: Neftali G.

description: Really solid Americanized Chinese food. It has all the classics that I am ashamed I sometimes crave, especially General Tso's Chicken. But unlike the usual strip mall restaurant, it is crunchy, flavorful and not at all greasy. My boyfriend said the hot and sour soup was the best he has ever had and loved the big pieces of tender pork in it.
author: Colleen M.

description:
My first chinese food experience in SF, I must say i am impressed. There was a wait, as per usual but we were pleasantly surprised when 1hr turned into 35mins. The food was great, the server, especially the host were all very friendly and prompt. The best part, dinner for four plus alcohol $80. Cant beat that!! 
Five stars all around. Bravo
author: Ben K.

description:
I walked In and checked yelp while I was ordering.
I got in the trap of the lady with free appetizer dumpling coupon as well and was starving. I don't write yelp reviews but this place is surprisingly BAD!!
author: Dipanker J.

description: A bit too westernized for me, somewhat disappointing for a well-reviewed restaurant in Chinatown.
author: Vick Y.

description:
Doobie doo doo, just walking the streets the of Chinatown in San Fran enjoying all the adorable shops with windows that line the tiny steets, admiring the intricately designed dresses, fans, teapots, and much more. And then I see it out of the corner of my eye; Hunan Homes. I had heard such wonderful recommendations about this outstanding, authentic yet understated little bee bop. One would assume a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown is a guaranteed go, but there is also the double edged sword to highly rated business - sometimes the pressure is too much and the biz can't keep up to the standards. Is this the case with Hunan Homes!? Absofruitely not!

I was seated (alone, tear) and was immediately greeted with a complimentary piping pot of Green Tea I happily sipped while waiting for my Mongolian beef. The ratio of green onions, peppers, broccoli, and beef is so perfect. The flavor was one of those situations you can't describe. Kind of like goose bumps - you can't describe it but you know it when you feel it. I usually siss out after I ravenously inhale good Chinese food after three bites, but I just kept on going on. It's almost like my eyes glazed over and I went into 'frannie' world and all of a sudden I looked down and my plate was empty. Goodnight, I have to go into my food comma now...
author: Frances H.

description: This place has probably ruined other restaurants' Orange Peel Chicken for me because this dish was AWESOME! The chicken was lightly breaded, enough to give it a crunch, and moist. The chicken almost melted in my mouth, it was so good! Their dumpling was pretty darn scrumptious too. The only thing that kept me from giving them 5 stars was the server. He was buzzing around so fast he didn't even ask us for drinks and he gave us noodle soup instead of the wonton soup. And he was flying by too fast to flag him down to tell him.
author: Ellie B.

description: Best hot and sour soup ever. Appetizer combo plate was good too. Ordered the hot and spicy crunchy chicken. It was not as spicy as I would have liked and the entire dish needed more salt. Overall a good experience. The service was excellent.
author: Keith P.

description:
Like Chinese food with succulent shrimps and a nice place to dine?

Most unusual is that there is no 'free' soup.

Here you can order the soup of the day, for $1.75 . Today it was sweet n' sour, not usually one of my favs, but today... Ok, I'll try it. Nom Nom - Their sweet n' sour kicks butt and then some. A bargain. A must try: it's so complex and tastey. I can't describe it,  Japanese would say Umami.

We ordered the Shrimp with Snow peas, baby corn and mushrooms and the chow mein with seafood. We noted the shrimp dish had a red pepper next to the description, so we asked for mild, not too hot. The shrimps are abundant and succulent n' sweet. Snow peas are crisp and fresh.

The chow mein was delicious in a sublime way: you could taste the noodles, taste the tender sweet squid, etc.  It's a refreshing dish. Enjoy it slowly =)

All of the food tastes made with care and quality ingredients; so you pay a bit more because you are worth it.

Decor:  very nice place for a business lunch.

Music: none. yeah!

Customer service: very good.


Really 3.5 stars
author: Bert K.

description: Great classic Chinese food in San Francisco's Chinatown.  Was up here on business and was looking for something close to my hotel.  This was perfect.  I had the delicious orange peel chicken with shrimp fried rice.  I wanted to try more things but as it was I had more than enough food for my days' meals.  Next time.
author: Kimberly S.

description: Found this place because it was well rated on yelp.   We had to wait 30 minutes to be seated, but the wait allowed us to walk a little around Chinatown.  We ordered the B dinner meal.  The spicy wontons were lukewarm, but things got better when they brought the hot and sour soup, which was delicious.  We also got spring rolls, spicy orange chicken, and a beef plate.  The hubby and I fought over the beef plate.   Really good food, good swift service.
author: Andrea S.

description: Very great comfort food for Asians. The price is adequate and the dishes are very traditional.
author: Michelle C.

description:
This is an old school Chinatown staple.  Don't be fooled by the fact that it has lots of non Chinese customers - the food is actually authentic!   Pictures on the menu  do help :)

- XLB: not your traditional Taiwanese type but they did a good job, and the combination of chicken and pork in the filling makes it leaner.  The dipping sauce also had garlic (not just the traditional ginger and vinegar), and I love garlic 
- Shrimp fried rice: tons of shrimp, not too greasy
- Shrimp with lobster sauce: giant prawns, bell peppers, beef, lots of gravy. It had some black beans in it, which added extra flavor (like the Chinese black bean paste type, not actual beans per se).
- Mapo tofu: medium spice, good over rice, generous portion

All the dishes are well seasoned, but I didn't walk away with an msg coma or snugging. Prices are reasonable, and service is friendly. I also like that their food is less greasy than most places, and I like the different spin they put on common dishes (like the black beans in the prawn with lobster sauce).

Of course dinner ends with fortune cookies and orange slices.

It's not as glamorous as R+G lounge, and they don't have fancy cocktails, but they do have beer and wine. I like that it's a smaller place, and the owner / manager is much more personable and friendly (he's got a good sense of humor).
author: Marilyn H.

description:
My friends and I were at the exploratorium on Sunday and decided to go eat chinese in China town which was nearby. We yelped and this place came up, we asked if they had availability for 11 people, they said 20 minutes. Perfect!
We came in, waited 1 minute or two till we were seated. 
We squeezed all together in one table, its ok we all like each other. :)
Service was quick. We ordered a bunch of prawn entrees, one that stood out was prawns and chinese broccoli with oyster sauce. So good! The portions looked small but we ate everything and every single thing was delicious! 
The service was super quick and they were able to make any special requests we had.  It was also packed on a Sunday afternoon and that part of town is not that busy on the weekends. 
It came out to only $16 each, super cheap and good. I will definitly come here next time I'm in the area!
author: Lana K.

description: Very good straight forward Chinese food.  Had to have Peking Duck. Excellent! Wonton soup was brothy and flavorful.
author: Larry J.

description:
Simply good food. Thanks to Yelp we ordered mongolian beef. Different from the usual fast food taste or look. Not as saucy, but the flavor was great and spiciness was perfect!

Service was alright, there were a few staffs.  A younger guy and a grouchy looking lady. The younger guy seemed very friendly, but he was tending someone else's table.  The grouchy looking lady and the owner/cashier made us not really care for anything else but the food. Thank goodness it was good.
author: Lilian P.

description:
Best Chinese in San Francisco maybe even the planet. 

Get ready to wait an hour and line and not be disappointed. 

My restaurant ever. Next time your there get the spicy garlic eggplant.
author: Nick O.

description: man this place is popular but everything is such americanized chinese food. everything came out with an orange glaze and while its craveworthy to some its definitely tiring and creates a gross lacquer at the roof of your mouth after consuming too much of it. sucking on the peppers gave great flavor though! and i liked the salt pepper fried fish, but that was about it. portions were small and prices were insane, but i guess i'm just used to more traditional cooking. i'm not too sure where all the hype is for this place but it was nice to be able to eat family style.
author: Jessica W.

description:
Oh what a disappointment! But, it was pretty cheap at $7-$10 a dish!

Was recommended this place by Nisha, so the hubs and I came here after a day of strolling around downtown. Not sure if they use MSG in their food, but we forgot to tell them not to, and we felt kinda sick afterward.

FOOD:
-Succulent Fried Bread- ordered this based on tips. DON'T. It's this weird sugary thickness and the condensed milk dipping sauce does not help. Felt squeamish later.
-Seafood Crispy Chow Mein- I only wanted the prawns and added Broccoli. The crispy chow mein were actually pretty soggy.
-Vegetarian Fried Rice with Tofu- Hubs said it was very bland and then felt sick after coming home

SERVICE:
+Made reservations and were seated right away. It's a very straightforward, no nonsense kinda atmosphere. What do you want? and Sit Here. But, our hostess made some funny comments like charging us $5 for wanting to use forks instead of chopsticks.

AMBIENCE:
What I would expect of a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. It was packed on a Sunday night though!

*Really wanted to like the place, but not sure if I would take a chance to come back

-Hungry Hungry Pongy
author: Sangita A.

description:
I was never really a big fan of Chinese food.. until now. This place has the best Chinese food I have ever had! My fiancé and I are visiting from Seattle and have been here twice already - once for lunch and the other time for dinner. Waited 10-20 minutes both times without reservations. A couple in front of us had reservations and also had to wait 10-15min. This place gets busy!

We've had the pork chow mein, Kung pao chicken, honey walnut prawns, Mongolian beef, fried wontons, and xiao long bao (soup dumplings). Everything was so flavorful!

The owner/manager/guy in the red vest has shown some great customer service skills. He went around and not only checked in, but he took our order, showed people how to try the hot chili peppers, and would crack jokes with the customers. Cool guy.
author: Summer F.

description: The food is delicious, well portioned, and the restaurant is clean and warm on a cold night. The owner is gregarious, which is another plus!
author: C J.

description: We were looking for a place in Chinatown to get some fantastic food and we found it. At so many Chinese places the food is either blah or it all pretty much tastes the same. Not here. We all got something different and shared and it was all amazing. My only complaint is their chopsticks are super slippery plastic and a little hard to use. Everything else was great!
author: Wendy H.

description:
I was there for a weekday lunch.  Nothing special.

And that describes what I got: nothing special.  I had the Hunan Chicken.  The meat was tender, the vegetables crisp.  The sauce was plentiful, but the flavors were muddled.  

Certainly passable, but nothing special.
author: Tony L.

description:
Came in with family after day at the Wharf.  Authentic and awesome!!.  Had shrimp fried rice and shrimp chow mein with egg rolls.  Friend had General Tso and said loved that it had more chicken than batter.  Asked for orange sauce and totally loved
 Good service.   Would definitely return.
author: Redblisspotatoes ..

description:
Had reservation, but really did not need one at 6pm on Friday.  Food was quickly brought out and it was OK. Kung Pao chicken, Mongolian beef, pork fried rice, garlic broccoli, egg rolls and pot stickers.  The pot stickers were very good and the best of the lot.  None of the food was bad, just nothing noteworthy. 

We did feel pressure to get us out once we were wrapping up eating. I ordered another beer and did not feel like they wanted me to do that. We stayed until I finished my beer and paid the bill. 

No need for us to visit again.
author: John M.

description: We ate here for dinner last evening having seen all the very solid reviews on Yelp. We have eaten some excellent Chinese Szechuan in the city on several occasions. The first observation we made upon arrival at the restaurant was that there were no Chinese people eating dinner. We ordered a spicy fish, spicy eggplant, and hot and sour soup. Everything about the service and overall experience was fine. However, the food was just OK. It was far from authentic Chinese, but very westernized. If you like "American Chinese" then you will like this place.
author: Blake M.

description: Wonderful Chinese meal! Lots of food for the price. When they say spicy, they mean spicy too. Food was brought to us very quickly as well.
author: Jalissa N.

description: Tried it based on good reviews and found both the service and good very mediocre.  The basil chicken was flavorful but many of the pieces of chicken were way to chewy and undercooked to eat.  I had an upset stomach for a few hours after the meal.  Also, the fortune cookies were too stale to eat, but the orange slices at the end were good.  Just ok for me.
author: Elizabeth C.

description: Good food .. Was full was good sign the egg flower soup was different than I've had but was good .. Fast service .. Decent food and would recommend.. Very friendly staff .. There spicy Hunan shrimp was tasty .. The restaurant was slightly of main strip. Overall a good experience
author: Adrian N.

description:
We decided to go to Hunan Homes Restaurant after reading many positive Yelp reviews.
 
After coming here on a busy Saturday night, I suggested this as the best Chinese food he had ever eaten. My friends and I decided to come back and see if it would be as good as I praised.
After we arrived around 3:00 pm we were quickly sat and given complimentary jasmine tea. There were few other patrons in the restaurant and we were hungry. All of us decided to each order a different item and then share it. Our choices were the Chicken with Orange Peel ($10.75), Sweet and Sour Pork Ribs ($9.95), and Prawn in Honey Walnuts ($13.95). After a short wait, we were brought the meals. 

Overall, we rated Hunan Home's restaurant 3.5/5 stars because the quality of the food during lunch was disappointing compared to their Saturday night dinner. So, if you're planning on having great Chinese food in San Francisco wait until it's in the evening on a busy night if you're planning on going to Hunan Home's Restaurant.
author: Christoph F.

description:
The other day I found myself looking for a lunch spot in Chinatown without a clue of the best or worst. But, heck, even I know to dodge a menu being thrown at me by a loud woman on the street corner. 

But thanks to Yelp, I was led to Hunan Homes. And, by golly, it was pretty darn good!

We were immediately seated and offered hot tea. The service was really quick and efficient; the restaurant clean and tidy. And a good mix of people eating around us.

We ordered a bunch of their appetizers:

Wontons in hot sauce
BBQ Pork
Xiao Long Bao
Wonton soup

Everything was really good. The pork could have been warmer, but it was still tasty. I'd read reviews touting the Xiao Long Baos, and they certainly lived up to the hype.

Yelp didn't steer me wrong with this place!
author: Greg S.

description:
Very mediocre restaurant, I was here for lunch and the quality of food was not better than any other Chinese restaurant in the area, the reason why I score 2 stars is because the female server that took our order was not friendly or engaging at all, was kind of upset that when she approached the table one of my guest was not ready yet to order-
The restaurant was not busy at all, also we asked for the salt and pepper ribs and she said that they run out- not sure why the table next to us that order after was able to get it!!
Very bad!!!
Not coming back...
author: John F.

description: Really enjoyed this restaurant. It was quiet and empty around 3pm on a Monday. My aunt and I shared a late lunch, ordering the asian broccoli with shrimp in an oyster sauce and the shrimp chow fun (which is made with a rice noodle). Both were very good. The oyster sauce was the best I've ever had. The shrimp was succulent. The broccolini was cooked to perfection, tender yet crispy). Also loved their hot tea. The decor and vibe felt very traditional and the meal tasted really authentic. Would definitely recommend.
author: Bella B.

description: The food was very good. Only one waiter was serving 10 tables. Although he tried hard. It was difficult to keep up.
author: Marcelo M.

description: My family has been going here for a few decades now and we make a stop whenever we're in the city! Restaurant is located on the edge of Chinatown. Service is fast no matter how busy they are. Prices are on par with the area with lots of delicious options that are great for sharing. Our favorites are the steamed dumplings, hot and sour soup, asparagus prawns and broccoli beef.  Decor hasn't changed much over the years but experience remains good every time!
author: Courtney O.

description: Hmmmm disappointed, unfortunately this place did not live up to the the 4 stars. Possibly this caters to tourists? The xiao long bao appetizer was the best part of our meal juicy meaty dumplings. The chow mien was ok nothing special. Kung pao chicken, well not sure if it was chicken, it had a certain snap/crunch that water chestnuts have. The honey walnut shrimp was just that it did taste a little too much like sweet mayo. Just like a previous yelper noted I guess having been spoiled by what the San Gabriel valley has to offer, has raised the bar for other Chinese restaurants meet.
author: jorge e.

description: My family chose this place bc there was a long line and yelp gave it high reviews. We ordered To-go and the wait wasn't that bad. We ordered the BBQ pork fried rice and it was surprisingly pretty tasty. I was very skeptical but my dad insisted on trying SF Chinese food. Although the portions were small and a little pricy, it was a positive experience.
author: Nicole N.

description:
My wife and I ate here for the first time. We were very pleased with the food overall. We had the egg flower soup which had a lot of flavor. Unlike most egg soups that are watery, this had really tasty broth.

We also has steamed dumplings. They too had good flavor and the sauce they made for it was very good. The sauce had scallions, soy sauce and some additional flavors.

Finally the chicken and broccoli was excellent. Good portions of chicken and perfectly cooked broccoli that too had great flavor. 

The atmosphere was lacking and while the servers were polite they weren't as friendly as the place across the street. However the food here was more flavorful.
author: Jack U.

description:
I've been to this location twice. Once we dropped in with a group of eight on a Saturday evening. We were fairly early (about 5:30) so there wasn't a wait. This was lucky since the place fills up fast and is very popular for dinner.

I was really impressed with this place mainly because of the stellar service and the price (we got out of there for $44 + tip!).

Come to find out, this is one of my brother-in-law's favorite places in Chinatown (he's a long-time SF resident) and he took us here when my father-in-law (his/my wife's dad) came to town. He wanted to impress is father with the stellar chinese cuisine in his city.

Unfortunately, this time Hunan Homes fell short of the mark...

We had a reservation for 7:30 on July 4th. We showed up on-time and were promptly seated. It took a while for the waiter to come and greet us. We ordered drinks but he left without taking the kids' orders! When he came back with the adult's drinks we got him to take the kids' order. They didn't have what my kids wanted so we said they'd just drink water. We ordered soup, several appetizers, and several entrees. 

The soup came out quickly (but not the waters, we asked about that). 

The appetizers followed shortly after we finished our soup, but, again, not the waters. We asked again and were told that the busboy brings the water; "Ok, so get the busboy to bring the water, please."

After a few minutes we received the mu shu pork, but, again, not the waters! We asked again and he promised he'd get them out asap. The mu shu was excellent, BTW.

Now we waited. We had ordered 5 entrees total but all we'd received so far was the mu shu. The one ray of sunshine was that my children finally got their waters!

My father-in-law got up to speak to the manager. The manager came over and told us that they have a "process" and what we have to understand is that they hold back the entrees when we ordered appetizers. Well, that didn't really hold water since it had been 30 minutes since we finished up our mu shu.

The entrees came out immediately.

I think if the manager had simply apologized and got us our food we would have had a great time.

Based on the food and our first experience here I'd give this place 5 stars but the poor service we experienced on our last visit knocks them down by two.
author: Donley P.

description: Great food but crappy service. Can't split checks three ways. Rude servers. No parking. If you can handle all of that then it's a decent place to eat.
author: John G.

description: We had soup dumplings, wontons in chili oil and a shrimp dish and everything was perfect. Far better than anything in the area! It's a bit crowded though so we had to wait a while for our walk in table. Can't wait to come back!!
author: Lucia B.

description: Chinese food, YES. We ordered the hot & sour soup, orange peel chicken and sizzling prawns and it was all delicious. I was down for a second round but my progressively tightening jeans said otherwise. We chose this one based on its Yelp stars and I don't live in San Francisco so I have no idea how this particular restaurant compares to any other in Chinatown but I can say that it is a solid choice if your experience is as limited as ours. Go for it!
author: Scarlett C.

description: Decent food, but not authentic at all. Pure American Chinese food. Nothing special, would not go back again
author: Yun L.

description: Good chinese food, I had the ginger, green onion crabs which was good! I wouldnt recommend the hunan pork though, too salty. Would come again.
author: Sunny L.

description:
Excellent.  See, I'm not a fan of Chinese food- at ALL. 

But not only do I love this place, I actually craved to go back!!!!

Amazing food no matter what you pick, seriously great food.  Their orange chicken is recommended and it looked amazing.  I had usual walnut shrimp, LOVED it. Even the kids, loved their noodles. 

Small place but that's SF.  Good service.  

This place make me change my whole attitude towards Chinese cuisine.
author: Angie E.

description:
To start, I'd give this place 7 stars if I had the option.

We originally had made reservations at Empress of China for dinner on Thanksgiving.  Day of, we actually looked at the Yelp reviews and were not feeling confident we'd have a great meal.  At the last minute we did a quick search and came up with Hunan Homes, and headed over immediately.

The wait was about 45 minutes when we arrived.  The owner kindly put our name down, and told us to feel free to walk around Chinatown and come back at a certain time.  We came back as instructed and were seated promptly.

Based on the Yelp reviews, we ordered:
- pot stickers
- egg rolls
- hot and sour soup
- orange peel chicken
- honey walnut shrimp

The potstickers were fantastic - I loved that our server came to our table and made a quick sauce on our plates.  The egg rolls were fresh and had an almost cinnamon-like taste to them that was quite addicting.  The hot and sour, however, was the star of the show.  I order hot and sour soup at every Chinese restaurant I go to as its one of my favorite dishes, but it often is not spicy enough or has enough flavor.  This hot and sour soup was the best I've ever had.

The orange peel chicken was fantastic, and the owner even stopped by our table to suggest we suck (not chew!) on the peppers to get an even greater depth of flavor.  I asked him if the peppers were preroasted, and he explained to me exactly how that dish was cooked.  Its always nice to hear that your dish is made to order, which explains the length of time between dishes, but also confirms why everything was so tasty.

We left full, totally satisfied and didn't break the bank.  A win all around!
author: Ashleigh B.

description:
Simply. Amazing. 

After some yelp research while in Chinatown, we decided on Hunan Homes. It is off of Grant so we were hoping to avoid the crowds and lines at some of the other popular spots. We were seated right away and good thing too... this place fills up quickly at lunch time. 

Wanting to sample a little of everything we ordered hot and sour and won-ton soups, xiao long bao, egg rolls and the spicy garlic chicken, to share. 

We sipped on green tea while we were waiting... which was not long at all. Service here was fantastic. 

We absolutely loved everything! The won-ton soup was so fresh and not overly salty like so many end up being. My boyfriend loved his hot and sour soup, as well. The egg rolls were also delish and not greasy at all. The xiao long bao was a treat, but the real find here was the spicy garlic chicken. I've never had chinese food this well-cooked, flavorful and fresh in my life. My mouth is watering now just thinking about it and I'm a little sad that I will not be trying it again for some time. 

We loved it so much, we came back on our last day in the city for another go round. This time we skipped the soup and appetizers and split the mongolian beef (also excellent) and another helping of the garlic chicken. Yum!
author: Jo C.

description: While the décor here is much more dressed up than a lot of its neighbors, the food here just didn't live up to expectations.  The tea smoked duck - while full of amazing, smoky aromas - was greasy (even for duck) and the skin didn't have the crispiness you would expect.  Other dishes were better but also greasy.  Not a bad meal by any means, and worth going if you are with people who are sketched out by the no-frills places nearby, but certainly not near the top of my list.
author: Chris C.

description: This place is, by far, the best Chinese food I have ever had. From the soup to the entrées, each dish was outstanding. We had the family meal for 6. Service was friendly and fast. We will definitely be coming back again!
author: Kyle T.

description: Fast service at lunch time.  Had the cashew chicken and chicken chow mein which were very good.  Recommend both.
author: Jennifer M.

description: This is my favorite place to eat in China Town.  Every time I come to San Francisco I make a trip here.  The pot stickers are amazing.
author: Tom T.

description:
A New Yorker walks into this restaurant....and LOVES IT!! The wonton soup was great and they serve everything for you right onto your plate. The mooshoo pork was also on point. It's priced right and the service is A+
As far as I'm concerned I don't need to try another Chinese spot when I return to SanFran. Hunan Homes hit the nail on the head. Tasty as heck.
author: Ming T.

description: Quick service and really good food.  Although I'm not big on Chinese food, the food was tasty and the restaurant was clean.
author: Bye F.

description:
I came here a few days ago with friends while visiting SF. We were a party of six on a Saturday night and still only had to wait five minutes before a table was available. 

Upon being sat, we were given menus, tea, and water. After glancing over the menu a few minutes, we decided to order a variety of dishes, which included: Xiao long bao (Soup-filled dumplings, hot and sour soup,  hot spice crispy chicken, squid with spicy salt, and mapo tofu. 

The dumplings and soup came out first. The dumplings were pretty standard; I liked them but unfortunately some of them ripped before getting to our table so they were missing the yummy soup filling. The hot and sour soup was delicious!! The flavors were very complex and it had just the right amount of heat! I definitely recommend it!

All three main dishes were really tasty; definitely a great combination of flavors! The chicken had a nice crunch to it, was seasoned well, and had this yummy garlic sauce on it. The squid was crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside, and also was well-seasoned. The mapo tofu was really good. I was a little surprised at how firm the tofu was compared to other places I've had it; however, the flavors were well-balanced and the sauce was scrumptious! 

Oh, and as an unexpected surprise, they brought out fresh ice-cold orange slices with the bill. At first, my party was reluctant to try one since we were so full; however, soon it was a free-for-all as they were some of the sweetest and juiciest oranges any of us had ever had. So, make sure to save room!!! 

All in all, this place is a definite winner if you're in the mood for some tasty non-Americanized Chinese food.
author: Heather M.

description: Every aspect of the dining experience here was phenomenal. We were seated and served quickly, the waiter was helpful and had a good sense of humor, amazing wonton soup, amazing pot stickers (the waiter mixed is a delicious sauce for them), amazing mushu pork (rolled into the pancakes by a woman with SPOONS), and amazing orange peel chicken! One of the best overall dining experiences I've ever had!
author: Derrick M.

description:
Fantastic food, great service. Never disappointed. 

Had sizzling rice soup which was not oily. Sizzling chicken, Mongolian beef and orange chicken.
author: robert s.

description:
Wanted to get some authentic Chinese, saw the Yelp reviews, and tried it out! Couldn't get reservations, but only had to wait 5ish minutes (on a Saturday or Friday night!) to get a table. Ended up being pretty disappointed. It wasn't really authentic Chinese, but the sweet and sour soup was some of the best I've had! +1 for that. 

We also had soup dumplings, which were decent, chicken with orange peel (grabbed some recommendations from Yelp), which was standard, and Mushu pork, which was somewhat of a let down -- I couldn't finish it. 

Overall, I'd recommend trying something else. Nothing to write home about.
author: Courtney N.

description: Tried it based on Yelp reviews. Spot on in terms of taste and service. Wor wonton soup was great however the xiao long bau was cold. I've had better. Crispy spicy chicken was good, worth a try. Not bad at all overall, will still return to try other menu items. Service was good too.
author: Liza C.

description: The food was absolutely delicious. Best Chinese food I've had in my life. We got sizzling prawns, Kung pao chicken, chicken with orange peel, honey walnut prawns, chicken chow mein, and chicken fried rice. I LOVED all of it. Definitely best Chinese in San Francisco.
author: Shelby S.

description:
Came here because it was recommended by a lady in a Chinese shop. Found very poor and slow service. Food was below average. Toilet was not clean. 
The best was the fortune cookie at the end. Would not come back.
author: H 8.

description: One of the best in Chinatown! Environment and service are also very good. I strongly recommend EGGPLANT^_ so yummy!
author: Waffle M.

description: Life can not get better when you have Yelp with Google maps on your smart phone. Wife and I were visiting Chinatown for the first time. Having no specific recommandation and hundreds of resturants to choose from, I whipped out my phone and went directly to Yelp for suggestions. First one to pop up was Hunan Home's Resturant. We ordered hunan chicken and chicken fried rice. Food was wonderfully seasoned and the service was great. Not much more you can ask for. Plan to head back to Chinatown on our next visit and use Yelp as before.
author: Harold J.

description:
Whenever I am hungry in China Town, this is my go to place.  One of my favorites is the honey walnut prawns.  The candied walnuts and the sauce on the prawns are crazy good, and goes great with a plate of veggie fried rice.  Their hot and sour soup is also superb.  The customer service has always been great, and they validate parking for the main garage right down the street!!

I've had almost all the prawn dishes here, and they are all quality!  Only downside is it is a bit expensive, but the food quality and quantity is worth it!
author: Brice H.

description: We are from Chicago and were not disappointed with this place.  We would return if we visit SF again.  The 30 minuet wait was worth it.  we had a beer at the restaurant across the street.  Great food.  Try the head on prawns.
author: M D.

description: sat down very quickly, was immediately served some delicious hot tea. decor and room was slightly outdated but it's about the food here. had the pork chow mein, sizzling beef, Hunan strong beans, and steamed rice. all were delicious, although the string beans were a little too salty for our liking, but still good. there's a garage right down the street on the right past Hunans. $2 per half hour.
author: Brian B.

description: After reading all the great reviews visited this place and was not dissapointed. The Chicken with orange peel was delicious! We had the Dumplings in Hot sauce they were great, potstickers were good and BBQ Spare ribs were very good. Also had the combo chow mein and was delicious! Service was great and very friendly. By the time we were leaving there was a wait out the door. Would definetely come back!!!
author: Claudia S.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in Chinatown!  I've found the service to be prompt and polite when I'm here with my family (large group) or just with the boyfriend.  It might be a little more expensive, but the entrees are quite large (and delicious).  I always have leftover moo-shu vegetable (my favorite dish) to have for lunch the next day. :)
Just a quick note: they only validate parking tickets for the dinner hours.
author: Julia G.

description: Saw this on yelp. Comments were place was clean, pot stickers were fresh, and staff was nice. All of the above. Food had a nice fresh taste and we are stuffed for $25 including a Tsingtao. You can see in downstairs and the kitchen is also kept clean. I'd come again if in the Bay Area.
author: Pmcrider S.

description:
I was craving good Chinese food and decided to give this place a try. My husband loves Peking duck and although they suggest ordering it a day in advance, he called earlier in the day and they were able to accommodate his request and he loved it. It was also nice that they offered a half order of the duck, since I was planning to order other dishes. We shared the hot and sour soup, which was a larger portion that we wanted, but it was delicious. I also had the Kung Pao chicken, which I ordered extra spicy and it was great. 

Don't go for the ambience, nothing fancy. Service is quick, not rude, but not friendly. Efficient is best way to describe it. We were entertained watching the bus boy clear and set new tables as he moved so fast it was as if he was slamming the tea cups on top of chopsticks, but obviously a pro because nothing broke. Oh, and the free tea was nice.
author: Robin D.

description: Wandering through China town there are a million places to eat, but we picked this one thanks to yelp. The reviews did not disappoint! Very quick service. Authentic Tasty food, huge menu and cold Tsingtao beer. What more can you ask for! I had the 3 seafood lunch special it was delish, gingery and perfect. Check it out next time you are on Jackson street.
author: E T.

description: Good solid Chinese food. We really like the beef chow main noodles.  Tasty meat and nice noodles. Good "wok" taste. Had to wait a little but not too long.  It was a Wednesday night.  It seems like a touristy place but the food worked for me
author: Deb G.

description:
Hunan Homes and I go way back...way, way back. I had a manager about twenty bosses ago that used to love bringing us here when we were wet-behind-the-ears corporate pups hanging on his every word on how to get ahead in the rat race. I think the only part of the advice that took was coming here all these years later. I just like this place for the food, the efficiency, and the teal carpet (see my photo). OK, I really hate the teal carpet, and there is a heavy Caucasian predominance among the diners. But trust me, this place is very good by Chinatown standards.

Among the many choices on the menu, I like - brace yourself - the $10.95 plate of Steamed Chicken pieces covered in ginger and scallions (see my photo). I know the sight of raw-looking chicken skin makes many stomachs turn, but I just like the freshness of the taste without the burden of an unrecognizable brown sauce. I do get the occasional random piece of bone, but I am usually able to maneuver it before it reaches my gullet. Am I getting too graphic? Anyway, you can probably guess this is not a commonly served dish, but I get it here because they do it very well.

Otherwise, the rest of the menu is perfectly fine. In fact, their dishes make them a perennial winner of Citysearch's annual polls. The menu is mainly a combination of Hunan and Cantonese dishes, but I've enjoyed most everything I've had here over the years. So don't be put off by the big family from Iowa taking over the center tables. They just couldn't fit through the rickety stairwell at Sam Wo's.

FOOD - 4 stars...honestly, one of the better Chinatown options even if I do order strange stuff
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...clean but that teal carpet has got to go
SERVICE - 4 stars...completely buttoned-up
TOTAL - 4 stars...Home is where Hunan is...there's your slogan...I'll send my bill later
author: Ed U.

description:
I'm at a loss of what to say about this restaurant. Let's start with explaining why I only gave it 1 star.

I'm an ABC who considers myself very experienced in eating Chinese food, having eaten at hundreds of Chinese restaurants in my lifetime in the Bay Area and during my stays in 10 different cities in China and Taiwan. I travel to China or Taiwan about once a year.

I came here during lunchtime on Friday with my family, because we were in Chinatown and I wanted something good. I pulled out my phone and found this place rated as 4 stars.

My ratings:
Cleanliness: 4/5, better than the average Chinese restaurant, I'll give you that.
Service: 3/5, the waiter seemed impatient because we were asking him all these questions about what was good to order, because the menu was practically completely in English, and I'm not familiar with the names of dishes if they're in English, because a dish that everyone knows as 4-5 Chinese characters becomes an incomprehensible English sentence describing the dish.
Food: 0/5, don't even bother.

Boy, was I disappointed. As soon as we stepped in, I looked around and saw that most of the restaurant patrons were Caucasian. First surprise. After we were seated, I pulled out my phone again, and actually READ the reviews for this restaurant instead of just trusting the star ratings blindly. Profile pictures of several more Caucasians. Second surprise. By that time, the waiter had already poured the tea for us, so we felt bad about leaving, hoping to wait out the initial bad impression and for the star ratings to be proven right.

Saying this place is authentic Chinese food is like saying Panda Express or P.F. Changs is authentic Chinese food. What they created here at Hunan Homes Restaurant is a Chinese restaurant for Americans. Don't come here if you want real authentic Chinese food--I can recommend you a couple other places around Chinatown that don't appear as clean but are actually delicious--you know, the greasy Chinese restaurants where they do a haphazard job of wiping down the table with a dirty rag and you don't want to rest your elbows on the table.

I don't remember if there was any Chinese in the menu--the words were completely in English. So we ordered 3 lunch specials and sauteed string beans, because nothing else looked appetizing.

The fish, shrimp, and seafood lunch specials all came out with exactly the same sauce, and overly salty at that. My dad took three bites of it and stopped eating--that's how bad it was! My wife (who grew up in China) had 70% left on her plate and I had about 10% left on my plate when we were done. I was raised to not waste any food, so we packed up the leftovers. The next day, I made fried rice in the wok at home by adding three cups of rice and three scrambled eggs to the leftovers--the resulting creation was much better than the original.
author: Jonathan T.

description: I had the hot and sour soup and the Hunan chicken. Excellent food and service at a great price.
author: Tony S.

description: Fast service eventhough it was so crowded during lunch hour. The food did not disappoint.
author: mai t.

description: We might choose wrong dishes. We got dumplings which I could tell they were frozen and fried (too much... their bottoms were all black!) meaning they were certainly factory products not restaurant-made, honey walnut shrimps (way too much sauce, less than ten shrimps), and crispy spicy (Not spicy at all; I needed to add a lot of chili oil) chicken. Overall, foods were in such a low quality. Rather go to panda express. Later we realized that a Chinese restaurant right across the street received Michelin award and was visited by Obama. I don't get why this place got such a high rating :^/
author: Heri K.

description: Great spot for authentic Chinese food near Chinatown.  Need to get there early because gets crazy busy.
author: Tal S.

description:
I was in San Francisco last year and was in Chinatown. I wanted Chinese food but did not know where to go. I used Yelp and Hunan Home was the top on the list. I was very happy with everything I ordered. The food was very delicious. I just went back to San Fran last week and went back to Hunan Home and the food was better than I remember. 

I would recommend the egg rolls and the hot and sour soup
author: Nikki S.

description: Loved it.  Great authentic food and feel.  Great prices. Orange peel chicken was excellent.  Some of the best wonton soup I've had. Fast friendly staff. Will definitely go back
author: Andy S.

description: I had the "steamed chicken" from the menu which turned out to be the hainan style chicken despite the fact that the waiter did not know what I was talking about when I asked for clarification when I was ordering if that was indeed what out was. Delish. My fiance had the garlic green beans lunch special. Also very yummy. The place doesn't have much ambiance nor the most polite service, but good enough and the food is what was quite good. It had a huge menu. A bit curious to why Chinese people didn't seem to flock this restaurant the way they did with the others around there. Regardless, I'd say yes to this place.
author: Ming C.

description:
Satisfying and delicious Chinese food that is worth a few extra dollars.

I had quite a meal at Hunan. Five of us ordered 6 dishes to share. All of the dishes were quite satisfying. Not everything we ordered was the most authentic, but everything was tasty. It is definitely not the cheapest Chinese restaurant in town (most main dishes costing ~$12), but the food was worth it and the service was great.

The Mongolian beef was great. I do not usually order this dish, but it is probably the best version of the dish I have tried at a restaurant. The meat was tender and just spicy enough.  

Another good dish was the deluxe seafood sizzling platter. It was impressively served at the table on a really hot plate to great effect. It was loaded with pretty sizable scallops and also had some shrimp and squid. I definitely recommend you order at least one of the sizzling plates. 

We also tried the honey walnut prawns (which for some reason are a staple at every Bay Area Chinese restaurant), the orange chicken, some egg rolls, and the string beans. All of the dishes were good, my least favorite being the egg rolls. Some of the members of my party expressed disappointment at the orange chicken. I thought it was fine. It is hard to know what good orange chicken is because it is not the most authentic dish and thus varies a lot based on the place you order it. 

Overall the food was enjoyable and filling. We ordered drinks which brought the price per person to about $23. Definitely not the cheapest, but the food was worth it and the service friendly and professional. All of the food was freshly made, served hot in a timely manner. They take reservations and the restaurant is spacious and appropriately decorated. I would say Hunan is a very 'tourist friendly' restaurant.

If you are in the city with a group of friends and/or family definitely check it out!
author: Augusto T.

description: I came here with a professor and another student on the Professor's recommendation. Fairly typical Chinese food, the whole experience was good and the service was on point for a busy lunch hour. We all left stuffed, with leftovers!
author: Stephanie D.

description:
We were on the look out for a great Chinese place in China town to go eat at; and we had someone recommend this place to our group and we were all thoroughly satisfied and filled.  The place was packed and it was packed with Chinese people so we knew we were in the right place.  We let our waiter handle our order and just told him recommend his favorites and we said let's do it.

I would highly recommend this place and I will go back for more next time I'm in the city.

Keep up the great work over at Hunan Homes, you guys are doing an A+ job.
author: Jarrod F.

description:
Awesome traditional Hong Kong food. Price was fair. I had the jellyfish as an appetizer and it was complimented perfectly with sliced cucumbers and dikon radishes. It was drizzled lightly with sesame oil and really gave it a nice and light lift. 

For the main course, I had tea soaked and deep fried duck which was divine. Really tasted the tea marinade and def reminds me of a home cooked Hong Kong dish. 

Just when I left, there was a line out the door so plan ahead!
author: Andrew K.

description: We were visiting SF to attend our niece's graduation at nearby UC Berkeley.  Though I've been to the Bay Area many times, my brother and his wife and kid has never been... so we took a tour all over and wanted to eat at Chinatown for some real deal Chinese food (not that PF Chang whitewashed blandness) so yelped it and found this place.  No regrets...great hot and sour soup and their seafood specials, but man, their Peking Duck was off the hook.  Great prices and great food.  Recommend it highly.
author: H W.

description: To ensure good service I called in ahead to confirm seating would be quickly available and prompt bringing out of food could be accommodated, which the restaurant was able to deliver. This restaurant accommodated my small party of 2. We enjoyed our sizzling rice soup, crispy duck, veggies, and prawn dishes. The logistics of the inside the restaurant were not as big as could be desired say if I had a larger party, which I've taken before to RJ Lounge not too far away. As the inside was the only negative, I'm still a fan and could see returning back. Much better options than any House of Nanking also not too far away. There is this nearby parking lot on Jackson street that we would park at, that was just a walk down from the restaurant.
author: L L.

description:
We dined here during the Autumn Moon Festival in Chinatown - definitely a busy Saturday!

We had the fried wontons, egg rolls, and pot stickers as appetizers. The potstickers were fantastic!  You could easily skip the wontons and egg rolls if you come - although they are good, they aren't anything special. 

As entrees we had the Mongolian Beef and the House Special Crispy Chow Mein.  The Mongolian beef was delicious - although it had a spicy after bite. If spicy food is not your thing, you'll want to skip this dish. The Chow Mein was a huge portion with loads of seafood and vegetables. It's a great meal to share. 

Overall we were very pleased with our Chinatown dining experience!
author: Veronica J.

description:
Came here for dinner at around 6pm on a Saturday.  It was good timing as about 15 minutes later the place got instantly full and people were being told there was about a 30 minute wait.  

We had the Hot and Sour soup and Pot Stickers to start.  My wife raved about the soup.  We then had the Walnut Shrimp (very good) and the Orange Chicken (meh).

The service was good, but nothing spectacular.

If you're looking for Chinese food that is good but familiar, give this place a try.
author: Kevin H.

description:
Found this place from others Yelp reviews, as I find it super sketchy to just walk into any old restaurant in Chinatown. 

They gave us soup, even though we ordered a la carte. That was nice. My mom and I dont typically like hot and sour soup, but this was very good.

Ordered the sampler appetizers, though they were fried, they didnt seem too greasy, which was great.

Then the BBQ Pork Fried Rice, very good. also not greasy.

Lastly the Honey Walnut Prawns. They were good, but it wouldnt have been what I would have selected, my mom wanted them!

The service was alright, but I dont expect much from a place like that in the service category! 

I would go back for sure.
author: Amithyst B.

description:
This is your typical family-owned Chinese restaurant. The seating is reasonably limited (not too few, not too excessive), with many large round tables to accomodate groups. Service is a plus because they were very attentive.

The food was very impressive. With all the high rated reviews from fellow yelpers, I found comfort in my selections on the menu. We got the seafood fried rice with sauce (not sure of the actual name. please see my photo. it's been a while), salt and pepper pork, a vegetable dish, and a tofu hot plate dish. They were all freshly prepared and simply delicious. I don't think you could go wrong with anything on the menu.

Prepare to be amazed by these fabulous home styled meals. Just be weary of the limited parking.
author: Anna B.

description:
Wow, this may be the best Chinese food I've ever had.

After numerous recommendations by locals to come here, I decided to go for it and get the hot and sour soup they were raving about.  

After just gazing upon the bowl it was served in, I was actually taken aback by how pretty the presentation of the soup was.  How is that possible???  It's soup!!  It tasted even better though, with a nice balance of flavors.  My only gripe is that it could have had more pork in it like the menu promised.

Unsure what to order for a main course, I figured the restaurant's namesake Hunan chicken wouldn't disappoint.  And this is why this is the best Chinese food I've ever eaten.  IT ACTUALLY TASTED LIKE CHICKEN!
author: Stewart K.

description: I had to wait half an hour to get seated, but it was worth the wait! I ordered a wonton soup and the honey walnut shrimp- both were delicious! I only wish I had room to try more dishes. I last came here about three years ago during another trip to SF and I remember being just as pleased.
author: Tania D.

description: Great service, fast. And delicious. Some of the best in Chinatown for a casual lunch or dinner. Kung Pao, string bean chicken, and the double mushroom shrimp and prawns were wonderful. The hot and sour soup and the wanton soup were also fantastic. Highly recommended!!
author: Chris P.

description:
Very good, but not extraordinary.

Decent service, standard to above average decor for the area & good but not great food.
author: Miguel S.

description:
My friend and I were looking for a place in China Town to grab lunch while we were on vacation in San Francisco. I read a lot of really good Yelp reviews about Hunan Homes and after eating there, I definitely agree. 

Pros: 
         Great prices for lunch combos
         Good food
         Clean as far as Chinese restaurants go
         Fast, friendly service

No cons really come to mind.

I had the eggplant with shrimp. It was delicious and included hot and sour tofu soup. The dish was large enough to fill me up, but not so much that it was a gut buster. For desert we got oranges to cleanse the palate(which I thought was cool) and fortune cookies. The total bill including tip and everything was less than $20 for the two of us.

Great place, Yelpers did not lead me astray, and I would love to go back.
author: Brett P.

description:
Excellent food.  Good and friendly service.  Reasonably pricing.

I had the sizziling beef and scallops and a side of white rice.  The beef was tender and juicy.  Beef was placed on a hot plate at the table.  I got a satisfactory number of scallops (5). Side of rice was 2 bucks and came in a pot.  

Very good overall!  Really good meal.
author: Pavel V.

description:
Nice family owned restaurant.  Convenient for financial district staffers and Chinatown locals.  I usually order the Ma Po Tofu or the Hunan smoked pork or prawns over rice.  Eat in diners get a small bowl of hot/sour soup with their lunch plates.  Pot stickers are well made as the skins are hand-made by their kitchen, not the frozen ones.  Sizzling rice soup and Crab Corn soup are good too.  
On weekends, their lunch menu adds many local Taiwanese dishes such as soup dumplings, Tainan Pork Noodle soup, hot soy bean soup with fried bread (for dunking).  Not many places that serve these dishes in the city anymore.  One of the few Chinatown restaurants that serves Northern Chinese cuisine.
Almost forgot to mention their Noodles with bean sauce (jia jiang mien), comprised of small tofu cubes, ground pork, julienne cucumbers, and bean sprouts.  Good stuff.
author: Mike C.

description: We came to Chinatown and there are many choices so we yelped and Hunan Home got great reviews. We were not disappointed. The eggplant with prawns and chicken was terrific. The chicken fried rice was also excellent.
author: Larry P.

description: Very fast service. Great dumplings, Oolong tea & Mongolian beef. Egg rolls were very good and my chicken & broccoli was pretty good. The owner was so accomidating
author: Misty K.

description: Not good. Shrimp appetizer was nothing but breading, plus they did not devein the shrimp. They ran out of beef. The chicken entrees tasted the same and the chicken was fatty, mushy, and disgusting. Definitely go somewhere else.
author: Katie C.

description: Sooooo delicious! Kind and courteous staff, delicious soup dumplings and string beans. Yummy tea. This place is a gem!
author: Corinne P.

description: I was really craving some Peking Duck, so I did some research on Yelp and found this restaurant. Peking Duck needs special preparations, so I reserved it days in advance. Of course the duck wasn't as good as the ones in China but the duck turned out to be great (4 stars)! I took one star off because there were still a little bit of duck hair on the duck skin. The Xiaolongbao was terrible though (1 star); it was the worst Xiaolongbao I have ever had. We had to wait 30 minutes for the food to come out which was quite disappointing since we ordered the duck in advance. It was an overall okay experience, so I won't revisit unless I crave Peking duck again in the future.
author: Chen Y.

description: Don't go by the ratings. Definitely deceiving. The food was absolutely terrible. While we were eating, we thought the food tasted off, but made nothing of it. To our surprise we got sick soon after leaving. On another note, the customer service is awful. There are better places to eat at. Don't waste your time at this place.
author: Nisreen T.

description: Yelp never lets me down, and when i went to vacation up in San Fran, i had to yelp a Chinese place that was CLEAN and had tasty food....guess what Chairman Mao, this place kicks ass. The only reason why i didnt give this place 5 stars, was that the restroom and floor in hallways were a bit dirty.
author: Victor G.

description: Delicious.  Great value and super-friendly staff.  We go here often and always leave happy and full.
author: Paul W.

description: This was a great find!  This place had amazing vegetarian options. We had king pao tofu & assorted vegetables. The service was great too!
author: Jacki C.

description:
I am not a fan of Chinese food...not at all! However, I recently tried this place with a group of friends and liked it so I guess I should retract the statement.

If I had to eat Chinese food, this would be the only place I would go.  I would recommend going with a group so you can use the lazy susan and try a lot of different dishes.
author: Vanessa L.

description: Food incredible-could have been a little friendlier- but they did what was expected! I went for good food I got good food! The best spicy wontons ever!!!
author: Laura F.

description: Next time I go here I'm getting the Mu Shu.
author: Ameer N.

description:
Food is amazing! You can definitely tell it's pure authentic Chinese food. 
The server was running around and wasn't the nicest but the food made up for it.
Prices were decent and the lunch special, if you can make it, is SO worth it. 
Definitely recommend this place though!
author: Erin R.

description: Unfortunately I can't agree with many of the reviews.   We were treated rudely by the person taking our order.  He was nasty and upset that he had to take our order during the end of his shift.  Three meals came in so spicy that they were uneatable and one came in after everyone else had eaten.   Very disappointed with the whole  experience since we had very high expectations based on all the reviews.  Although, they tried to make it right by discounting one meal, I would never recommend to a friend.
author: Rita R.

description: The service was rude!!! The waiter was being extremely rude and we werent being serviced after a long time after our initial sitting and when we finally said we were ready to be serviced, he came up to us, pulled out his pen, and angrily said "OK". Not "how can i help you?" Or anything of that nature.  There was one kind server walking around and the food wasnt even that good. Out of the six meals served to us, only two was considered "enjoyable". Would NEVER recommend this place to anyone. We came because it was apparently number one, but wow were we disappointed. Food was bland, unenjoyable, and not really good quality. Too bad, we were really looking forward to this place on our trip.
author: Danny R.

description: Great experience. Had the sizzling prawns, xiao long bao, and white rice. The XLB had a great texture - the best I've had taste wise. The prawns were phenomenal. They had some heat, but it wasn't overwhelming. The sauce they were in also wasn't too sweet, it was an excellent combination of hot and sweet. I ate all that (6 XLB and the prawns and rice) by myself; though, I had just walked a dozen miles and was hungry. I'll be recommending to friends. Service was quick as well.
author: Caroline S.

description: Not an expert on Chinese food and what is authentic or not, but this is delicious. Egg rolls are always a good start, everything we've ordered has been fantastic.
author: Justin L.

description:
Found my way to the Hunan Homes via fellow yelpers. We were in Chinatown for the afternoon and looking for lunch.

We arrived in the early afternoon and there was plenty of seating available in the restaurant. I ordered the orange chicken and it was great. I would definitely recommend this place for anyone visiting Chinatown.
author: Jason K.

description:
Food was excellent. The best American style in china town. Only
Downfall was our party was 11 so took awhile to get food
author: Mark S.

description: It was like a Chinese restaurant in any town in America. On the plus side, it was a great value for the money at lunch time. The quality was pretty good given the low cost. It was also a restaurant that allowed us to have a conversation. Not quiet exactly, but not as cacophonous as the one across the street that looked so hip and fun. The downside is I didn't feel like I was having an especially Chinese experience.  They were mostly Gringos eating there when we went, a troubling sign if we were looking for a true Chinese restaurant. The restaurant is a little tattered, just like the ones in your own home town. But value for the money, definitely 4 stars.
author: Kristy H.

description:
Have any of you fellow Yelpers...
ever been sooo hungry, that your legs were shaking, and
you literally wound up diving into the nearest restaurant?
That's my epic tale of how I wound up at HHR.  

I got the Hunan Smoked Pork, complete with lotsa cabbage, and green onion/leeks. I asked the waitress if they could add some chewy noodles to the wok, instead of ordering steamed rice. They obliged. The dish was good, nothing great, and yet was satisfying. I liked the pork slices. The dish was fairly greasy, but then again, we are talking about a pork dish. Not great, yet not bad. A semi-solid 2.5 rounding up to 3.0.
author: Derek N.

description:
8/2011

We dipped into Chinatown for some authentic grub - we were not disappointed!  

They had such an expansive menu, not your typical take Out you see in your average (Nebraskan?) communitiy!

Soups and Sauces had a depth of flavor you don't get just anywhere.  I had a Sizziling rice entree that I would order again in a heartbeat. Loads of fresh veggies.

Service was good.  Atmosphere was okay.  Diet Coke was served out of cans.
author: Amanda B.

description: Pork pot stickers rock big time! Chicken with orange peel was OK. Mongolian beef was great.   Service was horrible.
author: Larry S.

description: Make a reservation because this is a popular restaurant. We had the orange peel chicken, Hunan pork, broccoli beef and sweet & sour pork ribs, pork fried rice. Everything was great!!  Service was excellent.
author: C M.

description:
Nice enough restaurant.  Large eating area downstairs in the back.   Food is MEK.   Service was very poor - typical in Chinatown!   Too salty for all the dishes we ordered.  Clams in black bean sauce, salt & pepper ribs & string beans.   

I was going to have the family Chinese NY dinner here........so glad I didn't. 

Is it true that to REALLY enjoy a great Chinese meal - go out of Chinatown?

I think so!
author: Marie E.

description: great place, drive from Concord to eat there. honey walnut prawns are fantastic as well as the white fish with veggies plate.
author: Kris C.

description: This restaurant has a very misleading name that made me think they will have typically Hunan dishes. But from their whole menu, I can only find two Hunan dishes. Hunan beef doesn't exist in China. I asked them if they have Steamed Fish Head with Diced Spicy Red Peppers, the most famous human dish, they told me they don't have it. Moreover, I also didn't see that they provided chopped chili, they spicy that differentiate Hunan food and Szechuan food. I have to say most of their dishes are American Chinese food, usually these dishes won't even show up in a real Chinese restaurant. In terms of their food, you can see the guts of the shrimps, which weren't properly cleaned. Again, they put to much soy sauce to the dishes that covered the flavor of materials. So, if you want to have something fast, this place might be ok, but overall, as a Chinese, I had a very bad experience in this restaurant.
author: Tong L.

description: Really good Chinese food! First time here, we had Beef w/ Orange Peel, Spicy Chicken Chow Mein, and Pot stickers, everything was delicious! Some of the best Chinese food I have ever had! I highly recommend this place.
author: Albert S.

description: I do not understand how this restaurant has obtain so many good reviews! It was disappointing and discussing. We pick a restaurant in China Town so we could have real authentic Chinese food! The menu was  bland nothing exciting. We ordered sweet and sour chicken and the sizzling beef. The sweet and sour chicken was cold and the chicken tasted like it was dipped in hot wing sauce. The sizzling beef was thrown onto a hot plate in front of us so all it did was make noise because the beef was already cooked on a different plate. So happy we paid an extra 4 bucks for some noise. On top of that NONE of the vegetables were cooked! We would have asked our server if we could have a different on tray or maybe even just a heat up, but they were no where to be found till the bill came. Should have went to New Panda.
author: Taylor W.

description:
I came with a small group of out-of-towners after they found this place using Yelp and filtering for good and cheap.  Parking was terrible in this Chinatown close to downtown.  We had driven around for 20min, were a few sec late on a couple of spots and lost out, and were about to find the paid parking garage when we found an empty spot off Grant and Jackson.  Our perseverance paid off!  

Once inside, we were seated quickly and they didn't even check our reservation.   We quickly noticed that almost all of the other tables were full, but only one of the groups was Asian.  So, using the measure that if the number of ethnic customers reflects how good the ethnic food is, this restaurant loses.  

The menu offers a variety of dishes and is in Chinese and English.  We ordered the sizzling prawns in chili sauce, Hunan beef with veggies, and fried rice with shrimp and pork.  They tasted fine.  Portion sizes were reasonable and served family-style.  The 3 entrees were ordered were perfect to fill the 3 of us up.  Service wasn't too bad either.  Everyone greeted us and they were quite speedy and attentive.  They've won a lot of local awards for their restaurant.  All in all it's a good, safe place to go if you're a tourist or easily intimidated by ethnic cuisine.   However, if you're looking for more exotic fare, perhaps something more challenging to your palate, I would go elsewhere.
author: May N.

description:
Hot Sour Soup: Good, a little more spicy than the typical hot sour's. A small was enough for 4 people so don't feel the need to order a ton.

Xiao Long Bao: Probably the best thing we had. They had a smoky flavor and a light wrapper so it wasn't too filling before the other dishes. 

Egg Rolls: These were okay, nothing special.

Pork Fried Rice: Not as fried as the standard which was a nice change. The ingredients were fresh and it had a ton of vegetables.

Kung Pao Shrimp: As suggested by the waiter--lots of shrimp, bamboo shoots, red and green pepper and whole peanuts. The spiciness builds, so watch out for the peppers throughout the dish. 

Orange Peel Chicken: My sister loved this but it seemed a little mushy to me. 

Hunan Chicken: Once again a ton of vegetables and a good hearty, gravy-like sauce. 

Service was friendly and fast but it felt a little touristy seeing as the restaurant was filled with tourists. I would go back if I wanted good Chinese food, but would probably consider other places first.
author: Hayley H.

description:
I just had the Hunan Smoked Pork and it was absolutely incredible.

The pork was just unreal! Reminded me of the Smoked Pastrami dish from Mission Chinese. 

You need to eat here!
author: Alexander M.

description: Great food and service. We came here around4 and were promptly seated and orders taken. Hot and sour soup was delicious along with pot stickers and moo shoo. Highly recommended!
author: Kris K.

description:
My wife and I were on vacation in San Francisco and we took a walking tour through Chinatown. It was a beautiful day and we saw that Yelp gave this place a good review.

It isn't really a flashy facade, but inside I liked the atmosphere. It was quaint, but I went to the restroom, and there is a whole other room downstairs for parties I think.

My only complaint about the place is that our waiter didn't really seem to want to be there, but the food more than made up for it.

I had the Squid Kung Pao. There were lots of pieces of squid and the sauce was wonderful. Tangy yet with the added hot chili oil I added, it was super flavorful and just fantastic.

They also give you free tea when you walk in, which was a nice touch. Plus they refilled our pot when it ran out.

My wife ordered a side of brown and white rice. Very delicate, I loved the brown rice with chili paste added to it with some soy sauce. Just perfect!

If you go to Chinatown, you must try this place. I think the owners were there and their kid was helping out I think. So good!

The prices were pretty reasonable too. I think my squid was 12 bucks.
author: Jason K.

description: Best part of this restaurant wasquick service. The dishes were just ok. We had Kung pao chicken and beef with string beans. I would not return.
author: Irene C.

description: Could have been batter but it was busy. Also, there wasn't any soap in bathroom, which clouds my judgement. But overall, food was fresh, fast to come out, and tasty. Only reason not 5 stars was how curt the staff was...quick no talking, checking in on tables, taking cashed bill back and giving change in timely fashion. And of course the lack of soap. (We were there for dinner time on a Thursday...6pm)
author: Jo V.

description: 2nd time here and again an awesome experience!  The food is authentic and EXCELLENT!  James made our visit that much more richer!  Thank you James! We will be back again!  :)!
author: Jami Y.

description:
After reading all of the reviews, my friends and I decided to try Hunan. We weren't disappointed. As everyone is saying, the orange peel chicken and potstickers were delicious. So was the mu shu. When you go, get several dishes and share with each other. That'll help you get the most of your eating experience.

Also, the service was wonderful. Everyone was friendly, and one of the managers showed me how to taste the peppers without setting my mouth on fire. Overall, it was a wonderful experience.
author: Donna N.

description:
This is the epitome of Chinese in SF.

Its nothing fancy inside, but that is part of the experience. It feels like you just stepped across the big pond and into a restaurant in Beijing. It is just a fun place to eat.

The food is pretty much exactly how I prefer Chinese. I have never been to China, so I can't comment on how authentic it is, but I don't care, this is great food. Not too greasy or sweet, fresh "al dente" vegetables, and identifiable meats ;)

The service has always been really good and they always serve yum jasmine tea right off the bat.

They have great lunch and dinner specials that I usually get since it makes ordering much easier for me. Too many choices makes my head spin sometimes.

I come here every time I visit SF, an easy place to recommend.
author: Dan K.

description:
On our trip into Chinatown we were hungry and we Yelped (of course) this place came up with great reviews. 

The waitress was funny trying to speak English,  fast English at that.  Ha! 

I had the orange chicken (yes, I know boring, but I like to see how others make it) and the salt and spicy rib-lets.  Anything Salty and Spicy in my mouth is pure HAPPINESS.   

I can't wait to go back
author: Nikki G.

description: This place is sooooooo good!!! I come to San Fran often and haven't been able to find a good Chinese restaurant until now! We stayed at the Westin st. Francis and they suggested this little hole in the wall place, it was great! We got the orange peel chicken, Mongolian beef, pork fried rice and chicken chow mein, I suggest all of them as options!!! So good! Will def be coming back here from now on!
author: Regina L.

description: Food was okay at best. I had the Hunan chicken, spicy eggplant, and vegetable fried rice. Honestly very very disappointed given the great reviews. This was place was just not that good, and I would not return.
author: Krishna P.

description: Best Peking Duck I've had in a long time. I've been back twice in 2 weeks. Good price too. Potstickers great and would order the pork dumpling soup again too.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I was taking a class nearby and came here for lunch. I thought it was odd that they didn't have a lunch menu..but everyon on menu was pretty inexpensive. I was craving noodle soup and was disappointed to find  that there was only ONE noodle soup option on their menu. 

The soup was decent..I saw that others who got rice dishes received huge portions. This is prob a better place to come with a larger group so you can try various dishes.
author: Mimi T.

description: Fellow Yelpers, you let me down.  We went here based on the 4 stars but the minute we sat down and read the menu we knew we were screwed.  Total whiteyfied menu - boo.  And super expensive for what we got (and we just ate at Aveline & Kin Khao so we're happy to spend money, but not for this type of touristy rubbish).  The pea tendrils stir fried in garlic were something like $13!!??!!  It really should have cost no more than $5 at best (they are cheap to source/buy and take no skill to fry up in 30 seconds.)  The Sizzling Shrimp were got were in a gloopy cornstarch filled hot and sour sauce.  That's about all we could muster.  They received 2 stars and not 1 because they cooked it well and perhaps it's not their fault that they serve the whitey food that the average tourist wants.  They're just supplying their demand.  But we were sad.
author: Ella G.

description:
I am sincerely surprised this place has such good ratings. We (my two teen kids and I) for lunch a couple days after Christmas 2012. I chose it based on Yelp review. Have been a Californian all my life but have never eaten a meal in San Francisco's Chinatown. We were killing time while Dad had a business meeting nearby.

The food was simply blah and far inferior to a place we, thankfully, found near our Sacramento home that has the most fresh and flavorful Chinese food we've ever had without all that starchy thick sauce all over it. I kept silent wondering if it was just me then halfway through our meal, I had to know so I asked my kids very lightly (so as to not tip my hand and get a really honest opinion) what they thought. They both were not impressed. All three of us thought is was somewhat tasteless and too "saucy" in that generic Chinese restaurant way. Our place at home has super fresh dishes without any of that cloudy saucy look to it. The beef two of us had was overcooked and flavorless. All three of us were so disappointed.

None of us finished our meal and, this is a first, none of us asked for it be boxed up.

That was only paralleled by how indifferent the staff were to us. I felt we were invisible. We were the first patrons in at lunch time. No warm hello. More of a wave to a table and a "sit there". No one came by to say "how is your lunch?" The ONLY smile I got was (no surprise here) when the hostess came to give me the check. Smiling for the first time when bringing the check is a huge turnoff to me. That says "I am now hoping the tip will be good and I'll pretend to be friendly even though no one in here has given you any attention whatsoever"

My daughter had some sort of 3-seafood dish. My son and I both had Mongolian Beef. All, in all honestly, terrible.

I don't review restaurants on Yelp often. This may only be the 3rd in many years but I had to share our very, very disappointing experience.
author: Stella M.

description:
The staff here is great. Great sense of humor and the place must be good because it was practically full the entire time we were there. Luckily although there were 6 of us we were seated within two minutes.

I enjoyed the appetizers we had (egg rolls, veggie dumplings).

The Hunan Chicken and the chow mein has a good taste.

The food just didn't leave a lasting impressing on me. I would eat here again though.
author: Chris T.

description: Here on vacation and my family was in THE MOOD for "Chinese" food...... Boy, did we ALL get what we were craving!! Not only was the food EXCELLENT, for a Saturday night with a line, we only waited 30 minutes. We anticipated an hour. The staff and food was AMAZING!! We highly recommend the Green beans and shrimp, hot and sour soup, house special crispy chow mien!! ALL of them were EXCELLENT!!
author: Andrea J.

description: Great food, fast service, very inexpensive.  Crowd for lunch.  Little bit of wait.  Had asparagus chicken.  Yummy
author: John R.

description:
We ordered the Family Plan A or whatever it was called and it was excellent. They let us substitute the mixed veggies for the orange chicken and it was awesome. 
Service was quick, friendly and *quick*! Excellent wonton soup (the best I've ever tasted), some potstickers (excellent!) followed by spring rolls, sticky rice, Cashew Chicken, Sweet and Sour Pork, Mongolian Beef. The Orange Chicken and Mongolian Beef were spicy but not too spicy. Just right.
We'll come again!!
author: Christiaan V.

description: We will definitely be back when we are downtown for our "Tourist" day. Great Chinese food, and I am very picky. My friends say I only like white guy Chinese, so that may tell you something.
author: Brent J.

description: I really enjoyed dinning here. The food was hot and good especially the chow mien. The service was nice and fast. The place was busy and everybody seemed happy eating.
author: Janet P.

description: Exceptional and affordable food ($20-30) per person. Service was not fantastic, but the food more than compensates.
author: Jonathan H.

description: The food was good but the service wasn't great. Took forever to wait, and they couldn't keep up quality customer service during busy times. Food wasn't the best either. It was just good.
author: Asem A.

description: Food was okay, but nothing to write home about. Still, it did satisfy my appetite. The customer service was NOT GOOD. I have NEVER been to a restaurant at which the waiter pointed to my table when the hostess told him to seat us.
