(I could've sworn I just saw this on the Food Network's "Mystery Diners" or some show like that.) But after we were seated the service got a LITTLE bit better; it was just the older waiter at the beginning who was a P.O.S. In the end, I probably won't return here.
author: John H.

description: love this place, drive from the east bay just to eat there. White fish with veggies is the bomb!!
author: Vince C.

description: The food could hold its own with the best that Safeway has to offer. Everything was bland, everything was over sauced, everything was underwhelming. Ordered the Xiao Long Bao, and was dismayed at the dearth of soup in the dumplings. Chicken chow mein was the best dish we had (we also ordered the Hunan beef which was a mistake).
author: Nicholas H.

description: Even though the chefs are Chinese, the meal doesn't taste like real Chinese food. It's kind of American & Chinese food, like Panda Express. Maybe that's why it is rated 4 stars. And the restaurant looks a little bit dirty.
author: Qing Y.

description:
I saw the four star review on yelp and while visiting Chinatown my wife and I stopped by this restaurant. We ordered sweet-and-sour pork and fried rice. When our food arrived I tried to cut a few pieces of sweet and sour pork. There was so much gristle in those pieces I could not cut them at all with my fork. 
We were very disappointed with the food and service.
author: Kenneth W.

description: Meh so many high reviews but my Chicago Asian cuisine blew this place away. All in all not bad but not great. Living off of reputation. War wonton was good. Orange chicken so so along with fried rice. I'm trying something else next time I find myself in Chinatown.
author: Jim G.

description:
Found this place via Yelp (thank you smartphone) while looking for a place to eat in Chinatown/North Beach before walking to Monroe later on. I was able to call in and get reservations for six people the same afternoon. We walked in and the place was packed - always a good sign when there are so many food choices in the area. Our table wasn't quite ready yet but they got us seated within 10 minutes of our reservation time. Right away a server brought out hot tea and menus. The menu is extensive and I am sure everyone can find something. 

The dishes are served family style and we all were starving due to no breakfast or real lunch. Decided to order a bunch of items and share. We ordered:

Xiao Long Bao - didn't try this but heard it was good but didn't have enough broth in it
Tai Chin Chicken - this was excellent, definite reorder
Chicken with Spicy Garlic Sauce - so good, smell of the chilis went up our noses as we passed this around
String beans with Chicken - asked for this to not be spicy and they obliged. 
Prawns with Honey Walnuts - I don't normally eat prawns but tried this and liked it. Not too sweet.

Needless to say we inhaled the food. At the end they brought out (of course) fortune cookies and sliced oranges. Opted for no dessert since we were in a rush. Total per person came out to $12 - not bad at all for all we got to eat...my friends were very happy with the restaurant selection I made (whew!!) and said they would come back again. 

Definitely a do-over when back in Chinatown!!
author: Jessica S.

description: I'm not sure which was worse the service or the quality of the food- the question might be answered best if you can choose what you like best-  abuse -vs- greasy salty brown sauce which goes by any dish-name found on the menu - On this night Hunan Homes exemplified the china-USA trade deficit by palette and cost- that is to say that this was a lousy exchange of commerce for nourishment I would mention flavor but there was none!. Run don't walk-  across the street to Z&Y, which is always consistently good.
author: Yehonatan K.

description:
I'm not going to pretend that I am some sort of expert on Chinese cuisine or what passes for authentic in Chinatown or anywhere else for that matter.  On a recent trip to San Fran we used our trusty Yelp app and found this gem and were not disappointed in the least.

We split the Wonton soup and it was easily the best either of us have ever had. Fiancee dined on the Kung Pao Chicken and I went with the Chicken with Green Beans - both were spectacular. 

If you're in SF and in Chinatown - be sure to grab your meal here, it's well worth it.
author: Jessica S.

description: They deep fried the crab which you can't taste it anymore...it was like chewing potatoes chips.  Boo boo.  Not authentic at all.  Wonder why they got such a high ranking.
author: Amy V.

description: Best orange chicken!  Comes with pickled carrots and radishes which were new to me but fantastic!
author: Debby G.

description: Everything is packed with flavorful seasoning, great atmosphere and people,  however could brush up on customer service and it'll be a 10.
author: Lawrence M.

description: Great food! I had the asparagus and prawns with black bean sauce. Yummy! Fast service. Large menu.
author: Vida S.

description: Yum... Went here with my young kids, husband and my mum... Was really good place. Waiter suggested that we would have enough food for all of us with just the banquet for 3.... And we did. I love places that don't oversell to you. Reminded me of the typical Chinese restaurant the we use to go to as kids....even down to the fish tank and live crabs! Got busy quickly... But we came early so had no problems getting a table. Yum!
author: Peta P.

description: You must have the Orange Peel Chicken! Wonderful flavor and perfectly spiced! My husband and I will definitely return when we visit San Francisco again.
author: Terri S.

description: Really good authentic Chinese food. Had chow mein, chicken fried rice, Mongolian beef and  cashew chicken. Delicious!  Reasonable prices, quick service.
author: Pat F.

description: Stay away from this place if you are looking for a great authentic Chinese food. Here you will find Americanized caricature of Chinese cuisine.
author: Olga I.

description:
I'll make this one easy.

The good: hot and sour soup, vegetable dumplings.
The bad: tofu and eggplant (tofu tasted sour), honey walnut shrimp (unless you're really into mayo.)

Come for the apps but leave immediately after.
author: Allison B.

description: AMAZING!! The service was average, as expected. However the food was great and for a great price too! Paid $55 for 4 people and we ate well. Recommend fried rice, bbq pork, chicken cashew nut and pot stickers! Would go back many times and this place was very clean
author: Stef M.

description:
So tremendously disappointed that I'm prompted to write my first-ever Yelp review.

Things started otherwise fine. The appetizers were delicious (bbq spareribs and long xiao bao). It went downhill from there. I wasn't thrilled that my wife's cashew chicken came 10 minutes after my meal was served. That's perhaps forgivable, but NOT the fact that she discovered the tab of a soda can cooked into a piece of said chicken. 

This should get 1 star flat-out, but I'm being (far too) generous with 2 because of the aforementioned appetizers and the very attentive service, especially after our little discovery.
author: David K.

description:
The hostess yelled at me and my wife 20 minutes. When we arrived. We stood at the door then she was yelling at someone else who works there. Then she jabbed me in the shoulder with her index finger to tell me our table is ready. The waiter arrived quick. I asked for steamed rice and before I finished the word he snapped "one dollar per person" and raised his index finger to indicate that it is one dollar. He did the same to the couple on the table next to us. 
On the positive side the tea was good. 
The food was good.
author: Tom M.

description:
Hunan heaven.

Sizzling shrimp. I want you to be my main dish for breakfast, lunch and dinner.

At 7:00 AM. please plan to land somewhere near my alarm clock, gently sizzling and oh so spicy.  I want to design a food ramp that would propel this amazing dish to my face and allow me to consume this heavenly tastyness before I even open my eyes.

I hope there is an App for this.
author: Paula D.

description:
Thanks again, fellow Yelpers.  
I have been to San Francisco's Chinatown about 4-5 times over the years and have always just ended up at the 2nd or 3rd place past the gate.   You cajoled me into venturing onto a sidestreet where my dining partner and I found this little gem.  

I had the Hunan Smoked Pork with cabbage and leek.  The pork was fantastic - I am not a big fan of overcooked, oversauced (i.e., typical) Sino-American meat options, but this pork had just the right amount of smoke and red pepper heat.  The cabbage and leeks were done to perfection as well.  

Epic win.
author: Darin E.

description: My wife and I came on a recommendation from our double decker bus tour guide.  Big Mistake! As I saw in another review, the only locals here were the employees.  This had the same menu as our local take-out place in GA.  The lunch special came with Hot and Sour soup.  My wife is not a fan, so we asked to sub egg drop.  The waiter emphatically said no.  Also, we asked for water after waiting more than 5 minutes to be acknowledged.  The waiter said "Your order?", like don't bother me.  We didn't.  We left and went across the street where there was a line of locals and the place was packed( Great Eastern  was the name of the place, I think.  In fact, Obama apparently ordered take-out from there.  It was authentic dim sum and excellent!  Don't bother with these places catering to American tourists.
author: Edward K.

description: Best Chinese food I've ever had! Went here 3/weeks ago when were in vacation thanks to all the yelp reviews we were not disappointed! Truly excellent quality food we had the BBQ pork,  pork dumplings and beef chow mein all complete perfection. We loved it so much came back the second day for lunch. Highly recommended for the most delicious Chinese in China Town!
author: Maryann M.

description: Our group decided to go to a Chinese Restaurant that offered an authentic experience in Chinatown. This place delivers on all level. Nothing fancy but extremely tasty. The spicy dumplings were the bet I have ever had and the hot and sour soup was also exceptional. We all shared primarily Hunan dishes and all came out fresh. The smoked pork Hunan was the most unique. In the vein of authenticity the staff was abrupt, fast moving and attentive. If you get the chance and you want the type of experience described give this place a shot. Word to the wise though - if it's a busy time get a reservation. We went on a Sunday evening and despite the fact that several of the local restaurants had only a few people in them this one was jammed.
author: Chris S.

description:
how have i not posted a review on this place.

food is great! James the Manager is awsome.

cheers from Los Angeles
author: Hank B.

description: Great food and amazing service!  We all loved the food, the kindness of the waiter and the hot tea was a nice touch.
author: Carrie Q.

description: Fantastic hot and sour soup. The wontons in hot sauce were delicious. Tender beef and chicken.....quick service. This guy HUSTLED! A great stop in Chinatown!
author: Christie S.

description: You know this is a traditional China Town restaurant when you are the only tourist looking people in the restaurant. Family owned with traditional recipes brought back from the home country. Food cooked to order with no spice to teary eyed fire out of your ears spicy. Very interesting and different wines. Oh, forgot about the comfort about having a pot of fresh tea brought to your table. Will come back next trip and will definitely recommend to others. Just one thing - PARKING SUCKS!!!!  We drove around for a good 30 to 45 minutes till we even found a pay lot. Prepare to play find the parking spot. But the food is worth it.
author: Maureen H.

description:
My family and I wanted to go to Chinatown for some traditional Chinese cuisine. I wasn't looking to try new weirdly prepared dishes or strange fish or bizarre new animal parts. Hunan Home was exactly what the doctor ordered!

We started off with hot and sour soup which was spicy and nothing out of the ordinary. I enjoyed the egg rolls (also not the best ever, but still very good) and the xiao long bao dumplings--I probably could have eaten the whole order myself!

I really enjoyed the pork fried rice! It was super flavorful, not an obese sized portion, and was much better than I usually have had. I could eat three servings of this by myself, easy.

Since I don't like Chinese dishes that involve veggies or anything remotely green, I chose the orange peel chicken. It was fantastic! Very flavorful! Not so crispy that you lost sight of the chicken inside (like Panda Express), but still crispy and fried like orange chicken should be. I parted with three small pieces of chicken for my family to try and ate the whole rest of the plate myself.
author: Kiki H.

description: Why didn't anyone tell me about this restaurant? This is where I am glad there is Yelp. Just had lunch here and will certainly be a regular since I work nearby. Clean place, attentive service and good food.
author: Reena C.

description: Pretty decent American Chinese food.  I went alone and had the wontons in hot sauce, hot and sour soup and chicken with spicy garlic sauce.  Despite the name, the wontons were not spicy.  But, there was chili bean paste on the table and I added a couple of spoonfuls to help.  The hot and sour soup was served piping hot, but needed vinegar.  There is no vinegar on the table, though.  The chicken was also served piping hot.  Each piece was a large cube of chicken breast, which many will like--but I prefer dark meat in fried dishes like this.  The sauce was sweeter than I expected, but probably less sweet than the orange peel chicken sauce.
author: Amber B.

description: Oh my gosh this is the best Chinese food Id ever have! We ordered sweet and sour soup!  Prawn walnut shrimp, chicken with orange peel and garlic chicken and everything was a perfect 10!!!!! I recommend it to everyone to come here if ever in Sam Francisco!!!!
author: Mayra U.

description:
Good food, good service, good price, hilarious front of house who is like wonkys in London

The hot and sour soup is good

Who can ask for more ?
author: Greg B.

description:
Awesome place. We originally were going for another place not far away but arrived to find it was only open for dinner on Saturdays and it was 2 in the afternoon. So we used Yelp and found Hunan Home's. My daughters and I had the xiao long bao, pot stickers, sweet/sour pork, chicken w/ orange peel and TWO dishes of chicken fried rice. They hadn't eaten breakfast since they knew we were headed to Chinatown, which means EAT. And HH did not disappoint. There was no wait, the staff was friendly and quick and like I said, the food was great. That's all we need to know.

We will definitely be back.
author: Jerry M.

description: Meh. It wasn't particularly great food and the service was rather terrible. Not going back again.
author: Yael S.

description: The best Chinese food in San Francisco, my wife and I drive from San Mateo to eat here 2 times a month to eat here.. We have been eating here for the last 18yrs
author: Wally B.

description:
The food here was amazing!
Service was super fast since they are apparently always very busy they try to keep things moving to get people in and out quickly.
So not a place you can think to relax and chat, but definitely worth the wait to get a table!
author: Caroline D.

description:
On a recent trip to SF I knew I wanted to eat in Chinatown and Yelp has become my go to for recommendations. I have heard of R&G's but wanted an alternative to the $40 salt and pepper crab and maybe something more like a local favorite and right away noticed the reviews for Hunan Homes. I was sold.. I already knew I wanted Sizzling rice soup and orange peel chicken days before we even left on our trip. I also found a restaurant.com coupon for it so it was obviously the perfect choice. 

The restaurant was only a short walk from our hotel which was again, perfect. So far this was working our great. The food did not disappoint once we got there and were sat, with no wait. The sizzling rice soup was very good, but not amazing. The pot stickers and orange peel chicken, awesome... some of the best I have ever had. We also got the Mongolian beef which had a lot of great flavor but was just a little bit on the spicy side for me. The Yang Chow fried rice, good, but not impressed. 

The service was ok, not overly friendly but got the job done. Then something happened that I'll never forget. I took out the restaurant.com coupon and laid it on the table for our server to have as he prepared our bill. A few seconds later a different server came over and placed the bill on the table and seeming somewhat annoyed said that he had included our coupon. He did in fact, and we paid and even left a few extra dollars tip on top of the 18% included gratuity. Then we waited a minute or so. Our bill got picked up and we waited another minute. Are you kidding me, am I not getting a fortune cookie and little orange slices like every other table in this Restaurant?! Apparently our restaurant.com coupon was so grievous that they saw fit to rob me of my fortune. Deduct one star! 

They are pretty lucky the food is delicious and i was about to walk through Chinatown and buy myself a whole bag of little fortune cookies!
author: Sarah S.

description: Why I haven't written a review is beyond me, went here for lunch today had to review finally! the sizzling fish is amazing , sizzles right in front of you when they bring It. Eggplant is bomb love the garlic sauce and not too spicy, the environment is nice, I love walking around Chinatown after to relax. Parking is a bit hard as you are in Chinatown I've lucked out and found parking down the block on Columbus; it's hit or miss. The potstickers wow well thank you for making it my little nephews all time favorite thing in the world; he refuses to eat potstickers anywhere but Hunan homes.. we've tried!! bill is fairly good compared to the quantity and quality of food and can't wait to come back!!!
author: Nessa H.

description: skip the line at Z&Y and eat here! best hot and sour soup i've ever had.
author: Kristian C.

description: I'm a HUGE fan of Chinese food and Hunan Home's is definitely an Americanized Chinese joint. Props to having great jellyfish and service. :)
author: Sara P.

description:
Another case of bad service paired with great food.  It's so hard to rate a restaurant in cases like this.  It tears me up inside to put a rating on a restaurant like this.  Ummm.... well not really.  3 is not a great rating in my opinion, but if you're going to be rude then you deserve no better.

It's shame when the cooks are so good at what they do and the waiters just ruin it for you.  One of the things I ordered was the tofu and it was SPICY.  Awesome.  We loved it.  Even the other entrees were really good.
author: Anuj S.

description: This is the worst Chinese food I have ever had! This is not Hunan food! I really love Hunan food, but this place is more like Guangzhou food! If you want authentic Hunan food! Don't come here! I'm so disappointed!
author: Celia P.

description: Have been here twice on two separate trips to SF. Both times were awesome. Second time it was 9pm, we had just arrived in the city after hiking at Yosemite and were starving- half an hour wait even late at night but totally worth it. We got a spread of appetizers and all were great. Love the potstickers. Can't beat the prices.
author: Ashley K.

description: In a city with probably 10,000 or so Chinese restaurants, this could be #1. It's certainly my personal favorite. Every dish comes out piping hot and has tons of flavor; leave the soy sauce at home. Special shout out to the hot and sour soup. Add a few giant Tsing Tao's and you have a great meal.
author: Anthony T.

description: Found this place thanks to yelp. It did not disappoint. Very nice staff. It was a rainy day in SF and they let us "hang" longer than we ate. Great find. Very good spicy wontons.
author: Diane S.

description:
This is a good choice near Chinatown.  The interior is rather standard Chinese restaurant fare, so nothing special there.  The service was prompt and attentive.  We particularly enjoyed the banter with one of the waiters/manager, who seemed to wonder the restaurant to make sure everyone was well attended to. He prepared our dipping sauce for the pot stickers (very nice as we were hosting guests from Florida and this was all a bit new to the dipping sauce thing!).  

The food was very good.  We had wonton soup, pot stickers, sizzling oysters (different and yummy), shrimp with honey walnuts, and chicken with snow peas (a bit boring, but it was tasty).  Everything was good to great.  I particularly enjoyed the sizzling oysters -- very large oysters with ginger and lightly sauted sweet onions.  The shrimp with honey walnuts was also great; the large juicy shrimp were covered with a light sweet sauce and served over a bed of cabbage with glazed walnuts.

The price was also quite reasonable.  Overall, the food and service warrant 4*.  The ambiance could be improved to warrant the fifth star.
author: Brad B.

description: Food was OK. The very popular chicken chow mein that other people yelped about was not that great. You had to really search for chicken... And when you found it, they were slivers of meat. When I asked the waiter about it, he acted like that was enough chicken and that I was over-reacting.  Bummer.
author: Jessica B.

description: Excellent food and service! We absolutely enjoyed everything we ordered from the egg roles to the orang chicken, pork...everything!! Worth the wait!  Try the Chinese beer while you wait!
author: Ame B.

description: Really good food but waitress didn't smile. The place was packed on a Saturday night so apparently service with a smile doesn't matter.
author: Roger K.

description:
I'd been here twice so far and was convinced by the reviews of it here on Yelp. After more than 4 years in the Bay Area (once having been a resident of Nob Hill) I am surprised that this is the first time I'd ever dined at a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown!

To keep the story short (since I'm not really in a mood to write long winded essays currently), I'd like to emphatically state that this place serves really awesome food at a great price. I am told it's Hunan Cuisine as more than hinted at by the name of the establishment, as well as by the numerous reviews on here, so Hunan it must be.

Over the two visits, I've had some great chicken momos (or "potstickers"). The tea roast duck wasn't to any of our liking as we were partially put off by the pink color of the meat. 

The orange chicken was great; I am usually not a fan of the dishes that lean more towards sweet than savoury but this one was definitely up my alley, and not because it was any less sweet but simply because of it's flavours.

The chicken and string beans was great with the black-beans sauce; I like my savoury entrees spicy and this one did the trick for me -- just about enough heat and spicy flavours. A discovery (for me) was the chicken-shrimps-and-eggplant dish; I thought it was simply fabulous !!! All these entrees would have been a perfect foil for steamed rice (we ordered fried rice instead) 

I enjoyed the "chicken in garlic sauce" but my friend disagreed. The 
generous portions of soup is good for 3-4 people. They were really tasty and served to whet up the appetite unless you overdo it. 

The chicken Mui-Shu too was really good. The fried rice and chowmein were pretty decent if a little greasy. I think I will go with the steamed rice instead on my next visit. A veritable feast of no less than 5~6 dishes shared amongst the three of us came to barely hit the $60 mark. 

This place is definitely on the money!
author: Umesh T.

description:
We relied on yelpers and they were dead on. Thank you. 

Everyone one of us loved the Orange Peel Chicken, the Honey Walnut Prawns (we all wished our neighborhood place had them this good), the Eggplant with spicy garlic sauce, the Dungeness Crab in Ginger & Scallion sauce and those amazing double fried Green Beans. 

The service is almost too good, at times you feel like they are hovering (but I'd rather take that than nonexistent service any day). 

The only real downside is the parking, but that's the way it goes in the N.Beach/Chinatown.
author: Mike V.

description:
Had dinner here tonight, we really wanted to find something in Chinatown before we went back home. After checking out the menu online it appeared to be something more along the lines of what we would find at your "typical" Chinese restaurant. We were very glad we went. The wait wasn't too bad, about 10 minutes or so. The food was very good, great variety on their menu with lots of different dishes. The soup and egg rolls were good and the entree's were great. I had the Mongolian beef and it was unlike any other I've had (spicy, which made it that much better).

The prices were very good, the service was ok, the location was great.
author: David S.

description:
Excellent food! Flavorful, savory, spicy 

I had the hot and sour soup followed by Kung pao squid. Little place, quiet at 4:45 :)

No service issues.
author: Joe P.

description: Very good Chinese food and an authentic atmosphere! Starts with a lovely green tea and hot and sour soup. Both of which are complimentary. My family had the chicken fried rice, orange peel chicken, and Mongolian beef. All were really good but we particularly recommend the Orange peel chicken! It was wonderful!
author: Alex J.

description:
We picked up family in SFO for the day and took them here. First time for all of us and thanks to the information from Yelp reviews, it won't be the last!

The food was excellant!  We each had a different dish and shared. We all could not say enough about the Hot and Sour soup. A perfect balance of flavors and heat.  Next up was Chicken with Orange peel (a nice, light batter that retained texture under the sauce) and, the Shrimp with Honey Walnut (the shrimp were perfectly cooked with a wonderfully light sauce)
We also had a (good) vegtable fried rice and, stir-fried vegtables (while good. Not the best I've had).
Of course, chinese beer through out the meal and a finisher of crisp fortune cookies and an exceptional green tea.

The readon for only 4 stars?
The service was pretty pretty dreadful. I almost wanted to apologize to the older man waiting on us for taking up his time. When the food was served, I asked for steamed rice, as neither meat dishes came with it. The look he gave me was pretty amazing. I'm surprised that I didn't get a stern NO with it.
The plates were taken throughout the meal, wether they needed to reach over you eating to get to anothers just finished plate or not. 
The check and fortune cookies came IMMEDIATELY after the last bit of the last person was taken. We waived a young man over, who got our waiter as a couple of us wanted tea. When I asked him, he was not happy and turned to yell the length of the restaurant to the young man to bring tea.
Definitely felt like we got the bums rush throughout.

HOWEVER...REALLY good food always trumps mediocre service and this was really good food! I would definitely go back and would take others with me.
I HIGHLY reccommend this restaurant.
author: Crystal W.

description: We got the chicken with spicy green beans and it was sublime. The heat was strong but not overpowering. The flavors were awesome under the heat. A special lunch treat. We also had the hot and sour soup which was also spicy, but not overly so. In addition the pork in the soup was also very flavorful. The other dishes coming out looked fabulous. We wish we could have stayed and ordered more. We will definitely go back.
author: Rod R.

description: Great food I really recommend the hot soup dumplings and the hot and sour soup. The service was good but not great but the food is excellent and very well priced. There is usually a wait but it goes pretty quick.
author: Jason V.

description: Food was okay at best but the service was abominable. Probably the worst I've been treated since getting frisked up by the TSA on my way to Thailand. Go somewhere else where they appreciate your business and treat their customers with respect. Definite one star experience.
author: Jarvis W.

description: I hate giving one star reviews but when you're still sick from eating here and its been 3 days.....yeahhhhhh. Seated quickly by some lady pointing to a table. Interaction from staff was very minimal. Food tasted okay but beware the after effects. No bueno
author: Nicole T.

description:
Came here for dinner on weds night around 7 and had to wait 7 minutes.

Ordered the string beans good
Hot and sour soup good
Sizzling fish ok
Eggplant good
Ginger and scallion chicken good
Hunan pork was ok 
Walnut shrimp my friends said it was good
Oyster sauce broccoli good

Servers were pretty much on top of their game

I would come back to try the Peking duck
Tea duck, sizzling eel , and pot stickers
author: DOM d.

description: AMAZING. Best Chinese food I have ever had. We had the sweet and sour soup, potstickers, orange peel chicken, and Mongolian beef. I can't even pick a favorite because it was all so delicious. The service was fantastic (our waiter was really sweet and funny). Be sure to say hi to the adorable puffer fish in the aquarium at the front door (I've unofficially named him Wonton).
author: Illona A.

description: I don't get how all these san fran restaurants get 4 stars! this is another one of my disappointments in san fran 4 star restauants. It's def not authentic chinese. the food tasted decent enough but not authentic. i wont recommend it if you are seeking authentic chinese food
author: Xinyi T.

description: Has to be the best Chinese I have had . Manager was really hands on and proud of his food. Potstickers and chicken orange peel did not disappoint .
author: Gavin K.

description: I have to say its a pretty good dinner and you really get more for your money. I am very surprised this place was full of non-Chinese people, then I learnt many of the groups were actually tourists group pre-organized. While I was talking with receptionist, she was talking on the phone and getting tour reservations. What I need to say is the food is Americanized Chinese food, and it's way too greasy even for authentic Chinese food. The waiting was not really worthy as you will be "competing" with pre-booking tours, and it takes a lot of time to prepare for such big groups.
author: Yuchun W.

description:
Great flavor, very reasonable prices, portion sizes are reasonable, so order appetizers.  We had green beans with pork, which was not overcooked and shrimp that was yummy and asparagus chicken with lots of asparagus.  I had tons of vegetables by he time I left which really felt  healthy and it wasn't greasy.

They took reservations on a Friday night, which I appreciated.

Great service.
author: Carolyn P.

description:
Hunan Homes serves a legit chinese food dinner. This place is really a 4 and a half in my book with a half star off for overall condition of facilities which are old (read: bathrooms) 

The staff here hustle and read tables well from what I've experienced and seen. They are food service professionals. The menu runs a wide spectrum of chinese food offerings, served family style with plenty of spicy options (which I'm all about.) 

The most recent meal consisted of hot & sour soup which was delicious, flavorful & spicy, dry-fried green beans which were a smidge on the salty side (which I happened to love), cooked with small bits of crackled pork, garlic & chili and could not have been better. We also had orange peel chicken (which wasn't my choice but) was breaded, saucy, and tangy (and now would decidedly order again.)

Jasmine tea is kept hot at your table for self service; water cups filled anytime they reached less than half full, white rice served with your meal and brown rice is available upon request (and a small charge.) 

The mirrored front dining room was bustling on a weeknight and while we were waiting for a table, we overheard two different groups of people rave about hunan homes so they're consistently making the mark with an assortment of customers. 

Keep it up Hunan Homes (but seriously, what's this name?)
author: Jen Y.

description: We came on a Sunday afternoon it was not too busy, we sat down right away. The staff was every friendly. We ordered the hot and sour soup, the chicken and corn soup, chicken chow mein, lemon chicken, and Mongolian beef. It was all great. The hot and sour soup was my favorite and some of the best I've ever had. The noodles were good and not greasy the chicken and beef was tender not dry or trenched in syrup. I will come here again next time im in town.
author: vince g.

description: We ordered a few vegetable dishes, chow mein, and some prawns. The food was good, well made, not too oily, and all our dishes tasted fresh. The interior is dated but not a big deal to me. My biggest issue was the price. The veggie dishes were $10 each and were the size of a salad plate. Seemed a bit over priced for veggies. The other dishes were fair priced.
author: Cupcake S.

description: Great food that you get fast.  This place is all business, cranking out the food  very quickly.  But it's good. Had wonton soup, prawns with lobster sauce, and Hunan pork. All were some of the best I've had.  Service was great. Atmosphere is your standard Chinese restaurant.  There are a lot of choices in Chinatown - this is a good one.
author: Marc C.

description: Tourist trap, don't go here if you're looking for decent Chinese food. Had a tea roasted duck and fish in white sauce here. The duck was so fat that it almost wasn't edible. Seasoning ok though. The fish was better, but still quite slimy. Awfully unfriendly service.
author: Daniel W.

description: Was in the area and used my phone to find a good restaurant near by.....LOVED this place!!! will go back in the future.
author: Hilary B.

description: I discovered this Chinatown restaurant on Yelp. I was my second choice since my first choice, Don Ho's was closed. Hunan offers quick fast friendly service. The food is delicious and is served hot. The portions are large and will leave you stuffed. I ordered the Kung Pao Chicken which had just the right amount of hot for my taste. My daughter ordered the Vegetable Chow Mein which she really enjoyed. If I ever have the opportunity to return to Chinatown I will be going here again.
author: Robert B.

description: I came to eat here with my boyfriend for his birthday and we had an extremely bad experience. First my plate was very dirty and I asked to get a new one. Then, we ordered potstickers and when they brought the vinegar it had flies inside. This was DISGUSTING. We lost our appetite and will never come back here again.
author: Ruby L.

description: Pretty good , Si buscas comida china real este es el lugar. Also there's always this guy who force everyone on trying to eat a chile, it's pretty damn funny :)
author: Rodolfo C.

description:
The food was OK, however my rice was burned.   They would not sell a cup of soup and I ended up with a giant bowl.   The waiter was not very friendly, however some of the other folks that stopped by were. 

My meal (sizzling chicken) had two very spicy peppers that I did not realize were there until I bit into one.   I spent about 20 minutes swishing water around until the pain subsided.
author: Bob P.

description:
This restaurant is awful, it has no appeal at all. The service Is insulting, everyone is so rude. 
When we walked in the door, we were looked at as intruders and we reluctantly accepted a table which was finally offered to us. There were a lot of employees and not a lot of customers.  The servers were all standing around avoiding eye contact. Finally, after a long time a gentleman came to take our orders and when he ran away we realized we didn't get to order drinks so we had to start the game all over again. 
Our dishes came out one at a time, every few minutes.  The food was lukewarm and mediocre at best.  
I went with two coworkers and we wanted to have separate checks and they made it out to be the biggest drama ever.  They were refusing to split the bill three ways but meanwhile, we told them right when we first arrived that we were each paying separately.  They finally relented and took our credit cards for a very long time. They ended up having to make multiple charges on each card and I can't even imagine why.  I have no clue what they were doing with our cards.  If you go, bring cash to be on the safe side. 
I've never had such an experience while trying to enjoy a lunch. We chose this restaurant based on reviews so maybe it was a bad day. 
I do recall hearing years ago, that San Francisco's Chinatown is known for being very rude. Maybe it's just part of the ambience.  It's not for me.
author: Karen B.

description:
I really cannot fathom why Hunan Homes is all the rave on Yelp. Seriously, this was worse than Panda Express. 

Hot and Sour Soup- Tasteless. It was like drinking watered-down, lukewarm chicken broth thickened with cornstarch and seasoned with a few specks of stale red chili peppers. Adding a crapload of white pepper wasn't even enough to make up for how much it sucked.

Orange Peel Chicken- Candy sweet and grease works for maple n bacon, but not in this case. The sauce was overpowering with an unpleasantly sharp tang of orange zest, loads of sugar, and day old grease. Not a very nice combo if you ask me. Recipe for heartburn. What were they trying to hide? Low quality meat?

Hunan Spiced Garlic Prawns- Not spicy at all. Slathered in a similarly overpowering sauce as the OPC. Shrimps were tough and chewy, overcooked. Vegetables were limp and mushy, cooked too long as well. They didn't add any texture to the dish.

House Special Crispy Seafood Chow Mein- Worst I'd ever had. The gravy was cold and there was no authentic 'wok fried aroma.'

In addition to all of the dishes being of poor quality, the portion sizes were way too small for what we paid. Hell, why are the prices twice that of similar chinese restaurants in the vicinity? Just because it was rated Best of the Bay? Couldn't be because of the atmosphere nor the service. I'm clueless.
author: Colleen W.

description: We arrived at this restaurant solely based on the good reviews. Unfortunately, it did not meet expectations. The meat dishes were either chewy or had a lot of fat. The rice was excellent. The service was ok and the restrooms were clean.
author: Carlos G.

description: Best Chinese food ever. Ate the moo shu pork, orange chicken and wonton soup. Had a bit of a wait around dinner time.
author: Adonica G.

description: I don't understand why do people give them such high review. Horrible environment, looks not clean, food is just okay, worst service ever.
author: H.L. W.

description: We were tourists but this place isn't touristy which is what we were looking for. So good! We went for lunch and husband got the Mongolian Beef and loved it. I got the Asparagus Chicken, also delicious. I would highly recommend this place.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
One of the shining stars for our 5 day visit to San Francisco! Look no further in your review hunting my friends, we went here twice and the food was incredible. One night we had a grouchy waiter but his fellow staff were all great!
Try the spicy wonton!!!!!!!!
Jon..... May 2012
author: Jon U.

description: We've been popping in to this restaurant for years.  The food is always tasty, nicely spiced and authentically flavored.  We'll be back I'm sure!
author: Willanne W.

description: Super good.  A little under the radar, but one of the better Chinese restaurants I've eaten at in Chinatown.  The prices are very reasonable, and there's a huge selection.  They have an entire downstairs section for seating and so it was easy to get a table for one even though they were very busy.  Food made fresh to order, and piping hot when delivered to the table.  A little bothersome they charge for rice, but that's kind of a California thing it seems.  The food was excellent, and I'll certainly be back.  This restaurant is near the top of my list for fast-casual Chinese food in the Bay.
author: Zach S.

description: Took my parents who have lived in SF forever but tend to stick with Cantonese cuisine. Dad really liked the Orange peel chicken. He thought the Mongolian beef was a bit spicy for his taste but Mom and I thought it was just right. Paired with the brown rice and Chinese broccoli, I thought it was a perfect meal!
author: Laura F.

description:
We were on a family vacation in San Francisco and we're looking for a good restaurant in Chinatown.  I looked on Yelp and decided to try this place.

The food was "ok", but the service was very unfriendly.  I asked if they could make prawns in black bean sauce and the waiter matter-of-factly said "no."  No explanation, nothing.  I found this interesting because there were several dishes on the menu with prawns and black bean sauce, just not combined.

My 12-year-old son then politely asked if they could leave out one ingredient in a dish that he was interested in.  Same response, a stoic "no."  It appeared that this waiter might have been one of the owners.  Even more astonishing.

I would not recommend this restaurant.  Mediocre food and bad service.
author: Tony S.

description: They don't communicate a lot, but they have fast and amazing service! My water glass never got below half empty and my food was delicious. It's also a great price!
author: Kelsey B.

description: Tangcu fish is great!!! And the dumplings and xiaolongbao!! I don't know much about hunan food but this is a good place for Chinese!! We also ordered the soup and some vegetables, just like the taste I ate at China
author: Luna Z.

description: Orange chicken is the best of the best. I love it a lot, but other than that, I don't recommend it. The ratings are so high, but the people eating there weren't natives. It's more touristy than anything.
author: Michelle N.

description:
(See pics)

A sitdown place that is only $6.95 for my spicy eggplant with chicken and prawns on rice, that also comes with hot and sour soup and an orange, just an unbeatable place!

The food was decent with loads of salt so be prepared to drink lots of water and/or caffeine afterwards to keep replenished and also not falling asleep.
author: T L.

description:
Wonderful! 

Some of the best Chinese food I've had.  I came here with a friend for lunch. We ordered one appetizer (potstickers, great!) and one entree (moo shu vegetables, also outstanding) and went home FULL. 

The waitstaff was really funny and friendly and I would go here a million times again.
author: Helen S.

description: Had visited Hunan Home's monthly for years 15+ years ago. Returned for a long overdue meal.  Just as I remembered it! Great food. Fast, attentive service. Hard to beat the value.
author: Dugg T.

description: Quick service. Clean. delicious food. We had the hot and sour soup, orange chicken, and basil chicken and all were delicious. Great Chinese in the fidi/ Chinatown border.
author: M D.

description: Good food.   Pot stickers were above average.  No General Tsos on the menu and waiter said they could make it for me.  I was brought an order of garlic chicken.  It was good but it wasn't what I ordered.  Portions were small but price was fair.  Wont go out of my way to return here but would visit again if in the area.  No wow factor here.   3 1/2 stars for me.
author: Robert B.

description: The food was very tasty here however the wait is a bit long. Once seated they seamed to forget which party was first and take orders randomly which I didn't like after waiting 45 mins for the table. They just need to figure this out, I would def be returning because the food is very good but hope this doesn't happen again.
author: Johana G.

description: I left here unimpressed. The staff was great but the food was very bland. Chicken was decent but the sauce was missing something to make it taste better than the much cheaper places around.  Also the shrimp tasted cheap, farm raised. Again, bland.
author: Eric R.

description:
I went to Hunan with my parents for lunch last week and was quite satisfied. It's not as down and dirty as some of the other places in Chinatown, yet not uptight or expensive either.

I started with the hot and sour soup which comes with the lunch combo. It was very flavorful and relatively spicy, as hot and sour soup should be. For our entrees, my dad and I shared the Hunan Spicy Garlic Chicken and the Chicken with Orange Peel. The garlic chicken was flavorful and quite garlicy, the way I like it. The chicken with orange peel was deep fried and didn't have much orange taste, except for a couple pieces of orange rind that were visibly indistinguishable from the highly sauced and battered chicken. I don't think I'd be able to pick it out of a lineup against general tso's. But it was quite tasty nonetheless.
author: Adam B.

description:
Thanks yelpers, this place was great! 
I highly recommend the Kung Pao Deluxe which has beef, chicken, & shrimp. 
Another plus is how clean the restaurant is
author: Melissa E.

description:
I have a bff who is really a princess. Dinner out for her is never going to be at a little hole in the wall. If there are no crystal chandeliers, she thinks she is slumming and she gets depressed.  But like everyone else, she's on a budget. What to do? Well this place fits the bill perfectly. Pretty everything, nice ambiance and yet..good cheap food! Well, in reality about a dollar or so more per dish than places out in my neighborhood, but considering the super fresh food, comfortable atmosphere and service, I didn't feel over charged at all.

Last night we had an absolutely delightful meal consisting of tender pot stickers, prawns with lobster sauce, and house fried rice. Everything was so tasty, and we had plenty of food for 2 people.

This was my second trip back and while it's a little out of the way, Hunan Homes did not disappoint. It's an affordable restaurant  where I will always feel comfortable bringing the most discerning of diners. 

On a more personal note, I like the fact that the booths provide a lot of privacy from other diners, and the noise level is moderate. A very comfortable and relaxing restaurant.

Just looked at their website and had no idea they validate parking! The parking gods have been good to me fortunately but if you are not so lucky: 

Two hours of validated parking  Portsmouth Square Garage from 5:00pm - 9:00pm when you spend $30.00 or more.

Now that's what I call a deal!
author: Sharon J.

description:
"Succulent Bread" 

My friend's family has been coming to this restaurant for 28 years. I'm not sure if this is even on the menu, but ask for it. It's a fresh baked, white soft "succulent" Chinese bread, that they deep fry ever so slightly. The result is a perfectly thin crisp layer around the soft white bread. 

It's served hot, with a sweet condensed milk, but my friend tells me that there are really TWO dipping sauces, the "Sweet" (condensed milk), and the "Salty", your own concoction made at the table with soy sauce, vinegar, and hot chili paste. 

I've never had anything like it in my whole life. My mouth was watering. I had to ask the owner what he called it and he looked at me the way people do when you ask something stupid, and he says, "It's Succulent Bread". 

Of Course. Duh!
author: Sandy C.

description: Outstanding potstickers!!!! Not the best sweet-and-sour chicken I've ever eaten, but still very good. Excellent service as well. Glad to have found another Chinese restaurant, for future visits, in S.F. Chinatown!
author: Phil I.

description:
We visited Hunan Homes on the strength of other Yelpers' recommendations and we weren't disappointed.  The wonton soup was very fresh and light with wontons that used a quality meat.  The Shrimp Chow Mein, Prawns with Honey Walnuts and Potstickers were our choices and everyone was happy.  Portions were generous, the service was attentive.  We took it as a good sign that the restaurant was filled with folks of Asian background.  

The bonus was the pricetag.  Three of us (no drinks) ate dinner for less than $50 and everyone had food left on their plate.

Thanks Yelp for steering us right once again.
author: Carol A.

description:
First off, make sure you go on restaurant.com and get the coupon for this place.

I will say that I was surprised how pricey this place was.  Even with a coupon, we ended up spending a lot of money for mediocre food.  We had chow fun which I love love love.  Again I could have gotten better noodles at the Chinese food place down the street from my house, and we were in Chinatown.

We had beef, shrimp, and chicken dishes and really nothing was memorable.  I actually would skip this place.  There are better and cheaper places.
author: Ally F.

description: We are from Atlanta and wanted authentic Chinese food.  I  don't think I can have takeout Chinese ever again.  Food was delicious. We ordered 2 "sizzling" plates, seafood and beef. Service was okay and I liked that we were immediately greeted with tea. Xie Xie nee
author: Angela B.

description: I had the Wonton soup and it was delicious.  The wonton had a burst of flavor and the broth was flavorful. I would eat there again and I would bring friends too.
author: Joey M.

description:
We saw the zagat sticker in the window and decided to try the place out and I am so glad we did. 

The place was packed on a Friday evening and luckily we were able to get a table. We shared the Family A meal and it was more than enough food for three of us and less than $20 per person with tax. The service was quick too. The moment we were done with our soup, the appetizer was out and subsequently the main dishes. It sort of felt like we were being rushed but I didn't mind.  

It took awhile to get a bill and take out boxes and that is why I am knocking a star off.
author: Jackie L.

description: Ordered a la carte with 5 of us ... Wonton soup was excellent ... Egg rolls were OK ... Pork Dumplings were good ... Kung Pao Chicken... Beef & Asparagus ... Prawns & Walnuts ... ALL DELICIOUS !!! Great food!
author: David F.

description: If you want your down home average priced Chinese Food with decent service,this is the place.Had hot braised shrimp,Beef n Brocoli,Hunan Chicken all well prepared and tasty.
author: Andrew S.

description:
On the plus side, the wonton soup was delicious. Seriously it was very good. On the negative side, our soy sauce was filled with dead bugs (like fruit flies or something... I counted about a dozen in the 1/2 ounce i poured on my plate), and when we mentioned it our waiter handed us the soy sauce from the next table and walked away without saying a word. 

So yea, the soup was great, the other food was ok... But if you go i'd ask for your soy sauce in packets.
author: Brit A.

description: Average Chinese food and service. The ambiance is all right, other than it's pink and green decor. We were seated promptly but afterwards it took a while for the waiter to notice we were ready. Service was slow after that, food was average to mediocre. We ordered hot and sour soup, mongolian beef and crispy noodles (which weren't crispy).  The food actually made my head feel hot and flushed for a while afterwards.
author: Apple P.

description: Seriously delicious. Try the orange chicken, shredded pork with peppers and Greens with garlic. Wonderful service, clean flavors. I would go back in a heartbeat.
author: Meg T.

description: Service was lacking. Also long wait for meal. Meal was average, nothing special, not worth more than 1 star. If this is the best china town SF has to offer I'm disappointed. On a positive note the restaurant was clean. Wouldn't recommend this place.
author: Dillon J.

description: I ate here once and the chicken tasted odd. A few hours later I was puking furiously for hours and hours into the night. It was one of the most painful experiences of my life. It was food poisoning.
author: Matt D.

description: Will not return.  Have been to Hunan Home's for years, my go to place for Friday night Chinese food.  Good food, nice quantity, good prices.    Have found the service and quality slowly going down over the past 6 months.  Simply put, the place is no longer clean.  Had dinner in the back, downstairs room.  Tables were no longer cleared after parties left.  The waiters simply placed the dirty glasses/plates on a common table, while they set-up a new table.  The dirty glasses/plates stayed on a table for an hour during our meal.  As we left, we pass by the kitchen.  I poked my head in and wished I hadn't.  Our waiter was standing there, waiting to pick up plates and picking his nose.  The kitchen was filthy.  Too many options in China Town to come back here.  Will find another "go to" place.
author: Phil P.

description:
I am so happy I have Yelp to depend on to find good food when your from out of town. Here on vacation from Baton Rouge and listened to some 4&5 star ratings for chinese food. I wasn't disappointed. Best I have had for a world traveler! Thanks people of Yelp.
Kenron
author: Ken R.

description:
I did not take a picture of my favorite dish here for fear that it will scare Yelpers away. Pale, raw-looking chicken covered in ginger and green onions does not make for an aesthetically pleasing dish.

But, if you can get past this unappealing presentation, you will be rewarded with one of the best Chinese dishes you've ever had. Yea, I said it. Bold words, especially in SF Chinatown!

If you're a fan of Hainanese chicken, you will love the steamed chicken at Hunan Homes. The pale, raw-looking pallor of the chicken masks the juiciness and tenderness of the chicken. It's truly surprising and unexpected how flavorful the chicken is. The juicy chicken is an ideal pairing with the topping of crisp, fresh scallions and sharp bite of ginger. The broth of the chicken mixed with a light soy sauce reduction is delicious over steamed white rice. 

Due to the grease and MSG, I typically feel heavy and lethargic after eating Chinese food, but this dish is refreshing.
author: Monelle A.

description: We have four people, ordering four main dishes and one fried rice. It was not bad but definitely not very much deserve the name. The amount was not much, but the taste was okay.
author: Angela J.

description:
Should have read the reviews more closely instead of relying on the Yelp star rating! This wasn't authentic Chinese food at all. The meal was edible but was not 4* by any yardstick.  

The XLB had no soup inside (and no red vinegar was served with it), the sizzling chicken had no sizzle and the hot and sour soup was definitely not the best in the Bay Area.

I did think the mushu chicken was pretty good and the potsticker sauce was good as well.
author: Stephanie C.

description: The best restaurant in Chinatown and in all of San Fran. Do yourself a favor and eat there!!
author: Christy M.

description: Great food.  Terrible service.  But I'd go back...  In general, I think the place is understaffed.  The kitchen pulled a lot of flavor out of every dish.
author: Mike L.

description:
I'm being really generous by giving this restaurant 2 stars. I knew as soon as I set foot inside that I would be disappointed. My friend & I stood at the entrance of the door for about 5 minutes before we were acknowledged. I'm guessing b/c we were Asian. The patrons were about 90% non Asian. 

I Yelped before going and everyone had only praise for the hot & sour soup and potstickers. Since those are my two fabs, I decided to give it a go. So listed below is my ratings of this overrated & overpriced place on the outer edge of Chinatown. 

Hot and Sour Soup  $5.95 small, $8.50 medium
With pork, bean curd, mushroom, bamboo shoots, and eggflower.
2 stars-it was sufficient, over sour and not much ingredients. 

Pot Stickers (6) $6.25
Stuffed with ground pork cabbage to be boiled and pan-fried.
4 stars-this was the best thing that arrived at our table,  

Prawns with Honey Walnuts $13.95
Deep-fried prawns topped with special sauce.
3 stars-this was ok, had much better

Hot Spice Crispy Chicken $11.50 (half)
Deep-fried chicken topped with hot spiced sauce.
1 star b/c 0 star was not available, wtf is this?! the chicken was tender but had no flavor. The best way I can describe the sauce to you is that it reminded me of snot! A thick gross slimy tasteless gravy(?) that absolutely had no flavor. I wouldn't have given the leftovers to a homeless person. DO NOT ORDER THIS even though the waiter endorsed it.
author: May G.

description:
Wonderful food!!!!!! The pot stickers were my favorite, but all of the food was great! We make sure that we stop here every time that we are in San Francisco!
Don't mind the décor....its just typical of the Chinese restaurants in Chinatown.
author: Luanne D.

description: Service bad!  Asked for a recommendation of food but didn't give us a suggestion. Asked for a drink - was charged but never brought it. Food alright but rude wait staff.
author: Jan P.

description: Great mu shu and pot stickers, but we weren't huge fans of the shrimp and green beans. They were actually too saucy. The staff is very attentive and helpful.
author: Elyse B.

description: This place was so yummy! I had tea and chow mein, and it was so good! Definitely a good pick in Chinatown
author: Alexia H.

description:
BE AWARE: THIS PLACE GAVE ME EXPLOSIVE DIARRHEA. 

TMI, yes, I know. And as cute as it sounds, don't risk putting yourself in my position. 

Came in just before 5pm since my boyfriend and I wanted to grab some dinner before the Macy's Tree Lighting event at Union Square. We parked at Portsmouth Sq, so it was a short walk, and the yelp reviews were the main selling point of this place. Chinatown usually "closes" around this time, so places that cater more to the locals are getting ready to shut down for the night. 

This place was extremely understaffed, and as a server myself, I empathized. Plus, growing up in CT, customer service isn't much of an expectation. Probably why this place is full of tourists... I digress. 

The restaurant itself is pretty small. Typical "oriental" decor and some cutesy Christmas lights. 

We ordered the green onion beef, chicken with asparagus in garlic sauce, Chinese broccoli (gai lan) with oyster sauce, plus rice ($1/person). THE FOOD LITERALLY CAME OUT 2 MINUTES AFTER ORDERING--I should have been skeptical, rather, I was amazed. Green onion beef was good. It came out piping hot and the meat was tender. The chicken with asparagus dish was as well. Tasty, but one of the asparagus that I had was sour and not clean, so...shit (no pun intended). However, the Chinese broccoli was not worth it. It's a bundle of $.50 choy from Stockton St. right up the hill with enough oyster sauce for a few leaves. Note: we found mini white specs of tofu residue on our Chinese broccoli, so I assume they'd been using that same pot of water for who knows how long and for who knows what.  

Constantly had to flag down a server (as if there were multiple servers...HA); at this point, I just wanted to get out of there and go on with my evening. You get a couple slices of orange and fortune cookies along with your bill. 

I left this place extremely dissatisfied. There are SOOOOO MANY other establishments in Chinatown that will give you at least mediocre service and good, cheap food that won't get you sick. Go next door, cross the street, walk up the hill--for goodness sake, please, don't risk it.
author: Rebecca N.

description: If you order a lot of foods -- in some restaurant -- you always rate them one by one, which is good and not.. And this Hunan Cuisine is the best.. Their honey walnut shrimp is the best of all the Chinese restaurants where I've been to, also the fried rice is like no other...... My favorite is Original sweet and sour spareribs... Damn, i love this restaurant... 5star for me.. I like the service too... Well normally, Chinese don't smile, but the service they given us is a five star.. ;)
author: Miguel O.

description: We had a terrific meal here with a large group of about 12 hungry people. We ordered 12 different dishes and sizzling rice soup for all. Everything we ordered was delicious. I was especially impressed that our dishes were served without much wait, and that the kitchen was able to serve them all at once. We shared them lazy Susan style, so everyone tasted a wide variety of Hunan Home's favorites. It was yummy, and the very friendly staff made it a great evening. It was the perfect Chinatown experience. (Note: if you're going in a large group, do yourself a favor and make reservations. We arrived en masse and did not have to wait for our table.) Don't miss this place if you're looking for a classic Chinatown meal.
author: msue A.

description: I work in the Financial District and love spicy food. I always went to Z&Y, but tired of their inefficiency. I tried this one with a to go order of their 'smoky pork' which is a popular Hunan dish, it turns out really, really good. Very yummy, less greasy than szechuan food. I had a little bit concern it might too salty but it taste just amazing. If they can make a bit more spicy would be even better, but just my own taste though. I love it, and decided to go again today. :-)
author: Weiwei Z.

description: Looked on Yelp for a place to eat in China town and this one came up with best reviews. I loved it! Ate there twice during my stay in SF. Would recommend the Orange Peel Chicken. The tea they serve at the beginning when you sit is free from what I experienced, it wasn't charged on my bill either time. Would also recommend adding rice for a $1. One serving is enough for two.
author: Karen R.

description: First time here and thoroughly enjoyed it. Fried rice was delish (not too greasy) and chow mein was perfect too.  Husband got a eggplant entree and Xiao long bao dumplings and was also very pleased. We will absolutely be back!
author: Donna T.

description: We loved this place. We ordered veg potsticker, hot and sour soup and kung Pao chicken and kung Palo tofu.  Food was excellent!!  People who served us were awesome - the owner was also excellent and showed how to actually eat the chilli peppers. Make sure to ask him how :) thanks - great meal!!!
author: V V.

description:
got here around 6 pm the place is packed. the trick here is to befriend the manager as you enter. As you befriend her, try to order before hand therefore you don't have to wait long after you have seated. Remember people, these are Asians its all connection connection connection. 

The food here is great. their seafood fried rice is good. its not like other Chinese restaurants that serve food with a lot of bamboo shoots. They actually serve a fair amount of meat and seafood per order. I suggest you also try their roasted duck and orange chicken. I give this place 5 out of 5. Great job Hunan Homes.
author: Mike B.

description:
Let me start by saying that Hunan Homes is easily the best restaurant in China Town, but can easily be one of the best, if not the best in the city. 

As a party of 10 we ordered wonton soup, hot and sour soup, 2 plates of chow fun, 2 plates of special fried rice, walnut shrimp, sweet and sour fish (cod), wonton soup, beef broccoli, and sweet and sour pork. All the dishes were outstanding, the only gripes being the fish was small and the hot tea was a tad strong, but nothing that gives the food anything short of 5 stars. I'd recommend any of the dishes I just mentioned. 

The service was outstanding too, I've been to at least 3 other dine in restaurants in China Town and in the other 3, no offense, but the English of the servers were limited. Here they were ALL absolutely fluent in English. They told us many jokes and made us laugh consistently throughout the course of dinner, they were quick in refilling the drinks as well as reheating or refilling the tea. I had a Restaurant.com gift certificate and they accepted it right away. We tipped them well above the 18% tip

I absolutely recommend this place for anyone looking for some good Chinese food.
author: Elijah D.

description: Cheap Americanized Chinese food in Chinatown? Yes please! I came here 30 minutes before closing and found that there were a couple of people waiting outside the restaurant waiting for their name to be called. I asked the employee how long the wait for 2 people was and she snarled at me and shooked her head saying that the wait was 40 minutes. Possibly to deter me from dining in? i don't know. Instead, I ordered take out and all of a sudden, the slightly rude woman put on the biggest smile and agreed to do a take out order. I ordered the Honey Walnut Prawns, chicken Corn Soup, and Combination Chow Mein which were all great! If I'm ever in the area, I wouldn't hesitate to come back!
author: Joyce E.

description: Yum x2.  Terrific spicy food at terrific prices!  King pao shrimp, chicken and string beans, egg rolls, hot and sour soup and shrimp fries rice!!!
author: BridgetLoves L.

description: Stopped in here for lunch while visiting San Francisco for a long weekend. I heard great things about Chinatown and this place delivered. Ordered the combination plate to start, followed by Kung Pao Beef and Chicken with Spicy Garlic Sauce. Everything was great and I would go back.
author: Michael D.

description:
So, my bf decided to embark on a quest to eat at each and every restaurant on this block. Last weekend we tried Hunan Homes. Wow!

The food was excellent! We had the XLB which were very tasty. We also ordered the smoked pork, beef with string beans and mu shu chicken. The pork had a really great smoky flavor, the string beans were crispy and delicious. 

I had never had mu shu before, so I wasn't quite sure what to expect. I definitely did not expect the waiter to fill the pancakes for us at our table using two large spoons as his only tools! It was awesome! (also quite tasty).

I will definitely go back. The food was impressive and the service was awesome.
author: Carly S.

description: Nice place. We asked the waiter for recommendations and he told us about the string beans (contains minced pork) and the Orange peel chicken in addition to several other items. Both were comforting. The string beans were slightly on the salty side, but the orange peel chicken had dried and caramelized peels. Very interesting. We also tried the Wontons in Hot Sauce. Those we're amazing and decently spicy. We actually ended up keeping the bowl sauce on the table for the duration of the meal to eat with rice.
author: Suhaila S.

description:
Meh. Was really expecting a lot from a 4-star Yelp restaurant but this was really disappointing. I picked this place to have a special dinner with a family friend who wanted to have Chinese food in Chinatown. Plus she needed it to be wheelchair accessible. Thank god for Yelp for having that as a feature!  
The good: service (5-star), hot and sour soup (SOUR!), chicken with cashews 
The bad: honey prawns, bathrooms not accessible for a person in a wheelchair, fried wontons (no filling, just fried skins), and the price of what we paid for what we received. 
Perhaps we ordered to conservatively. Other reviews call-out some things that sound really delicious... but what we received was just not cutting it. The Mayflower in Milpitas is better... and that doesn't say that much!
author: Amanda W.

description:
I wasn't in a great mood when I went here for lunch today, so please bear that in mind when reading this review. (Blame fantasy football: Cecil Shorts' shoulder injury may have cost them a star.)
Hunan Homes was recommended to me by my Chinese landlord, so I expected great things. The interior was Boring Chinese Restaurant Standard, and everything looked pretty clean. Sadly, the plate I was given for my appetizers wasn't clean, so I asked for another one. With the new plate the waiter also brought me somebody else's soda, putting the idea into my brain that they were just phoning it in. The restaurant had a fairly standard menu, loaded with basic generic Chinese dishes - it lacked the ducks' ears, pigs' knickers, cow's foreheads and so forth that I have come to love seeing on a Chinese menu. (Possibly they had a different menu for their Chinese customers, and I got the safe one, but if so, that's a mistake: I often like ordering the weird stuff.)
I ordered the potstickers as recommended here on Yelp, and they were kinda meh. I found them a tad greasy, and I didn't get any of that tasty dippin' sauce I was promised, unless it was the orange-red liquid stuff in the bottle, which was okay, but not all that tasty.
For the main course I had the kung pao squid, which also was a mixed bag. There was plenty of squid, but the squid pieces were quite large -- perhaps a bit too large -- and therefore a bit stringy. There was also too much green and red bell pepper for my taste -- I believe that a proper kung pao should contain meat, peanuts, and perhaps a few bashful vegetables hiding in the brown goop along with the dried hot peppers. I have no proof that this is the correct recipe, mind you, but that's how I like it. Given all of that, the dish had a subtle, smoky heat that was quite enjoyable. It felt like I disliked all of the ingredients, but the whole thing wasn't too bad. 
In summary, it's possible that I caught them on a bad day, or they caught me on a bad day. However given all of the other restaurants in this city that I haven't tried yet, I doubt I'll come back here until Cecil Shorts' shoulder fully heals.
author: Paul M.

description: Quick service. But Hunan chicken lacked any real flavor. Bland. Hot and sour soup was very thick and again no real flavor. Overall disappointed.
author: Kevin B.

description: This is my 3rd or 4th time eating here. I enjoy the sweet/succulent bread but this time the orange peel chicken was average. Also the wait staff was ok but not great
author: John A.

description: Had the xlb and the pot stickers.  Both very good.  I tried to go earlier but went somewhere else due to the long line.  The next day I went right before dinner rush to get seated right away.  Would go again.
author: Sang J.

description: where do i start? food was top notch and the waiter saved my life. he was the only waiter at the restaurant, and he handled all 30 tables like it was no problem. took our order quickly, delivered us water and forks when we asked for them, and he didn't even break a sweat. (do asian people even sweat? the waiter sparked an argument between my brother and i on the subject). back to the part about him saving my life...i accidentally inhaled and choked on an entire piece of chicken because i failed to use my chopping sticks properly (i am white). as i was aspirating, the waiter (still with 29 other tables), dropped all the food he was carrying to another table and ran to assist me. in one swift movement, he pulled out a chair and threw me over the back of it, forcing the lodged piece of chicken out of my throat and back onto my plate. now that's what i call economical. after the mishap i went to the ladies room to freshen up. to my surprise, there was an entire plate of steaming hot general tso's on the back of the toilet. just sitting there waiting for me! i sampled a piece because i figured nobody would notice, as i did not order it so it was not for my eating. but really, who can resist general tso's? suddenly, and without any warning, i lashed out and ate the entire plate. i don't know what came onto me but that general tso's sure was delicious. peculiar though because they don't sell general tso's at this restaurant. i checked the menu. on my way back to my table, i discovered the room where they store all the rice. the door was opened and marked "men's." i don't speak chinese but i'm assuming that's the chinese word for rice. .bags and bags of rice were among fancy looking porcelain rice washers attached to the walls. let me just say, this place is extremely fancy. porcelain rice washers!!! have you ever seen such a thing? i helped myself to some of the rice already in the washer. was also delicious (no surprise there). anyway, 10/10 would eat here again. i gave the waiter an $80 tip even though our bill was $40. how do you properly thank a man for saving your life?
author: Terry M.

description: Orange Chicken 5 stars, S&S Pork 3, Hot & Sour soup 3, Bao Dumplings 5 stars.. Had take out, no delivery... Decent
author: r k.

description:
I came here during a vacation to San Francisco, and this was the highest rated Chinese restaurant in Chinatown.

I've always heard San Fran has some of the best Chinese food in the country, and I was a little bit surprised there wasn't a single Chinese restaurant over a 4 star average.  

In any case,  I ordered the most commonly mentioned items in these reviews; the  Orange Chicken and Mongolian beef.

The orange chicken may have been the best Chinese dish I've ever had. Very crispy and flavorful. Definite must get at this restaurant.

The Mongolian beef was very good, though not as amazing as the orange chicken. We also had the egg rolls which were very good.

We did not wait very long on a Sunday night (maybe 20 minutes). The service was good, and the prices reasonable. The dishes do not come up rice (you have to pay extra for it) which I've never seen, but for $2 we received a lot of rice so it was not a big deal.
author: Eddie D.

description: Great food.  This was our  first time in san Francisco and we ended up eating here twice.  Worth the wait.  Everything was delicious
author: Laura M.

description: Very delicious food! I found this place using yelp! My boyfriend and I ate here on vacation and we ordered egg rolls, which were super fresh and delish! We shared an order of the Hunan beef, chicken chow mein and some steamed rice...everything was super fresh and perfectly seasoned. I would def check this place out if you want good food!
author: Carly T.

description: Best Chinese food I have ever had! The food was fresh and has great flavor. I am not from the area but if I was I would be a regular here. Give this place a try and you will love it
author: Kris K.

description:
Service is horrible in this place. Server took a cell phone call while he was serving us. Then he returned and poured water spilling around without care. We had to repeat things like 3 times and still he did not understand. 

Food was bad. Wonton sauce had a chemical taste and fluorescent color, same color on sweet sour pork. 

How can you make bad fried rice? Incredible.

They rudely told us they could not divide the bill between 3 credit cards. Really? 

I feel bad because yelp suggested me this place. Did had to pay for their rating!

By the way. There were 6 of us and all of us had the same opinion, horrible experience, etc
author: Delfin R.

description: Came here with our (un adventurous) boys. Really good "standard" Chinese-American fare. Wait staff was friendly and efficient. Not too pricey. All around solid pick.
author: Tom S.

description:
I was expecting something amazing.  It was better than all those weak Chinese places in the FiDi, but it really didn't blow me away.  Was a decent experience, but doesn't compare to places like R &G Lounge.

Hot and Sour Soup: A little slimy, but super savory.  Way better than that swill that is often thrown in delivery combos.

Xiao Long Bao: Sad.  These Shanghai dumplings can be such a treat when done well.  This barely had any soup inside and I think the soup was chicken based instead of pork.  The sauce was more like a standard potsticker sauce rather than the glowing red sauce used for Shanghai dumplings. 

Home's Succulent Bread: This was pretty cool.  Bread, like the kind in a pork bun, all soft and gooey inside but deep fried on the outside.  Like a Chinese fried dough.  Loved the condensed milk to dip in.  Way tasty, but probably horrible nutritional value given the carbs, the oil and sugar.

Sizzling Prawns: Shrimp with a gooey corn starchy sauce poured over an extremely hot metal platter.  Fun presentation to hear all the sauce bubbling.  Didn't notice much texture difference though as no portions got seared.  The sauce base was ok, but nothing amazing.

Pork Chow Mein: Nothing special, but a more exciting starch than rice.
author: Adam B.

description:
Strolling in Chinatown and wanting a quick Chinese food, I Yelped my way into this place.

I have to admit that I feel like the menu is too big to give a review after one visit, but the few dishes I ate was very good. I will definitely come here again and will recommend it if you're looking for a casual Chinese food in the area.
author: Assaf B.

description: We got the family meal type b for 3 people. Service was fast and friendly but we came craving friend rice but we were not allowed to update our meal. We don't mind paying extra but the only option was to buy an additional portion.  The family meal was a lot of food already,  No need for more.  Other than that good place to experience China town. We are not from here so we were looking for  a good experience
author: Gustavo V.

description:
Hands down my all time favorite place for Chinese food in San Francisco. The food is really delicious --the entrees that are on the top of my list the are Spicy Garlic Chicken (it's actually not that spicy, it takes like Orange Chicken), the Walnut Prawns & Kung Pao Chicken. This is a good place to go with a larger group of people and share the different entrees that you have chosen. All the ingredients are fresh and the meat very tender. 

Things to watch out for: 

- Parking can be tough - BUT they validate at the Hyatt Hotel -- so park at the Hyatt and ask for the validation so you aren't going in circles for hours

- Since it is a popular spot it can get crowded, so plan to get there earlier or later

- They also offer take out if you don't want to dine out
author: Ivannia D.

description: High prices for small portions. The food itself is only mediocre. They use cheap tea bags if you care for that sort of thing. Also there was a piece of hair in the pot.
author: Hawk O.

description: Walked over to Chinatown on the recommendation of the concierge at Grand Hyatt.  An unassuming little hole in the wall but WOW!!  The best fried squid with sea salt ever!!!  Very buttery feel and melts in your mouth!  Companions had a beef and pepper dish and pork dish that were both outstanding.  Very inexpensive and prompt friendly service.  Make reservations.  They get busy!
author: Karen B.

description: An average experience in Chinatown.  Food unremarkable although reasonably priced.  Service not terribly attentive.  Sat in a booth; decor unremarkable.  Overall:  adequate to the task.
author: chris s.

description: The food was as good as I've read on Yelp!  The Hot and Sour soup really was amazing and the Orange Peel Chicken was probably the best I've ever had.  The service wasn't the best but that was to be expected.  I'll go back next time I'm in town!
author: Jessie W.

description: Terrible service. Mediocre food at best. Overpriced for the quality of food. I have no idea why this spot has such high reviews on yelp.
author: Amanda Y.

description: Not an authentic Hunan restaurant AT ALL. For those who want Hunan dish or just REAL chinese dish, this is not the place to go. It's probably for the Americans
