author: Claire Z.

description:
We had "Hot and Sour Soup", "Pot Stickers", "Xiao Long Bao", "Crab with Spicy Salt", "Mapo Tofu" and "Prawns & Scallops Over Fried Rice". Bit too much.

All of those tasted great, and the price was decent.

Their "spicy food" is not such spicy, although it is said that the "Hunan cuisine" is the spiciest and hottest among all of Chinese cuisine including Szechwan. And it suits my palate. I guess yours, too.
author: Toru K.

description:
I've head SF has good food, and this place validates the reputation. Hunam Homes serves the best Chinese food I've had. 

Dining in a booth is a special treat, since you can view their fun fishtank. I love watching the pufferfish while I eat!
author: Chris T.

description: Went in around 2 and hod the overpriced dinner menu! I'm not sure why this place is getting such high reviews- the food was average to good (egg rolls were overlooked, the chow main was nothing special and my children who usually finish every bite,  left 3/4 of their dish. The spicy garlic chicken was really good, as was the sizzling chicken was good..BUT the customer service was appalling! No one ever smiled or welcomed us at any time throughout our meal and acted as if they were doing us a service just by allowing us to eat there....had to ask to order drinks after our meal order was taken- the tea was missing any color or taste of tea...it was hot water!
author: BeBe H.

description: Had lunch and was not disappointed with anything. I had the Kung Pao Beef and wifey had Hunan Chicken. Just the right portion. The staff could smile a bit more when interacting while taking the order, serving it and bringing the check. Then I would think they are enjoying their job as much as I am enjoying the meal
author: Peter B.

description: Typical tourist food. The waiter kept leaving utensil on the table instead of on the plate. The food does come out pretty fast.
author: Desmond L.

description:
I guess my expectations of Chinatown and its cuisine was built around the excitement of my first visit to SF. 

Any restaurant with a sheet of plastic on the table is mediocre at best and this place is no different. Nothing special. If you live in a city with a Chinatown, try a fusion restaurant for something different. Otherwise this place won't disappoint but won't impress either.
author: Doug D.

description:
Get a reservation!  We were lucky to get a table for two at 6:30 on a Saturday night because it is literally FULL of guided tour groups now.  

The food was very good and mostly authentic (with the token americanized dish thorn in to appease the visiting Texans and non-adventurous types).  Prices are average $10-12 for main dishes and $5-6 for apps.  

Eggplant was very good, pot stickers were delicious as were most of the main dishes and noodles.  Wait staff was very attentive and efficient (even with hoards of name tag wearing elderly folks vying for their attention too).  

FYI Peking Duck is $35 a duck, call and order ahead.  Looks amazing, I will have to try that next time.
author: Owen S.

description: The worst service ever.  Haughty, slow, no eye contact, less than average food.  Only 3 tables were occupiied; I was ignored when I entered the restaurant.  A table of workers was visible.  Two waiters were serving the 3 tables.  After some time, I walked in and asked if I might have a table.  A waiter dropped a menu on the table, came back after an extended wait. After he brought the food, I never saw him again.  I flagged down a waiitress for my check. I left part of the meal as the squid was tough and smelled funny.  I used Discover on a $16.00 check  and  tipped $1.00. My Discover statement showed a tip of $10.00.  They added a zero.  Stay away from Hunan Home.
author: Mary P.

description: We ordered eggplant garlic, sliced sweet and sour fish, and pork. Was mediocre tasting and average quality with bad service.
author: Satyan C.

description:
Took a friend to Hunan Homes late one Monday night, and we had a decent meal, though not the best. 

Garlic Eggplant: My favorite dish that we ordered. Properly prepared eggplant with satisfying garlic flavor. Super good on brown rice. 

Orange Beef: Tasty, but nothing special. 

Sweet and sour fish: Really oily fried white fish covered in an overly sweet sauce, and basically raw vegetables. This is my favorite thing to order in Chinese restaurants, but I wouldn't order this again. 

We were still hungry, so we asked for a recommendation for a chicken dish. We got the house spicy chicken - which was really average, not spicy, and un-exciting. 

White and brown rice are extra; house tea is complimentary. 

Service is typical for Chinatown - quick and without pleasantries, and they didn't overtly try to rush us out of the restaurant after they closed.
author: Andrea B.

description: We ate family style: 2 app's, a soup, 5 entrees. EVERYTHING was delicious. Service was fast. 9 people ate for $160, including the tip.
author: Shawndra P.

description: Let's just say, Panda Express has even better Chinese food! I should have known better when we looked around the restaurant we were the only Asians dining there.   That's a red flag!  We ordered hot and sour soup. This was the only tasty thing here. Also ordered sizzling prawns- it was tossed in this gooey sauce that was like bottled chili sauce mixed with ground pork.  It had a very weird taste to it....almost as if it was masking a pungent shrimp gone bad... I hope I don't get food poisoning. BBQ pork was tastless... my 6 yr old wouldn't eat it.  Tea smoked duck was greasy and flavorless. Sautéed peas sprouts were ok if you drench in soy sauce.  We came 1 hr before closing and got horrible service.  They forgot our drinks.  We had to constantly flag a waiter down to get service.  Maybe they're tired and wanna go home.  I don't understand why this place has 4 * and so many reviews.  My husband said because only white people yelp and they don't know good Chinese food.  Dinner for 4. Over $75.
author: linda t.

description: This is one of the best Chinese restaurants in San Francisco.  I have been going for at least 30 years - and it is consistently delicious.  So many great dishes, but the spicy bean curd and hot and sour soup are favorites.  It gets very crowded - because it's that good - worth the wait and reasonable prices!
author: Marie C.

description: Came to Frisco for my Birthday and had to have some good Chinese food. Totally scored at Hunan's. I did not expect a line on Christmas Day, but I'm glad I waited. The egg rolls were the best I've ever tasted. They were super hot and freshly made, I dipped them in the chili oil waiting at the table beforehand, that was super yummy as well. Had the best chili flavor and included a lil kick. I also ordered some garlic chicken dish that didn't last long on my plate, I love me some garlic. Overall, I would def. dine here again. =)
author: Alice C.

description: Had the Salt and Pepper Fried Fish and other various dishes, it did not disappoint. Waited probably around 30 minutes to be seated but its very worth it.
author: Terry T.

description: Mongolian beef, hot and spicy soup and BBQ pork were great.  Chow mein was too soft and we had to return it.  Overall good experience, better than we expected.
author: Valarie R.

description: Food is tasty. Had on one visit Orange Chicken, very good. Next time there got the Hunan Beef. Enjoyed that as well. Lunch is fast, served with soup, rice and tea. All for around 9 bucks. Good deal. Will go back again and again to try more of their dishes.
author: Tim S.

description: As always the food was amazing :) but they changed the recipe for the hot and sour soup :( and I'm bumping it to 4 star because of how horrible the service was .....
author: Matt N.

description: I really enjoyed the lunch that Hunan Homes catered for my office this week.  We had it served buffet style - brown and white rice, broccoli beef, curry chicken, and some tofu dish.  The meat eaters and vegetarians in the office were all satisfied with the choices! The flavor of the curry chicken was delicious, and not unbearably spicy for me like some curry dishes sometimes are.  They even brought us a bag of fortune cookies, which I loved.  Overall, great lunch and something that I would eat again and recommend to others.
author: Kristen F.

description: This is the best Chinese Restaurant in SF! My favorite items to order is the mushu pork and the potstickers. I also really like the green beans...My family has been eating here for years and we really love it! Good tip: You can purchase a gift certificate on restaurants.com for $10 and the voucher is worth $25 at Hunan Homes. Great deal and super yummy!
author: Ally V.

description:
I had really, really lovely ma-po tofu here the other day.  I loved that they used a little bit of vinegar in the dish to brighten it up a bit.  It was spicy, but not overpowering at all.  Definitely the best ma-po tofu I've had since I came to the States.

I wish it hadn't been just a quick stop, and that we had eaten more items off the menu, but the dish we ate was phenomenal.
author: Katie M.

description: We went here due to the high recommendations of others.  The egg flower soup was the best I ever had. However, the chow mien was soggy and flavorless. The Mongolian Beef was way too spicy, beyond what we could eat. So, we ordered an additional dish -- "not spicy, not hot, mild" orange chicken. Maybe they thought we ordered extra hot. We sent that dish back since we specifically ordered it mild (unlike the beef, which we mistakenly thought would be mild). While waiting for that dish to be remade, we found not one but two hairs in our chicken asparagus. That was just too much. Such a disappointment!
author: Janelle P.

description:
Pretty good Chinese food... We asked for everything to be spicy, even the dishes that didn't have the spicy symbol on the menu, and it was the perfect level of spiciness. It was hot but my mouth wasn't on fire.. if I were to go again I would order the same way. I can't really speak about the "authenticness" of the food, but I thought it was good, and step up from a lot of Chinese restaurants I've been too. 

A little pricey for Chinese food I thought, but overall I had a good experience. Service was good, the waiters were all welcoming and seemed to actually care whether we were enjoying the meal or not. I'm sure I will be back...
author: Alison B.

description: THE BEST CHINESE FOOD EVER!!!!!!!  Seriously the best Chinese dishes we have ever had and a wonderful experience.  The hot and sour soup is to die for!  Don't skip it!  The 2-3 person portion is plenty for 4-5 people really.  The spicy garlic chicken and szechuan chicken were delicious.  The sauces were amazing - seriously the best!  The owner was a little grumpy when we first entered, but then really cheered up and chatted with us quite a bit through our dining experience.  Give it a try - you will be happy you did!  It's definitely on our list of places to return to next time we are in San Francisco!
author: Amy A.

description: Very good. Try the potstickers!  Chicken with orange peel was also good - crispy and the sauce had some zing. Tea was a bit weak (I look forward to this in chinese restarants) but my Gewurztraminer was good with the spicy food. Service was average.
author: Sally H.

description: Man, do I love this restaurant. The food here taste so freaking good. Just thinking about the sizzling spicy tofu and hot and soup soup makes my mouth water like crazy. In my opinion, there is no Chinese restaurant in the entire city of San Francisco that serves food as good as here.  My family and I have been dining here since I could first remember. We always dine here whenever we have the chance, i.e special occasions (i.e. Chinese New years, Christmas, family birthdays), passed by Chinatown, or simply craved the taste of delicious Chinese cuisine. Whenever my family and I go there, we usually order the same three dishes and soup: hot and sour soup; sizzling seafood with prawns, scallops, and squip; shredded pork with beancurd; and sizzling spicy tofu. I highly recommend this fabulous Chinese restaurant and these particular dishes if you enjoy the taste of spicy authentic Chinese food.
author: Don C.

description: Man I wish they had one of these in Los Angeles. Wanted to try some Chinese food so me and my GF stereo walking down this street and looked in to see which place peaked our interest when a nice, older couple asked us if we were looking for a place to eat. We said yes so they recommended a place a few restaurants down. Boy was I glad we listened to her. Enjoyed everything here. Can't wait to go back to SF and have some more Hunans.
author: David P.

description: This place is a very old school Chinese restaurant, but maybe not in a good way.  We came here last April during the week and it was packed.  We were led to their back dining hall, and on the way there, I saw a bucket of mushrooms on the floor, waiting to be used in the kitchen.  Like, already washed and sliced, ready to go.  Ugh.  The items we ordered were typical -- fried rice, Kung pao chicken, some dim sum.  The entire time eating it, all I noticed was that everything was very greasy, and the chicken was like mystery meat.  Service was decent, the servers really hustle and work hard.  It's not the cleanest place, I wouldn't recommend it.  I've had great Chinese food in Chinatown in other big cities and was disappointed, and quite frankly, a little grossed out.
author: Mai T.

description:
Definitely a solid Chinese food option amid many in this town.  While they haven't always been my first Chinese option, depending on where I've lived in SF, I go every once in a while and am never disappointed.

Hunan Homes does justice to a number of Chinese food staple dishes.  Unlike some places that try to get creative and deviate from the blueprint, this joint knows the formula works and sticks to it.  

Just tasty Chinese goodness, up and down the menu...
author: Clayton S.

description: My boyfriend and I went here due to the good reviews. Unfortunately, this place did not meet our expectations...especially with their "high" ratings and cost. We ordered the Hunan  beef and shrimp/chicken fried rice. In honesty, the dishes lacked in flavor. How could this be? A Chinese restaurant in the middle of the biggest Chinatown in the country and no flavor in their dishes?! We left very disappointed.
author: A K.

description: The restaurant was very clean and homey feeling. The food was pretty good, we had the egg flower soup, pork fried rice, combo chow mein and beef broccoli. I wasn't blown away, but would definitely eat there again and recommend it to others. We got there around 8pm on a Sunday and didn't have to wait very long for a table.
author: Cheryl C.

description: Went here after House of Nanking was closed/not taking anymore customers. Went right around the corner to this place. Very happy with the food. Sauces on both the cashew chicken and asparagus prawns were delicious. Hot and sour soup was also perfectly prepared, not too spicy or thick. I guess you can't really go wrong with Chinese food in Chinatown.
author: Erica S.

description: Went here with my boyfriend during the lunch time. Even the restaurant was crowded but we were seated and served pretty fast. I liked the atmosphere here, everyone seemed very friendly and I was talking to the Chinese guy setting next to me. Honestly, I didn't enjoy the food that much so I wanted just to give them three stars but my boyfriend, he really enjoyed his food so I upgraded to four star. overall, a good place for a casual, reasonable, quick Chinese food!
author: Mimi T.

description: My first visit tonight was outstanding. The food was well prepared and the atmosphere was friendly and inviting. The manager made me feel like a local. Highly recommend.
author: Joe V.

description: Incredible. Best Chinese I've ever had.  Hot and sour soup, asparagus, & orange chicken were delicious.
author: Adam V.

description:
So, we came back a few months later and had more hot & sour soup.  It was NOT the same!!!  I guess it was a different cook or something, this time we ordered 2 soups and an appetizer.. sizzling rice soup and some fried wontons with a dab of pork in the middle..LOL!  

I feel everythings overpriced here, well it is S.F.!!  Skip the sizzling platters, what a rip off!!
author: La La T.

description: Great authentic food.  The place was very clean and the service was excellent.  The only problem we had was finding how to get here because of the road work on the same street.
author: Donald M.

description:
Searched Yelp last night for Chinese Take Out suggestion.   We ordered Orange Peel Chicken, Garlic Chicken, Veggie Chow Mein and Hot and Sour Soup.   Based on Yelp comments, we were looking forward to our meal but we ended up a little disappointed. There was no orange peel nor flavor in the Orange Peel Chicken..   The soup was very spicey (which we like) but lacked any developed flavor.     

On a good note---- THE SERVICE IS FRIENDLY AND VERY ATTENTIVE!  CLEAN RESTAURANT.  :)
The veggie chow mein was very good.
author: JoAnn S.

description:
Its good. Its not mind blowing and i think all the hype for SF chinese food had me expecting more but its still good. 

The service was actually really good and we got everything quickly, the waiter rolled the mu shu for us and then left us alone. We had everything we needed and no one was hovering over us which is kind of nice. 

The food really seemed pretty typical and i spent a super long time looking for something new and interesting but in the end came up with nothing that really caught my eye. I settled for the peanut chicken (i believe) and it was decent. The mu shu was good. On a sunday at 2 pm there was a chinese family and two white couples. It was actually kind of empty but not in a creepy way.

I think if this was in any other city it could easily be a 4 star place but in SF, which is supposed to be the mecca of chinese food on the west coast, i expected more.
author: Sergei N.

description: Best hot and sour soup I ever had.  Always good quality Chinese food here.  We actually ate here for thanksgiving.
author: Jason B.

description: Not Hunan-ish at all. More like a Cantonese style spicy food place. Good service tho.
author: Kaye Y.

description: Nah, just a standard american Chinese food that is not that good. Also very pricey for average food.
author: Ryan H.

description:
OVERATED. Place was insanely packed. Waiters were rude. They literally threw the menus at us. And I saw them do it to other tables. Food was mediocre. And they never brought out our pot stickers. It was no bigey when we first got our food, but when we're all done with our food and still no appetizer, kind of disappointing. 

Not to mention the place is small, cramped, and loud. Total cattle call. Big tourist trap.
author: Juan E.

description:
After a nice day in San Francisco a friend and I decided to eat in Chinatown.  Yelp brought us here.  The good reviews had us excited to try some delishness.

When we walked in I held up two fingers (for a party of two) and the owner immediately started saying, "yes, peace!"  Funny, nice guy.  We knew if nothing else, the service here would be great.

We were both kinda tired from a long day (we biked to the Golden Gate Bridge and then through Sausalito) so we were most unambitious when ordering -- beef fried rice, with no eggs for me and no peas for my friend.  It was basically rice, soy sauce, and beef, LOL.  The waiter laughed, as did we, but we were too tired.

Well, we liked this uneventful dish enough to order a 2nd batch when we decided we were still hungry.  So the waiter smiled and brought us out another one.

Normally I'd be embarrassed to have ordered something so plain at a restaurant that has such high Yelp love, but we were tired and the staff was really nice, so we enjoyed ourselves nonetheless.
author: Eduardo X.

description:
Not being from SF and after getting turned away from the R & G lounge down the street due to the long line, we tried this place out based on the Yelp reviews.  Now I'm no racist but I do practice racial profiling as a rule of thumb when it comes to Asian restaurants and being in one of the most populated ethnic Chinese (if not the most) one can understand my reservations when I don't see any Asian patrons.  But I was giving Hunan Homes the benefit of the doubt.  Maybe San Franciscoans are more savvy about Chinese food? 

For the most part, my inclination was correct.  Menu wasn't much more complex than some Chinese restaurants I've seen in small towns in the Midwest.  Having said that, the food that we did order was prepared nicely and was tasty.  Although the salt and pepper shrimp was way too salty.  

Decent restaurant if you're new to more authentic Chinese food or if R & G is booked.
author: Hubert L.

description:
This is my go-to place for a weekday lunch when I am craving spicy, Chinese food

I also think it is pretty cool that at this same exact location used to sit my parents' restaurant back in the late 70's so coming here brings back fond memories.

My favorites here are the eggplant with chicken and shrimp, hot spiced bean curd (AKA mapo tofu), and pot stickers.  Their hot and sour soup which comes with the lunch special is really good, nice and spicy

Sitting here writing this review is making me crave this for lunch tomorrow.  Guess my diet is out the door!
author: Sharon S.

description: We came here at the recommendation of our tour guide guy. He told us to order the spicy wonton soup, which we did. This was by all means the BEST wonton soup I've ever had! I saw the ladies making the wontons by hand so you know this was very authentic! We will be coming back to this place every time we visit San Fran!
author: Ruth A.

description:
too be honest, i didn't have much expectations coming here even though they have a solid 4 star review on yelp. why? well, i grew up eating in chinese restaurants for the first 18 years of my life growing up in san francisco. however, hunan homes- i have to say- you did a good job satisfying my hangerness.

located in the heart of chinatown, i totally passed this place when i was coming here with my group. i should have know that hunan homes is the restaurant with the crowded entryway/front door, full with people (native san francisco families and tourists alike) dying to get a seat and eat some authentic yummy chinese food. seriously, this place is packed! if you are in a large group, make sure you make reservations in advance. 

so the food? well let's just say the food was fantastic. we were a group of 9 and we ordered 13 dishes. our stomachs were elated with every single item. come to think of it- we didn't leave a crumb behind! our plates were all licked clean :)
author: The Hangry Chef O.

description:
We went there for lunch yesterday. It was ok.  We had the Hunan chicken which we thought was quite western. We also had the hot and sour soup and it lived up to its reputation. 

If you like western Chinese food then it's the place for you. If you are looking for an authentic Chinese meal, go to Hong kong Claypot restaurant on grant ave (corner of Jackson)
author: Violet K.

description: After looking over dozens of Yelp reviews (and health scores) of various restaurants in San Francisco, I chose this place to have my last meal. I walked in and just like the menu says est. 1983, the place looked like it had not been redecorated since then. I guess it adds to the charm. Anyway, I was seated near the door (host gave me the ocean view AKA the fish tank..hehe) and I looked over the menu. I ordered the hunan beef and sipped some tea while I waited...which took about 10 minutes. My food was out fast and hot. I dug in, chop sticks and all. Nothing spectacular about the dish. It tasted no different than any other hunan beef dishes I have had before. It was satisfying and just what I wanted on my last night in San Francisco.
author: Robin F.

description: This place was so good!!!!!it was four of us and we all got something different to try everything . Delicious!!! Everything was delicious no wonder it has great reviews if your ever in town you have to stop by.. It's busy we got lucky only waited 10min. But sometimes the wait is really long.
author: Sol M.

description: They have extremely nice and soft meats. Try Orange Peel Chicken and Mongolian Beef.
author: Renan C.

description: Really nice atmosphere and staff, and loved the food! I had the orange chicken, and was probably the best I ever tasted! The servers also came over to teach us about the different ingredients like the chili, and how we were supposed to eat that. Will defiantly come back here on a later opportunity.
author: Stian J.

description: Vegan works here!    One of our favorite haunts in San Francisco.  Fast and friendly service.    Usually no wait but it's popular.    There's another room in the back that is as big as the front dining room.
author: Michael R.

description:
tried take out for the house special crispy noodle.
it's not good. too much sauce but not enough seafood/meat 
hunan fried bread is ok
author: Rina C.

description: Really amazing food.  We made a reservation, so we didn't have to wait long.   We ordered soup and two meals, and the portions were enormous, so we had enough bring home.
author: Sean N.

description: My wife and I wanted a place to sit down and enjoy our meal in Chinatown. Hunan Homes had us seated right away and they have two sizable dinning areas. Service was ok but got my wife's order wrong, the food that came was good.
author: Dave L.

description:
Stopped by for lunch while in the city on business.  In a nutshell we liked it.
Restaurant is clean, seating is comfortable, pleasant atmosphere.
Service was attentive and fast without being overbearing.  Our order
had a curve ball but the waiter got it perfectly correct.  The restaurant is
a small street level storefront with the kitchens and restrooms in the basement.
The stairs to the restrooms are steep so keep this in mind if you have
problems with stairs.  The food was respectable, our best dish was the
fish in white sauce.  The lunch menu is a pretty good deal looking at the
size of the servings.
author: Jim M.

description: Excellent Xiao Long Bao!! Closest I've tasted in US to what I've had in Hong Kong. Medium spiced Sizzling Prawns and Chicken in Spicy Garlic Sauce were modestly spiced.  I would ask for hotter next time. And Spicy Chicken Salad was nice twist in noodles in Sesame Sauce. I'd come back.
author: Bruce M.

description:
This place had the best food we had during our entire visit to San Francisco. The location and service was typical Chinatown. Attentive and mostly very polite. It was a little gruff when we were seated, but this is not all that unusual at these places. They brought us a pot of warm tea which was fantastic. We started off with Jellyfish. it was very fresh and tasty but needed some chili oil to help spice it up a bit. We moved on the moo-shoo pork, orange flavored beef and kung-pao chicken. All were fantastic, but we were particularly fond of the first two. The Orange Beef was crispy and flavorful, which can be hard to find!  I would have given five stars, but they forgot our order of pot stickers and burnt the ones we asked for once we understood they had missed that order.  Kudo's to them for telling us that they were burnt rather than trying to serve them to us anyway.

Even with the glitches, I was impressed and I would recommend this place to anyone  Good job Hunan homes!

PS - We paid less for all this food than we did for two appetizers and two drinks on Pier 39........
author: Scott S.

description: I haven't been able to find a Chinese restaurant in SF or around that is comparable to what I had when visiting China. In addition to having so much bad experience eating Chinese food here in Chinatown that I was very hesitant to come to this restaurant. This place really caught me off guard and I'm glad I wasn't dissapointed.
author: Moua L.

description:
Good food, fast service.  My wife and I actually laughed about the great service received here.  We were in the city for a full week and of all the places we at and we ate in a multitude of places from high end down.  We seemed to received the fastest and most attentive service at HH, not the warmest but not rude.

Would eat here again, wish all of SF restaurants actually came back to your table for water refills once in a while.
author: Aaron F.

description: I came here thinking China town and 4 star Yelp review. Must have been hacked. Unimpressed with the over garliced Mongolian Beef. Egg rolls were small and lacked taste or composition outside of cabbage. Service lack personality and was more full service cafeteria. Overall a disappointment.
author: Mark H.

description: Very good food! Hunan Homes is a great family restaurant for all ages. The hot and sour soup was one of the best items on our table. We also had some delicious sweet and sour chicken, orange peel beef and other scrumptious treats. A welcome ending to our meal was the fresh, chilled oranges and locally made fortune cookies. The furnishings were a bit outdated and the bathroom was somewhat out of the way but overall a great restaurant!
author: Nancy B.

description: First day in San Fran! We ate here for lunch, a nice walk into china town from our hotel. Food was very authentic & the service was acceptable. At 2:30 pm there were no empty tables (a 50:50 mix of native & tourist) which to me, gave the place "street cred". Generous portions made the half mile walk home welcome!
author: Scott A.

description: Generous portions, large seating area, the restaurant goes way back.  Soup was very good and so was the beef and broccoli.  Excellent service all around.
author: William B.

description: Pretty good stuff. Got the pot stickers which have a wonderful dipping sauce. The BBQ spare ribs were a bit fatty and weird but had a good crust and flavor. I walked in and ordered to go and it didn't take to long. Not bad, I'll deffinatly get it again.
author: C.M. S.

description:
Best Chinese food I have had so far in SF. 

Non-greasy fried rice, non-gelatinous veggies - I'm definitely a fan! Fried rice isn't oily, snow-pea sprouts in garlic sauce are delicious, chili garlic prawns kick a punch but are still flavorful and the cashew chicken (I'm told) is very tasty.

Inside the restaraunt is a cozy upstairs and a spacious downstairs, with clean plates, real napkins, and not a pre-chewed chopstick in sight!

Great for tasty take-out also!
author: Beekay M.

description: Great food. Excellent service.  I had the Kung Pao beef and my other half had the wonton soup and beef chow mien.  No complaints here.
author: Michael V.

description: Had dinner here last night, yummo! Some of the best pot stickers around!
author: Christopher B.

description: We read good reviews about this place but we were not impressed by it.  The hot & sour soup was very salty, sour, and tasted like vinegar. All if our main dishes contained chicken and pork that was very fatty, definitely not from the breast of the chicken.  Even the Chinese restaurants out in the suburbs of Philadelphia where we're from have better Chinese food with non-fatty meat. The worst part was how unfriendly our waiter was, he was rude, didn't take our drink order and got annoyed with us when we asked if we could order sodas, and he never came back to the table after he brought the food.
author: Sarah R.

description: As an authentic Chinese, I authentically tell you guys that this is NOT authentic Chinese food at all!!! This is TOTALLY American Chinese food!!! I'm soooooo disappointed!!!
author: Ji C.

description:
Hunan Homes was my first restaurant experience in San Francisco.

In 1991 I was living in L.A. and had just gotten my driver's license. To celebrate, I rented a car and drove up here. Toward the end of my first day I was zig-zagging the streets of Chinatown on foot, peering in windows and examining menus, trying to decide how to bust my restaurant cherry, when I found Hunan Homes. I ordered the beef with orange peel to go and headed back to my hotel room. By the time I settled in the food was cold, but I was starving so I dug in. HEAVEN. It was sweet and savory and chewy and beefy, laced with chile peppers and strips of orange peel and served with shredded carrot and daikon in a vinegary marinade that perfectly offset the sweetness of the beef's glaze.

I returned to L.A. and tried many restaurants over the ensuing year, searching in vain for that same perfect flavor. In 1992, I came back for my second visit to San Francisco with Hunan Homes at the top of my to-go-to list.

In 1993 I was in the midst of planning my third visit up north when everything got turned topsy-turvy and instead of planning a vacation to San Francisco I was planning a move here.

So, since 1993, Hunan Homes has been right in my backyard. Over the last decade and a half I have taken many friends and my entire family there and every single person has been as smitten as I am. Many of us remember when "the old man" was still alive...the family patriarch who oversaw the dining room with his never-empty glass of wine, stopping at each table to charm his customers.

The restaurant is now overseen by his son, James, and has retained its family-run feeling. When my parents come to visit twice a year, Hunan Homes is at the top of their list of must-go places as well, not only because of the food but because they appreciate the way that James and the staff make them feel so welcome.

But back to the food. I've been all over that menu and there hasn't been a single dish I didn't like. Today, among other things, we had the hot spice crispy chicken, a half-bird fried until the skin is crispy and even the bones are crunchy, then chopped up and slathered with a delectable sauce perfect for sopping up with rice or their "succulent bread". The sizzling sliced fish...how do they get so much flavor into a simple white fish? The house special crispy seafood chow mein is a nest of thin, crispy noodles topped with squid, fish, scallops, mushrooms and an assortment of vegetables.

I could go on and on but I won't. Just go to Hunan Homes already!
author: Valeria R.

description:
Very good food. We had the Hot and Sour Soup, Potstickers, Orange Peel Chicken, and Hunan Sautéed Pork. 

The Hot and Sour Soup was peppery with a ton of flavor. Spicy enough that I was a little worried about the Hunan Sautéed Pork, which turned out to be very spicy, but not so much as to be overpowering. I really enough when food is spicy and the spiciness enhances the flavor, which this certainly did. 

The Orange Peel Chicken had a lot of different flavors to it. It was sweet with some sour from the Orange, with nice pieces of breaded chicken.  Plenty of crispy bits. 

Overall, and extremely enjoyable meal. And the price was very reasonable.
author: Gene G.

description:
When I think of Chinese food, I don't think of Sizzling Beef, Mushu Pork, Tea Smoked Duck, Hot and Sour Soup, Walnut Prawns, Fried String Beans with Garlic, but these are all Chinese dishes, and this place does it well.

You walk in and its a stereotypical Chinese Restaurant, something that might be depicted on a TV show. All the wait staff are Chinese with not the best Engrish and the captain is, "Oh that Funny Chinese Guy." Look around and no one looks like me, except the wait staff. Every one is non-Chinese and you can tell some are tourists. 

I was really excited for the Sizzling Beef. I even held my napkin in front like a curtain so that the hot oil or the steam wouldn't get all up in my face. But when the lady poured the beef onto the stone plate. .. ss. NO SIZZLE. I was made a fool holding up my napkin. Oh well, I thought.. but then I heard SSSS and SSSS and SSSS from all other tables around us. Smoke in the air, sizzling here and there. What the heck?! How come all theirs sizzled and not mine? MAYBE IT WAS BECAUSE I WAS CHINESE AND SPOKE CHINESE. I don't know, but their stuff is okay so I ate some fried string beans and got over it.

thumbs up: American Chinese Food, friendly staff
thumbs down: no sizzle, the mushu pork only comes with 4 pancakes... if you want another one, its 50 cents. So if you come with a party of 5, make sure someone brings 50 cents.

Tip: Pork Blood not on menu, but you can order it.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
This was one of the times that Yelp didn't really come through for me. 

I was trying to find an authentic and clean place in Chinatown for a nice dinner with my gf. 
When we walked in, it was pretty nice, the waitress greeted us with a smile and brought us to our table. When I opened the menu, I was pretty disappointed, pretty much the selection of dishes you could get at any American Chinese place. My gf wanted to try something new and exciting that she has never tried, and I just didn't see anything new or exciting for her on that menu.

We ordered the Mongolian Beef, String Beans with Pork, and the Sweet and Sour Chicken.

Portions were small, and honestly, the beef and the pork had the exact same flavor. Sweet and Sour chicken was average. 

Just not what I was looking for, and I was pretty disappointed.
author: Ronny D.

description: Really great Chinese food. In fact, one of my favorites in the city. The only reason I don't give it the full 5 stars is that the last time I ate there, my friend and I got MSG poisoning. We were sitting at the table and all of the sudden we both got weird numbness and nausea...we couldn't even move for a bit. Granted, we ate SO much food that night that of course we'd ingested too much MSG. At the end of the day, though, the food is amazing, and the service is great also. I'd still go back...
author: Jeff S.

description:
Needless to say, Chinatown has a million and one Chinese restaurants. Some are outstanding (ok haven't found that one yet) and the rest are run of the mill. Hunan Homes is in that "fine but definitely average" category.

We came to eat here with the fam because my parents had eaten here long ago and recalled it being particularly good. We ordered mu-shu chicken, chicken chow mein, sizzling rice soup, Mongolian beef, Hunan chicken, beef and broccoli and steamed rice for five adults. The soup was bland and the entrees were small and nothing special. They were fine, but not like "the best beef and broccoli I have ever had." The only dish that was outstanding was the mu shu chicken, perhaps because the waitress wrapped each pancake for us so thee wasn't the usual dripping of chicken and veggies and plum sauce all over the place.

The plates are very small so order at least one or two more than you regularly would for your group size. Oh, and the fortunes in the cookies are not interesting either. 9 is my lucky number for the week. Grand.
author: Emilia S.

description: We went here on Yelp's recommendation. It did not leave us unsatisfied. We had the Peking Duck. It was very tasty and moist and not salty. Service was quick and good. Would definitely come back.
author: Glenn B.

description: Best Chinese food I have eaten in America! No kidding. They are gooood!
author: United R.

description: Garlic Ginger crab honestly the best thing I've ever eaten - outside of a gourmet rest. The crab was super fresh
author: Jason s.

description:
Food - 3 stars
Service - 10 stars!!!!

We tried this place out because of a restaurant.com coupon.  I agree with Hasan S. - the service was insane. As soon as I took a sip of water, my glass was refilled. The place was packed on a Friday night yet service never suffered - yay!

The food wasn't bad, but it was memorable either. Hubby and I ordered the Tai Chin Chicken, sizzling beef plate and asparagus (oink - had to meet the coupon minimum). The asparagus was the best dish. Chicken came spicy as promised with nice bits of quality chicken. Beef was a bit chewy and tasteless. Hubby liked it but you can read more in his Yelp review.

I think I'll try out other restaurants before coming back.
author: Kim W.

description:
Ate here after a day trip to Alcatraz. We sat down early at about 530pm and there was only one other table occupied at the time. The old lady who greeted us looked very fierce and scary but it turned out that she was very pleasant and helpful. Food was high quality and the bill was reasonable.

Good friendly service and by the time we left the restaurant was full.
author: A S.

description: Food was pretty good til the garlic chicken was partial raw.  Brought it back to heat up and still raw when it came back out
author: Wai H.

description: First time in Chinatown & couldn't have picked a better restaurant! We had mushu chicken, egg rolls, sweet and sour chicken, shrimp fried rice, beef lo mien, & steamed vegetables in garlic sauce.  We had family style & the waitress plated our mushu for us. Delicious food, wonderful service, couldn't ask for a better experience!
author: Tracy K.

description: Small little Restaurant on Jackson st Crosses the main street of Chinatown. Good service. Typical Chinese Restaurant decor. Had the Potstickers and they are very good... The salted pepper fried pork ribs are Dlish... Other than than everything was pretty average from any other restaurant. As soon as you get seated you get Green Tea. White Rice was a little dry..
author: Diego V.

description: Xiao long bao.  Pretty good.  Not an amaze-fest, but good.  And they know how to work the street visual for us gweilo.  But for folks living in a town with few options, this is a fantastic stop.  The citrus at the end removes any unfortunate traces while leaving you open to, well, whatever is appropriate.  Plus there's this bookstore nearby...
author: Jason R.

description:
We ordered chinese potstickers, broccoli beef, double mushroom scallops and prawns and chilli garlic eggplant. 

The dishes were all tasty.  The prices were a little inflated due to SF and its odd business.  The portions were smaller than we expected. 

Service was fine, except the smart-alec man who asked why I needed a fork since I was Asian looking.  He also said we should pay to get a fork. 

I eat off of a plate with a fork and out of a bowl with chopsticks.
author: Jeffrey T.

description: The food was really good but the service was the reason to come back. We ordered the moo-shu pork and the waiter built the wraps table side without using his hands. It was cool, he used spoons like chopsticks, check it out.
author: Jim N.

description:
Ok, 2nd visit wasn't that bad.  Starting my best xlb in San Francisco quest, I came here after being informed that going to Kingdom of Dumpling was just too far.  Not to be deterred, we got the xlb, salt and pepper spare ribs, basil fish, and string beans.  

The XLBs actually came with a pretty good sauce that was different from your typical black vinegar with ginger.  Instead, it looked like it had a little bit of chili and garlic, which went pretty well with the XLB's, though non traditional.  As far as the quality itself, the skin was a tiny bit thicker than preferred, the meat tasted a little like wonton meat, and the soup inside the dumpling was low to medium.  This really was the only bad part of the meal as the other 3 dishes were really tasty.
author: Jeff N.

description:
I think I enjoyed it...
I'm just not sure due to the hot and sour soup. I liked the soup a lot but it was just so "spicy" hot that it meant everything else had a dented taste. I'm sure the food could stand up well but I just couldn't tell.
The potstickers were average and the orange peel chicken had a good amount of zest paired with spice.
The wife had beef stew with wontons and it left us wontin!! The portion size was good but the hor fun was not up to the dish. The wontons were so so and the beef was good. 
Service is good for Chinese restaurants and it's clean.
All in all - a solid 3 stars.
author: Nick L.

description:
Yelp led me to Hunan Homes and I couldn't be more grateful. After a long morning of work and a walk up the biggest hill in my life, we FINALLY arrived in Chinatown. I was ready to order everything on the menu... so I did. 

Started with some fresh hot tea which felt like the perfect way to wake up my pallet. Order some apps to get the party started and chose the potstickers and hot and sour soup. The potstickers were great but the hot and sour may have been the best I've ever had in my entire life. It was more hot and spicy than it was sour and I loved every slurp. 

We ordered three entree dishes for the table to share - orange peel chicken = amazing; kung pow deluxe = spicy wonderfulness of chicken, beef, prawns and veggies; mongolian beef = rich, spicy, beefy.

A lot of the dishes and soup that I had was spicy, which I love. So, if you don't like a little spice with each bite then you might go for something like the orange peel chicken. However, the menu was very extensive and there's plenty to choose from. A great place for great Chinese food in the heart of Chinatown.
author: andrew h.

description: In town for vacation and we always hit a restaurant  in Chinatown. Wow what a great find. Hot saki was the smoothest I've ever had. Pot stickers were very meaty and cooked just right, add some of the chille paste that on the table and bang you've got the flavor going. Spicy crispy chicken was very tasty, prawn w/green beans was so good my mouth waters just thinking about it. Pork fried rice topped off the whole meal, damn I can't wait to come back to SF. !!!
author: Mark M.

description: Food was ok. Service was ok. Peking duck came with pancake instead of bun. The rice was super dry. Sweet and sour pork came with too much sauce and pepper. Average dinning place.
author: Tracy L.

description: We chose to eat here based on the high Yelp ratings, and were a bit disappointed. Upon walking in, we realized that this is a Chinatown tourist attraction. Very few Chinese customers. This is definitely Americanized Chinese food. We ordered the fried buns (no condensed milk accompaniment, sadly), Mongolian beef, hot and sour soup, and seafood chow mein. Still, the hot and sour soup was tasty; the other dishes were not bad, but they were nothing to write home about. The service was prompt and friendly, but I felt weird being in Chinatown and waiters automatically responding/speaking in English. Wouldn't come here again, but the restaurant is not a bad offering if you're in the Chinatown area and want a clean restaurant with decent food.
author: Wendy L.

description:
I went here with my mom on a recent trip to San Francisco. I noticed that this place had very good reviews on yelp so we decided to eat here.

Indeed this place is very popular, when we got there all tables were full. We waited about 10 minutes for a table. Once we were seated, we were given ample time to look over the menus. They can improve here by reprinting their menus to make them look new, you can tell that the menus have been looked over quite a bit.

We had the pot stickers, great tasting and a really great appetizer. We also ordered the Egg foo young soup. Very hot and fresh as well. We also ordered the orange peel chicken and the chicken chow mein. (We love chicken, hehe) Orange peel chicken, was sweet and tangy, cooked to perfection. The chicken chow mein was also cooked well. My mom and I were impressed! We didn't wait long for our meals to be prepared. Prices were reasonable.

We will definitely come back to eat here again. It's thanks to this place that we left with a good impression of SF's chinatown.
author: Hector A.

description: The food here is quite good, although we were in a group of 5 and all of our food came out at different times which made no sense. some people waited up to 15 minutes to get their meals.
author: Jeff W.

description: Headed into Chinatown and found this place thru Yelp. Kinda intimidated at first by the decor but don't let it fool you. Food was awesome. We had Kung Pao Prawns and Squid. Mongolian Beef, Spicy pork, a soup (I think called west lake beef) and House Fried Rice. Everything was delicious, TsingTsao beers were flowing and the staff was cordial. Bathrooms were surprisingly clean. Would def recommend it.
author: Tyler D.

description: Food was decent, not amazing.  However, they took it upon themselves to increase the (20%) tip I left, not so much that I would call my credit card company, but something like that just doesn't sit right with me...will not be returning.
author: Amy B.

description: Nice atmosphere, good service, and great food. The Hunan Beef is my favorite. A great option among many in San Francisco's Chinatown.
author: B C.

description:
I was visiting San Francisco for the first time in my adult life over the weekend and was turned on to this place by Yelp. 4-stars, with 300+ reviews? It felt like a "can't miss" type of place.

I ordered all the Yelp favorites: hot & sour soup, potstickers, and orange peel chicken.

Here's my breakdown of each dish:

Hot & Sour soup: This soup was more sour than anything else. I didn't get that hot/sour balance that makes hot and sour great. Although, the ingredients were good and plentiful and gave the soup a nice consistency, but again, it just tasted like a sour soup. Maybe this was just a bad batch?

Potstickers: These were my favorite of the entire meal. They had pretty good flavor, and I liked how they were prepared. A nice seared crust on one side, with the rest of the potsticker being steamed. It gave a nice balance of texture throughout the dish. Although this was a good dish, it did have one MAJOR ISSUE. When I cut some of the potstickers in half, some of them had the pork mixture completely raw in the middle. This is unacceptable for any restaurant, and I had to knock them a star for this. If you are going to order this dish, please cut them in half to make sure they are cooked all the way through so you don't end up with food poisoning.

Orange Peel Chicken: This was a slightly above average rendition of orange chicken. It had a nice flavor, but I still tasted the "starchiness" of the batter which took away from it. This dish was served family style, but the portion was very small and couldn't even satisfy two people with average appetites.

As alluded to my many previous Yelpers, I found that this place did not have any Chinese people eating inside. Probably most of the people inside were tourists, and the rest fellow Yelpers like myself being led astray. I could overhear some conversations about what people heard about on Yelp.

I think this is the first time I've probably been outright disappointed with a place that had at least 4 stars and this many reviews. I expected a lot more than this, especially this being Chinatown in San Francisco. I've had way better Chinese food where I live in a suburb of So. Cal, where no Chinese people live at all. Next time, I'll just follow the trail of Chinese people to another restaurant.
author: Angelo P.

description:
I came here with my mom and dad because I had bought the restaurant.com coupon a while back and it was the perfect time to use it because we were in the Chinatown that night.

First of all...we walked into this Chinese restaurant in Chinatown and we were the only Chinese customers there, which was a bit awkward but I guess these restaurant.com coupons worked and helped bring a wider and much more diverse scene to the place.

But on to the review...the service is pretty good...they seated us right away and were always attentive and asking us if we needed anything else. We took forever to order because my parents are super picky, but we ended up ordering the same things we ALWAYS order...so typical.

We ordered:

1. Mapo Tofu - very bland and not very spicy at all.
2. Hunan Beef - was a bit cold and very mushy.
3. Sweet and Sour pork - There wasn't much pork at all but rather a plate full of green/red bell peppers.
4. Hunan Shrimp - Like the Hunan Beef, it was a bit cold and mushy.

The food in general is below par for Chinese food and the servings are super small. The one good thing about this place is the service as our food came right away.

Buy a restaurant.com coupon if you want to come here...otherwise, forget it.
author: David W.

description:
So my family used to regularly visit the one in Los Altos on a regular basis... and believed that this was the only edible restaurant in tourist laden Chinatown. We've been here a couple of times and twice... we saw a furry fat bald tailed rat running around late last year. Of course all the kids were screaming "RAT RAT RAT!!" and the waitress kept insisting that they had no vermin... Until Mr. Rat scurried across her feet since a neighboring table also started screaming. 

Food is actually good here (4 stars)... but sanitation is VERY VERY bad.... Unless... you have a thing for rats. The show was very entertaining I have to admit...

So the owner of the restaurant contacted me about the sanitation issues... and said that there are some "rat-proofing" methods done around the kitchen area. I don't know how that changes things in terms of keeping the furry friends out of the kitchen... or out of the dining area. (Yes it is Chinatown... and I would never trust the sanitation at ANY restaurant here... but this is the first restaurant where I've actually seen a live rat running around.) But still... vermin is vermin. He also requested that the time frame of my visit.  SO YELP READERS... This review is from 4 months ago! (If that makes any difference.... since we know that rats live a lot longer than 4 months... and can breed exponentially in tha time!) 

To the restaurant's credit, the salt and pepper crab and lobster are done VERY well here. And if you are fond of little oinky-innards, they have this dish that boils pork blood cubes with pork intestines with tofu that's served over this flambe thing. That is very well flavored... I avoid the intestines and blood and go for the tofu.
author: Vicky L.

description: Attentive and friendly service. Had a wonton soup and Peking duck, delicious and for a decent price. Good place to eat when you're on your own.
author: Ben K.

description: Loved Hunan Homes! We went at the recommendation of our friends who travel internationally quite extensively! We were not disappointed!  Service was excellent! Food was perfect! The atmosphere was warm and inviting! The String Beans a la Hunan are a must!
author: Michael B.

description:
I like my food how I like my men: cheap, quick and delicious.  And sizzling hot.   Tsssssssssstt.

Actually, I don't like cheap (or quick) guys.  But when it comes to food, yes please, as long as it's also delicious.

In comes Hunan Homes, a place that I always walk past but never go into because Chinatown restaurants can go one of two ways: amazing or terrible.  I had the opportunity to Yelp it before I tried it with Boyfriend and his coworkers.

Cheap: Actually this place isn't as cheap as other Chinese restaurants, but it's not by any means expensive.  Lunch for 5 of us came to $46.  My two dishes (yes I'm a fatty) came out to be $16 JUST for myself, so if you're not like me, lunch will definitely only run you sub $10.

Quick: All of our dishes came within 10 minutes of us ordering.  This place is all about efficiency, and our bill was on the table, fortune cookies included, before we were even done eating.

Delicious: I love sizzling rice soup, and this is the best I've had.  Flavorful broth, tender pieces of shrimp and chicken, and duh, sizzling rice.  They only come in a medium bowl, which could theoretically serve 2-3 people, but what they didn't understand was that I wanted it all for myself, so them pre-splitting it into smaller bowls was counterproductive, and it also prompted Boyfriend to take one of the bowls.  Not that I'm not about sharing, but this is all mine.  I also ordered the string beans a la carte (didn't come with rice, nor was it really considered a lunch dish), and they were deliciously spicy and yummy.  I would totally give Hunan homes 5 stars had their green beans been better than the ones at Betelnut.  But it's still delicious, and it's still a big portion.

Another great Chinatown CCG lunch spot.  Dang it - I hit it, and now I can't quit it.
author: Tori S.

description: I found this through yelp.  I liked the outdated comfortable vibe of the restaurant including a fish tank with a big blowfish. The soup and soup dumplings were great. The sliced white chicken had a weird weird texture - sort of puffy. I liked the looks and smells of the sizzling dishes that our neighbors ordered and will back and try those. Note: 2 hour validated parking!
author: Andrew K.

description: You can find this level of Chinese food place anywhere in Asian town. Nothing special, nothing that great.  Fried rice was meh, spicy tofu dish was meh, orange peel chicken was not that good.  It doesn't worth waiting at all - go somewhere.
author: Miho Y.

description:
My sad east coast self has obviously been sheltered from authentic Chinese food. In Philadelphia, any Chinese chicken is covered in some sort of breading? whatever you want to call that. The orange peel chicken at Hunan Homes was awesome. Spicy and delicious, and clean actual chicken meat. We ate that with some chow mein and vegetables.

For the appetizer, we had the spicy wontons which were excellent. I just kept dumping the sauce on my rice. Also the potstickers were pretty good but nothing out of the ordinary. Nothing like a nice Tsingtao to wash it down.

Great place if you are in the Chinatown area.
author: PJ H.

description: Mmm!  Affordable, tasty duck!  Nice, English-speaking host.  Good tea.  A nice mix of local Chinese peeps, non-Chinese peeps, and tourists.  Pretty trustworthy stuff.  Even their xio long bao were good.  Even if the skin was rather thick and undelicate, the filling was tasty, ginger-y, and the sauce was yummy.  Go Hunan Homes!
author: Sara L.

description: Had a wonderful meal. Tried the chicken chow mein and the chicken and string beans. They were both really good. The service was prompt and courteous. The diners looked like neighborhood regulars, and I overheard two different tables complimenting how much they enjoyed their meals. Would definitely come back again.
author: Samantha A.

description:
This place had some of the best potstickers and orange peel beef I have ever had. It was very tasty and I'm sure the rest of the items on their menu is equally as good.

I definitely would love to come back, the next time I'm in town visiting San Francisco.

The only reason I didn't give 5 stars was because I felt rushed to leave. But I understand as they were busy and I was just a party of one. 

I'll definitely be coming back :)
author: Fredrick F.

description: We chose this restaurant purely on the basis of Yelp recommendations and I don't have that much experience with Chinese food - but that said, we were extremely impressed. We arrived about 5.30pm and had to wait for about 10 mins for a table. As we waited, the line just got longer. The service was very quick (but terse) and the food was delicious. We had the Family Meal 'A' for four and our children (10 and 12) really enjoyed it. It included a selection of 2 starters and 4 main course dishes with rice and tea. The stir fried vegetables were the highlight for us all. Very good value as well at under $80 for all of us. Highly recommend.
author: Donald D.

description: Fantastic. I had the pot stickers and moo shu chicken. The chicken was great, but the pot stickers were amazing.
author: Kevin B.

description:
This place is AWESOME, I came here with my girlfriend and we had the spicy wontons and the walnut shrimp, they were DELICIOUS!!!!!  The staff is friendly and the food is super tasty!!!! I came upon this place by yelp recommendations, so thank you yelp for helping me find a fantastic restaurant. =) and thank you hunan homes for the tasty food.
With Love: the guy with the Woody Woodpecker T-shirt
author: Saul M.

description: Great Chinese food in Chinatown! This place gets very busy and it's small inside so it can get cramped! I recommend ordering takeout! My meal was great! Best Chinese food in Chinatown!
author: Korrin R.

description: Great hot and sour soup, awesome lunch specials and has a good number of vegetarian options.
author: Kushan P.

description: Upon checking the Yelp! reviews in the area, we opted to visit Hunan Homes for dinner.  We didn't have to wait to get a table on Friday night, which was great.  The service was prompt and the food was delicious.  The price was right, too.
author: Jeff N.

description:
I've been here a couple of times.  Delicious x2.

Potstickers perfectly fried, dough texture is great.  Westlake soup has tender beef (in fact every dish with beef is tender), not too salty, just right.  beef chow fun.  Droooool. There was not a single dish that I had with my friend that wasn't good.  

Forget trying to go at dinner time on Friday or Saturday.

I plan trips to San Francisco around this place.  There ya go.
author: Nick K.

description: This was one of the best culinary experiences I have ever had. We had a party of 9 so we made a reservation, and I'm so glad we did. There were plenty of people outside waiting for a table, which made it seem like we had made the right choice. Since we were in a large group, we were seated at a table with lazy Suzann so we ordered family style. It has been awhile but the dishes I remember were the Peeking duck (AAAAAAAAMAZING!), honey walnut prawns (so good), sizzling beef (tasty), a steamed whole fish, Lemon Chicken, and the most adventurous plate of all the Jellyfish appetizer. PLEASE do yourself the favor and try the jellyfish, I expected it to be a weird texture and slimy, but it was nothing like that and really tasty. I look forward to coming back to SF to eat here again.
author: Crystal M.

description: The food gets five stars! The hot and sauer soup is the best ive ever had.  The only reason i gave it four stars is because of the looks.  Almost walked out becuase of the very old decor decide to give it a chance and was super surprised.   Amazing amazing food
author: CJ B.

description: Darn good food, with no complaints.  It would probalby rank higher, but I've had Hunanese food three times in the past few weeks, and this was the least spectacular of the three.  So Hunan Homes suffers by comparison, but that doesn't mean we didn't enjoy every bite. The pork dumplings were excellent. I had Velvet chicken, which was lovely.  Sweetie had 8 roasted vegetables, which he thought were spectacular.  He also had Tofu kung pao, which was good, but too spicy for me. The environment could use some sprucing up, it's sort of lackluster.  Service was quite attentive.
author: Beth G.

description:
Nice place. The service was quick and attentive, even though they had a huge party of about thirty show up after we did. The pot stickers were excellent, as was the mu shu pork and the orange peel chicken. The sizzling beef was very good, but the hot pepper steam from the sizzling made us cough. ;-) 

We had an excellent meal. Very much recommended.
author: Julie G.

description: Monday evening 6:30 with the kids. Had to wait less than 10 mins for table. Waiters were fast and efficient but not particularly friendly. Walnut prawns and vegetarian pot stickers were great and the kids loved the egg fried rice. Family bean curd was bland, but it may be because my wife asked to get it non-spicy.
author: Joakim S.

description:
very pleasantly surprised.  was expecting mediocre Chinatown fare and got much better than I thought.  (The chicken actually looked like chicken, real white chicken mean in the General's chicken!)   I've eaten at many many Chinese places in SF over the past 25 years and this was at the top.  i took out-of-towners here from the east coast and they loved it.  a great combination of good food with the whole chinatown experience. 

all the dishes were great and the price was right.  I'm really happy to know I now have a go-to place in chinatown.  will definitely be back!
author: Aaron R.

description: The waiting time was a little too long, then again, we arrived at the busiest time of the day and it's a holiday. Foodwise, a definite 5 stars. I recommend this place.
author: Anthony S.

description: Local knowledge: This place is a great hole in the wall spot for tasty Chinese. I live around the corner and make frequent runs for won-ton soup. Winner-Winner, chicken dinner!
author: Matt K.

description: Hunan Homes is probably one of the best Chinese restaurant in touristy SF chinatown. We live in the city and go to Chinatown from time to time, each time we must go to Hunan Homes for a quick fix of their awesome hot and spicy soup, mongolian beef and salt and pepper calamari. Their dishes are pretty affordable and the serve is good. I recommend Hunan Homes if you are hungry and wondering around Chinatown!
author: Vickie Z.

description: Awesome Awesome food always go here when in town visiting nothing but the best food great service & makes my tummy happy & all my family & friends also :)) if your in the area & want great Chinese food you must go here !!
author: Shaynapet M.

description: a real 4 stars here. Less wait line than his neighbors in that price range, very good food with serious choice and some specialties that are not to be seen everywhere. The boss is funny, making sure that you enjoy your time here and won t hesitate to lead you to better choices when needed. I would recommend the Tea Braisted Duck, crispy, tasty and very original.
author: Nixo A.

description: It's official:  My favorite Chinese food outside of Singapore. This is a must have , whenever I find myself in sfo.  I've had an assortment of dishes and they've all been top notch.  have taken friends and family here and they all dig it.  Great stuff.
author: John L.

description: Born and raised in China Hunan province, this is one of the most random shameless use of Hunan and Hunan food in menu I've seen. Upon entering, I noticed none of the tables were Chinese. We ordered fried tofu as appetizer which was decent. But the two main courses were total westernized rubbish that shouldn't exists at the heart of Chinatown: the first course used tomato sauce for starch, authentic Hunan food never use starch in the first place, let alone tomato sauce in starch. The second one was Hunan Smoked Pork: it's NOT even Hunan style smoked pork. It's obviously Cantonese style: red, grilled, sweet instead of black, smoked, spicy and full of flavor. Hunan food is also normally famous for its spiciness, oily over high fire, both of our main dishes taste bland and sour. I understand why it is getting four star overall reviews despite our experience. It is perfectly westernized Cantonese food with a random Hunan branding, the dining area is also tidier and cleaner than regular Chinese restaurants, catering to its western customers. The server were all dressed up giving you this upscale vibe (the service though is no better than regular Chinese restaurant, we were basically invisible to them after ordering, and it took a long time for the to notice that we are ready for the check, when wife stands up and starts leaving our table, but we don't care and we still tip). But make no mistake, this is no Hunan food, not even good Chinese food. There is no shame in catering to its specific market segment. It might very well be a more profitable market. There is also no shame starting from westernized Chinese food if you really do enjoy its food, kudos for trying something different. The shame is in the restaurant's use of the word "Hunan" and reference of Hunan food on its menu. And this is especially for the foodies who are looking for  authentic Chinese food and also as a note to myself: observe the makeup of a restaurant's customers before trusting Yelp's overview ratings.
author: Francis Z.

description: THE BEST Chinese food I have ever had and service is terrific. Try the orange peel beef!
author: Ellen B.

description: Happy find thanks to Yelp reviews!  Definitely lived up to the reviews.   Beer was cold and all entrees were excellent. Hunan Shrimp, veg chow mein, egg rolls, orange peel chicken, 3 ingredient seafood all great choices.
author: Christine D.

description: After a couple of years living in Hong Kong, I've been missing good Chinese food! This place was great - good service, big menu, and lots of veggie choices (the bean curd with 2 kinds of mushroom was actually one of the best I've ever had). To eat good food and see a bit of China town whilst you walk there's, it's perfect.
author: Joanna M.

description:
My wife and I ate here three years ago on a business trip and when I heard we would be back in San Francisco I knew exactly where we would have dinner. 

The Hunan smoked pork is just as good as I remembered. The thin slices of smoked pork pack so much flavor you could just eat it by itself. But the addition of the spicy Hunan sauce and vegetables make this a must try. 

The Hunan prawns were tender and plentiful and the potstickers with their simple sauce were great. I can't answer for every item on the menu as I haven't tried them all but I would definitely give them a vote of confidence based on what I had. 

Service was friendly and efficient and the owners were all smiles. The whole experience was great. We're already looking forward to our next visit.
author: Mark P.

description: First of all do not be fooled by the interior when you walk in. I know it doesn't look like much, but this is one of the best Chinese food restaurants I have ever eaten at.  The service was attentive and the food was excellent.  The lemon chicken was exceptional.
author: Andy B.

description: Loved it! Great traditional Chinese food as well as all the American favorites. Good place for larger groups too (we had 6 and had no trouble being sat). Excellent egg rolls and crab rangoon.
author: Jessica E.

description: Ate here with my wife last night, having come from out of town (south Florida where it isn't easy to find such good Chinese food). I thought the quality of the food was top notch. We had a combo menu that included egg roll, hot & sour soup, hunan beef, and orange chicken. It was all really good. Cooked just right so that those components that should be crispy (such as snow peas and carrots) were, and the meats were perfectly tender and not overcooked. The waiters were serious as can be, great job. There was even a guy who would come around and clean up the mess we were making with a hot towel. The only possible drawback was that I like my food really spicy, and they weren't really receptive to us asking for a certain level of spiceiness.
author: Andrew M.

description: Waited 20 minutes and so glad we did. The orange chicken was so good we ordered a second plate. The Hunan shrimp was great too. Service is fair but the food makes it worth it.
author: Lois U.

description: This is a somewhat famous restaurant and one may have certain expectations regarding its food taste and quality. Generally, I think the food does live up to the expectations, but the prices have gone up in the last few years. The restaurant environment has also changed, it wants to be more upscale now, which perhaps justifies the prices. Service is good, parking is pretty bad.
author: Andrew S.

description:
One of the better Chinese restaurants in Chinatown. Slightly off the beaten track (it's on Jackson Street). It's nothing fancy, and yes the decor is garish, but the food is quick, simple and tasty. 

Reasonable prices and much higher quality than what you would get at a very touristy place on Grant street. Not sure why all the tour books direct people to house of nanking. This is by far a better option.

Get the Orange Peel chicken---it's sweet and spicy. Service was quick but I wouldn't exactly say it was friendly.
author: Dave S.

description: I'm not sure if I would come back to this restaurant, but I wouldn't avoid it if I was hungry. It was just ok. It wasn't terrible, but it wasn't amazing. My boyfriend and I were walking around Chinatown and yelping a good chinese food restaurant, and the 4 stars of Hunan Homes pulled us in. We looked at their menu and I was digging their lunch specials. Much to my dismay, they didn't have their lunch specials at the time. How convenient. Sometimes, their menus are so overwhelming with sooo many items on their menu booklet, that having a lunch special that you can just pick from is much more convenient. I can't remember what we got, but it was good. Like I said, not terrible, but not super amazing.
author: Angeline E.

description: Just visiting from Portland and got inside with yelp reviews. Well I have to say this is a great Chinese restaurant. You gotta try shrimp sizzling. Egg flour soup and pot stickers were great! Very quiet but funny waiter.
author: Koichi M.

description: I was told by no less than 5 people that this was a place before my trip to San Francisco. Long story short, as advertised
author: Adrian D.

description: The food here is a very good example of Americanized Chinese. The service is inappropriately rushed and straddles the line between indifference  and frank hostility.
author: Dan G.

description:
HHR was great
.... Sizzling Oyster.....Awesome
.....orange beef.........Awesome
Good/friendly/fast service
author: Mark G.

description:
James our server is the man! The food was excellent. I would recommend the salt and pepper crab, the fish filet in black bean sauce, and their sweet and sour soup. The food was fresh and very tasty. This place is good for groups and has a touristy clientele. I will definitely be back soon.

The restaurant is surprisingly clean and so were the restrooms. A+
author: Bobby D.

description: Orange chicken and sizzling rice soup..omg.
author: Leah B.

description:
My fellow yelpers helped me once again!

Was walking around SF Chinatown with no idea where to go, I just knew I wanted sizzling rice soup, so I consulted my yelp for blackberry application, and saw the great reviews for Hunan Homes and decided to give it a try.

Great choice I must say. The soup was just what I needed on a cold and drizzling afternoon. Bits of white-meat chicken, shrimp, and veggies in a flavorful broth poured over dried rice. I love to here it crackle and pop! MMMmmmm. 

Service was quick and consistent. Hot tea came free with the meal (in LA some places charge for hot tea, ugh).

Will be back next time I am in the area.
author: Rell E.

description:
Amazing food - Best I have had. Mongolian Chicken (spicy) and wow - flavorful, spicy.
Atmosphere was great - friendly staff. A must for anyone.
author: Kevin F.

description:
The reviews say it, the rating shows it, the food proves it... this place is legit.

Gan chao niu he.  Da dou miao.  West Lake beef soup.  Yes please.
author: Alex C.

description:
We arrived here at 7:45 on a Saturday night - it was crowded, but there wasn't a line and we were seated very promptly.  They have a lot more seating than it seems at first, as there are multiple back rooms.  Still, I would recommend making a reservation just to be safe, especially if you have a larger party.

We were served hot tea literally about two seconds after we sat down, and throughout the meal our waiter was amazingly fast and attentive - some of the best service I've ever had! 

We had:

Steamed meat buns (has some Chinese name on the menu that I have forgotten): Very good, and delivered to our table piping hot!
Chicken and corn soup: slightly more peppery than I typically find this dish, but pleasantly so.
Honey walnut prawns:  These were amazing.  I highly recommend them.
String bean chicken:  This was the only thing we ordered that wasn't featured in a picture on the menu, and it stood out from the rest of what we had gotten as notably worse.  It was pretty generic mediocre Chinese fare.  From our experience, I'd recommend sticking with the pictured items!
author: David B.

description: First time to this place and we loved it!  My daughter looked it up on Yelp to find out that it was good before going there.  I don't usually like Sweet & Sour soup, but theirs was very good and spicy :)  All the food was very good, service was good and everything was nice and clean.  About the only drawback was that they only have canned sodas instead of out of a soda machine.
author: Tina B.

description:
UPDATE: 11/11/06  Came here for a rare dinner and though it does cost a bit versus the lunch price, well worth it because you can get way better stuff.  We had for 3, Potstickers, Moo Shoo Pork, Spicy Garlic Chicken (best item ever), Curry Beef, and Hot and Sour Soup.  Worked out to about $18 each all-in, but it was a lot of food and excellent.  Upgrading to Five Star.

An old standby, this place is the most well-known amongst the businessperson set as an affordable and nice atmosphere Chinese place. Waiters are personable and joke a lot with the regulars. The hot and sour soup is the best I've ever had here. The main dishes are a little skimpy on meat, though, so I don't normally go here too much any more, but it still is very good. It's a good safe place for a group outing. Also, their potstickers are among the best. Also their dinner items are fabulous, but too costly for lunch. Shrimp fried rice was tasty and had good amount of shrimp. They also have the best fortune cookies here, with a hint of vanilla.
author: Marc S.

description:
Whilst taking a leisurely Sunday walk through the City I ended up here. 

The decor is a bit garish but the food is pretty good.

The honey walnut prawns were the most memorable dish I had there.
author: Miriam W.

description:
I like this place. A lot.

It's a homestyle Chinese restaurant with pleasant, friendly service (yes, they do exist) and a vast array of delicious comfort food.

I threatened to order the sizzling eel platter for my group of ladies, but decided against it because they know the menu much better than I do and they did an amazing job ordering the faves.

Orange peel beef
Crispy chicken
Mixed veg
Spring rolls
Mandarin spareribs
Steamed rice

I love dining with the girls, and hope next time I get to treat.
author: May T.

description: Good food & service. . We especially liked the green beans with minced pork (ordered mild for the kids), crispy chicken and eggplant with prawns and chicken. The tofu with beef was good, but heavy on the garlic.  Would definitely come back.
author: Jane T.

description: Great chinese food. Fresh and doesnt leave you feeling bloated and sluggish. Good prices and quick service. Missing 1 star for lack of customer service - it's not a warm and fuzzy wait staff kind of place. That said, it's well worth it for the amazing food.
author: Jen A.

description:
The place was clean, everyone was very friendly, the food was great! I can't complain. 

It was my first time being in Chinatown in San Francisco, and I didn't know where to eat, but I'm glad I came on here to check.
author: Cindy G.

description: Been here many times and going again tonight. Great food. If you want spicy just ask. Many wonderful dishes. Surprise yourself with veggie dishes. Enjoy
author: Alistair D.

description: Hot and sour soup had a very earthy pepper flavor- good stuff!  The potstickers were great- perfect crispy side and amazing taste.  Kung pao chicken had a great kick that was tamed by the rice. Good service and great food- no complaints!
author: Katee V.

description: We came in with a family of 6 and had an excellent meal for lunch. Orange Peel Chicken and Beef & Broccoli along with some succulent bread.
