We couldn't have been more pleased with the service, food, and overall experience. We feel like we had an authentic Chinese food experience in Chinatown, which is what we were looking for. Highly recommended!
author: Alex M.

description: A decent Chinese spot. I had the potstickers (very good) and the green beans/pork which was also very good. There were not a lot of people here
author: Randy H.

description: Lousy service and average food. Avoid this place and seek better options.
author: Shane F.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in Chinatown. The food is excellent. On a recent visit, we ordered kung pao chicken, veggie potstickers, hot and sour soup, and mu shu chicken. Everything came when it was supposed to, and each dish was delicious and had a distinct flavor. Be warned: the lunch specials are not as good as ordering from the a la carte menu.
author: Michael B.

description: Salt and pepper fish, need i say more? Do yourself a favor and add this place to your must visit restaurants and order the Salt and Pepper Fish and you won't be dissapointed. It's the perfect balance of spice and salt, mmmm. I get a smile on my face just thinking about it.
author: Dennis L.

description: Sizzling rice soup and dim sum. A-Mazin!!!! Been here twice, for dine in and take out. Fantastic Chinese food!!!
author: Cinnatea L.

description: Great meal. We had the prawns with Chinese broccoli and assorted vegetables with garlic sauce. Both items are delicious, highly recommend. Lots of prawns and perfectly cooked veggies. Not to be missed if you want to eat Chinese in Chinatown.
author: Leslie S.

description: It's a difficult task to ignore every restaurant while you're walking thorough Chinatown hungry, but the previous Yelp reviews helped guide me. Orange chicken was delicious, best I've ever had, hands down. The fried rice didn't look like it would taste as wonderful as it does. We had the chicken fried rice and I highly recommend it. Mongolian beef was not as good as expected. Can't stop thinking about how awesome the hot and sour soup is! Ignore your urges to stop early, keep walking to Hunan Home.
author: Abby C.

description:
This place is my all time favorite! One of first places I had chinese food in, after moving to US.
I love their Hot n Sour soup, hunan chicken, wontons in chilli oil (to die for!).
author: Parminder Nayyar C.

description: The food was delicious, and the service was excellent. They were friendly, and very helpful with making decisions and recommendations. I had the pot stickers and chicken fried rice, and both were very good. The portions are good for the price paid.
author: Jake R.

description: Definitely a great place for dinner. The wontons in hot sauce were amazing. We ordered the mushu chicken and chicken in garlic sauce both were delicious. The service was quick very attentive. All together a great night and experience
author: Sarah W.

description:
The hotel concierge turned me onto this place (as well as another place).
Good place - good food and the waitstaff were very attentive, pleasant and even hammed it up for the kids. 

Enjoyed the standards - sizzling rice soup, egg rolls, chow mein, orange chicken, mongolian beef. As good as I would expect it to be and I'd have no problem returning.
author: Tony R.

description: Awesome food great service.   Took the family here - sizzling beef Hunan style amazing!  Kung Pao shrimp - very spicy, pot stickers were great, and wonton and sizzling rice soup delicious.   Best part - locals and ethnics eating here as well as fellow yelpers.   Definitely recommend
author: Leif L.

description: Stopped here based on the reviews via Yelp.  Very good Chinese food, wouldn't say it's authentic Chinese food, but very good nonetheless.  Hot and sour soup was delicious.   I recommend this place to anyone in the area.
author: Erik C.

description: Best Chinese food I've had! Flavors are so fresh. Best sweet and sour soup ever. Try the snow pea leaves. Awesome!!! Potstickers, too. Service was great and very funny.  Must come here.
author: Janice D.

description:
I love Hunan Homes - both here and on the Peninsula. Their wonton soup is amazing, plenty of wontons to go around. The dish I always order without fail though is the mongolian beef. This is my go to dish at just about any chinese restaurant, and needless to say I was not disappointed.

Very reasonably priced, definitely doesn't break the bank for college students.
author: Drew M.

description: Good food, good service and good price. It was pretty popular when we went and there was about a 20 min wait
author: Will M.

description: The vegetable delight was very enjoyable.   Also quite enjoyed the hot and sour soup.   Would definately visit again.   Fast service on a friday at 9
author: Sameer B.

description: The food was amazing - the best Chinese food I ever had. The service is good, but don't look forward to small talk or a friendly smile, but the food far makes up for that. My family and I loved it
author: Mike A.

description: We had a great dinner here during spring break - the kids and adults loved it!
author: Moe C.

description:
Best time to go is during lunch. You get the special (spicy hunan chicken) and it is soo good! You also get hot and sour soup. The spicy hunan chicken with rice is super good. It has a lot of flavor and is just the right amount of spiciness. 

The decor is okay. It seems kind of rundown but I believe that the rest of Chinatown is too. The waiters are very quick so they have a very fast turnover ratio. Expect to wait if its the peak time for lunch because it seems to be a very popular lunch spot for the businessmen and women.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
A new discovery thanks on my recent swing west...thanks Yelp!

One thing that is great about San Francisco Chinatown spots is that the staff's a generally more friendly than New York Chinatown. I stopped by just before closing midweek and felt very at home if you will.

Had just the salt and pepper shrimp. Actually not a bad dish to judge a place in my opinion cause deepfrying is a bit of an art. My ship had head and shell on which I like and where not over fried, had a very lite batter, and a striking but not overwhelming salt and pepper treatment. There is a touch of spice in it is fried with slices of peppers, but that heat doesn't transfer very far and you can ignore them if you like things mild.

Also they serve a solid rice...not as good as a good Korean spot but always a good sign when they don't skimp here.

Happy to find a Hunan Home in SF!
author: Erik F.

description: In the heart of Chinatown. Great food and a friendly host!  Probably the best chinese I have ever had.  Our group of eight all agreed!
author: William Z.

description: Great food. Great service. Great price. Yummy pot stickers!!
author: Steffanie D.

description: the food is good here but the customer service by the owner is horrible...she has a bad attitude and doesn't seem she wants you to eat there...it's a shame!
author: Meisam M.

description: I was pleasantly surprised by the great service. Our food was Deeeeelicious and I was really happy that our server took the time to show us how to eat some of our food. The atmosphere was fun and clean. Really really enjoyed our experience. Highly recommend.
author: Melissa E.

description:
I have been  in search of an  illusive authentic Hunan style cuisine in northern California.  And just like my previous attempts, this was a flop.  Doubly disappointing because I went to a very friendly Wok Shop just few blocks away from Hunan Homes and asked for 'the best hunan restaurant in SF'.   The friendly lady at the Wok Shop suggested Hunan Homes.

Well, it was not to be.  I ordered Kung Pao Chicken.  I asked for very spicy.  It was extremely salty, unbelievably SOUR (NO, IT IS NOT HUNAN STYLE).  

Thanks to all the people who rated this place very low because a place like this should not get any star above zero.  I should have read the review of Eileen T.
author: Abid K.

description: The food was delicious! Chicken Orange Peel, Kung Pao Beef, Hunan Prawns, and Lemon Chicken! The egg rolls and egg drop soup was good, too! It was a short wait for out table. Our server was not so friendly or patient with us but the second server was great! Highly recommend.
author: Greta W.

description:
It's bigger than you think! Located in the heart of chinatown, this place was quite delicious.

And to top it off, it was one of the cheapest meal we had during our trip.

Ordered the Spicy salt squid, wonton soup, string beans with beef, eggplant with spicy garlic sauce and seafood chow mein.

The wonton soup was ok, the seafood chow mein needed more seafood and sauce. The string beans was really good, so was the spicy salt squid.  The eggplant with spicy garlic sauce is highly recommended.

Overall a standout within SF chinatown.
author: Thomas L.

description: Holy moly! Everything was incredible, second time here, best Chinese food EVER!
author: james w.

description:
In Chinatown, hungry.  So here we go Yelp. 

They have a pretty extensive menu. There were two of us and we started with the veggie egg rolls and hot and sour soup. Both are very simple and hard to mess up. 

We ordered chicken in garlic sauce and kung pao beef for our entrees. They were both very good. The meat was prepared well, and we were particularly intrigued by the chicken dish. There was no breading on the chicken, (which normally I don't like because it's so fattening) and it was all white meat. Usually you can really tell what your eating when you order meat at a Chinese restaurant, but we were definitely eating chicken!

The restaurant is also very clean which I have had a difficult time finding a clean Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. 

All around, it was a good experience and I would return.
author: Aubrey Y.

description: I had the bean curd szechuan on a late evening.  It was well prepared and of medium heat.  I need to return to really get a good feel for this restaurant.  It was filled and had a relatively large back room.  This is a more traditional Chinatown restaurant than what you will find at R&G and House of Nanking.
author: Thomas W.

description:
Good solid food, but nothing blew my mind.  We did only try two menu items, though.  I'll describe them here.

Prawns in walnut sauce were not at all what I expected, but very tasty.  The walnuts were sweet with some sort of honey glaze.  I couldn't really put my finger on what the sauce was made of, but it kind of reminded me of a mayo-based sauce you might get with tempura shrimp.  The prawns were very fresh and fried really lightly, which was a good complement to the sauce.  They were served atop shredded lettuce, which was also a nice complement to the dish.  I added chili oil and a little soy, which I thought made it even better.

Black mushrooms with delicate greens was really black mushrooms with bok choy.  I love both of these ingredients, but I have had this dish done better.  In fact, I've made this dish better myself at home.  There was very little sauce, but lots of garlic.  It was definitely good, but nothing memorable I'll be trying to replicate at home.  

All of the staff were extremely friendly.  And they bring orange slices for dessert, which always makes me happy.  I'd give an extra .5 if I could just for that.
author: Melinda I.

description:
Came here with a huge group as part of a conference event.  I was hoping for some tasty Asian food and thought this place would satisfy my cravings.

A family style pre-fixe meal was chosen for us, so we got to sample about 8-10 different dishes.  

To the naked eye, the food would have been considered "good" but if you're looking for authentic Chinese food, this is not the place for that.  I found a lot of it to be your typical Chinese fast food fare.  Service was slow at first but picked up quickly, so fast that at one point we had about 4-5 plates on the table.  Eh.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
I went to this restaurant for lunch today, as most people I read the review and curious to go there. The place was full, waiting for about 15 minutes and got the food in about 25 minutes. If you really hungry forget this place. I was wondering the family that come long after us got the food first maybe because they speak same language.
The food was ok. I have taste better Chinese food in southern CA. 
Order sizzling rice soup, come warn and far from sizzling big disappointment.
The fried potsticker veggies is good. I recommend that.
The orange beef to sweet. Beef and broccoli was ok but not great. The Hunan prawns us a bit spicy for us. The snow peas leaves was great, I would recommend that.
Overall this place is just ok not great.
author: Risa H.

description: Possibly the best kung pao chicken I have ever had.  Went for lunch - reasonably priced and great food.  Would definitely return.
author: Jim S.

description: Been dining here since they opened.  EVERYTHING is fresh and delicious.  Don't miss the Succulent Bread.  It is indescribably delicious!
author: Maggie L.

description: Very bad attitude and not impressive food. My conclusion: there are so many excellent restaurants nearby why pay for below-average service???
author: Jay F.

description:
Best Chinese food in Chinatown.

I WISH we could get a comparable chinese meal in Chicago at their quality and prices. The Xao Long Bao is simply to die for - don't miss out!
author: Jeremy O.

description: My husband and I ordered way too much, but we just couldn't decide on what we wanted to order. I'm so glad that we did as we got to try a little bit of everything. It definitely did not disappoint. The food was really good and our server was funny and engaging. We will definitely be back.
author: Tara B.

description: After reading the reviews, I was anticipating some amaaaazing Chinese food from this place... But alas, this restaurant is just average in my opinion. I especially wanted Mongolian beef, and multiple yelp reviews said this place has the best. However, the meat was thick and soft instead of thin and crispy, the sauce was thin and watery, and it wasn't very spicy despite visible chilis... Overall a disappointment. The chow mien was better, but I'd rather find a one-stop-shop where I like ALL of the menu items, not just some.
author: Rachel S.

description:
SF Chinatown is a big place with lots of restaurants and unfriendly people. It was great to find a place where the owner knows all of his customers, the servers were extremely friendly and accommodating, and the food tasted as good as it looks.

We had our rehearsal dinner here. It was sixty people, we had the room downstairs, James (the owner) helped us choose a menu based on our favorite items and made "milder" modifications for our older guests (at a very reasonable price), and we had EXCELLENT service throughout the night.

Everyone commented how great the food was - the orange chicken was the favorite.  They also have this great whole fish (which James included in our price) with soy and tofu and veggies that looks gorgeous on the table and tastes even better.

The other great advantage of this restaurant is they validate parking at the Portsmouth Garage and the HIlton on Kearney.

Mmmm, orange chicken!
author: Christine O.

description: Just ate at this resto and service sucks! We were 12 in the group and as we were ordering waiter didn't even inform us of entree size serving.  We were still having our meal and our waiter quickly handed our check half way through our meal. We were rushed and the place wasn't even packed. Bad service, average food quality not our typical Chinese resto.
author: Jojo H.

description: We were visiting from Chicago, we were thinking" when in Rome". We yelped looking for a good Chinese restaurant and stumbled across this one.  Boy were we happy we did,  everything we ordered here was OUTSTANDING!!!! I wish we could of ate here for every meal. To start we ordered sizzling soup, my sons were fighting to see who was going to lick the bowl LOL. I fell in love with there pot stickers, they were tender and there ginger sauce was something that should be sold in a jar so everyone can partake in something that taste this good. Next came the main course, I can't go into as much detail as I would like,  because there is to much good stuff to put into detail. The only thing I can say is try the sizzling beef, your taste buds will think you for it. My kids were asking the whole trip to go back more orange chicken(and to see the puffer fish that was smiling at them). Another thing that I liked was the owner went to every table to see if you needed anything and ask how the food was. It was nice to know that he care about his guest. All in all I would recommend this restaurant to anyone in the area looking for some good food and a wonderful atmosphere.
author: Daniel S.

description: Best Chinese food in San Francisco, plus the service and staff are wonderful. My fave dish is the smoked ham.
author: Lorraine F.

description: Loved the food. Great price and wide selection.
author: Maria B.

description: Yum!!!!  Friendly service, our waiter was a comedian. We ordered the ginger and spicy salt crab...delicious!  Best jellyfish salad, I loved their sauce. We also ordered soup dumplings, pan fried noodles, seafood with fish tripe soup, won ton soup, sizzling beef and pea leaves. Definitely returning on my next San Fran trip. It's definitely a place to go with a big group so you can order lots of dishes to try.
author: Coriander L.

description: Very extensive menu!  We started with Egg Drop Soup, which was very tasty, and then went on to the combination chow mein and honey almond shrimp.  the shrimp stood out - great size and covered in a yummy sauce.  They were busy as it was a holiday weekend, but you can put your name in and then go for a quick drink anywhere nearby.  The older lady at the counter is busy, but has a great sense of humor.  Excellent Chinatown experience.
author: Kristen A.

description: Went to Chinatown for lunch - the restaurant I had been to before was gone - so good old yelp helped us find this place and the reviews were great and true! Delicious food, fast service.  Staff were nice but could do with a few more smiles - I say you should all give here a try !
author: Suzanne H.

description: Delicious! One of my favorite Chinese restaurants in the city!
author: Shell I.

description:
THANK YOU YELP!!

Hunan Home's (yes, that's how it's spelled) is the shit!

On the recommendation of all the glowing review here, we walked over here one night on a recent trip to SF and LOVED IT.

Had the pot stickers, sweet and sour pork, crispy fried squid, and the soup. Sooo good.

You can't find Chinese food this good in LA.
author: mike l.

description: We waited 30 minutes for the check, which is just too long. Enough to ruin an experience.
author: Claire W.

description:
The best! 

I've been here 3 times in the past month or two, and have had an amazing experience every time. It's one of the more Americanized Chinese places in Chinatown, but the food is excellent and the service rivals the meal. 

The other day we shared the Hot and Spicy soup, Orange Peel Chicken (THE BEST!), the combination Lo Mein, and the Spareribs with Spicy Salt. This fed a girl who usually eats like a bird and a guy who could eat everything yet doesn't gain a pound. Yes, we took home about a half meal's worth too, which fed him the next evening for dinner (bummer, I wanted it). A couple of little bonuses... they bring tea to the table upon arrival, and the prices are also hard to beat. It's delicious!
author: Kristin F.

description: Wow. What a great dinner! How things change if you bypass the trendy House of Nanking just down the street who's food this place has beat by a mile. Fast friendly service is highlighted by the house dumpling or pot sticker, which is made of very fresh ingredients to order...Juicy inside and not greasy. Definitely order this!!!!  The Kung Pao Chicken goes well with a cold Tsing Tao! Definitely worth coming back and the price was oh so low for San Francisco
author: Nors D.

description:
On a cold day we knew we wanted Chinese food, particularly soup but were overwhelmed with the plethora of choices in China Town. Thanks to Yelp, we stumbled upon Hunan Homes. 

The hot & sour soup is hands down the best in the bay. And the sauce used in the spiced bean curd was incredibly tasty. While chatting with the hostess on our way out, she told us that the walnut prawns dish is the most popular so we will definitely be making a trip back to here to try it!
author: Komal P.

description: Amazing food! Didn't have left overs to take home. Would for sure come back and eat here again!
author: Mykul C.

description:
Everything is great. Food, service and ambiance.
We ate the hot and sour soup,  string beans pot stickers, and kung pao chicken were all wonderful!
author: Linda L.

description:
All this time living in the city and we never actually have eaten Chinese food in Chinatown until coming to Hunan Homes! We picked this place cuz it had decent reviews, seemed causal, had decent prices and could accommodate a group of 7 on a Sunday after noon. 

The staff was really friendly and service was good. The food wasn't spectacular. But it not bad Chinese food. The only thing I would not recommend is the wonton soup - too watery. 
The restaurant was a family friendly place, meaning my younger brother with Autism seemingly went unnoticed when he had his moments of "acting out" at the table. Also the table next to us had a couple toddlers roaming the restaurant and it did not bother anyone.
author: T K.

description:
For a place with 200+ reviews with a solid four-star average, it had to be good.

Thank you, Yelp!

The xiao long bao was a hit, and even though I don't want to admit it, it was the best that I have had in a long while. We also ordered yang chow fried rice as well, but it wasn't too flavorful, and I had to add chili to bring it back to life.

It's pretty easy to find, as well, so if you're in the area, it's worth the trip inside.
author: Vanessa A.

description: Staying right next to Chinatown we had a wealth of restaurants to pick from and based on other's reviews we went to Hunan Home's and were not disappointed.  We worried we wouldn't get in because it was already 6:30p.m. on a Friday, but we were easily seated within about 10 minutes.  We tried the sizzling rice soup which was a nice balance of meat, vegetables and rice.  I had the Mongolian ribs while my hubby had the Hunan beef.  Both dishes left us wanting more even though we'd had the soup and had practically licked our fingers following the Xiau Long Bao served with a soy/sliced ginger (?) sauce.  We washed it down with the lightly flavored tea which is on the table when you sit down and a bottle of cold sake.  Judging by the line of people waiting outside when we left, we made it just in time and would definitely come back here!!
author: Alora M.

description: Inexpensive, relatively quick, and good attention to detail.  Service was a little slow, but this was because the restaurant gets very crowded at peak meal times.  If you ask the locals they will recommend this place for it's hot n sour soup and it's potstickers.  I was not enamored with either, but my main course (Orange Peel Chicken) was hot and delicious.  Overall, a good place to try in Chinatown.
author: Hana J.

description: Hands down the best Americanized Chinese food my MSG-loving butt has had the pleasure of enjoying.  The Orange Peel Chicken is to die for.  The Sweet and sour soup is a great starter with dumplings that should end your culinary night.  Until they bring the Hunan String Beans and pork.  Washed down with a Tsing Tsao this was by far my City highlight for many years to come.   Highly recommended!!
author: David M.

description:
I've only been here twice, and both times we ordered pretty much the same thing (because it was soooo good the first time!)

Potstickers - YUM! and I don't even like potstickers...
Dry cooked string beans - YUM!
Mongolian Beef - Best I've had in the city
Veggie Fried Rice - YUM!

Definitely going back
author: Nancy O.

description: Fantastic food! Exceptional service! Try the sizzling rice soup & you won't be disappointed!!
author: Jessica M.

description:
If I didn't have a gift certificate to come here, I would never have noticed this place. Hunan's doesn't seem anything out of the ordinary and out of the thousands of Chinese restaurants in the city (hell, on this street) nothing really stands out. 
But once inside, we were seated promptly, food was good (bit on the salty side, but what chinese food isn't?), and service was polite and courteous. 
Why dine here? Why not!
author: Christine Y.

description:
Great food at fair prices. The hostess is very accommodating and most of the staff is very friendly. Best seats are the ones before the stairs because once you get closer to the kitchen or at the lower level the place tends to be a little too warm.
It is also very cool that they can spice up/down some of the dishes on the menu as you would like.
author: Renato M.

description: Incredible!  Looks like nothing but looks can be deceiving!   Kids (14 & 11) loved it and want to go back the next night.  4 of us ate well and with tip was under $60.  Food was fresh and hot.  String beans and chicken and chicken w/orange peel are a must.  Will definitely go back.
author: G K.

description:
Um YUM! Didn't know what to expect coming to Chinatown to eat. I live in the Richmond district and never have to leave my hood for a good meal. My friend had her going away dinner there. Everything she ordered was immaculate:

-Hot and sour soup. Wow, not usually a fan of this but damn, it was good!! Nice and spicy, great kick.
-Eggflower soup. Also really delicious and well made. Homey. Non-spicy.
-Fried pot stickers. SO GOOD!! So juicy! Accompanying sauce, somewhat spicy, was a perfect complement!
-Spicy chicken. Really tender and flavorful chicken. YUM YUM! When our table ran our of this, we hijacked the 2nd table's plate of this and everyone ate a ton of this!
-Sizzling mongolian beef. Really good. Lots of good sauce.

We must have had way more dishes but I can't remember everything we ate. :(

The quality of the food is amazing like that of a wedding. Everything was delicious! Come here if you want good hunan cuisine.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
The hot and sour soup is not as spectacular as everyone says it is. Maybe I just haven't tried bad hot and sour soup, but their hot and sour soup does taste like how the soup should taste. But their spicy hunan chicken and their orange peel chicken were very delicious! 

The best part was that the amount of food they give you, the price is very reasonable, during lunch time. My friend and I each got one dish and we were able to split it, family style and each dish came out to be about $8! 

Also a very nice walk through chinatown to get to the restaurant so you're able to enjoy the area.
author: Simon L.

description:
I live in the city so this is one of my regular Chinese food haunts, especially after coming back into the city from a trip out of town, I love ordering in advance and stopping by to pick up the food.  Ling Ling (the manager?) knows me by face (and my orders).

They have great veggie choices.

By far they have the best (imho) veggie potstickers anywhere.  They are made fresh and you can tell when you bite into it.  It seriously reminds me of my childhood when my mom use to make them.  I seldom ever get that nostalgic feeling for food from a Chinese restaurant.  I would highly recommend the veggie potstickers.

My other usual entree is the pea shoots (dou mieu), which most restaurants I find seldom offer that.  Super awesome and super tasty.

I also highly recommend the crispy chicken dish which comes with a yummy sauce.... yum!

Only four stars since they don't do delivery.  You have to eat in or pick up your order.
author: Ann C.

description: Come here everytome we are in SF. Love their walnut shrimp.
author: Brian E.

description: Good food and decent service. I was pretty happy with everything.
author: Kimmie C.

description: So many choices in Chinatown but finally decided to try HHR. Did not regret it. Got in early Sunday afternoon and started with Mu shu pork. Yum. Orange peel chicken. Yum, yum,yum!
author: Ann R.

description:
I have been using Yelp for years, but I never felt the need to make a Yelp account until now. This restaurant is by far one of the worst Chinese restaurants I went to in San Francisco. Its so bad it made me create a Yelp account to warn others. 

The warning:
This restaurant made my girlfriend and I sick. Literally sick to our stomachs. 

Be vary of the reviews and ratings of this restaurant. I thought it was a good restaurant after reading the reviews too, but ultimately that wasn't the case when we got sick from their food.

The service:
The service is also incompetent and lacking. My girlfriend and I were ignored when we asked for the bill the first time. When we finally got the bill, we didn't get our change back. We had to ask them to give us our change back.

Please choose another restaurant when dining in Chinatown. There are so many better options than this restaurant. Options that has better service and food that does not make you sick.
author: Jason M.

description:
Good solid Chinese restaurant.

I went here with my Chinese friend who will be moving out of San Francisco. We went to R&G Lounge but it was packed and we were starving. Decided to go here for our last supper.

The place was nothing worth mentioning but the food was great. I love the string beans and several other food that she ordered for me. The xiao long bao, not so much (I had better) but this restaurant, by all mean, was not bad at all.

looking for good schezuan food? This is the place
author: Cliff T.

description: Read good things abt the restaurant. Nothing special. Pretty standard Chinese restaurant
author: Atanu R.

description: Wonton Soup. Yes, it's a simple dish, but they have one of the best I've ever had. In general this place is really good and the service was good. Both dishes we order (Hunan Beef and combo Kung Pao) were excellent. Definitely a fortunate selection during my trip to San Francisco.
author: Allison C.

description: Found this yummy chinese restaurant all thanks to my fellow yelpers!  Very quick service and they were very attentive to refilling drinks taking dishes etc... I wish I lived in the area so I can go back more:(   Until next time SF....
author: Nancy M.

description: It was the best Chinese food our group has had. The orange peel chicken was very very tasty.  The spicy pork was good as well. So good we went twice in three days. Service was prompt. We can't wait to go back. Also egg rolls are a must.
author: Mark M.

description:
I had thought that I was a chow mein hater. 

The only chow mein I've eaten were my mom's (sorry mom, it's your one singular culinary failure), at Panda Express, or Mr. Chow's. Blechh

But now I know! I'm not a chow mein hater, only a hater of bad chow mein. 
Hunan Homes has the greatest chow mein I've ever eaten. My friend actually ordered the chow mein with shredded pork and I picked some off her plate out of habit (I sample everything on the table). The result:  chow mein goodness inciting my epiphany which in turn, externally manifested as a moment of stunned silence proceeded by me devouring my friend's food and ordering another to go.

Hmmmm... chow mein. In conlusion, order any of the chow mein dishes.
author: B D.

description:
I took my brother's to Hunan Home on 11/12/10 because they both love Chinese food and wanted to see Chinatown. My brother Glenn who is now 38 had his first Chinese food experience at Hunans Home when he was 16 years old and he has been hooked ever since so it was good to return.

We arrived during the lunch crowd but had a table within 10-15minutes and was seated at the rear dining room. The service was quick but we did not feel rushed. I will say my brother Chris made a comment about the restaurant looking too "Americanized" meaning he wanted to eat at a place that had BBQ ducks and pork in the window but after our meal he changed his tune and agreed the food was pretty good. All three of us left happy and the bill was affordable especially if you order from the lunch menu. All three of us liked the battered chicken in orange sauce!

Thanks Hunan Home for a great lunch.
author: David P.

description:
this is only for the kung pao chicken, 2.5 stars.  i like my kung pao on the pure side...chicken, chilis, bit of green onion, peanuts.  most places go overboard with bamboo, bell pepper, celery (ouch).  other yelpers warned me about the bamboo so i had that taken out. 

it was edible but problems...too saucy and way too much garlic.  the garlic in particular killed the smoky flavor that the chillis are supposed to provide.  They also add bell pepper...why?

still working to find the best classic kung pao...
author: Raj D.

description:
This place is bomb. I've been going here ever since I was a little kid with my family, so I thought it would be appropriate to write a review. I'm not usually into spicy food but the spicy food here is amazing. Everything from the spicy bean curds to the amazing hot and sour soup. And the latter was just an understatement! It's no wonder why this place was voted by Zagat as the best Chinese restaurant in San Francisco. I will go here all the time if it isn't so far away from my house.

The owner and the waiters are all very nice and willing to help. I will definitely suggest coming here if you ever want to wet your taste with mouth-watering Hunan food.
author: William C.

description: This used to be a favorite of my husband and I but we were very disappointed today.  Our food was only a B- for quality.  We ordered spare ribs as an appetizer and they were ok, the moo Shue pork was a bit dry, the Mongolian beef was greasy and not especially tasty and the prawns with lobster sauce were again, just ok.  Service was good.  The walk to the bathroom was scary and didn't look very clean but the bathroom was clean.   Won't go there again!
author: Marcia K.

description:
Awesome... just awesome...

One late night the GF and I craved for Chinese food. It just so happened that we had a coupon for this restaurant, so we trekked out to the heart of San Francisco's Chinatown to get our grub on.

Parking: We went late night, like an hour before closing, so parking was abundant on the street. Really not bad. There is also a night life despite all the closed shops, gates, and shutters littering the block protecting the shops.

Cleanliness: Very good. When you think Chinatown restaurant, you get the image of a small cramped place that's sorta dirty and crumby... this place was the opposite. It looked clean, felt clean, and was very spacious. Not cramped at all. Overall it was great. Dishes and utensils.
 
Service: Awesome. Everyone was attentive and nice. Plenty of service at tables and constant attention that wasn't too intrusive. Loved it.

Food: We ordered the chicken hot and sour soup, tofu, and chicken with blackbean curd. All was GREAT! Very filling, portion was big, and wasn't filled with MSG... no crash after. LOL! It was very good. The hot and sour soup was great for a cold night. Got our nose's running and that's always a good sign. It wasn't too spicy at all, but just enough to satisfy the spicy soup craving. The tofu was cut thick, perfect. The provided a sauce with green onion in it that complimented it very well. The chicken and black bean curd was very good as well. Very tasty, not overwhelming on the pallet, and was a perfect marriage with a side of rice. 

Overall, I'd DEFINITELY come back. A great diamond in the rough among some of the dank and dark restaurants within the heart of Chinatown. Come and experience it yourself and you'll see.
author: Jay V.

description: Each time I go to this great town I have to stop here for my chinese food fix,the service is quick,the food is delicious and a short walk from the Hilton .
author: Patrick Z.

description: This place has been my family's favorite Chinese restaurant in San Francisco for 10 years or more.  The Moo Shu pork and honeyed walnut prawns are my favorites.  My daughter loves the fried rice.   Very family friendly!
author: Aerin L.

description: Very authentic Chinese food. Cleaned all of my three dishes there. Highly recommend. The pot sticker is the best one I had in San Francisco.
author: Justin T.

description:
Yelp helped me find this place when I was visiting San Francisco last week. It was SO good! The menu was totally overwhelming - so many items to choose from, but we finally settled on mu shu, ma po tofu, sizzling prawns and string beans with garlic. The mapo was my favorite, and it was REALLY spicy. 

The waiter was very friendly and joked around with us, and the prices were reasonable considering the portions. Can't wait to go back next time I'm in San Francisco!
author: Sarah N.

description:
Great food, excellent service - I highly recommend this restaurant. Sizzling rice soup was to die for. Everything we ordered was great and very tasty.

Reservations are recommended as the place was packed and we had to wait about an hour or so, but we did not mind.
author: Darek B.

description: I really like their hot and sour soup. It's really tasty without being overly salty. I appreciate that they have a lunch menu that includes the hot and sour soup, rice, and fruit. Overall, a pretty good place to eat at with affordable prices.
author: Anne K.

description:
Great hot and sour soup. Solid chicken with Chinese broccoli . Delicious spicy chicken and green beans. This has to be my favorite chinsese food place in the city. If you go with one other person and each order your own soup, the waiter will look at you like you have three heads for 5 seconds and then explain that one soup feeds two people. They never get that I like one soup and my girlfriend likes another and we just take the leftovers home and eat them tomorrow. We always laugh about it.

I like it even more now that I work with the owner's nephews and I will get to sample their secret items... :)
author: Chris K.

description:
Come on people, 4 stars just because it's clean and doesn't make you sick? 

"Cheerful decor"??? More like super cheeseball decor. It has baby pink tablecloths, cheesy sparkling chandeliers, and emerald-green Chinese roof tiles.

Average Chinese restaurant food. Nothing special about it. 

Service is fast with zero frivolity (no "hello"s, "thank you"s, etc.).
author: Marina N.

description: Husband and I were trying to find an amazing Chinese restaurant while visiting San Francisco. We had recommendations for another place but on Yelp only had a health score of 64 out of 100. Found this place that had  a 94 out of 100. We are so glad we followed our instinct!  We had the pot stickers- amazing!Hot & Sour Soup- delish! Mongolian Beef - a little spicy but amazing! Orange Chicken- fantastic!  Great service by James! ! Definitely coming back when we visit again!
author: elisa c.

description: I really like this place.  Everything we ordered was yummy.  The restaurant was spacious, which was a nice surprise, considering this is in the heart of Chinatown.  It's clean, but very well-worn, which gives it a cozy feel (not sure how they pulled that off).  Service was great: waiters are fast and efficient.  They are helpful if you ask for suggestions, but not overbearing.  The host was very friendly, but again, not overbearing.  They don't get 5 stars only because the food is not "to die for," but trust me, I stuffed myself.  I will definitely go here again, and I recommend it without hesitation.
author: JJ M.

description: Living near Chinatown has given me the chance to sample many Chinese restaurants, and Hunan Homes is still my favorite for taking friends and out of town guests for a quality Chinese meal.  From the outside, it may not stand out from the other choices on the block, but it delivers where it counts. While I've never had a bad dish, the sizzling beef and the honey/walnut prawns are my top picks.  I've scoured Chinatown for a worthy competitor to the prawns and have yet to find one.
author: Todd G.

description: Loved it - outstanding food, fast service, fine environment with kids (5 & 7). Had and loved: Spicy Wontons, egg rolls, orange peel chicken, garlic chicken, mongolian beef, hot and sour soup (awesome).
author: James P.

description: We order Mushu Veggie, Sweet and Sour Chiken, and Asparagus Prawns in Black Bean sauce. All very good with light but covering sauces. They do charge rice separately from the main meal though. Still good and would eat here again.
author: Caroline T.

description:
Went here for lunch and loved it!

Great traditional Chinese cooking. A step up from normal take-out. Good restaurant in the heart of Chinatown.

Would recommend the cashew prawns and the house special fried noodles!!

Average prices and average wait staff. Above average food
author: Ryan L.

description:
DAMN U FAILED ME YELP!! 

Don't get me wrong, the food here is edible.  However IT IS NOT HUNAN FOOD.  I REPEAT, THIS PLACE IS NOT HUNAN FOOD!!  They should change their sign so that it would not be so misleading..

Next time I'm gona read the reviews more carefully before choosing the restaurant.
author: Roy W.

description: This place is great if you are in the mood for Americanized Chinese fast-food. The dishes are glistening with grease & loaded with whole garlic cloves and red chili peppers. The Hunan beef was no better than Panda Express beef, and the Hunan smoked pork had of succulent salty slices of ham. The seafood soup was mediocre and the snow pea leaves were too garlicky. The restaurant is much more spacious than most places you will find in Chinatown. Two stars for the service and cleanliness.
author: Tina C.

description: The Chinese restaurant at the strip mall by my house in Minnesota was better than this place. If I could do it all over again, I'd go to a place in Chinatown that has zero English on the menus and maybe I'd get something more authentic. The egg rolls were good, however, and beer was cold:)
author: Brian O.

description:
We bought a restaurant.com $25 off coupon, so we decided to try it out.  Dinner on Friday night for the 2 of us was perfect!  We had wine, 2 appetizers and 2 entrees, and our bill came to under $40, so after the coupon and tax/tip, it was under $20 out the door.  
And the food was really good!  We had barbeque pork, dumplings, moo shoo, and chow mein.  Not as good as our favorite chinese place in Orange County, but I will definitely go back!
author: Autumn C.

description:
My girlfriend and I went here 2 days before Christmas. As I am sure you would expect, there was a really long line. But, it was mostly families so it made sense. Since it was just the two of us, they were able to seat us right away. When we walked through the main dining area up front, all the tables were full. They took us to the second dining room downstairs, which almost made us feel special, like we were part of an elite club of people. The downstairs area was pretty empty, so it was kind of weird that there were so many groups outside, in the rain, but it quickly filled up.

We are big Chinese food fans, normally eating it twice a month or so. And, I don't want to sound racist or anything, but you can generally tell a good Chinese food place by the people who are eating there, if you know what I am getting at. 

Now to the food. We ordered a bowl of Wonton Soup, Eggrolls, Vegetable Chow Mein, and Spicy Chicken in Garlic Sauce. They were all very good. I have said mostly really good things about this place and you might be asking yourself, "self, why only 4 stars?" Let me tell you. It is mainly just for the portion size. I feel like often times, when you go to a Chinese restaurant you get a little cheated on the portion size. That was certainly the case here. Between two people, we were able to polish all of this off with a bowl of rice and still go home slightly hungry. To give context, I am a 6 ft 170 lb guy and my girlfriend is 5'8" and 120lbs. That is the main reason for the 4 star, not 5 star review. Other than that, I would highly recommend this place.
author: Michael C.

description: Came for a second try and the hostess wanted to know if I'd be back more (the five star stalker, you know).  I tried the orange beef and although it was good, I prefer the Hunan beef much better.
author: Eric M.

description:
My SO and I were in town for a night out on the town and since she is a big fan of Chinese food I wanted to wow her with a place that I knew would be good.  After perusing Yelp for about 30 minutes I came across Hunan Home's.  I read review after review trying to get the best possible idea of what our encounter would be like.  The more reviews I read, the more my confidence grew that this would be the place that we would have to try!

Let's get to the actual experience though....
We walked in on a Monday evening and the place was absolutely packed!  There was one free table in the restaurant, and we just happened to get it since it only accommodated two.  We sat down and were immediately greeted by our server who took our drink order.  The server was very quick and attentive.  We ended up doing a family style combination order for the two of us which included the following:
Sizzling Rice Soup
Egg Roll
Fried Prawn
Pot Sticker
Orange Peel Chicken - Substituted to the Hunan Chicken
Sizzling Beef

We substituted out the white rice for the pork fried rice and then ordered some chicken chow mein as we wanted to try as much variety as we could.  

Our soup came very quickly and was delicious.  It had chunks of chicken, shrimp & veggies in it and was a great start to the meal.  Shortly after that, our appetizers came.  My first taste was of the fried prawn.  This prawn was the best prawn I had ever had.  It was extremely crispy.  From that moment on, I was hooked!  The pot sticker was great, the egg roll was pretty good also.  You could tell that everything was made fresh and I liked the fact that I felt I was getting quality food for a decent price.  

Our entrees came and they were also delicious.  My only negative would have to go with the sizzling beef.  The presentation of the dish was great as they let it sizzle right at the table (kind of like fajitas), but we kept getting struck by hot oil on our arms because of the small table and that was rather annoying.  The taste of the dish itself though....great!  The Hunan Chicken was also very good.  It had a little bit of a kick, but not too much.  The chicken was very succulent and the accompanying veggies were tasty with the sauce that came on the dish.  The fried rice had large chunks of pork and the rice was very fluffy.   Probably the best fried rice I've ever had.  The chow mein was also great.

Overall, I was extremely impressed and pleased with Hunan Home's Restaurant.  I would definitely recommend this place to a friend/co-worker/family/etc. and would not think twice about going back again.  While the prices are a little high compared to a lot of Chinese places, the quality is top notch and the service is great.  I don't mind paying a little extra when the overall experience is wonderful, and in this case it really was.  

Hunan Home's is now officially the greatest Chinese food restaurant I've ever had.
author: Craig C.

description:
5 stars again for me. My friends from Japan were here again and were craving a duck, so off to Hunan Homes we go.

The duck here is tasty. A little too much meat left on the skin for me, but still good. Crispy savory skin, not too greasy. My only complaint would be that the waitress put a little too much sauce on the pancake for me, so that the taste of the duck was overwhelmed. No biggie though. 

The Xiaolongbao were excellent, that's a must try if you've never had them, and the Mapo doufo was molten lava hot, as it should be. Steamed chicken with ginger was subtle and tender, and the asparagus was very fresh tasting.

We don't come here for the typical stuff, so I couldn't tell you how the sweey and sour pork is, but I've had better chow mein at other places. huey dewey louie's  (New Woey Loey Goey) across the street has better noodles.

The waitress is a kick, she was trying to correct our atrocious Cantonese pronunciation, and is always a lot of fun to flirt with. Overall, this place continues to provide very good food at a reasonable price, and deserves it's reputation.
author: Martin G.

description:
I usually stay out of SF if I can because most restaurants on the Peninsula satisfy my taste buds.  Hunan is the exception I make.  

Now, why in the world would I drive all the way into Chinatown just for Chinese food????   Hunan is the real deal.  They have a wide range of dishes for everyone.  Not only have they captured  the tourist crowds, they have a steady and strong  local following.

I've been going to Hunan for over 20 years.  I'm glad to report my taste buds have evolved from Chicken Chow Mein (seems like a simple dish, but no one makes it as well as them) and Beef Satay.  I still like those dishes, but now I really enjoy their other dishes such as the Salt & Pepper Crab.  It's very meaty and flavorful.  Not overly breaded or fried.   I'm so addicted to this dish! I LOVE, LOVE, LOVE the crab.  Give me that and nothing else and I'll be more than happy.

The ginger and scallion variation is also very good if you don't like fried seafood.  The veggie dishes I like to order are the green beans and egg plant.  They both have the right amount of heat and sauce.  The honey walnut prawns are delicious.  They aren't over fried or over glazed with the sweet mayo sauce.  My friends like ordering the pig's blood medley, the catch of the day and Peking duck.  No dinner is complete until the succulent bread is ordered.  It tastes magically delicious when you dip it into the condensed milk that is served on the side.

It's really best to go with a group of friends so you can try as many dishes as possible.
  
Sometimes, there is a wait when the place is crowded.  Walk around or enjoy the fish tank and see how many of them you can identify from "Finding Nemo."

Lastly, the staff.  James, the owner  and Dong Dong, the hostess are very nice and have a great sense of humor.  They create a very warm atmosphere along with their attentive wait staff.  They have become great friends and I'm very happy to see their restaurant doing well.
author: angela s.

description: good food but the Receptionist need to be smiling more. lol
author: Eranda J.

description:
This is one of the few places in Chinatown that I keep returning to. The prices and layout is more like a tourist attraction, but at least it stays relatively clean.  The service is decent, although they tend to be a little rushy when there is a line, not a huge problem though. The food itself is quite delicious. I like stronger flavored-food, so this place fits my taste buds. My favorite is definitely the hot and sour soup. Just thinking about it makes me salivate. It has the perfect level and mix of spiciness and sourness to keep me drinking until the very last drop. I'm not over exaggerating, but I would really lick the bowl clean if people were not around. 

Another favorite is the eggplant with chicken and prawns. The eggplants are always cooked so that it melts in your mouth, and the chicken is tender and juicy. They could probably add a few more prawns to the plate, but the flavor makes up for that. The mu shu pork is also delightful. The wrap is soft and chewy, which makes it easy to hold the ingredients in. It does harden within minutes though, so eat it up quick! They always end the meal with a fortune cookie and slices of oranges, so that's always a treat. I would definitely come back to try more dishes.    

Service: 3.5 stars
Ambience: 4 stars
Food: 4.5
Overall: 4 stars
author: B Y.

description: Four of us ordered three entrees, chow mein and egg rolls.  Friendly service, timely, it all tasted ok and was priced right.  The smaller than usual dinner plates and quantity of entrees was a bit smaller than we are use to, but we all left satisfied.  We would eat here again.
author: Jim S.

description:
I got turned onto this place by my Dad, who first went to this place in the late 80s while on a business trip to SF from Boston.  He took me when I was in college and spending a summer working in SF.  I've been coming here every chance I get, first whenever I visited friends and then, when I finally moved to SF.    

As many other Yelpers have said, there is no shortage of Chinese restaurants in SF, let alone Chinatown.  But this is BY FAR our favorite.   James and his staff create a warm and friendly environment.  The space is very clean and they make you feel right at home (thus the name I guess).

Our favorite dishes:  Potstickers are always fresh and with just the right mix if pork and ginger.  War Wonton soup starts with a killer broth, pack with chunks of chicken, pork, veggies, squid, scallops, shrimp (drooling as I type).  Peking Duck is just dynamite here.  They serve it with all the fixins.  String bean chicken, mushu pork, hunan chicken . . . the list goes on.  For a real treat, try the Crab done two ways.  You won't be disappointed.

What sets Hunan Home's apart is their sauces. They've had the same chef for nearly 20 years and it shows.  All the dishes are consistently good to great with fantastic and balanced flavors.  

We've taken many people here, from birthday parties to out of town guests, and every leaves happy.  Give it a try.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Rick W.

description: Great Hot & Sour Soup- nice and spicy. I've been here twice, and had good food both times.
author: Stephanie E.

description: I came here with 2 girls from China who were looking for real authentic Chinese food; I found this place on Yelp & joined them for lunch -- we had chicken chow mein, shrimp fried rice, & some tofu in sauce... the fried rice was sooo incredibly delicious & the chow mein was on point!! I'm not a big fan of tofu so I didn't care too much for that!! The girls told me in their very broken English that this food was good & it did indeed remind them of home!  Overall it was yummy & the service was very good, I will definitely go again when i'm in ChinaTown!  Minus one star for having a pretty dirty restroom, it grossed me out a little, good thing I used it AFTER I had my meal.
author: LuLu G.

description: I used to come here at least twice a week when I was working in downtown SF.  One of my favorite hunan restaurants in SF!!! We arrived and were seated immediately. The restaurant has lunch specials at reasonable prices and they give you a good amount of food. There was a group of 7 of us so we ordered dishes and shared family style.  All of the food tasted great!!! Service was great! I will definitely be back!
author: Janet E.

description:
This is my favorite Chinese restaurant in San Francisco.  It is clean with excellent service and amazing food.  I am very picky with foods and have high standards for restaurants.

For appetizers, I would recommend Home's Succulent Bread, which comes with sweet condensed milk, egg rolls, pot stickers, and wonton in spicy sauce.  Hot and sour soup is delicious with perfect amount of spiciness.  My favorite entrees of all time are string beans with chicken, pepper and salt fish fillet, and crab with spicy salt.  They are all so yummy!!

James (manager), waiters, and waitresses are prompt, polite, and attentive. 

All the friends and family who brought to this restaurant, loved it!  If you want great Chinese food and excellent service, you need to go to Hunan Home's Restaurant!
author: Catherine U.

description: Went here for dinner.  There was a decent amount of people waiting to be seated, yet we only waited about 20 minutes (by LA standards this is nothing). It looks like a small restaurant, but luckily they opened the lower floor which was quieter and roomier than upstairs (and if you sit upstairs, there are people constantly passing by).  We are Chinese food conservatives so we ordered the safe stuff: chicken fried rice, pot stickers, and mu shu chicken, all of which were delicious.  Make sure they give you that special sauce that's really garlicky (I don't remember the name and if I did I wouldn't know how to spell it anyway).  My 10 year old is pretty picky and she loved all of it! The service was good, yet I took a star off because it took a really long time to get our food (we started eating when others who were seated after us were pretty much done). All in all, it was worth the wait in a town where there are so many choices for food and it's hard to find a place with at least 4 stars.
author: Marlene F.

description: Awesome chinese food right next to Chinatown. Service was awesome and every dish was solid. There's plenty of seating in the dining room but there's only street parking available outside which is ok since most people will get to Chinatown via public transportation or walking.
author: Drew W.

description: Absolutely great meal here at a bargain price. I'm glad R&G Lounge had a long wait, thereby forcing my party to locate this establishment sooner rather than later. The hot and sour soup is at the top of its form, the sizzling hunan bean curd with shredded pork was a real treat as well.
author: O. K.

description:
Great restaurant in Chinatown.  Close to my work and on www.restaurant.com, can't get any better than that!  But actually it CAN!  The service here is awesome!  I loved our waiter who was so nice and attentive... I feel like whenever I walk in with a restaurant.com gift certificate that the service sometimes goes down but not at this spot.  This is the main reason I'm giving it 5 stars.

We got a ton of food for the minimum $35 we had to spend.  Definitely enough for 3 people and even enough for 2 more people with all the leftovers we had.  The sweet and sour soup was so yummy, perfect for a chilly SF day.  We also got chow mein and the kung pao beef and chicken, both yummy but next time I don't think I'd order two of the same kind (two kung pao's).

The best part was that on our way out, I got the leftovers to go and the waiter gave me even more soup to take home!  Such a great experience and the service was also fast!!

This is Chinese food so it's not gourmet but still good and definitely worth the price even without the restaurant.com gift certificate!  I would definitely come back here and recommend it to the homies :D
author: Kay R.

description:
5 stars.. This place is a keeper!!  Their dishes are great tasting , bar none.
Top notch !!!! Highly recommended
author: Joey C.

description:
Why oh WHY can't Oakland have anyplace like this??? Hey Oakland WAKE UP!!!

Clean, cheerful, delicious - did I mention clean? 

Hunan's Home is the antidote to every nasty, revolting dive you find in Oakland. They feature a cheerful interior with some decor and an utter lack of cracked linoleum flooring. The aquarium near the door features beautiful fish in clear water, not a dank glass bin featuring sad fish that may become your dinner.

How was the food? Just great, thanks for asking. They had a wide range of meat-free options for the table's vegetarians, including a rocking veggie Mu Shu. The pea sprouts with garlic sauce were as fresh and beautiful as any vegetable could hope to be. The hot and sour soup was good as were the broccoli beef and beef chow fun.
author: Claudius R.

description: Good food and not over expensive.  The service was a bit shakey though, never got our waters and slow but the food was good.
author: Wes D.

description: We stopped here for lunch during a visit to Chinatown. The food and service was really good, but I'm only giving it 3 stars because it wasn't anything special. I expected a little more from a meal in Chinatown. I could have gotten the same quality food and flavor from my local Chinese take out joint.
author: Ramona B.

description: We had the chicken/garlic/green beans dish and it was very good. The wonton soup - the small - is big enough for 2 people and is the best I've ever had!!! We went a 2nd time on our trip to SF and had the Mongolian Beef which was very disappointing. The place gets crowded very quickly so call ahead and it's not super large so not best for big groups (unless they have a large room that I didn't see). Great place! Just say no to the Mongolian Beef ;)
author: Michelle P.

description:
Hunan Homes has been a favorite of mine for years. I am pretty sure tourists outnumber the locals dining, but that does not mean we don't enjoy this restaurant! I love coming to Hunan Home for its food and cleanliness. Meals come with hot and sour soup. They have brown rice option- a rare find.

Recommendations:
Kung Pao Chicken
Shanghai Stir Fried Rice Cakes w/ Pork
author: Carol P.

description: Among the best Chinese eateries I've ever been to. The hot and sour soup was the best. A small order was plentiful. Prices very reasonable, service quick and straight forward. Front of house staff friendly. When you see a lot of locals packing the house, you know you've found the right place.
author: Robin D.

description: Pretty good home-style Chinese food (as opposed to banquet-style).  Prices are very reasonable - we ordered only seafood dishes and many were $11.50-$12.50.  Only downside is they don't have good service.
author: Beatrice W.

description:
Loved this place. I went with 6 friends. We were a little loud when we got there. The host, James, played right along with us. He offered suggestions as well as a few perfectly timed jokes.

Food was amazing. I had the eggplant with shrimp and chicken, medium spicy. Very good. 

This restaurant was the perfect pick in Chinatown.
author: Julia W.

description:
Stopped in for lunch with the girls on Labor Day Monday.

It was about 11:30 & we wre the only one in the restaraunt.

Ordered the Pot Stickers,Veg Chow Mein & the Walnut Prawns with steamed rice.

Not the best Chinese food I've ever had ,but pretty tasty.

Three items with rice(no drinks,just Tea)$32.42 + tip.

2.5 STARS......
author: William D.

description:
I would've given Hunan Home's another star, but a couple other negative reviews reinforced my perception of its shortcomings.  The restaurant is pleasant enough, but I totally agree with James B.'s review: the prices are above average for smallish portions and less than flavorful food.

1. We asked for pot stickers fried (not steamed).  They were small and mushier than I would've expected for fried dumplings.
2. The eggrolls were the size of small Vietnamese spring rolls, not the thicker kind we were used to from Chinese places back in Chicago.
3. The beef with broccoli was just that: beef with broccoli and a little bit of gravy/sauce.  We ordered a dinner-sized entree, and it was small.  Maybe you get more if you order carryout, but we paid $10.50 and thought it was paltry, even for lunch.
4. The shrimp fried rice was a total rip: we ordered a large portion and got what we thought was a small plate.
5. Like 98% of the other two hundred Chinese restaurants in Chinatown, Hunan Home's gives out cans of soda, and you'll pay something like $2.25 for every can.
6. When we order Chinese food back home, entrees usually come with at least a small steamed rice; not here.  Even though we ordered an additional shrimp fried rice for around $8, they charged us an extra $6 after we asked for steamed rice...why?

We thought our $59 bill for two appetizers, two entrees, an extra thing of fried rice, a can of Coke and steamed rice was expensive for just the three of us.  The service was decent overall, and we were seated right away.  We're used to Chinese waiters being less than gracious and friendly, and Hunan Home's didn't disappoint in that regard.
author: Robert S.

description:
We started off our meal with wor wonton soup, which was delicious.  We had shrimp chow mein and chicken with cashew nuts for our main course.  The shrimp chow mein was really good.  The chicken with cashew nuts was ok...a little on the bland side.

They have good customer service.  I was impressed at how hard-working the wait staff there was.

Since there were only two of us eating, we didn't get to try as much variety of dishes as I wanted to.  I would defintely go back to try other dishes if I'm back in SF.
author: Cookie N.

description:
Overall: A-
High ratings since most dishes are pretty safe bets and tasty to boast.

Food: A 
Try the sizzling prawns and walnut prawns dishes. The Peking duck is also killer. The mu shu pork was surprisingly delicious. I was expecting a dish fit for white folk but alas it was not. 

Decor: C 
Very simple and plain but I like the aquarium at the door 

Service: A 
Fast service, friendly and funny. James, the owner, is a quite a charmer and funny. 

Value: B 
Belly busting portions which are big enough to feed 3-4 people.
author: Roger H.

description:
I've been twice now and each time has been good but not great. The food is served quickly and is very tasty. The hot and sour soup has plenty of hot but could use a little more sour and the hunan green beans are very good. The kung pao dishes aren't that spicy unless you nosh on the peppers, I wish they were able to infuse more of the heat throughout the entire dish rather then just add some hot peppers to it. 

The price is ok, an average of $10 a dish and portion sizes are pretty ample. Go with some friends, order a bunch of different dishes, share with each other and enjoy!
author: Russ C.

description:
My wife and I just had the most amazing dinner! The best Chinese food we've ever had. 

Our first course was the pot stickers. You have not lived if you have not had the opportunity to taste these morsels from heaven. 

The other star on the menu was our second course, the dungeness crab with black bean sauce... yum!! 

We also enjoyed the hot and sour soup, spicy garlic chicken and the pork fried rice. To top it all off was the incredible service. It's a MUST visit when in or near China Town.  We WILL be back for more! 







t
author: Brandon B.

description: No frills dinner.  Plates were a little small.  I recommend if you are going to share plates among the table, you should order more food than you would normally expect.  They were flexible in getting us seated as a group.
author: David S.

description: The best Chinese food in San Francisco ! Service was great ! Food was outstanding and plentiful. You need to dine here.
author: Tito G.

description: Hot & Sour soup was great. So were the Kung Pao Prawns - sauced & spiced without being overdone. Portions were large, and the food came quickly.
author: Jason S.

description: Great food.  Best hot and sour soup and pot stickers ever!  Everything was fresh and flavorful.  Service was good for a busy Saturday night.
author: Lynn N.

description: Nice restaurant. My regular lunch place for many years.
author: TM P.

description: We came to SF for a visit and found this place from Yelping. The food was really good! I must say that this place tasted a lot different from other Chinese food I've tasted. It was more spicy and had more flavor, which I loved! If I'm back here again, I would definitely come back.
author: Julie L.

description:
My friend's parents own this restaurant & so we went w/ him yesterday. I LOVE this place ! You can park for FREE at the Hilton because they validate your parking !

Their hot & sour soup is THE BEST I've ever tasted ! The woman even warmed it up when it got cold.

Their Peking Duck was soo SOFT & TENDER & it was not OiLY at all. The waiter even did a little show when he was folding the duck into the little pastry thing w/ hoison sauce & green onions. I don't know what that dish was called because my friend had ordered it. 

The GARLiC PRAWNS W/ MUSHROOMS was very fresh. It was simple yet so flavorful. They even add the small corn I like.

I admit there was a lot of white people though, since they came w/ a party of 37 when I was eating. Nonetheless, thank you Jasper & SUPER NiCE Dad ! I love this place & will mosdef come here everytime I'm in Chinatown =D
author: SARAH N.

description: We got a reccommendation for this restaurant from a local and it was everything he said it would be! We bought the $19 per person shared family dinner and it was wonderful! Our family was able to try different appetizers, soup, and meals. Another table near us was raving about the sizzling platters. I also saw a plate full of perfectly fried pot stickers go by our table and wished I could eat there another day. Next time! It really is one of  Chinatown best kept secrets.
author: Luanne D.

description: I love this place.  The atmosphere is nothing special, but the food is great.  The Ma Po tofu is really good, especially with pork.  The orange chicken is better than anywhere else around.  Very crispy, but not coated with thick batter.  When we are in SF and in the mood for Chinese, this is the place.
author: Mark D.

description: A highly authentic (what else would you expect?) restaurant in the middle of Chinatown. A perfectly sized menu (good selection but not overwhelming as many chinese restaurants) and friendly staff. The feel, decoration, and utensils reminded me of some of the restaurants I went to in China. I'm not usually crazy about egg-drop soup, but i actually really enjoyed the dried scallop egg-drop soup (we were tempted after having seen dried scallops sold in several shops throughout Chinatown). The dumplings were subtly tasty and not too greasy/fatty. The sizzling shrimp entree was pretty flavorful as well (slightly sweet for my taste but overall delicious). The restaurant has a pretty cozy and pleasant feel, and I would recommend it as the best restaurant I've eaten thus far in Chinatown.
author: Madalina B.

description:
Hunan Homes has been my favorite chinese joint since I found it while working in the financial district back in the 90s. They have a great lunch special.  Great kung pao chicken and hot and sour soup.  In fact, this is the best hot and sour soup I have tasted in the city.  It is awesome and the perfect blend of flavors with just enough vinegar.  All the dishes I have tasted here were fantastic.  The Lemon chicken, general chicken...whatever you want, they've got.

Sometimes the waiters here are pretty grumpy.  But it doesn't bother me. The last time I went here by myself after a meeting with my banker downtown. I was starving. It was like 3:30.  I said, " can I get the lunch special?"  Answer:  no...   "Okay..  can I order a bowl of hot and sour soup for one?"  Answer:  no.....

Okay fine. I will take the hot and sour soup for 2-3 people and take the rest home.  

I ordered the kung pao chicken and hot and sour soup.  It was a great meal and I had some left overs to take home to nob hill.  Hunan Homes is simply one of the best chinese restaurants in town.
author: Georgio N.

description:
Love the food here... really, really good meal.  

Favorites are the Calamari w/ Spicy salt and sizzling rice soup.  Good potstickers and eggplant also.  There is usually a line, so come early and bring your appetite.  The food is subtle and not over the top like so many of the restaurants that cater to tourist near the gates.  

I noticed people complaining a little about the service and decor... I'm more interested in the food and used to Asian style of service.  I will take efficient and civil over friendly and sloppy any day.
author: Ami T.

description:
I came to Hunan Homes looking for a restaurant in SF that can come close in quality to Hunan Taste in San Jose. Sadly, Hunan Homes fell way short. 

I went with the chicken and string beans which is typically a good yardstick of how good a Hunan-style restaurant is. Hunan Taste in San Jose uses black bean sauce, fresh garlic and string beans that are fried dry leaving them very crispy. The dish at Hunan Homes was nowhere near as good -- the chicken and string beans were swimming in a soup of red sauce. While it was very spicy, it didn't have much flavor otherwise. 

The food was by no means terrible, it just didn't stand out in any way. My personal quest for fantastic Hunan cuisine in SF continues.
author: Aaron V.

description: I went here two nights in a row because I loved this place so much. The dry sauteed asparagus is amazing! Both nights I went with a group of people and so we ordered a number of dishes and shared them, and I didn't hear anyone say anything bad about any of the dishes we ordered. Service is incredibly fast, and the prices are good. This will definitely become a regular pit stop for me whenever I'm in SF!
author: Tanya H.

description:
Totally overrated, extremely average Chinese food. Zagat rating? Please... 
The prices are in the $10 range for such exotic hits as...sweet and sour chicken....or kung pao... or chow mein for $8? C'mon! The walnut prawns had some kinda sweet mayonnaise on them...yuck! The portions are also VERY small compared to other restaurants in the area. The service was not very good--the hostess/owner(?) never once smiled and the waiters are like zombies. We won't be returning...ever.
author: James B.

description:
Won ton soup was excellent!  Pork-fried-rice was again excellent.  Everything we ate was just so well prepared!  

Yelp sent us there and if you are in the area, I recommend!!
author: Chris T.

description:
One of the best Chinese Restaurants I've ever been to. Initially found out about this gem from Yelp.com and later discovered a spend $35 get $25 restaurant.com offer. My date and I ordered 4 different lunch meals- 2 to dine in and 2 to take back home. Sweet & Sour Pork, Chicken & Broccoli, Shrimp & Vegetables, and Spicy Beef & Broccoli. All were delicious. As other users have noted- the hot & sour soup is amazing as is the wonton soup. 

Service is exceptional and the waiter scoops out your wonton noodles and serves them in your cup. Servers are quick, attentive, and the food is Delicious. I was so happy we ordered 2 meals to go as I had a nice dinner for later on. When I'm back in San Francisco I plan on coming here at least 2 times haha. Excellent Food, Fair Prices, Attentive Service. A+ all around!
author: Brent G.

description:
I don't get what the big deal is with this place. I'm willing to give it another chance and try something new, but my food was not up to par. The shrimp wasn't very fresh, the sauce was too bland, and the rice had no flavor. 

Lunch Special $8. (not so bad?)
author: Shel Z.

description: Very nice meal. Had the usual, and it did not disappoint.  Great service and a nice thank you / good-bye. I recommend it.
author: Ned F.

description: Great restaurant. Quickly seated and were very nice. Enjoyed the Mongolian beef and orange chicken.
author: Colleen F.

description:
I love Hunan Homes.  I've been to the restaurant probably 2 or 3 times, but always get delivery.  You can now even order everything online and you get a confirmation call back within ten minutes.  I always get the exact same thing every time because it never fails me and is always super tasty.

Hot n Sour Soup
Hot n Sour Chicken (white meat only)
Brown Rice

Delicious and the perfect cure for anything!
author: Jenny W.

description: Pretty consistent but a little too Americanized for me.  Very few Asians eat here on the couple of times I went here.  Son and Daughter in law like it, so we go.  They order an  American Family dinner.  I'd love to try their Chinese Family dinner.   In the midst of Chinatown,  there are more authentic places
author: Guy B.

description:
Based on the recommendation of a shop clerk, I tried Hunan Homes.  I never would have found it if not for the recommendation as it's off the main streets and there are dozens of restaurants in the area.

I ordered the Chicken in Garlic Sauce and thought is was good, but nothing special. There was nothing to set this dish apart from what I get at an average Chinese Restaurant across the country.

I felt the price was a little too high ($10.50 for my main dish + cost for rice), my dish wasn't as spicy as I expected, and the service was too slow.  The waiters were friendly, but the one waitress seemed to have a chip on her shoulder.  Something else I didn't care for is the tea is made from tea bags -- I prefer loose leave tea and I'm in Chinatown...they could be more authentic, but I know that's being picky.

At 3 stars, there's a good chance I'll return when in the area, but I won't go out of my way to come here again.
author: Jody R.

description: These 5 stars are for two things: the chili oil on the table (which is even better than what Yank Sing sells) and the Sizzling Eel. If you are a fan of unagi, or if you've, say, enjoyed the exceptionally fresh eel in the town of Narita, then you will love this dish.
author: A M.

description: We were in San Fran for a business conference last week and were recommended this place from our bellhop at the Fairmont- This was the best Chinese food I have ever had, and that is saying a lot. I LOVE Chinese food. Definitely go here if you are looking for a non-expensive, authentic, amazing, Chinese meal!
author: Margot R.

description: My wife and I stopped here for dinner one night while on our vacation because a very friendly Chinese-American Muni worker recommended it to us. Well, my first impression when we walked in was that it was a sea of white faces (all anglos) and not a single asian face in there except for the hostess by the door. When I mentioned that to her and asked her if the food was "americanized" she said rather matter of fact-ly "you have to cater to the audience". So I had the Tai Chin Chicken and an assortment of appetizers. The mushrooms in my dish were great but the hot and sour soup and the egg rolls were so-so. The fried tofu appetizer was good though. My wife had the Hunan Spicy Garlic Chicken and she only picked at it.
author: Steve M.

description: Sevice and quality are up to snuff with my favorite chinese restaurants in Chicago (Yu's, Heng Wing, Yen Yen). My wife and I ordered potstickers and were confused why we didn't get any sauce beside two bottles that appeared to be vinegar, which didn't sound good. The owner or manager came over too us, as he must have noticed we didn't know what to do with the sauces. He showed us how to mix our own sauce on demand. Mix chili oil with vinegar and soy sauce, then dip and enjoy. Boy was he right. Much better than the standard potsticker sauce. Orange chicken and fried rice were top notch.
author: Gail B.

description:
i was there last night and was really tired after a long week of work. i just wanted to eat some good Chinese food to feed my soul and yes, Hunan Home did it for me!
We got the beef w/string beans and hunan style chicken (spicy) and chicken fried rice.
Even thinking about it makes me want to eat it! and i do not have any leftovers!=(.
Out of million Chinese restaurants in the city, this one is pretty good and i would come here again. I know people that do lunch here at least once a week (they have $4 lunch specials, good portions and delicious!)
Inside decor...just very Chinese...plates...Chinese, tables pink covers, Chrystal chandeliers...etc. Cute little place, big smile in my tummy!
I came home, hit the bed with a smile and 10 more lbs gained, probably! lol=).
Like i always say people; love for food, appetite for life!!=)
author: C A.

description: Absolutely great food. I loved the orange chicken. 'nough said.
author: Kent N.
