description: Ordered egg rolls too crispy. Got hot sour soup wanted substitute don't like told no substitutes on menu must be in Chinese not in English. Good broccoli and shrimp. spouse got Hunan beef with vegetables said it was good. You get hot tea fortune cookie and a few slices of Oranges. friendly service. But I can get better Chinese at home.
author: Susan B.

description: Love the food here. Great Chinese restaurant for both locals and tourists. The downstairs part is usually tables of tour bus riders who come to San Francisco for a good meal, and Hunan Homes is the place to be. Service is great and so is the food. Located in the famous Chinatown, it's a good restaurant within walking distance of food shopping and little shops with candies and other goodies. Go if you have the chance.
author: David L.

description: Came here with the family on a Saturday for lunch. They gave us the gweilo menu and refused to give us the more interesting (and cheaper) menu for regulars. Food and service were solid. Want to go back with a friend who speaks Chinese so I can experience the real deal.
author: Erik H.

description: Good place with a mix of authentic and American Chinese - good service the 3 times I've been here - must eats are the Xiao Long Bao and Sizzling Eel - which tastes similar to Unagil Sushi if you like that.  Lots more items on the menu I'd like to try!
author: Steven M.

description: Ok so here's the deal...don't waste your money. The black bean chicken is ok but in that location, it's like saying its nasty. It hurts me to even think about the schezuan beef. If you can at all help it, don't go here!
author: Jay H.

description: Ok, but very overrated. Pretty standard Chinese food without anything special but at relatively high prices.
author: Kermit T.

description: At first we were a bit skeptical based on the service from the hostess, but this quickly changed. The mushu app was amazing, and so were the Hunan scallops. Our server was super attentive and very funny. Will definitely make a trip back.
author: Vijay M.

description: really good authentic Chinese food. I had the best hot and sour soup I think I have ever had.
author: Irissa N.

description:
I love this fucking place, but I don't think the pot stickers are that tasty.

I've been under the weather and the phenomenal hot & sour soup really cleared me up.

Again, I love the hunan chicken!
author: Randal P.

description: Excellent food. Simply the best hot and sour soup. The orange peel chicken was terrific.
author: George E.

description: Every time I eat in China Town I come here for Orange peel Chicken, Bean Sauce Noodles, and their green string beans.  The service is excellent, great value for price, great tea and very clean. The locals like to eat here too so you know its good! Always people dining here.
author: Dawn M.

description: Choosing a place to eat in Chinatown San Francisco is tough to do- so many options and as far as I am aware, most are pretty good. Then the question, I think becomes what kind of Chinese you are looking for. Granted the food and service at Hunan Homes is very good but for my taste is a bit more home-style of cooking than I like, I would have liked the food to be a bit more restaurant cooking style. Hope that makes sense!
author: Carolina V.

description: I have been to Hunan Homes on my last two trips to San Francisco and will go back whenever I'm in town.  The food is spectacular -- best hot and sour soup I've ever had.  It has an authentic feel, and located in the heart of Chinatown, there's a lot going on.
author: Ryan D.

description: Gotta love Hunan Homes for good classic Chinese in Chinatown.  I have yet to have a disappointing meal at this"go-to" spot.  The place is clean and the service is fast. Not a whole lot of innovation here, but it is classic Chinese as we have come to expect in the States.  Waiters rarely crack a smile, but that's because they are usually serving a packed house.  Get to eating!
author: Rosanne D.

description:
$6.00 lunch deals! Yes!

Mr. Rico Suave Sav and I decided to go for some Chinese food for lunch. So close to China town, so many choices!  After being rejected by a cash only establishment, we were on the hunt to find a credit card zone restaurant.  And we found ourselves here! Hurrah!

Service was quick, just the way I like it during the rushed lunch hour.  I chose the $6.00 orange peel chicken lunch combo. Deep fried goodness in a sickenly delicious special orange sauce. Yes please! But this meal was good seemingly authentic Chinese food.  For $6.00 I could've gone to Panda Express and had two entrees and big heaping of MSG, but instead, I chose Hunan Homes. And I'd choose it again and again.

:D
author: Aim E.

description:
Came for: weekday lunch
Will come back for: weekday lunch special with brown rice option

It's yummy and a solid go-to to fill a chinese food craving near FiDi; it's consistently tasty and fills it's duty as a go-to.  It's in the cusp of Chinatown, so its decor and service indicate just that.  Their lunch (don't know about their dinners) is served with a hot-n-sour soup that stirs the palate to let you know that Chinese food is coming.  I love it that they have brown rice.  Personal fave is the chicken prawn with eggplant with brown rice, but they're flexible with lunch combos so take your pick.  My colleagues have been happy with their picks of the day as well.
author: Carol K.

description:
This is where my husband wooed me.  I know - I'm easy.  Back when we were just friends, when we both worked in the area, a group of us would have lunch here at least once a week.  He would always sit next to me and give me all of his dried red chiles.  I found out later that he wanted the chiles for himself but gave them to me to woo me.  

Being a junkie of insanely spicy food and a person of little dignity, I would eat all of his chiles and mine, turn beet red, sweat like a pig with my hair plastered to my head and I would fan myself while slumped in my chair rolling from the endorphin high.  Attractive, I know.  I was quite a catch.  Seeing that side of me on a regular basis while supporting my ugly chile habit and still falling for me - I knew he would be a keeper.  

I have never had a bad meal at Hunan Homes.  I LOVE and crave their hot and sour soup - best I've tasted anywhere.  Anything hunan there is exceptional with my favorite being the hunan smoked pork.  During lunch, you can order one of a dozen lunch special items (including the smoked pork) with a side of rice and a bowl of their hot and sour soup, all for around 6 bucks.  How can you beat that?  I could seriously eat there every day and not get sick of it.  

p.s. Now that we're married, my husband doesn't give me his chiles anymore.  Selfish bastard.  

4.5 stars.
author: mia s.

description:
that sweet and sour soup is soo good I cant wait to back.
beef and potstickers are amazing too!
author: roxanne m.

description:
Hey yeah for Hunan Homes!

We started off with pot stickers which were delicious and very garlicky.  The hot n. sour soup could've been a little more sour, but the vinegar on the table took care of that.  I had the tofu with asparagus in black bean sauce, which was great.  So often that dish can be overwhelmingly salty, but not here.  The tofu was also really soft and sliced into these irregular chunks, which I really liked for some reason. 

Other entrees were basil chicken (HOT HOT HOT) and the oft-reviewed orange peel chicken, which looks kind of nasty, but tasted good in  that bad-for-you-deep fried-chinese-food- kind of way.

Prompt, attentive service.  I especially like the orange slices they served with the fortune cookies at the end of the meal.

HH - I will be back!
author: .Hon H.

description:
Jesus H. Christ, could there be any more disgusting brown sauce on these dishes?  Actually, yes, House of Nanking is worse, and so is Henry's Hunan.  

The brown sauce is especially vile on scallops (a $12.95 dish!).  Skip anything that isn't pork.  If you stick to pork, and that doesn't bother you, you will walk away with a 3, maybe 4-star dining experience.  But it bothers me.
author: Ben A.

description:
I came here today for lunch with my coworkers. I've been once before and I totally enjoyed the experience. Lunch is not terribly crowded, and they have tons of places to sit. And the resturant is clean! Service there is exceptional, everyone is really friendly and actually rememvbers to bring whatever you ask for.

Lunch is inexpensive here. They have a special lunch menu that if you order the rice plates (ranging from $6.25-$7) you get a bowl of their delicious hot and sour soup. The lunch menu here is great, there is a lot of selection here! I've tried the chicken with asparagus, chicken with eggplant, and the fried rice cakes - all which were delicious. The food isn't your typical greesy chinese food either, which is great! They also have brown rice for only an additional 50 cents, if you choose to be on the healthier side! Food comes out quickly for those who just need a quick lunch. Overall, a great place to come for chinese food!
author: Betty S.

description: Typical by appearance and decor (note the gaudy chandeliers and pale magenta walls), once past the old man perched on a milk crate playing melodies from The Sound of Music on his weird chinese string instrument, you will discover surprisingly good food and friendly service at this mid-block Chinatown place.  We tried the walnut prawns (lightly battered and excellent), the broccoli beef in oyster sauce (good, but over-tenderized), and the General Tzao's chicken (not on the menu, made with white meat and quite good).  My dining companions requested that I mention that the women's bathroom is ridiculously tiny, with an unusually tiny toilet seat.
author: Rick H.

description: Lovely lunch spot, I am a regular. Cheap price for the portion, comes with super duper awesomely spicy hot and sour soup and some orange slices after lunch. Would not recommend ordering any chicken here though. Once I was there, a pigeon flew out of the kitchen. A basement kitchen with no windows...
author: Fiona S.

description:
I was in town for a conference last week and was staying near Chinatown and some of us wanted some good Chinese food.  The menu had a good deal of choices both from an authentic Chinese perspective as well as the American-Chinese food that has been copied and destroyed by food courts and malls everywhere.

The service wasn't horrible, but they did seem a bit rushed.  While I was seated and eating, I did see a number of regulars come in and be greeted like family, both Asian and non.  I think our less than stellar service was simply a result of us being obvious tourists.  Which doesn't bother me.  I'd be nicer to the people who keep coming back and paying my mortgage, too.

I'm having a hard time remembering what I ordered, but I do remember the egg flour soup was fantastic and the tea was hot and full when we sat down.  Soda/pop comes in a can, so be warned if you were wanting refills.
author: Bryan M.

description:
This is my favourite chinese restaurant in the city. I eat here at least 3 times a month, either at the restuarant or take out. I also live only three blocks away, but there are plenty of other Chinese options nearby since its right in Chinatown.

Pricing is great and flavors are authentic. My wife likes the pan fried noodles here and never eats anything else. I like the string beans and the hunan smoked pork (which is really ham). They cook and serve quickly. Queues can get long if you are there around 7pm or so as the place has been written up in some tourist books so you get a lot of out of towners trying to get an authentic Chinatown meal. I can't blame them.

I wish they delivered.
author: jeremy l.

description: Food was ok at best. Clearly catering to the tourist. The spicy Won Ton was outstanding everything else was slightly better than mall food court or Panda Express Chinese food.  One saving grace might be the sizzling platters. Everyone else ordered them we didn't. Our mistake possibly.
author: RJ V.

description:
A few bites into my prawns with lobster sauce, I realized I should have ordered something else. Fair enough - I did enjoy the prompt service, low-key atmosphere, and king-size Tsingtao beer. 

But, a couple of hours of a walk later, I found myself running with an intestinal urge toward a grocery store where I ended up in the bathroom, just in time, with explosive diarrhea. That's when I realized that even those few bites were a mistake and I should have gone somewhere else. 

From the reviews here it sounds my experience might be a fluke, but still, beware.
author: Peter K.

description: I am a total amateur when it comes to Chinese food, so I wasn't confident when I walked into Chinatown seeking lunch. I read about the place on yelp and was reassured when I saw multiple business people coming in for lunch and a few were overheard saying it was good food. I had orange peel chicken with the lunch special, including tea and rice. The entree was spicy, as advertised, but excellent. Large portions and very reasonable price - my bill was 12.46 with the lunch special and a tsing Tao to put out the flames (im a weenie). It's a nice atmosphere, the service was super efficient and friendly, and the food was great. I would go back.
author: Katie W.

description: Just ok. We got off to a great start with the hot and sour soup, which was delicious and very peppery, but the entrees were generic and disappointing.  We ordered sizzling beef and  Hunan scallops, both of which were fairly standard American Chinese style entrees, competently done but nothing out of the ordinary. Bok choy with black mushrooms was better, but also nothing unusual.  Finally,  look out for the MSG.
author: Julia S.

description:
So, we're looking for a Chinese place on Yelp, and her is the conversation:

Me:  What about this Hunan Homes place?
Her:  Is that homes like wassup homes?
Me: No way, its like John Holmes!

Of course, we get there, and the place is actually called "Hunan Home's"  which doesn't seem to help much at all.  I wonder how much extra they paid for that apostrophe,  Did they mean Hunan's Home, or is there really someone named Home who owns the place? I digress.

We walk in and none of the customers are asian.  That is usually a bad sign, but in this case, it ended up being OK.  Hunan Home's is strictly americanized chinese food.   A lto of people may have problems with that, but I do not.  I love my Moo Shu Pork and General Tso's Chicken.

And I liked Hunan Home's quite a bit.  And the staff was super quick and friendly.  So I would go again, especially if I had out of town guests who think they like Chinese food.
author: Steve S.

description:
I'll definitely go back.  Had the Mongolian Beef.  It was reasonably priced at $6.75.   It was served traditionally with green and white onions and hot peppers.  Unlike most Chinese/Hunan places in the area, they managed to make this sloppy dish of goodness presentable, as opposed to the colorless pile of overcooked stuff in a spicy gravy.  While still cooked and piping hot, the onions held their intended texture and color.  Most impressively, the beef was very good.  It was cut and cooked just right so that it melted in your mouth.  

When dining in, the hot and sour soup and hot tea is complimentary.  I'm not one for most Asian soups but I thought their hot and sour was very well balanced.  Not too sweet, not too sour, not too spicy.  It was also dense with substance (not just tofu and peas floating in broth).

Service was very good.  Never had to ask for my water to be refilled.  Despite the fact that every table was full (at 12 on a Wednesday), we literally had our beers within seconds of ordering them.

The fresh orange wedges were a nice palette-cleansing alternative to the fortune cookies (don't worry, they bring those too).
author: Dave H.

description: Honey Walnut Shrimp, Mu Shu Vegetables, and General Tsos Chicken. Delicious lunch for 3 at a reasonable price.
author: Jim S.

description: We went here following the reviews on yelp but were very disappointed. After a 15/20 minute wait, we were shown a table. The waiter took a long time to take our order. The food was fine. Nothing spectacular. The service was poor. No pleasantries, no manners, not one polite person.  I wouldn't go back.
author: AmAnda D.

description:
Rating is not for the food since we didn't end up eating here because I was not going to become their filler customers.  No way will I pay to be treated like 2nd class citizens, still upsets me.  

We were debating between Z&Y and Hunan Homes.  Hubby thought Hunan Homes seem more homey and authentic so we went there even though there was a wait.  We were told 15 minutes as some small tables were getting their checks.  The hostess was not friendly and down right rude, not so much to us but to others as they come in - she doesn't even look at them and just shout out the time they'll need to wait.  This kind of behavior is just not acceptable anywhere, doesn't matter how good or popular you are.  Anyway, she took on some calls while we were waiting - we can tell at least one call was from a regular because she looked out to the dining room and said something into the receiver.  Next thing you know, she walked to the dining room and then took a Reserved sign on a table that was being cleaned for US!  The nerve!  I was damn hungry and didn't need to take this kind of freaking service.  So I asked hubby, are we willing to stand around and wait for another table and the possible risk that it'll once again be taken by a regular who calls?  The answer was simple but I also blame them for my not so satisfying dinner at Z&Y!  

PS:  I had lunch here years ago and I do remember their chow mein was not bad.
author: Gloria H.

description:
I go here every Christmas Eve with my parents (what a cliche), because this is some of the best Chinese food in the city.

John, the manager is really nice, always helpful with questions, suggestions and reservations (which you should make if you are coming in on a busy night like xmas eve, or just a Friday or Saturday night).  

The whole braised fish is always cooked perfectly and they de-bone it at the table for you which is cool to watch, the hot spicy bean curd is just spicy enough without being overpowering, and the crispy duck is  
really flavorful--the fat of the duck just melts in your mouth....aaaaand i'm drooling right now.

I have been coming here since I was probably 4 or 5 years old (I'm 22) and I've never had a bad experience.
author: Ryan S.

description:
One of the safer bets in China Town. Always quality food with fast and good service. Everyone speaks English and the menu is HUGE. 

Not the best Chinese I have ever had in my life but everything is usually pretty good. If you're looking to fulfill a Chinese craving....this place will do it. They have really great hot and sour soup! 

This is also a good place to bring a large group. It is a really big place with a 2nd huge room in the back. They also have several large tables that can accommodate probably up to 12 people.
author: Dan L.

description:
This is not your ordinary hole-in-the-wall eatery in Chinatown.
Hunan Homes is THE hole-in-the-wall eatery in Chinatown!

Wifey has been going here since she's been a grubby, bratty, greasy little kiddie.  She and her family have been regulars and introduced me to this place about 5 years ago.

Little known fact:  The owners are Taiwanese
Helpful tidbit: Taiwanese-style specialties are available only on weekends. 
Word of advice: Don't stare at the fishtank too long, you'll get motion sickness.

The food is well-prepared and cheap.  I guarantee you'll be full when you walk out the door.
author: Gracie-C Y.

description: Excellent Mu Shu and Wonton Soup. Soup Dumplings were disappointing. No soupy goodness inside. Clean, prompt service. Filled with regulars.  Definitely a worthy stop in Chinatown.
author: Valerie O.

description: Good food fast service not rude like others good value for money best Chinese food we had in San Francisco and we had in 4 places other reviews will follow
author: Dashmit A.

description:
I'd probably say it's 3 1/2 stars.  It's decent and pleasant enough, but (at least so far) I haven't found anything particularly special about it that would make me want to come here instead of any of all of the other restaurants around here.  The food seems to trend toward the normal american chinese food experience (kung pao whatever).  Big portions for a small price.  And the hot and sour soup looked good, and the waitress was knowledgeable enough to tell me that it had a pork base, so I will never know if it is as good as it looks.  But at least she knew!

Update 4/6/08:  downgrade to 2 stars.  i've read all the good reviews and my former boss who lived in SF his whole life and knows all the chinatown restaurants still loves it, but i don't see what makes it all so special.  at best, it is just a run of the mill overpriced chinese joint with mediocre food.  at worst, well service is so formal it's stilted.  the waiter dudes need to smile occasionally or something or at least stop acting like automatons.  food is on the greasy side and seems like portions getting smaller and more expensive.  all in all, dropped $40 for two run of the mill entrees, mandu and a coke.  wife couldn't (or wouldn't) eat hers.  mine was okay, but nothing different than any other kung pao whatever i have gotten anywhere else at chinese carry out places in the whole country.  in fact, perhaps a little oilier than most.  

oh, and the "vegetable" section is pitifully small.  be careful, even most of the so-called vegetable dishes in the menu also say that they contain pork.  which makes me worry... if the kung pao string beans contain pork, doesn't it stand to reason that the kung pao shrimp do too?  menu says the beans do, but omits any pork references about the shrimp.  but, it doesn't give me a warm and comfy feeling about lackage of the porkage.  maybe the best bet is to just avoid chinese places altogether.

next time, i'll just wait in line at tomasso's.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
The blowfish in the fishtank by the door has seriously lost its mind, i watched it beating against the glass for 10 minutes with its weird little people face and thought "i feel you, my fishy, i feel you."  

As far as the food goes, the xiao long bao were absolutely deeelicious and if you don't know what they are, you just go find out (ok, they're little pork dumplings with broth inside).  just be sure you let them sit for two minutes before popping one into your mouth.  or maybe first degree tongue burns are part of the hunan dining experience.

the kung pao chicken was decent enough, for americanized chinese, but it had that generic thick brown sauce that i hate, which i don't recall ever seeing in kung pao chicken in sichuan province.  also, no huajiao, but that's just a sad given, eating chinese food around here.  of course i was at a restuarant named after hunan province, and kung pao chicken is a sichuan dish, so next time i'll try something else and see.  

even though it was really busy the staff was funny and friendly, while still maintaining that authentic chinese national brusqueness that we americans sometimes find off-putting in chinese establishments.
i do wish they'd let those fish go free, they're just going mad in that little aquarium.
author: Mynameisdavid M.

description: This is my all time favorite place to go when I visit San Francisco! Their sizzling beef and garlic chicken are my favorites, but honestly everything I've had there is delicious!
author: Amanda L.

description:
Hunan Chicken was
Sadly, hmmm, mediocre
Like Panda Express
author: Andrew B.

description:
A solid establishment, Hunan Homes Restaurant has THE MOST entertaining waiters ever! Go because you're hungry and leave laughing.

What a schtick!
author: Susan L.

description: Never been to a restaurant with soooooooo bad attitude. 2 of us walked in. The manager did not have any smile on her face or any greeting, but yelled at us, "20 mins" in Chinese, because we look like Chinese? We saw 3 empty tables, and asked why we can't sit. She said you are only 2, and those round tables are for more people. I asked can we share table with other guests. There was another group of 4 people waiting as well. She was annoyed by our proposal and started telling us out about their rules. And asked me,"ARE YOU THE FIRST TIME VISITING THE US?!" We were shocked to hear this!!! We asked back -- Were you discriminating tourists??? Her attitude was still so rude. We eventually still could not get a seat and both of us and another group left. Do not recommend any shops or restaurants with HongKongnese waiter/waitress. They are discriminating Asia people, especially discriminating Chinese mainland people. If you are Caucasian, they might give you a smile.
author: Elaine B.

description: The food here was so much better than the Chinese food I'm accustomed to.  This place loses out on a star because of a VERY rowdy group of college kids that had the wait staff obviously flustered (which resulted in my group's service suffering).
author: Nate H.

description: They have great food but their service and staff needs a lot of improvement. I've eaten at a lot of Chinese restaurants who had better service despite not speaking English fluently. We had to remind them about certain orders that they haven't brought out yet or about the water that we needed in order to continue eating. Oh well!
author: Glenda R.

description: A great family restaurant!  We were quickly greeted when we walked in , along with fabulous aromas coming from the kitchen! It's very clean, service is quite good (unusual!) and the food is spot on! Great choice for those weary after trudging around Chinatown!  Shrimp Chow Mein was particularly good!!!
author: Diana R.

description: The food was quite good overall.  Roasted Garlic Prawns were a delight; Egg Flower Soup, however, tasted mostly like beef broth, sub-par in my experience.  Spicy Chicken Salad appetizer tasted great and looked just as good.  Our waiter got everything right, just what we asked for.  On the other hand, he made us feel like we smelled bad: Not a word of greeting, certainly never a smile, no comments, not a wasted syllable on the likes of us.  It's like our presence was barely tolerated.  But the food made it all worthwhile.
author: Richard H.

description: Too bad I can't give a zero star. Horrible place. If you don't like Chinese food and like fried food. You will LOVE this place. This place does not serve Chinese food. They just fry everything well.
author: Ricki H.

description:
best mu shu pork and hot n sour soup you'll find.  Service is great and you'll be hard pressed to break $20/per WITH beers.  buzzed and bloated is how you'll always leave HH.  And that dude in the Red Vest is da BOMB.  
forget NanKing.....BLAH.  

go to dishes: spicy green beans, walnut honey chicken, mushu, hot n sour, sizzling beef....and another order of mushu. 

get there!  it's NiiiIIIIiiiIIIIiiiIIiiice.
author: Mitch M.

description:
Panda Express Orange Chicken - 1,  Hunan Homes Orange Peel Chicken - 0.

But I will say that it is a real close second.  And at $5.95 for the lunch special, that's not a bad choice.  The other lunch plates are a steal - kung pao, basil chicken, etc.  You even get a free hot and sour soup.  The spot itself is above par for Chinatown - cloth napkins, decent service, and clean.  

What is General Tao's Chicken anyways?  I'm Chinese and I don't even know who the hell General Tao is.
author: Isaac L.

description: This restaurant is right in the heart of Chinatown in San Francisco. The pot stickers were excellent to start out with, and then I had the orange chicken. They are heavy on the sauces but it's still good. We had a good sized lunch for two for $22 and walked away full. The staff are helpful and pleasant.
author: Alex T.

description: Great food (especially for the price)!   Pot stickers were great.  We ordered orange peel chicken, Kung pao chicken, sizzling spicy chicken, and chow mein.  Nothing was left!  I would highly recommend.  Not sure what the people ate that they said was bland. Our food had great flavor.  My son ordered the orange peel chicken and I wish I would have got it as well - it was awesome!
author: Steve P.

description: the hot and sour soup was great  the service and the rest of the food we had were also very good.  the only thing that wasn't that great was broccoli with oyster sauce. it was 95% stalk and no florets.  keep this in mind if you order it
author: Scott P.

description: The food was fantastic -- especially the xiao long bao.  You have to wait for them to cool off a little bit before you chomp into them, but then they are totally worth it!  The salty-spicy shrimp were perfect!
author: Chris W.

description:
My clients sent out for Chinese this time, instead of pizza.  Finally!  It was a welcome relief, and the food was OK.  The only hot dish they ordered was the Hunan Beef.  Everything else they ordered extra mild.  There were several vegetarian dishes.  The eggplant was tasty.  Mixed vegetables were OK.  

Bottom line:  Would I seek it out?  No. 

Update 10/19/2006:  
I'm upgrading my rating!  Although I didn't seek it out, the workgroup decided to party there today.  Food in the store is much better than the food delivered.  Service was good, and the barbeque was authentic Hunan, not the American style.  The rice had a flavor I couldn't get enough of.  Now I am convinced.  

Bottom line: Would I seek it out?  Yeah!  And recommend it to friends, too!
author: David D.

description: Picked up dinner on the way home from work since my husband was craving chinese take-out.  We ordered the beef lo mein and the orange chicken.  The orange chicken was good, but probably would have been better if we ate it at the restaurant.  It may have been a bit crispier if we ate it right away instead of letting it sit in the container for 15 minutes as we walked home. The lo mein was decent, tasty and greasy but not as greasy as some other places.  The woman who took our order at the front desk was nice.
author: Bling L.

description:
I could care less how "authentic" a Chinese place is. I'm an American, but I've eaten Chinese food my entire life. So I enjoy "good" more than "traditional". More often than not, hybrid/fusion/Americanized Chinese places are simply better than places that make you feel like you have to order in Chinese.

And that's the case for Hunan Homes. The chefs have skill and care about what they do. They go easy on the oil and use fresh ingredients. Their complimentary hot and sour soup is good. They have some unique dishes like the "Yummy Sliced Fish" that are as yummy as they are unusual. The Shanghai dumplings are very decent, especially for a place that doesn't specialize in dumplings. And for the protein-impaired among us, the vegetable dishes are good.

Enjoy!
author: Richard B.

description:
Service ***** Everyone was friendly and funny.

Food ***** Every dish tasted like it was described.  Best Chinese food      we've eaten. Many Chinese restaurants entrees have the same flavor. Not this place!  

Location ****
author: Hoku A.

description:
I love this restaurant. 
There are not a lot of restaurants that both have and get right my favorite dish, Salt and Pepper crab. For the uninitiated they batter a crab and fry the whole thing with tons of spicy peppers. 
This is not for the dainty as you end up getting pretty messy ripping the crab apart to get to the perfect meat. But rest assured they bring you a tea bowl and extra napkins for your fingers. 
Not only is HH S&P crab fantastic, everything else I have eaten there is also great. 
Additionally when my friend accidentally ate one of those chili's you aren't supposed to eat in something we ordered and looked like she might die, our waiter brought her a glass of milk even though he might of had to go to the store to get it. 
Thanks Hunan Homes!
author: Melissa H.

description: I am giving Hunan Homes five stars because I rate every Chinese Restaurant based on the hot & sour soup. It surpassed my favorite. The other food was very good but I couldn't get enough of the soup!
author: Jennifer B.

description:
This place is one of my favorite spots in Chinatown. It helps that both of my parents really like it and request to eat here most times that they're in the city to visit. 

They have really good spicy claypot, sliced fish, and spicy crispy chicken. Those are my favorites. Other good items are clams with black beans and deep fried scallops. YUM!

The lunch business seems to be booming. They have a good lunch special where you get a small bowl of hot and sour soup and a rice plate entree. For lunch I recommend the spicy crispy chicken or the yummy sliced fish (that's actually the  name, yummy sliced fish.)

The prices are not as cheap as other Chinatown joints, but it is well worth the few extra dollars.
author: ting b.

description: Not the VERY best chinese I've ever had but one of the better choices out there. The peking duck is simply wonderful.
author: Leo N.

description: Best chinese food in San Fran! We ordered the pot stickers! Great choice! Orange chicken and Kung Po chicken also great choices! Great service and packed out on a Monday night!
author: Tiffany T.

description: Reminded me the real Chinese tastes. Very nice food, regular service. Nice location and friendly owners.
author: Albert V.

description:
I just didn't have the same feeling of greatness from this place as some.  We did come later, and got in right before the cooks were leaving, which may have something to do with it.  We were rushed to order and rushed to eat, plus had to flag someone down to ask for drinks.  

The hot and sour soup was great, but our orange chicken and hunan chicken just wasn't that impressive.  It wasn't at all spicy and actually kind of bland.  The fired rice was just ok.. for the quality and quantity, we felt it was over priced as well.  We will not be returning.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
A small storefront leads into a surprisingly large dining area as one enters from a stretch of Jackson street that's mired between Chinatown, The Financial District, and the fuzzy edge of North Beach.  Medium sized tables cover the floor, while several rows of artificial bamboo eaves protrude garishly from the ceiling where their emerald green color forms a gruesome clash a with walls painted in donut-box pink.  There's two dining areas....a bustling one in front that's blessed with a small amount of natural light and a back area that handles larger crowds and lunchtime overflow.

Lightening fast service reflects a desire to maximize table turnover though the waitstaff is polite and never fails to greet, chat up, and briefly joke with anyone they recognize as a regular.

The lunch plates I've ordered don't give you the same bang-for-your-buck that you'll get in Daly City or the Outer Sunset, though they're quality and value are better than most you'd expect to find in these higher-rent surroundings. Service is fast, efficient, and businesslike....the waitstaff fills your water glass before it gets empty, and a check hits your table seconds after you request it.  While I've never eaten anything other than lunch here, the noontime vibe is definitely one of eat-and-exit rather than sit-and-socialize.

It's a great spot if you're looking for an affordable sit-down Chinese place, and especially so if you're on lunch-hour time constraints.  Furthermore, table-and-waiter service in combination with steam-tray deli pricing makes for a great lunch value.  My downtown client eats Chinese all the time in this area....it's her favorite, and one of mine too.  Mike says check it....
author: Mike W.

description: This was 3.5 stars.  An economical ($9) lunch with decent tasting cashew chicken and green beans.  It did seem to have an unhealthy dose of oil, however.
author: Niniane W.

description:
I'm korean, therefore I love me some good chinese food! I'm also severly biased when it comes to my chinese food. There's korean-chinese and then there's the plethora of hunan style, szechuan style and others I'm sure.  My caucasian husband dislikes chinese food, but whenever I'm in the mood for rice and spicy stir-fry foods, this is the place he'll take me to, because he actually likes it!  

I Love their hot n'sour soup, lemon chicken, mongolian beef and fried rice. Oh the fried rice! I love how it's light and tasty, not greasy. Last time we ate there, I had cubed chicken, deep fried with a spicy garlic sauce. It was very light, tasty and not drenched in sauce. Husband had sweet and sour pork. I'm not a fan of this dish, but the way they prepare it makes me like it.  Again, the sauce is light, not syrupy and the pork is still crispy and hot!
author: Joanne D.

description:
One of my all time favorite places in Chinatown.   The eggplant with chicken and prawns is definitely a hit - you can order other dishes like the stringbeans with chicken and savor the same sauce as the eggplant dish.  Would highly recommend to go during lunch - their lunch menu is under $10 accompanied by their complimentary hot and sour soup.  

The majority of the waiters speak perfect english (for those non-chinese patron).  Be sure to order their Chinese Coke (they like to joke about that!)
author: J H.

description: Our first visit to San Francisco and Chinatown - found them on yelp and were not disappointed!  Arrived at 11:45 on Friday without a reservation (party of 7) and they were able to seat us within 5 minutes. They got pretty busy just after that though. Hot & sour soup was excellent and was included with lunch special. Pot stickers were also very good. All entrees were tasty and devoured. Considering the bill was only $54 before tip, I'd consider it a great deal too. Would go back again!
author: Patty L.

description: Very good chinese food! Thanks yelp for the recommendation!
author: Chace D.

description: We were told that this place offer the best in SF. We ordered variety of food from apps to desserts. It was just okay and nothing special - maybe we should have ordered more Seafood since this is what they're known for?? But I really don't like Seafood so that wouldn't work for me here. However the owner was really nice and he tried very hard to pay attention to customers. He even made jokes to my kids. Now that's a good owner! Maybe I will give you another try...since the owner was so nice.
author: Myung S.

description: the food are ok, just ok. It's salty and with MSG with flavor catering westerners taste. that's why so many non-asian people go there. The price is not cheap.
author: Ying X.

description:
Awesome all-around!

This places started off on the right food with the smells.  Just stepping in made my stomach rumble!  After immediately getting a table and being greeted by a very friendly server, we enjoyed some incredibly good tea (some of the best I have ever had).

We had a $25 off coupon from restaurant.com that Hunan Homes was more than happy to accept (some places seem to become upset when you present them).

For $30 after tip, we had their won-ton soup, two full entrees (one was Kung Pao chicken) with brown rice, and an order of dim sum.  Each dish was very, very good!

Great food, very good prices, and great services equals zero complaints!
author: Charles B.

description:
I was in SF visiting family, and found Hunan Homes on Yelp and got a lot of kudos from the wife and mother in law for this one.   The hot and sour soup was the best I've ever had.  It was that perfect seasoning and texture where it's spicy and hot but not so much that you can't really taste the food.  Honestly, this may be the first time in my life where I've had this soup done right.  When you were done, there was this lovely aftertaste that you just enjoyed.  One of my Korean friends talks about enjoying the spice of a food after you're done eating.  Now I know what he meant.

The orange peel chicken was light and crispy and perfect.  I'd read about Hunan being a family business which was handed down from the father to his son James.  I realized that James was actually the one taking our order, and when I mentioned that I'd read about it being a a family business, people popped up around me talking about "the old man," even though he passed away something ten years ago.  This place has a history, clearly.

James didn't bat an eye when the wife and Mother-in-law asked to change their dishes due to dietary needs, or I'd review what they got too.  But clearly they're happy to accommodate vegetarians, etc.  Also, James is a funny guy.  He had us rolling with laughter right out the door.

This place is awesome.
author: Peter R.

description:
Chinese food isn't my favorite so I'm no expert, but this place has great food and a great staff that provides great service.  My friend and I had the Orange Peel Chicken which was delicious and the Kung Pao Beef which was also good.  A nice guy named Peter talked me out of a Bud light in favor of aTsingtao Light, which also was really good. 
The place is clean (the staff swept the carpet right away after the family with the small kids left). Nice prices too. I actually like it a little better than R&G, which is better for business lunches.
author: Britt C.

description: Really great little Chinese place. Service was friendly and the food was great. Reasonably priced and clean environment. The Hunan chicken was delicious and their fried rice isn't super greasy. I will definitely be going back!
author: Adrienne P.

description:
Absolutely delicious sweet and sour chicken. This was my first meal in China Town and I left very happy (and full). They also serve complimentary hot tea which was fantastic on a mild, rainy afternoon. The fried wontons were also delicious. 

Service was attentive and everyone at the table enjoyed their meal.
author: Andrea M.

description:
Not the best Chinese food I've ever had, but definitely way up there on my list.

Service was busy, so we had to grab their attention once. But, James, our waiter, was really good! He was very friendly, gave us a suggestion on menu choice, and joked with us the whole meal.

I'll definitely be going back when I'm in Chinatown next.

Oh, and at least on a Saturday night, it was REALLY busy. We had reservations, so we just walked in, but there was a crowd of 20-30 people waiting outside.
author: Greg S.

description: Americanized Chinese. Uninspired and dull. Service not much better. Def not 4 stars. Appears they cater to large tour groups. They sat 3 groups of about 20 people as we waited for our table. Tour guides yelling instructions for their adult charges to sit first then go to restroom in pairs to wash their hands. That was about as enjoyable as it got. Ordered Hunan scallops. Ten scallops, ten hot peppers, some celery and a few carrots. Rice extra. Costco egg rolls were great though. San Fran, Chinatown,really?
author: michael d.

description: First time in Chinatown and had to stop in.  Orange chicken light and delicious, sweet and sour soup great kick and flavor.  Green beens were amazing and we customized our order to accommodate no pork.  Service was fast, but lacking in friendliness and hospitality!  Overall would come back for the food despite the service.  Good portion, good price, good value.
author: Bernole N.

description:
I discovered this great restaurant purely by luck about 18 years ago.  We just picked it at random for lunch one day while in Chinatown.  Have been going ever since for both lunch and dinner.  Great luncheon specials that have probably increased by a about a dollar in 18 years!  Lunch portions are HUGE for the price.

While dinner is pricier it is still reasonable and very good.

Food is always hot and fresh.  Service is very quick and very attentive.  Great Hot and Sour Soup.  Moo Shu is terrific.  Never really had  a bad dish. 

I went to Brandy Ho the other day for lunch with an out of town guest who picked it --- if this is 4 stars -- Brandy Ho is about negative 4 stars.  No comparison.
author: Phil C.

description:
This location is not as good as their Los Altos location.  I forgot the story, but I believe they are separately operated by siblings or something. Whatever the story, the city one just doesn't compare. My review of their Los Altos location:

http://www.yelp.com/biz/IaXQrIJIJw0OcXyl70_wIQ?hrid=kofgM5iFD46u6vAYxWftMA
author: Bernard M.

description:
We were in china town and came across this place because one of the stores we went in recommended it.  it was odd walking down china town at night on a weekday, but this place was super packed!  as we got there, it was a typical asian restaurant greeting (kind of polite--sorta) but the waiter was cool cause i mentioned who recommended us. 

 we sat at a table downstairs and ordered the sizzling prawns and salty squid.  my bf LOVED the prawns, and i thought it was good, but the sauce wasn't very asian.  it was tomato-y and garlicky and yum.  the salty shrimp was not my bf's taste, but it thought it was great.  salty and crunchy and great with rice.  i definitely recommend this place for anyone heading to china town.  =)
author: thai p.

description: My husband and I stayed at the Omni hotel and decided we wanted to eat somewhere in China town for dinner . We were standing in line at a different restaurant on the street when a local gave us the advice to go to Hunan Homes . I am SOOO thankful that he took the time to let us know . When we walked in we were greeted by a very friendly smile and efficient hostess . While we were waiting for a table to be cleaned off a few people were leaving and told us we wouldn't regret our choice . We sat down and were almost instantly given a pot of hot tea. We ordered pork dumplings and they were amazing ! They came out quickly and were delicious ! The lady that brought them out made us a sauce for them and was very friendly! We stayed in San Fran for 4 days and this restaurant by far has the best service !!!!!! We ordered the Orange peel chicken , Kung pao chicken and fried rice ! The food was outstanding ! Again, the service was amazing! I highly recommend this restaurant when visiting China Town!
author: Amy D.

description: It would not be unfair to tell one of the best restaurant in china town. I had here two times I was really impress with the food ,service n ambience .yesterday I went with my frens we order app for pot-stickers N entree fired rice ,veg noodles ,dried asparagus  n chicken items lastly couple bottle of hot saki my ferns also impress with over all restaurant 1 hr time good time hope to visit
author: raja g.

description: This is where white ppl go eat in SF Chinatown. Being an avid fan of a very authentic NYC Chinatown restaurant, I was slightly disappointed in us for eating here. However, sometimes you're just in the mood for a tablecloth and friendly service
author: Mia-Mia B.

description: My wife and I went here because she saw some good reviews and had a restaurant.com coupon.  I thought the food was good and the service excellent.  I think I was more impressed by the food than her, but we agree their service was excellent.  We ordered their Hot and Sour Soup, which was good and there was enough that we ended up taking some home.  I had the Tai Chin Chicken which was good and she had a sizzling beef platter, which was OK, but not great (this may be why my wife wasn't impressed).  The ingredients seemed fresh and I liked that the chicken didn't have a coating on it like some other Chinese restaurants we've tried who seem to put it on everything.  We also shared an Asparagus dish which was very good.  Even though I ordered the chicken spicy, I had to add some chili sauce to it.  The waiter was very friendly and super attentive.  He also explained the way to enjoy the chilies in my chicken dish, which no one had ever explained.  I enjoyed the restaurant, but I'm not sure I'll become a regular.  It's a bit of a drive, but probably my favorite Chinese place so far in the area is Egg Roll King in Daly City.  I'll keep trying to find as good of place in the city.
author: Scott L.

description:
We were walking around Chinatown in San Francisco, on December 1, 2009.   It was noon, we were hungry, but were overwhelmed by the options.  I went to my yelp iphone ap, and searched near us, and found Hunan Homes.  

We ordered eggrolls, mu shu pork and curry chicken.  Everything was fantastic!   Hot and sour soup was yummy!   If I would change anything~ leave out the curry chicken and get more mu shu pork!

We went back later in the week, every dish was great (again).
author: Avonna S.

description: Seriously, best Chinese food ever. Witty Waitress too. There is usually a short wait to get in but tolerable.
author: Kathleen F.

description: Went here while in town because of high yelp reviews...was not impressed. We thought it would be extraordinary being in Chinatown but tasted like any Chinese take out back home.
author: A B.

description: The food was pretty good.  The spicy wontons and the hot and sour soup were especially good.  Not a particularly spicy restaurant though.  Had hoped for a little more bite but very tastee otherwise.
author: Gene K.

description: Good food, although not exactly authentic, and not a unique culinary experience that you would plan a trip to Chinatown to experience. But on spur of the moment lunch terms, it was very satisfying.
author: Nathan J.

description: You fancy huh? No really the most fanciest place I have ever eaten Chinese food in. I am used to informal dining spaces in Chinese restaurants. I was surprised to be served fresh hot tea as soon as I sat down for dinner. You walk through San Frans China town to get to this unusually fancy restaurant. I was sad that they didn't have my favorite dish sesame chicken but it opened up my choices and forced me to try new things.
author: Heide E.

description: Nothing special. With it listed in our travel guide and recommended by the hotel I thought it would be fantastic. Ultimately it was a disappointment. It felt like they didn't much care if we were there or not. They were preparing vegetables at a table in the dining room.  Despite seeming to be slow for lunch they took forever to take our order, had no suggestions for us, didn't put much effort into serving it, and the food was not great. If we lived here we wouldn't be back.
author: Brad P.

description: There was a piece of paper in my hot and sour soup!!!   This is Americanized Chinese food, not at all authentic.  Do not recommend.
author: D Z.

description: Really nice restaurant, great and fun servers, pleasant place to share dinner with old friends. I wanted to give Hunan 4 stars, but the food was not quite to the level that makes me want to come back. I'll likely try other Chinese restaurants before returning, but the maitre'd was so intriguing and fun, he makes me want to return. We'll see.
author: Keith R.

description: Four of us went to Hunan Homes based on yelp.com reviews, and we are so glad we did! We chose to do the Family Menu (option B, back of menu) because their menu is huge and we didn't want to look through it all, and because it included the hot and sour soup that was much talked about in the reviews. The soup it AMAZING! We couldn't stop eating it, and left craving more. Everything else that was served to us was delicious and the portions were huge. The restaurant is a little run-down, so if you're looking for an upscale place, this isn't it. But overall, we were looking for yummy food and we definitely found it. Thanks for a great night, Hunan!
author: Jessika R.

description: One of the good cheap gems in Chinatown near Jackson & Kearney.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I went here with 7 other people  and our total came to about $170.00. We had about 7 main course dishes, plus dumplings and jellyfish appetizers and soup, and I think most of us had a beer. A bit expensive, but the food was good enough so I'm not really complaining.  Everything was very fresh and tasty, but the prawns with walnuts were particularly delicious - crispy and sweet on the outside, soft prawn flavor on the inside, and the walnuts really complemented it. Definitely try it if you go. 

The restuarant itself is pretty clean, as others have mentioned, and they earned a 71 from the SF Department of Public Health's food safety program, which I guess is OK. (Although on some level, who really cares about scores? I ate at this one dim sum place that got a 31 and I'm still standing - can't let rodents and lack of sanitization deter you from good food.) 

Finally, I thoroughly enjoyed the Finding Nemo and large dolphin stickers on the bright blue walls upstairs.
author: Annee T.

description: Went here after a birthday happy hour last weekend.  I must say I had my buzz going before I ate so they could have served me last nights dish and I would have ate it!  But really, the food was very tasty, but somewhat to salty and I think they use some kind of MSG because I felt sooooo bloated that it was on the verge of uncomfortable.  I thought, did I eat too much?  Nah!  Its was the M to the S to the G thing baby!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Dan Z.

description: Good, but the Hunan beef had an odd preponderance of celery.
author: Robert W.

description: a must when you are in china town. An authentic China Town hole in the wall, no ambiance, but good service and food.
author: Kayt B.

description:
A few years ago, a friend of the Dearly Departed Daddy recommended we try this little place and boy-oh-boy has it held up to stiff competition across the city, the state and the country. 

Because the Dearly Departed and his boys of summer  travel so much, they don't put up with nonsense, at least when it comes to satisfying their monster apetites. So, we found ourselves in this humble abode, sampling what was touted as the best honey walnut prawns in the city. 

And whaddya know, the Kool-aid was real. 

This prawn dish is lightly breaded, fried and served with candied pecans and a tangy mayo-esque sauce. Normally, this girl tries to be good, but every once and a while, I've got to give into temptation and enjoy the sweet rewards. 

Everything else on the menu is straight-forwardly good and reasonably priced.  And if you prefer something else that's not on the enormous menu, just ask and they'll make what ever you like. I've done that several times, and an extra buck or two is not too much to pay for the royal treatment, is it?

Over the years, I've tried, tried, tried other places near and far, but always end up back at Homes. And it's my go-to place when visiting friends and family want a little dining experience in China Town. 

The only down side: at times, the service can be a little too efficient, and you feel rushed. 

Overall: Honey, I'm nuts about this place.
author: CharliesAngel L.

description:
Went there for a banquet with the clients for Macworld (right, business party and THIS is where they book? Go figure).

The most entertaining aspect (aside from 50 computer geeks locked in a room being forced to be sociable) was the service. Every course was preceded by precise instructions as to which sauce was to be used with which item, and points were automatically deducted for reaching out for food, emptying your glass before they were ready to refill or wanting to go to the bathroom. Aside from that, our guards - eh, servers - were extremely efficient and quick.

The food was ok, some dishes, like the whole broiled fish and the sizzling rice soup were very good, others, like the mystery beef with unidentified vegetables were disgusting.

2 1/2 adequate stars.
author: Tatjana G.

description: Great value, reliable and delicious food....no surprises at this old stand by.  The service is fast, friendly and the food very tasty just not for the adventurous eater.  Our group if 14 had a great meal in the basement dining room....not much in the way of decor but I'd go back in a heartbeat,
author: Lisa B.

description: Nothing special  about the food to merit a higher review although the service is great.
author: Alfredo G.

description: I went with a large group from work (25 people). My boss raves about this place and picked it.  I really enjoyed it. One of the better Chinese restaurants I have been to in SF.  He pre-ordered a bunch of dishes so there was no ordering.  But there was a good choice of different dishes, but I don't remember the names of them.  I would go back again.
author: Mike E.

description: Typical Chinatown hole-in-the-wall with tasty food.  Cant say I'd go out of my way to go back, but if a group decided to eat there I wouldnt say no either.
author: brewgirl b.

description: Very enjoyable Chinese dining experience.....  Hot and sour soup is the best we ever had, awesome!.....  Whole crab in spicy salt another winner!
author: Stacy S.

description: The food was good and so was the service, I liked my husbands dinner better ( as i usually do) - string beans with beef..but did not like mine as much - hot spicy crispy chicken (which sounds better than it tastes). The pork potstickers and the hot and sour soup were as good as the hype indicates :)!
author: B P.

description:
Not very impressed.   I ordered fried rice and salt baked pork chops.  The price was standard (about $9-10 per entree) but the portion was literally half of what other restaurants give...  I thought I ordered enough for two people but nope...

Their salt baked pork chops tasted awful too.
author: Roy M.

description:
I've had a lot of Chinese food in my life, and this was probably among the worst.  I ordered three appetizers: dumplings, spare ribs and egg rolls.

The dumplings were good.  But the egg rolls were too greasy to eat (and seemed to contain only oil and cabbage) and the spare ribs looks more like knuckles than ribs to me.  Lots of white cartilage sticking out.  I took a couple bites and it was also tough - too tough to eat.  I got out of there and went to Buster's on Columbus for a Philly Steak. Now THAT was a great meal.
author: Kevin D.

description: I found this place through yelp on a recent trip to san fran. Yelp didn't let me down! the food and service were wonderful and the restaurant was very clean. I really enjoyed the potstickers. They were big and delicious! You have to walk by the kitchen on your way to the restroom so I looked inside. The kitchen was very clean and organized... something not very common in many chinese kitchens! I will definitely come back next time I'm in town. Highly recommended.
author: Brandon K.

description: I came here for dinner with my parents while visiting sf. There was a 15 minute wait and as we were waiting outside for our table I noticed a dead fly and a live fruit fly inside the restaurants front window. As we were waiting there also seemed to be large tourist groups that were showing up w a guide and going inside for dinner. I didn't take any of this to be a good sign. Once we sat down we were promptly given menus and warm weak tea. Then we waited for approximately ten minutes for someone to come by and take our order. I would normally flag someone down but that wasn't possible here, anyone who walked by was paying us no mind and in a v big hurry. If you would like anything to drink other than weak yea you need to ask for it, you won't even be offered water. Our check never came. That also took forever and we ended up walking up to the hostess stand to pay so that we could finally leave. The food itself was pretty ok. I don't know enough about Chinese food to determine how authentic it was but it was tasty and to me that's all I care about. Overall it was an ok experience
author: lydia d.

description: Well for Chinese food this is the most Amazing food I have ever had, Its in China Town.We ordered Pot Stickers,Barbeque Pork Fried Rice,Pork Chow Mein,Egg Rolls,Sweet and Sour Pork with that amazing orange sauce. The food was hot and fresh.I loved this place so much I ate here twice while being in San Francisco. Will Highly Recommend for any tourist or local residence. You wont get any better than this.Great service also. Ann
author: Ann R.

description: We found this place using yelp while walking through china town 8 months ago. I am not big on Chinese food but I find myself craving this place. We've been here three times in 8 months and we live 500 miles away.  We've been in large groups and as a couple. We pick from the whole meals labeled A thru C every time and then add half a Peking duck. I think we might just go back tonight now that it's on my mind.
author: John B.

description:
*3.5 stars*  (Sorry, can't quite give it 4 stars even though I rather enjoyed this place.)

Grab me a tissue, will you?  The sinuses always clear up when I eat Hunan food, which, by the way, I'm not the biggest fan of.  But for some reason, I ended up here after about an hour of trying to figure out where/what to eat...

Pretty damn good!  I ordered the eggplant w/ chicken & shrimp and it was deeelissh-ous!  Food was not at all greasy unlike the oily grub from Henry's (which I happen to crave from time to time) and the sauce was not an ugly brown color (like food from Henry's).

So yeah, cute food, cute restaurant decor (by Chinatown standards, anyway), decent food (OK, this was my first time and I only tried the one dish plus the OK hot & sour soup) - I'd come back the next time I have a taste for Hunan food...
author: Christine T.

description: I have lunch there mostly but occasionally I have dinner there as well.  Like past Saturday evening.   We ordered a few appetizers including succulent bread & fried tofu, we loved both!    The service was very good, as always!
author: Linda L.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants as a kid.  Used to come here quite often as my aunt owned a bakery a couple blocks away.  After the bakery reached closing time, we would often come here in large groups with my grandma, aunts, uncles and cousins.  

So if you can think of an Italian family at their usual Family restaurant, this is what Hunan Homes was to me.  

A Plus is that I love this cuisine.  Love spicy Chinese food with all the flavors and sauces.  Perfect with White Rice...  

The prices are now a little higher than what I am used to paying for Chinese food but for me to go back in time, sure, I'll come back once in a while...
author: Mark W.

description:
Overall, Hunan Homes gets a 1 star. 

We ate here on Sun, Aug 31st. 2008, about 8pm.  First and LAST time.
Service was AWFUL.  AWFUL. The best service we received here was from the busboy who cleared off our table.

30 minute wait to get seated. No problem. We had no reservations, so I was okay with that.

At least 20 minutes to get someone to bring us MENUS. Yes, MENUS!
We had to flag someone down. 

Unbelievably, after getting our menus, it took another 20 minutes for someone to show up to take our order, and this ONLY after flagging down our busboy to send over a waiter. No kidding!

By this time, the only thing that could save our dining experience was that the food would be INCREDIBLY good. We ordered a simple orange peel  chicken, vegetable chow mein, and rice. Thank goodness, it didn't take an hour to get to us.

Unfortunately, the food DID NOT make up for the wait. The orange chicken was okay, the vegetable chow mein barely had any vegetables, and the rice was rice. 

I think we could have walked out without paying and no one would have noticed. Maybe we SHOULD have.

Based on reviews on Yelp and other places, this was the China Town restaurant that we decided to try. It was the ONLY Chinese food we were going to have on our visit to Frisco, so I did the research, and figured we'd do the tourist thing and have chinese food in China Town. 

What is everyone talking about here? Service was horrible and food was average.
author: Shinobu K.

description: Great Restaurant in the Chinatown. Have been there a couple of times. Wallet friendly yet a great food. Recommended!
author: Lata N.

description: Good food worth going back for. I enjoyed the pot stickers, roast pork appy, and chicken and broccoli with white garlic sauce.
author: Debbie R.

description:
Lunch time is the best time to go...

You can get a very filling AND delicious meal for TWO all for around 20 bucks. 

I recently visited with a friend and ordered their lunch special with the orange peel chicken and another savory dish. I really enjoyed the hot and sour soup. Cannot find another Chinese restaurant that serves such good soup! 

Minus 1 start only for the waiter who took our order. I have heard of many horror stories of bad waiter service and never really thought it would happen to me. And so far it hasn't, I just didn't like the amount of attitude we received when we were ordering. I know, we all have bad days and I'm not expecting you to kiss up to me, but please, just be a bit more courteous.
author: Peit P.

description:
I love this restaurant.

Now I haven't been to every Chinese restaurant, but I have been to a few, and this place is in my top two. 

The other favorite, Best Hong Kong Dining, is located in Mesa Arizona, and particularly impressed me by steaming there bell peppers with a little bit of jasmine flower water before adding it to their black bean chicken.

But Hunan Homes is just as good.
Things to order here:
Sauteed snowpea leaves (in season)
Crab in scallion/ginger sauce
fried bread (don't ask -just order it -its GOOOD!)
Salt Pepper Pork Chops
and
dare I say
The best sizzling rice soup on the planet?
There is a sister restaurant in Los Altos where they used to know me well. The service is always impeccable and the food is flash fast unless it is Sunday Dim Sum -and then- well- it isn't THEIR FAULT that all the crowds come and invade them is it?
author: Kimberley M.

description:
I went here for lunch today, and it was great! I had the Hunan Beef lunch special, which came with sweet & sour soup, dish & rice, and oranges.  I really enjoyed the food here, and definitely will go back soon. The Hunan Beef dish had cabbage (which is always good with the brown sauce), bamboo shoots, mushrooms, and lots of other veggies which went well with the slices of thick beef. 

My friend got the kanpao prawns, and that was super delish! We were sitting and talking for about an hour, and they were really nice about it; I know most Chinese restaurants give you a hard time!  If anyone works in the financial district, go here for lunch one day. Super good, super cheap (my dish was $6.25), and very fulfilling for a chinese restaurant.
author: Chieko H.

description: I can't believe I hadn't been to this place before I found it on Restaurant.com.  Even though we received a large discount on our final bill, I would definately go back and pay full price!  We had the sizzlin' beef, kung pao prawns, combo fried rice and potstickers, all which were delicious!  I can't wait to go back~
author: Dana D.

description: I am a big fan of chinese food and eat it all around the country at least 25 times per year.  We had a great meal there with my family on vacation.  Pot stickers and hot and sour soup were both very tasty.  All our entrees were very flavorful except for beef and broccoli, which we would strongly recommend you skip.  The pink decor is a throw back and the service is spotty, although our waiter did have some funny banter with us.  I would absolutely go back again and plan to on my next visit to the area.
author: Jill S.

description: Great place for an afternoon lunch in Chinatown. I recommend putting a focus on the Hot and Sour soup with the Kung Pao Prawns.
author: Kelly K.

description: As always, I hit up Hunan Homes when I came back to the city. AMAZING! I had to use a fork this time because the chop sticks didn't let me shovel it in my mouth
author: Jonny J.

description:
I've been here so many times. Hunan Homes has been a long time family favorite, and their spicy dishes are the perfect Chinese comfort food for a cold winter's day. We haven't been disappointed yet by any of their dishes. The last time we went was around Christmas. We ordered, among many other things, the fried salt and pepper squid, sauteed green beans, a smoked ham dish, and our usual chafing dish stew with pig's blood, pig's intestine, tofu, preserved vegetables, and chives. 

That last dish might sound a bit disgusting to some, but it is the best dish on the menu. It is the only entry not in English. Order it! I myself am a bit grossed out by pig's blood, but the dish is so good that I just pick out the cubes of  blood and give it to my parents instead. The sauce is amazing! Don't let the gross factor deter you.
author: Michael F.

description: Second trip to San Francisco in a row where we made sure Hunan Homes was on the dinner list.  The hot & sour soup is fantastic but large (even when you order the small).  The potstickers are a must (we rarely eat pork but made an exception).  Ask for the garlic sauce (or any of their sauces) to go with it because they only bring vinegar and chili sauce.  The orange peel is delightful (although I ordered brown rice and just wanted a little an they brought what seemed like enough for 8 ppl).  The Kung Pao combination of beef, chicken & shrimp was delish!  Highly recommend.  They also have a large tank with live crab an I saw a really good looking dish of crab going o another table so you may want to consider that but I can't give a review because I was too full to order anything else.  Enjoy!
author: Fawn W.

description: Great Chinese food! They can get better customer service skills but the food makes up for it! Highly recomment this place for lunch! Enjoy!
author: jen b.

description: Good American style Chinese food.  Great service, loved the hot and sour soup.   Orange peel chicken was on point as well.
author: Ari F.

description: Best chinese i've had in a while. It was recommended by the hotel and word of mouth. The waiter was ok, little short with us but adds to the experience. Haha.
author: Garrett B.

description: Yum! I recommend the Xiao Long Bao, Sizzling Chicken, Hunan String Beans and Yang Chow Fried Rice. Then roll me home.
author: Emily B.

description: One word describes this restaurant. TERRIBLE. Save your money and go somewhere else. The food is absolutely tasteless. This should be a 1-star rated restaurant. The waitstaff is rude and left me with a feeling of being rushed to finish my meal. This was a very bad overall experience.
author: Robert F.

description: We have traveled throughout Asia and lived in  Japan.  Nothing we have had in the U.S. compares to the best there, but this is close.  The Tri-seafood and Happy Fish were terrific.  The pot stickers were very good.  The service was efficient and precise.  I would revisit Hunan Homes if ever again I visit Chinatown.
author: Tom R.

description:
One of the best Chinese restaurants in Chinatown, and I've been to a lot of them. Just go, you won't be disappointed. 

Pros:

Excellent food.
Great price.
Kid friendly; large area in the basement for families where you can put your strollers etc.

Minor nitpicks:

Service is brusque but not bad or unfriendly. They're just busy, because it's usually (and not surprisingly) packed. So not a big deal, just thought I'd mention it so you're not surprised.
Their child seats look as though they come from communist China, but they are functional.

Recommended: Peking Duck.
author: Frey V.

description: Fabulous Orange chicken and light egg rolls
author: Molly S.

description:
this is the real deal if you like tasty chinese food without the weird dim sum- type stuff.  

Kung Pao chicken-- great
Orange chicken-- great 
veggie dish-- great 

takeout was fast, packed well.  

note:  yup it's americanized, but that only means that you get white meat in your chicken dishes when feasible, and there is no mystery in the cooking, and the restaurant is clean and presentable.  i noticed that some who gave Hunan Homes one star still ate the leftovers the next day.
author: eshwar k.

description: This place is for non-Asian customers.  This  is not authentic Chinese place. I should read the review carefully next time.  We were the only 2 Asian customers.
author: F N.

description:
We went here tonight based on some of the reviews on this site.  They're only a few blocks from our house.  What can I say?  Delicious, delicious, delicious. We started with potstickers, since they're my favorite.  They were the best.  A lot of people on this site mentioned the honey walnut prawns. Holy crap, they were mouth-wateringly good.  We also had the double mushroom with prawns and scallops.  Also delicious and such a creamy sauce they were in!  There were so many tempting things on the menu, but I know when I go back (most likely  next week), I'll order the honey walnut prawns.

What else I liked: the serving sizes were normal. Usually when you go to a restaurant they give you a ridiculously large amount of food.  These were regular portion sizes and I appreciated that. I hate getting three portions on one plate.

As a former waitress, my standards are pretty high as far as service goes, and the staff here more than surpassed it.  I couldn't believe how attentive the service was. Right before our potstickers came out, the server mixed a little sauce of hot oil, vinegar, and soy at our table, and when the stickers came out, they actually served us the first ones.  Our drinks were kept filled at all times (and letting my water get low is my biggest peeve in a restaurant).

Caveat: this place crawls with hick tourists.  One man kept trying to tell his server about "how they do "egg drop soup" in Florida."  Oy vey, what a knob.  But it was worth it for the delicious food and wonderful service.  This is my new favorite Chinatown Chinese restaurant.
author: Jamie C.

description:
My fiance and I always make a point of eating at this place when we are up in the city. The staff are friendly and everything we try is very tasty.

Favorites:
spicy garlic eggplant (yu xiang qie zi)
spicy tofu (ma po dou fu)
Chinese donut (you tiao)
fish flavor pork (yu xiang rou si)
brazed short ribs (wu xi jiang pai gu)
author: Brian R.

description:
A superior Chinese restaurant. Not necessarily the most innovative dishes...but classics (which is what I want most of the time) rendered with superior skill.

Flavorful stir fries that still maintained the texture of the ingredients and crispiness of the vegetables. Not excessively oily. Potstickers beautifully browned. Very helpful wait staff. I'll be back.
author: Allen C.

description: We were here for business near Union Square, so it was an easy walk to come to Hunan Homes in China town.  Have to admit we came here because it caters to Caucasians.  Hey we are from Wyoming!  We came on a Tuesday night and got right in and served fast.  We got the family meal on the back of the menu.  We loved the egg rolls and pot stickers.  We wanted more. The dinner was very good.  We flipped for the shrimp with walnuts.  We all were fighting for the last piece. We felt we made an excellent choice.
author: Mike G.

description: I came here with my husband at the start of our holiday weekend in San Francisco. The other reviews have been pretty accurate regarding the food and ambiance. This was definitely one of the clean restaurants in Chinatown. We ordered the combination appetizer with fried prawns,potstickers, and egg rolls. Then had the Hunan beef, sizzling beef and fried rice with pork and shrimp. Everything was delicious but the potstickers were a bit overhyped.  The service started out slow as we waited five minutes before we received menus. However, the staff and owner became really friendly later in our dining experience, thus I'm giving them back the fourth star. Very reasonably priced and I would recommend it.
author: Kellie N.

description: Their Food was acceptable but not authentic Hunan style food. The food more like for American people taste and Cantonese style. If you looking for real Hunan food u will be disappoint by this place!!!!!!!
author: Jian Cheng Z.

description:
This was my first time here... and definitely not my last.  The service was amazing.. our waiter was very attentive and humorous. The food was outstanding and overall experience was positive. We ordered a bunch of different entrees for our table to share, which were all really good. Amongst our favorites were the Mongolian Beef, Orange Peel Chicken and the Combination Fried Rice.  

One last thing... when I went it was so incredibly busy with people just lined up to put in their name for a table.  When I got to the front, I was told a 45- 60 min wait.  So, I put in my name and phone  # and after just 10 minutes, I got a call from the restaurant telling us they could seat us now! How awesome is that?! Talk about top notch customer service.  Thanks for a great time!
author: April B.

description: Really great egg rolls and pot stickers. Great prices as well.
author: Joel C.

description:
Ate here during a San Francisco vacation based off of reviews. Went around 2pm, so the restaurant was pretty quiet. Service and food were excellent! The kung pao chicken was especially good. 

Would definitely recommend!
author: Katherine F.

description: I guess it's a matter of expectations.  I followed the yelp reviews and went to Hunan because of its high ratings.  The bottom line is that the food is quite mediocre, the decor is decent and clean, the service is very fast, and it's a nice, safe Chinese restaurant in the heart of Chinatown.  The first thing i noticed after sitting down is that there were zero Chinese people eating there; that should have been my clue.  If you want something safe, solid and comfortable, this place works.  If you want to experience Chinatown and eat where the locals eat, I would avoid this restaurant.  I would not recommend this restaurant.
author: michael r.

description: We really enjoyed the orange peel chicken from the set menu Type C; all together a good dining experience and good value too. Busy with a good mixed clientele. Exactly what we were looking for in Chinatown.
author: Tim A.

description: We dined here on Chinese New Year's Day. Despite a discount offer we were treated really well. The service is excellent. The food was very well also. Hot and Sour Soup was excellent, I even spotted a few peas in there. Entrees were strong as well. The experience was delightful, even exceeding expectations. Our old Hunan joint now has competition.
author: Frugal B.

description: Wonderful hot and sour soup. Extensive Hunan entrees.  One of my favorite SF restaurants.
author: Mark H.

description: I am still liking this place. Veggie mu shu was excellent. It's hard to eat at a place like this when you are dining alone. You can only get one or two dishes.
author: Scott M.

description: this review is for the xlb alone. (i had a few other things. they werent memorable.) xlb was ok. but i think the spot on balboa is better (both spots)
author: Lisa N.

description: This place definitely lives up to its rating. My coworkers and I came here for weekend brunch, the food was excellent.  The soy milk and salted rice balls are the items to die for on the menu.  Not to mention the great service, we left with big smile on our faces.  I will definitely come back for weekend brunch!
author: Avril C.
