description: after reading all the positive reviews about this place my family and I decided to come take a look during our trip to SF. sad to say that what we experienced was not nearly as great as the reviews on here. we ordered vegetable pot stickers for our appetizer, and while the pot stickers themselves were alright, we received no special dipping sauce and were told to use soy sauce when asked. for dinner we ordered veggie fried rice, kung pao chicken, and cashew prawns. while the entrees were okay, the worst part was our service. our waiter barely made eye contact with us throughout the evening and had to be asked multiple times for things like water, sugar, the works. altogether was an okay meal but I've got to say, we were a bit disappointed.
author: Maya C.

description: Very mediocre.  What's all the hype?!?!    Seriously- I've had better orange chicken at a chain restaurant?  Mongolian beef?  So much garlic I could hardly taste the ultra chewy meat.  NOT as amazing as is reviewed.
author: Jayne M.

description: Ok, we love chinese food. This is in China Town, and we were on a mission to eat our way through there and find a great place! This was our first one, day one. We went at lunch time. Some of these places in China town are funny, they just put hot tea on the table, I guess assuming that everyone wants it, and that's that. But it was an amazing Jasmine tea. Really, I could have just stayed there and drank that stuff. We did order the typical things Americans order. Sesame chicken, egg rolls, dumplings. It really was not bad. The service was a little brusk and put-offish. There were two women running the show. Male waiters. No smiles or any pleasantries whatsoever. When we left, the older of the two women was at the door, and she said nothing. So my husband said "Thank You!" She said "Uh huh." We had a good laugh, and lunch was not bad. By the end of the week it turned out to be one of the better, food wise, that we went to in China Town.
author: Nancy P.

description: Excellent little place in Chinatown. The Hunan smoked pork was out of this world.  We also had the Hunan Chicken which was also great.  Both had a very nice heat that would sneak up on you.  Lots of food for very reasonable prices.  We picked a winner with this place.
author: Gary W.

description: This place was very good.  I went with a good group of people and was lucky enough to try several things family style.  My favorite dishes I tried were the salt and pepper spareribs, shrimp walnut prawns and the string beans.  I tried several other things that were also very good, but these were my favorites.
author: Crystal Z.

description: Definitely try the hunan string beans and orange peel chicken with steamed rice.
author: Alexander C.

description: Very pleasant service, above average food (we really liked the wanton soup), bland decor, moderately priced.
author: Ken K.

description: I decided to try Hunan Home after a reccomendation from a friend.  I had a large group and wanted to make sure we could go somewhere in Chinatown that could accomadate us.  The restuarant is in the heart of Chinatown and the ambience is nothing special.  We were promtly greeted and seated once we arrived.  The menu is very large and there is a wide variety to choose from. Unfortunately in the past restuarants with large menus underwhelm with the actual food.  This place was no different.  For me the food tasted like a normal Chinese restaurant I could find anywhere in the US.   I even tried a few other peoples dishes at the table and still felt the same.  I see this place has some good reviews but I can't agree.  The service was also underwhelming.  The place was not busy so there was no reason for the service to be so slow.  Also, our waiter had no idea what Siracha was.  I asked multiple people and they seemed confused and told me they didn't carry it.  On top of that on my way out I saw a big bottle sitting at the bar!
author: Sayjul P.

description: chinatown small street dining...chinese hunan homes...various dishes....from chicken to beef....eggplants to tofu....portions smaller noticing for same pricing elsewhere...finding variety to be uni-sauce seasoning...bored of similar tastes...just different texture...good for solo dinner....rice and one item....group dinners finding disappointing by lack of taste variation....uni-flavor...
author: Hen A.

description: Excellent. Every dish is a treat. Don't expect the staff to fall over you because they don't. But the great food makes up for anything the staff may not do. Everything is fresh and tasty. The wife loves the shrimp. Our son enjoys the spicy beef and I had a pork dish that was also very good. The starter plate was also very tasty.
author: richard b.

description:
This restaurant is definitely on my top 10 list! I've been eating Chinese food all my life and I didn't really expect much when I stepped into Hunan Homes. However, every single plate I try/order is so good that it keeps me curious about what else this place has to offer. Some of my favorites include the duck wrap, honey walnut prawns, and their sizzling platers(please excuse my if-fy descriptions of their food!). On top of the superb quality of the food, I absolutely love the cleanliness of the restaurant! Honestly, I've been to many Chinese restaurants which are "icky" - with my standards, I consider them filthy. But Hunan Homes is so well-kept that I feel perfectly comfortable with dining there. 

Their prices are very reasonable and it is a great place for tourists, groups, and kids! I also think that the services are fantastic. To sum things up, I would definitely recommend Hunan Homes because of the delicious food, welcoming atmosphere, and the owners are so awesome!
author: Kelly Y.

description: My friend and I felt kind weird walking inside because there was no Asians eating here haha ! Seriously .. I don't think I've ever seen a Chinese restaurant without one single Asian customer dining there . I had the ma por tofu which was not bad ... it was decent . I asked for very spicy but it was only a little spicy . My friend complained that his fried rice had grains of salt on the pieces of egg lol . Oh , and the bathroom smells HORRIBLE .
author: Eileen L.

description: Pretty tasty. Had wonton soup, Hunan prawns and scallops and pork fried rice. Green tea was excellent. Wonton soup was some of the best I've had. Main entree was decent--not too spicy and good portion size. Prawns and scallops was not on the menu but they obliged me. Pork fried rice was adequate. Didn't knock me off my feet but had the perfect wok taste I love (does that make sense?).
author: Bryce K.

description:
Very Good
Solid Four Stars

Best Dishes
Hot & Sour Soup
BBQ Pork Fried Rice
Pot Stickers
Mu Shu Pork

This is one of the best for 
"Old School" Chinese In San Francisco
author: Tommy T.

description: I don't really enjoy Chinese food that much (other than dim sum), but I have to admit this place is good.  The potstickers especially are addictive.  I also like the mushu and peking duck here.
author: Veronika A.

description:
I really love a lot of the food. The people there are really nice. The food also came fast. I add this restaurant to my favorites. We went here last year and really liked it so we came back this year.
I suggest the sizzling rice soup. The rice is also good. I did not want stuff inside the mu shu so they let me have it with nothing in it. I also suggest the mu shu.
Five stars!
author: Chow b.

description: Great lunch spot, price competitive, uber fast service, friendly host's, multi level seating, great aquarium, good for all sized parties, food is solid.
author: King O.

description:
Having a restaurant come highly recommended is a blessing and a curse.  It can often lead you to a location you would have otherwise missed, but more often than not, it has also heightened my expectations of the establishment to a point that I am disappointed by a "good" meal.  So, at my sisters suggestion, 8 of us went to eat in Chinatown last night at Hunan Homes.  
     We had no reservation, but were immediately seated to a nice round table towards the back.  Even though there were only 3 of us there when they sat, the friendly staff never pressured us to get started.  By the time we had all settled in, I was so ready to order it was painful.  I had been looking over their extensive menu for 20 minutes, and by that time, each minute felt like an hour.  We were unsure how much to order, so each person around the table suggested a dish.  I added a few, needless to say, to the raised eyebrows around the table.  The order was:
Prawns with Honey Walnut, Kung Pao Chicken, Beef Fried Rice, steamed white rice, Combination Chow Mein, Sizzling Beef Platter, Mongolian Beef, Hot Sour Soup, Eggplant with Spicy Garlic Sauce, and Xiao Long bao.  
   The hot and sour soup came out first, quickly followed by a succession of dishes.  The entire order had been served in about 10 minutes, which was just perfect.  it gave us each time to take a serving off of each new plate before new ones arrived.  Let me just cut to the chase and say, it was FANTASTIC!  
     I had read about the Prawns w/ walnuts and the sizzling beef platter on Yelp, and the other dishes were some of the usual standards I order at Chinese restaurants.  Here were some of my thoughts about the individual dishes.  
     The hot and sour soup was good.  Perfectly spiced, good consistency, and perfect temperature.  At first i thought there was something lacking, something missing, but reflecting back on the meal, it did exactly what it was supposed to. It awakened my pallet and got me ready for more.
     The combination chow mein was one of the best i have ever had.  Perfect consistency, not too greasy, AMAZING flavor.  I could have eaten it all to myself, but was grumpy to only taste a small serving before it was gone (I would go back for this alone).
     The prawns w/ honey walnut were good, but I was a bit disapointed.  I might have preferred the walnuts crushed and tossed with the prawns in the honey sauce before served.  Still, the prawns were perfectly cooked and had a nice, sweet flavor.  I seemed to be the only one at the table not blown away by the dish, so dont take it personally. :)
     The sizzling beef platter has an amazing presentation.  A hot cast iron plate sits with a few sizzling onions on a wooden plate, before the beef and vegtables were dropped onto it at the table.  GREAT flavors! Very crisp vegtables, tender beef... love it.
     The Mongolian beef was also one of the best i have ever had.  A perfect combination of scallions, hot peppers, a small amount of those crispy rice noodles that sometimes overwhelm the dish.   
     The kungpao chicken was perfectly executed... nice cuts of chicken with fresh vegetables.  I dont know if i will order it again.  It feels like a comfort food for me now, and im looking for new flavors over old favorites.  Still, very tasty.
     The real winner was the Eggplant with Spicy Garlic Sauce and minced pork.  If you go there, you HAVE to order this dish if none other.  I was skeptical at first when we ordered it, ive had it before at a few places and was never impressed.  So glad to be surprised.  I scooped the extra sauce over the Xiao Long Bao dumplings to perfection.  Wow.  This is getting painful to write.  
     In summary, it was incredibly consistent.  Each dish had a unique flavor (so rare in common Chinese restaurants), was perfectly cooked, and excellent presentation.  The staff were patient, funny and always attentive and available.  The bill with tip came to $164 (20% tip).  per person, it was $20.50.  I cant remember the last time I feasted at a restaurant and only spent $20.  that included three Tsingtsao's and 3 glasses of wine.  Without that, it would have been closer to $15 per person.  If you haven't eaten here, please check them out.  I hear they have free parking validation with a $20 purchase.  I will certainly be back and am very grateful for the recommendation.  I cant remember the last time a meal lived up to such a good buildup.   

As an afterthought, I saw an order of the Sizzling Prawns go out as we were leaving... they looked and smelled so good i almost ordered it togo.  Next time.  Very very good.
author: Beau S.

description: Excellent, the definition of Hunan food. I was pleasantly surprised by how good it was. Prawns were fresh and excellent. Fast and good.
author: Robert L.

description: We wondered around with no agenda and were hoping to find a busy place because that means its popular. We walked in we were greeted by 2 very nice hosts and were served right away. The lunch specials were ok, the dinner menu offers more but still very good selection. We ate orange peel chicken, BBQ pork soft noodles and asparagus with beef. It was not bad!
author: Cecilia M.

description: Went to this restaurant on a recommendation...big mistake!! I'm Hispanic and I can tell that it's fake Chinese food. Knew I made a mistake when I didn't see any asains eating there.
author: Karen H.

description:
I've been coming to this restaurant since day #1. Even before day #1, since I used to eat at 822 Jackson when it was a restaurant called Sun Tai Sam Yuen. A San Francisco native, American-born Chinese kid who has eaten all over the Bay Area can't be too wrong about Chinese food.
     Hunan Homes is consistently terrific. What they do, they do well, and the owners and staff are very nice about it. If they can prepare foods I don't like (taro root, tofu) in a way that makes them delicious, imagine what they can do with foods that I've always preferred!
     I've never had a bad meal here. Hunan Homes is definitely my comfort food!
author: Corey C.

description: my favorite place to eat in china town. service is always great, nice atmosphere.  large portions, try the Kung pao chicken!
author: Kristi H.

description: Excellent food--we enjoyed the Moo Shu chicken, sweet and sour chicken, and especially the sizzling soup!  Would give it six stars if I could.
author: Kate S.

description: I went to this place based on other yelp reviews. I had the won ton soup, which my husband absolutely loved, but I thought was a little too salty, but good flavor overall. The vegetable pot stickers and house sauce were very yummy and the mixed vegetable dinner plate was perfect: the veggies were not over cooked, they were perfect and tasted fresh, with very good flavor. The service was very prompt. I would try this place again.
author: Janet R.

description: Great take on chinese food. Order from the Chinese menu - cannot understand much unless you know Mandarin - but whatever i ordered was awesome!
author: Shyam S.

description: I've been going to this restaurant for 5 or 6 years. In the last couple of years it seems to have gone downhill. Not sure why - maybe new owners. I'm now looking for a new favorite Chinese restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Dana W.

description:
My boyfriend and I came to eat here  on Christmas night. The wait was about 25 minutes, and maintained a line the entire time we were there. I'm fairly certain it's always crowded since there were a lot of regulars coming in. Good service--always had water in my glass, and were friendly.

I think the restaurant is probably as good as people have said, we just didn't order the "right' things. We started with Potstickers--delicious, moist pork in a tender dough that was wonderfully browned on the bottom side. Very yummy, and about $6.

We then split three main dishes: Kung Pao Chicken, Chicken with String Beans, and the FIsh with Spicy Salt. The fish was interesting: basically deep-fried in a Fish-&-Chips-style, but the seasoning was really good. Salty, but spicy...There wasn't any visible spices on the surface of the fish either--it was all cooked into the batter. 

The Kung Pao was forgettable. It actually looked & tasted quite a bit like the chicken with string beans (though, chicken is chicken...so what did I expect)/ But they were cooked the same way, diced, and in a similar sauce. The beans were good--double fried so that they dry out and form a blistered skin. 

Total came to $47. It was good, but I don't think I would order either chicken dish again...I would go back, but for some of their sizzling plates, other seafood, and mu shu.
author: Sarah H.

description:
you know you have stepped into a bad chinese restaurant when you are the only asian in sight...

are people who are reviewing this place with five stars on CRACK or something? 

the food was a total waste of my dinner calories...
author: J Z.

description: Plain & simple: really, really good Chinese food.  I was looking for a non-skeezy Chinese place around Nob Hill where I could eat without risking food poisoning and this is definitely it.  My friends and I showed up around 8:30 PM on a Sunday night and the place was pretty crowded (so I'd hate to see what it's like at dinnertime on Friday or Saturday night) but somehow we got seated immediately upon walking in the door.  The restaurant itself was clean albeit tacky (but that just gave it character!) and the waiter brought out tea and water ASAP.  The food came out piping hot and everything tasted amazingly fresh.  Just remember that when you order, rice doesn't come with the entrees and needs to be ordered separately.
author: Christy L.

description:
holy crap! the lemon chicken. 
the lemon chicken, the lemon chicken.
some tasty food.

and the service was awesome. hilarious host.
author: Zachary B.

description:
Went here with friends on a recent trip to SF and we enjoyed it very much.  We were able to get seated right away (arrived around noon).  The menu here is extensive and everything looked really good.  We settled on the sizzling rice soup, chicken with spicy garlic sauce, squid with spicy salt, string bean a La Hunan and Hunan smoked pork.
The soup was very good with lots of shrimp and vegetables and a flavorful, clean broth.  The chicken was well cooked (all white meat) and the sauce had subtle spice and a strong delicious garlic flavor.  The squid was surprisingly tender and the spicy salt a little addicting.  The Hunan pork was tender and good with lots of smoky flavor.  The string beans....it is very odd for me to like a vegetable over a meat, but this dish was great, great flavor and very spicy.  I don't recall how much we paid, but most dishes are around the $9 range, which I feel is a good value.  We loved this place and can't wait to go back.
author: Donnie R.

description:
Hunan Homes, is a San Francisco Classical Chinese Restuarant
since 1983.   They are located in the heart of China Town, 
with parking close by on Kearny Street.

Hunan Homes, offers some of the favorites dishes, at fairly reasonable prices.    The food is fresh and tasty, and well presented.

I unfourtantly, could not give a 5 star rating due service issues. 
Upon coming on Wednesday evening, no host was found to seat me and my party.  Basically, you had to flag down any employee for seating.

Next, upon recieving my appetizers, I had to request the waiter 
to give us utensils, and ice water.   

Upon dining, a family of four waitied for several minutues at the door, because again, there was no host.

Lastly, portions sizes have gone down.  Half my honey walnut prawns
plate was empty, and sweet snd sour chicen had 4 times more veggies
then chicken.

There, you go.
author: Robert S.

description: We were in town and decided to visit china town.  We found this restaurant and it was packed.  This told us that the food was probably pretty good.   We got in and got a table - the waiter was quick (however he never checked back to see if we needed anything else to drink), the food came fast, and it was pretty clean.    The food was really good, we had a large group so we sampled what we all were having.   Everything that was ordered was very good!
author: Chris M.

description: hunan home is a decent three. it's the only place i know to go to for zha zhang mian, though i'm sure there are other places that are better. the xiao long baos (xlbs) are okay as well. i really haven't ordered anything else from their standard chinese menu fare but they must do pretty well for weekday lunches. for me though, there are better places to go...
author: Andrey C.

description:
lunch was inexpensive and service was attentive.  Nothing really spectacular but good food at a reasonable price.
Skip the fortune cookies, they were stale but oranges were tasty.
I found the basil chicken to be very good.  The beef dish was standard Chinese, very chewy beef.
author: William R.

description:
I spent some time researching chinatown places on yelp this afternoon. My choices were reduced to this place and Eastern Garden, the later which was so packed and out-the-door that we decided to go across the street. Also the florescent factor isn't a factor at Hunan Homes. If you want to go somewhere where you'll look good, it's Hunan Homes. They have little chandeliers and the place is painted a calming mauve - lending an air of charm and peace.

It's actually pretty busy though - most tables were taken and there was a farily large team of waiters working. 

The service is very good here. We were never for want of anything and also never felt rushed. If we finished something, we were offered more. Water and tea were refilled quickly and everyone always had a smile. 

We started with the Xiao Long Bao, thin skinned pork dumplings with broth inside. I finally found out the proper way to eat a dumpling here! Put the dumpling in a big soup spoon, add the dark dipping sauce, and guzzle all. Delicious.

Then we had dried scallop soup. It looked exactly like hot and sour, but the strands of egg and bits of mushroom were interspersed with flakey chunks of dried scallop which was tender but smokey tasting and the soup had an overall sweetness of shellfish. I found it a little thick but overall it was delicate and interesting.

Our last three items were snow pea leaves with garlic, walnut prawns, and salt n' pepper spare ribs - a bit more generic. I think I want to go on a general salt n' pepper spare ribs hunt to find my favorites. The ribs here were not greasy, and not all ribs had bone in them. I didn't find them too fatty and the spices in the coating were just right. Also, the pork had a nice porky flavor - not overcooked or dry, and meaty. Now that I've ordered walnut prawns in several places, I'm pretty much over them. Usually when I order them from Thai Chi they send them with the mayo on the side so you can add it after you receive them. Tonight they already had the mayo on them of course, and although that is specifically how the dish is always served, that to me is overkill - I prefer to dip them myself. But walnut prawns are always fun.A table next to us ordered an amazing looking whole fish. I think tapping into the seafood offerings here is probably the way to go.

We ate it all and enjoyed it. We also had a large beer and the price came to $72 with tip. This restaurant was a $$ so I pretty much expected this. Still, I want to tap into yelp's favorite "$" level places. We looked at a few of them, which my friend had been to, and made our decision. But plainly Chinatown has a lot of hidden treasures in these little hole in the wall places. I appreciated how friendly and inviting they were, and the manager was also very nice. Thanks Hunan Homes!
author: Roxmarie M.

description: Fantastic food, great service and very coZy atmosphere. Hot & sour soup best I've had in a long time If you are in the bay area dont miss this restaurant
author: Ron R.

description: Oh so very yummy! The waiters were helpful and very friendly! :) eight of us paid $105!!!!! We had leftovers too, we will definitely come back with our family :)
author: Lisa R.

description: Great restaurant off the beaten path in Chinatown. The food was excellent as was the service. We will definitely be returning again and again to Hunan Homes.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
Best Place for a Fantastic Hunan Lunch in San Francisco.

During weekdays, this restaurant offers lunch specials at extremely reasonable prices and it's always packed at lunch time.  They have the best Hot and Sour Soup on the planet, and it's ALWAYS good.  I've eaten at this restaurant about once a week from 1988 to 2000, and upon returning this week to San Francisco, I checked it out again.  And the food is perfect as always.

My usual menu choice for lunch is Kung Pao Chicken, which for the lunch special comes on a plate with white rice.  The chicken was perfectly cooked and very tasty.  

Lunch comes with tea and with your bill, you get orange slices.  Service is quick, attentive, and business friendly.  Don't expect "My name is X; I'll be your server" service, but do expect to have a waiter approach your table quickly, get your order and get it out to you in a cool efficient way.

It doesn't get any better than this--a perfect Chinese lunch on a weekday.
author: Anthony H.

description:
Here's the review I promised the owner when we were there last Monday. 

Fantastic food. All fresh (especially the vegetables) and great tasting. The SweetSour Pork was especially great. All of us at the table (3 generations) agreed that it was over the top delicious. Probably not the most authentic Chinese food. But perfect for our American palates.

Great service as well.
author: Becky S.

description: Very enjoyable meal.  Great wait staff.  Try the hot and sour soup and the pork pot stickers.
author: William S.

description: Every time, I am in SFO, this is the place I go for dinner. Great Chinese food. Try their salt and pepper fish.
author: Vijay D.

description: Their Orange Chicken and Chow Mein are good but their Sizzling Chicken is the bomb!!  I took off one star because I think for the ambience and area $11 a dish is pretty pricey.  Overall, I think Hunan Homes has pretty tasty Chinese food.
author: C L.

description: Yum. James, thank you for one of the best meals i have had in the city in a long time. Ginger and scallion crab, with the double fried crispy noodles, and some of the best service in town. well done!
author: Adam X.

description:
4* because there was no mandarin chicken and there weren't that many veggie options. with that said, the food is so authentic and delicious. not too greasy. if you take your food to go, you get little bento boxes instead of typcial square chinese food boxes (i'm just saying, it's easier to eat out of).
also, since I am a chinaphliic vegetarian, i always order things that aren't on the menu. the mother at the front desk didn't bat an eye at my request for schezuan  spicy curried chow mein with mixed vegetables and fresh tofu. it's been an hour and i'm hungry for more.

good place to escape the hustle of chinatown. they have a fishtank inside with crazy exotic fish. Thank jesus they don't have those tanks with the creatures you can eat or I would have ran out of there.

anybody know why the place is called Hunan Homes and not Hunan's Home?
author: Drew T.

description: This was one of the best Chinese food experiences I have had in a long time. The price was good, the food was delicious and bountiful. You must try the sizzling rice and sizzling beef.  We can't wait to come back here again on our next trip.
author: Stephen M.

description:
I have to preface this review by stating that there is a lot of family history with Hunan Homes.  I went first when I was 6 (and I'm not going to tell you how long ago that was!).  Then when we lived in the bay area we went many times, often with our then young children.  Now, after a 16 year absence from SF we were back.  It didn't disappoint.  The city guide in my hotel had an interview with Frances Ford Coppola and he listed it twice as his favorite restaurant in SF.  Met friends there, after 16 years we were a little worried that it would still live up to our memories and that our friends would enjoy it.  Boy, did it ever. The dumplings are delicate.  The won-tons in the won-ton soup are hand made at the restaurant and the broth rich and flavorable.  Love, love the eggplant in spicy garlic.  Now living over 1000 miles away I am going to have to figure out how to make it at home.  Enough garlic to keep the vampires away and just the right amount of spice to clear the sinuses but not enough to warrant ordering a glass of milk with dinner.
 The meal is finished as it always was with tasty fortune cookies (with real Chinese fortunes) and slices of sweet oranges.  I would love to have this closer to home but will have to plan more frequent trips back to SF just for good food!
author: Christine P.

description: It definitely caters to the tourist trade, but that doesn't make it any less delicious. You'll find the standard potstickers, spring rolls, and soups (the hot-and-sour soup is superb), but also unusual items like ningsi juen, succulent rolls usually steamed but available deep-fried as well. (The way I see it, if you're going to eat carbs, they may as well be greasy.) The Hunan spiced garlic prawns and orange beef are exceptional. Probably due to the market they attract, service is a lot less surly than in most restaurants in the area.
author: Gourmet G.

description: Good but a bit disappointing when you're expecting great. Mushu pork was some of the best I've had, pot stickers very good, other dishes not really distinguished.
author: Rob L.

description: If you thought you are not a Chinese food fan, I would strongly recommend to give it another shot in this restaurant. Food is amazing and service is fast and friendly. Instead of heavy sauces and noodles, you can try many vegetables in lighter and yummy sauces and meat to follow with that. The chicken curry and broccoli with prawns are very good. Get the rice with veggies, it is more interesting than the regular plain one.
author: Camila E.

description:
This Chicagoan checked out Hunan Homes after reading SF Yelper reviews...and VERY glad I did.  

The Hot Sour Soup and Egg Drop/Flower soup both superb.  The appetizer combo plater just so-so (I'd skip and go for another entree)  BUT then the entrees sampled were top notch...shrimp/BBQ pork fried rice, Moo Shu Pork....mmm.

THE BEST dish was their hot spicy salt dungeness crab.  I don't have a clue what the heck they do but the crab was perfectly moist inside with this dry rub outside (not battered) and it was 2  D-I-E  4.  Really.  I noted a few jalepenos on the platter and there was a faint flavor of garlic...whatever...unique and TASTY!

I also ask...what's with all the tour bus stops but I have to say my service did not suffer at all.  These servers bust a nut assuring you get your food and aren't left hanging.  If you have a small party you may want to stay in the front to avoid the bus loads of noisy tables that seat 10 each (achieved cafeteria noise decibel levels in a blink)..

Thanks again SF Yelpers....spot on with this one!
author: Dawn A.

description: So far, this is my favorite Chinese restaurant in San Francisco.  Most rice plates start around $6.25.  The service is friendly and the food is consistently good.  I've been coming here for lunch for the past 10 years and have tried just about everything on the lunch menu.  Mongolian Beef, Orange Chicken or Asparagas Prawns in Black Bean sauce are some of my favorites.  Hot and Sour soup comes with your lunch plate and is one of the best I've had in Chinatown.  You can call for reservations and parking is free at a nearby garage - just ask them for a voucher.
author: Denny L.

description: Delicious Chinese food!!! I work a block away from this place and I decided to try it instead of the other hundreds of Chinese food places around because of the reviews and I am glad I did. Great place and great service. I called ahead and my food was ready in 10 minutes for pick up, very clean place and friendly staff. I ordered the kung pao chicken because it is one of my all time favorites and It was yummy but the next time I went I ordered their spicy orange peel chicken to try something new and it was the BEST ORANGE CHICKEN i have tried to date. You can order your meals extra spicy if you like spicy food like me and they also offer brown rice instead of white.
author: Shirley E.

description:
apparently my family has been eating here in the past without me.  i got kinda sketched trying to figure out where the hell i was during those times, but i got over it.....so...

the food was good and was appropriately (maybe even cheaply) priced.  their portions are enough to share with around 4 people.  my family of 6 (minus one brother who was at work at the time) ordered 9 dishes and ended up killing each one.  the steamed snowpea leaves and spinach are tasty, and so was the walnut shrimp.  the other dishes were sufficient in flavor - the reason i say this was because I've had better tasting chinese food elsewhere - but regardless, the food was good enough to get the job done.

their restrooms are clean - a plus. the chinese restaurants i've been in the past tend to be in need of desperate maintenance and cleaning.
author: Paul A.

description:
After an inservice in the FiDi, my coworker and I decided to stay in the area and pick and choose...

After walking a block or two, we decided Chinese Food, and being idiots, we both decided to twirl around, lol, yes, in the streets, and point to the place when the other person said, "STOP." 

It was either between Great Hunan or Hunan Homes.

Great Hunan looked too ghetto, considering the fact it was in the FiDi, but Hunan had a "Yelp" sticker, so off we went on our lunch adventure.

Lunch was pretty good, considering that we're in Chinatown. Service was above par, yes, in a Chinese setting. 

Great lunch specials, nothing over $7, which includes complimentary HOT & SOUR SOUP (+1, ooh I love... it was actually good too.. not watered down! I swear, if they gave me Wonton soup, I was going to pass. Jk) Rice, tea and 2 pieces of fruit. 50c extra for brown rice.

She got the Broccoli w/Prawns $6.45. (I approve. Decent amount too! And they actually evened out the amount of prawn and broccoli)
Prawns w/Honey Walnut $12.50. Can you believe it? But then again, it's my fault for looking at the Dinner section... Still good... 

2 hours parking validation after 5pm @ Portsmouth or Holiday Inn.
author: Jennifer S.

description: I come here with regulars and always order an item that isn't listed on the menu.  Let me just say it's wonderfully salty, spicy, deep fried, and always fresh.  As far as appetizers go, I really like the potstickers and fried prawns.  Eggrolls, not so much.  The hot and sour soup is consistently delicious.  Once, I strayed from my usual lunch plate and ordered the mongolian beef and didn't care for it much.  You can pay extra for brown rice w/ the lunch plates, which is nice, but I've always stuck w/ white rice.  Service is fast and the owners are very welcoming.  We always walk here, but apparently they will validate parking in certain locations (call to confirm).
author: Lisa C.

description: Lucky for me, my bf's family has been patronizing this place for an eternity, so I have never been faced with the challenge of picking a random sketchy place in Chinatown. Hunan always delivers, the mushu rocks my world, and I enjoy the Kung pow prawns (say that 5 times fast) and spicy garlic chicken. The menu is extensive, the prices are decent and it is so yummy. I always bring people from out of town, and they are quite impressed. The only flaw this place had was that they only offered white rice, but not so anymore..now I have whole grains to absorb my sake. Credit cards, brown rice, and a Chinese burrito, it's all I really need.
author: Cassie C.

description: I've tried many places for Kung Pao chicken in the city. This is my number one place. They use fresh and crunchy peanuts. I also tried other dishes, very tasty. I give them 5 stars, just for Kung Pao chicken alone! The staff are very friendly too. I believe you get to park your car at the washington parking lot for a couple of hrs free after 5pm if you dine there.
author: The Black Cat C.

description: This place is great if you can handle spicy. Staff are friendly, service is quick and prices are reasonable!
author: Dayfu Z.

description:
This is my dad's favorite Asian restaurant--and heads there for lunch every time he visits me in San Francisco.
We LOVE the sizzling eel!
author: Amy C.

description: Dude, where's my chicken?  The lunch special that was supposed to be chicken contained the smallest bits of what I hope was chicken.  The sauce was tangy and definitely had a kick, but the dish wasn't all that.  Not likely to walk 8 blocks for lunch here anytime soon despite the $5.45 lunch price tag.
author: Amy Z.

description:
I went to this restaurant becasue it was highlighted on Eye On The Bay this past weekend.  So when my husband (who is a very busy man) invited me to lunch yesterday, I quickly suggested the "Hunan Homes".  Well, I used to work in the city and frequented quite a few of the restaurants that feature asian cuisine. I remembered trying this restaurant many years ago and not ranking them very high on the list. But because they gave it such high profile, I thought I would try it again. Unfortunately, it is exactly as I remembered it. We had the hot and sour soup, the combo rice, the mongolian beef and the spicy chicken and garlic dishes.  The first 3 dishes were bland at best. Then after we were just about done with the other 3 items, they brought the chicken dish out (at least I think it was chicken). YUCK!  So, I pushed it aside and continued to finish the rest of the food we were given. Well, when it was time to pay the bill, the waiter came over and asked were we done? We said yes. He gestured toward the chicken dish as if to ask what about it?  My husband very quietly said - "she did not like it". He then asks - if we want to take it home? Are you kidding me? So we still very quietly said - NO. The waiters response was to hunch his shoulders up, take the plate away and dump it! No, "I'm sorry you did not enjoy your dish, can I get you something else?" "Can I get the manager?" Nothing at all to acknowledge my experience.  

The food and service that I experienced yesterday did not deserve the glowing highlight that it was given this past weekend. As a matter of fact, there should be a disclaimer encouraging people to go there at their own risk.  On the other hand, the "Great Hunan" right down the street on Columbus has been there for many years. The food is terrific and fresh. It is a hole in the wall, but I have not been disappointed.  By the way, I have absolutely no connection to the "Great Hunan".  Just offering up and alternative.   :-)
author: Annie W.

description: The best Hot and Sour soup I have ever had. Everything else was mediocre.  Also I finally realized that they call lo mein - chow mein out here.
author: kristen l.

description: This place is awesome. Like Sile P. says, this is one of the good, cheap gems on Jackson.
author: Michael C.

description: I went here for the 2nd time for their good food.  However, being reminded of the small portions and terrible customer service, I doubt I will return.  The lady who seats you is very friendly but the waiters don't wait until you're finished talking to them before they just walk away.  As I also said the portions served are small and around 10 dollars which had us having to order additional food just to get full.  You also have to go down 3 sets of stairs just to use the bathroom.  Funny, I thought it was like they were just waiting to get sued, lol.
author: Doreen B.

description: My dad knew the owner a long time ago. We go here every so often. The fact that it is in Chinatown where it's hard to find street parking kind of drives us away. But if we happen to be in the neighborhood, we'll go there. I really like their food and staff. We used to order this dish that had pig intestines and pork blood which I LOVED. I haven't had that in years though because it isn't the healthiest thing in the world. I recommend trying this place.
author: Steph C.

description: This is a great place to eat on Sunday's with the family.  Here is a protip for you all.  On sunday ask them if there are any special dishes that are not on the menu.
author: Buddy R.

description: This is my Favorite Chinese Restaurant! I have been going there for twenty years and the food has always been hot, delicious and satisfying. They serve their entrees with hot tea, and orange slices and fortune cookies. I have never gotten sick from their food and I usually order a to go order  for the road after my dinner since it is so good I eat all of it!
author: Vanessa O.

description: I've eaten here basically all my life. My parents brought me here all the time when I was little. I LOVE their hot and sour soup and it's honestly the best i've tasted anywhere. They have a good variety of food on the menu, but if it's going to be your first time there, ask the owner James to recommend you a selection. The staff is very friendly and efficient. Make sure if you have a big party to reserve in advance! My favorite Chinese restaurant, hands down!
author: Miss Y.

description: Second Chinese place in China Town this trip.  Good Chinese food, great service, fresh and fast.  Liked everything about it.
author: Mike C.

description: Thank you yelpers for the recommendations.  We ordered to-go here for a night in and everything was awesome.  I was sad to say that there was no leftover to eat.
author: Anna S.

description: Good thing they have the big round family style tables because everyone in your office is going to show up if they hear you are going. Everything super yummy, the oft mentioned walnut prawns are to die. Attentive, accommodating service too!
author: Krismet C.

description: Delicious! i found this on yelp and asked exiting patrons how it was and they told me "it is the best chinese we've ever had." well, it was delicious. the one waiter took care of the whole restaurant and was super friendly. I'd come back here again! Not only that but most chinese food makes you feel sick immediately, this was not the case here.
author: A N.

description: Delicious!  This place used to be a family favorite until we moved out of the area.  I hadn't been here for a few years and made my way back this weekend.  The food was just as good as it used to be if not better.  The salt and pepper crab was one of the best I've ever had and also the smoked duck.  I'll definitely be coming back again soon.
author: Smokey G.

description:
I have been eating here for over 20 years.  The food is consistently great and the prices are very reasonable.

They make the best hot and sour soup!

Great place for a quick lunch especially if you work around the financial district.  Service is fast and courteous.  The host (James) and hostess (Lillian) know the regular customers by name and I can tell there are lots of regulars which indicates that this restaurant is worth coming back to again and again.  Menu has a large selection for the lunch entree specials which includes the delicious hot & sour soup, and dessert (slices of fresh oranges and fortune cookie).

Dinner menu has a huge variety of foods.  

Definitely a 5-star restaurant.
author: wee l.

description: I really like this place.  I should start by saying that I tend to prefer americanized chinese food to the real authentic stuff, but I hate PF Changs.  Hunan Home is what I imagine PF Changs was like before they blew up, I may be way off on that though.   Anyway,   I love the garlic chicken, orange peel chicken and peing duck at Hunan Home.
author: Raj M.

description: there is soooo great place that everybody shuld go there at least once. I am a their big fan now! I have ordered their food for several times becasue they are all sooo delicious. their special meal is soy milk and taiwanese style of rice roll. they are sooo good and they are offered only on the weekend. Also,
author: Yin-Pei S.

description: By far my favorite in SF for chinese and clearly a finanical district hot spot as they are quick. Plus you can decide how hot you want your entree to be, talk about a complete sinus flush!  Great food, totally cheap and includes hot and sour  soup, tea with each meal and to finish, orange slices and a fortune cookie.  This is the ONLY place in chinatown i will eat at AND won't do a number on the ol' colon.....TMI but so TRU!
author: erica u.

description: Went on restaurant.com and found this great Chinese restaurant. Enjoyed every morsel of the food, from wor wonton soup, potstickers, beef and stringbeans and seafood with eggplant. Could tell by the regulars in the restaurant it was well liked and frequented.
author: Beverly K.

description: Five stars says it all. Great place, family, and food are the key to this restaurant's longevity. Hunan Home's is not for everyone, but it manages to please a wide range from locals, to celebrity, to tourist. The Buddhist iconography isn't just decorative, so I guess  a little help from Buddha goes a long way.
author: Bibi R. R.

description: I ALWAYS come to this restaurant whenever I'm in Chinatown. Ever since I was 5 this was the place my family would eat at. It is by far the best Chinese restaurant in SF! Mongolian Beef is off the hook! Can't go wrong w/ Broccoli Beef or Garlic chicken either!
author: Ashraf C.

description: I love their xiao long bao! Order two sauces if you have more than one person eating because the ginger in the sauce is amazing to top the XLB with! When I lived in Taiwan I learned the proper way to eat them, definitely helps to not burn your tongue. You take one out and put it in your soup spoon, poke a hole in it to cool it off and let the broth spill into the spoon, top it with the sauce and some of the ginger strands in it. So amazing! Their mushu pork is great! They wrap your first one with 2 spoons in front of you to show you how it's done, I love watching the precision! The string beans with minced pork and steamed rice, is just a great combo! The hot and sour soup is fantastic and just warms you right up! The sizzling rice soup wasn't to my liking but everyone else I went with loved it. They always give you a complimentary tea, the last time it was jasmine and just the way I like it! We had a lovely woman host/waitress she was just wonderful and made the meal delightful.
author: stephanie w.

description:
we had the dumplings, chicken corn soup, sizzling plate (beef), and the yang chow fried rice. 
they're all very good and the service was excellent too.
author: Sheren H.

description: Get the Orange Chicken!!  They fry it in a batter that is light as a cloud!!!  The pot stickers were great as well.  Avoid the places that try to get you in the door with free pot stickers/ice cream.  Go here.  You'll be glad.
author: TJ M.

description: So delicious!  My friend and I were going to go to House of Nanking, but I'm glad I checked yelp first.  The hostess looked at us a little suspiciously when we showed up without reservations even though it was just a Monday night, but after that everyone was very friendly.  There was a mix of white and Asian people in there, so it seems to appeal to everyone.   Got the broccoli beef and chow mein; those two dishes plus rice and two Tsingtaos was $28.  The oyster sauce on the beef was delicious (though there was a little too much of it), and the chow mein was out of this world.  It's a nice place, with tablecloths and everything.  Plus there were two parking spaces right across the street!  Score.
author: Gina K.

description: Went to Hunan Home for the first time last night with friends and by far the BEST Hot and Sour soup I've had in a long while! The food was deliciously spicy and the Salt and Pepper Spear Ribs was so tasty and tender. My husband even liked the food considering he doesn't eat much spicy food (I'm slowly converting him into a spicy freak like me!) I work a few blocks from there, and I will definitely go there for lunch and drag a few co-workers with me!
author: Annie L.

description: I used to come here all the time when I lived close by. Consistently good food & good service. The Hunan chicken is garlicky & very flavorful. If you like unagi, you'll love the sizzling platter (huge piece of unagi cooked Chinese style!)  Food is slightly Americanized but sometimes that's what you're in a mood for
author: Jenny W.

description: After reading all the glowing reviews I had to go check this place out (with a very cute date no less =)). The staff was super attentive, the portions were perfect, the price was reasonable, and yes,...the prawns with honey walnets are to DIE for. I loved the atmosphere....simple and quiet.  Check out the huge blowfish in the front tank! He's always smilin and I named him stanley:)
author: Stacy L.

description: Based on the reviews I read, I thought I would try this place out.  I ordered some Orange chicken for take-out at lunch and was disappointed in what I got.  Maybe I ordered the wrong thing on the menu, maybe I shouldn't have gotten it take-out, maybe I should've...blah blah blah.  Well, in any case, my chicken was smothered with the orange sauce that tasted and looked more like orange marmalade than anything else.  I didn't even get the hot and sour soup that I was looking forward to from all the reviews.  So, be warned that if you get take-out from the lunch menu, it does not include the soup -- boo hoo! Anyway, I may be lured back in for an in-house dining experience, but with all the other Chinese restaurants around I doubt it.
author: Katie M.

description: Great food and good service.  Definitely a place to go with your co-workers so you can go family style and taste many yummy dishes, like "Yummy Fish," a sweet and sour fish delight.  Another new favorite is the crab with spicy salt, which you HAVE to get when it is in season.  This October is the restaurant's 25th anniversary... hullo, if they've been in SF that long, it MUST be good.
author: Lily S.

description: Food is decent but service was horrible.  I'm not saying they are racist but I will say we were the only Caucasions in the place and our service was horrid.  Impatient/rushed us while taking order, brought food out and said nothing, did not visit table again until picking up check.
author: Brent T.

description: Really outstanding fare here. My friend, who has a large family, regularly requests ten orders of potstickers to carryout after eating here and they're gone quickly once they arrive home. With good reason, as they're the best potstickers I've ever eaten. Other things that shine here for me are on their seafood menu, somehow fish in the context of chinese food usually doesn't work out for me- but when ordered here it's been crisp on the outside and moist inside and bathed in some ridiculously good sauce. Well worth the hassle of trying to find parking in the area.
author: Greycella L.

description:
best chinese food i've had in chinatown for the following reasons:

1) english on the menu
2) waiter that understands english
3) because of #2, ability to ask for no msg on the dishes and no meat in the soup
author: Lindsay T.

description: Authentic, great tasting and good value.  I'm pretty picky when it comes to Chinese restaurants but this one consistently delivers.  It's a great place to go if you have a craving for good Chinese food without breaking your wallet.  The menu is pretty extensive and will please both native, more adventurous Chinese diners as well as those who prefer more of the standard fare.  The atmosphere leaves little to be desired (think pink and blue/green interior) but personally not important when you want affordable, yummy Chinese food.
author: Judy C.

description: Two Thumbs Up !  Welcome Home!  Most friendly atmosphere. Very uncommon especially in Chinese casual restaurants/Chinatown.  I'd go back anytime!
author: Bella R.

description: Was looking for a kick-ass Chinese food place in Chinatown and Yelp led my wife and I in the right direction. I seriously have been thinking about the meal I had ever since I left. Great food, ambiance, and service. Get a bowl of chow mein and some Tsingtao beer and tell me you don't leave this place with a smile on your face.
author: K. G.

description: Our favorite place for over 15 years.  Took our 8 year old granddaughter there last week and she wanted to go back again so we ate there twice in just three days.  Soups are fantastic and our all time favorite is Prawns with Honey Walnuts.  Would go back to San Francisco just to eat there.
author: Lorraine D.

description: This wasn't our first choice in Chinatown since R&G lounge was the restaurant we decided on after reading yelp reviews.  We ended up here after being told that we would have to wait more than 1 hour for a table @ R&G.  There was a short wait @ HH too, but not as bad as the wait @ R&G.  We immediately knew the service was going to be less than great by the way we were greeted at the door.  The waiter forgot our water first, but then when he did bring the water, he completely ignored the fact that my wife asked for water w/ no ice.  The food itself was not bad.  The chicken corn soup and the hunan chicken were good (not great), and the vegetable chow mein was average.  Overall, the experience was average.  I am hoping the service is better when its not as busy.
author: Hardip S.

description: seriously THEE BEST Chinese food ever!!!!!!! the best and only Chinese food I will eat! my family and I have been coming here for years and I have not one think bad to say about this place!!
author: Aj G.

description: We walked over from the Financial District Hilton, an easy walk.  We went about 6 PM on a Thursday night, and there was no problem being seated at all.  Service was super attentive but not intrusive.  Food was absolutely amazing!  If it were closer than a 6-hour drive from home, we'd be here often.  We especially enjoyed the cashew prawns.
author: Irene A.

description: Good solid performer. Busy with tourists.
author: Daniel K.

description: We had hot n sour soup, shrimp fried rice, string beans, and clams with black bean sauce.....everything was pretty good...but the hot n sour soup is what would make me go back.....great service!
author: stephanie n.

description: Pretty good chinese food--I used to come every other week or so when I worked in the area. I almost always enjoyed it while I ate but often felt a little off later on. Their hot and sour soup that comes with lunch is great! I liked their green bean chicken a lot except for the one time I got it and most of the chicken pieces were not cooked through. VERY nice servers.
author: Katrina L.

description: Ate here for lunch today.  I had the Pot Stickers and the tomato beef chow mien.  For the price, I was very happy.  The portions were nice and the food was above average (you can certainly eat better Chinese food, but it will cost you more).  The service was insanely fast!  I can't vouch for the dinner menu, but lunch had a big menu with decent prices.  Will be lunching here again soon!
author: Ryan M.

description: This is the best Chinese place I've ever been to. Everything I've had here has been amazing. The servers are very attentive. I could eat here every day.
author: David S.

description: We have found this to be a really amazing place to take out of town guests with varying levels of Chinese food familiarity!  Not only is the food delicious and the staff helpful, but it is quiet enough to hold a converstation with your table.   This is where we eat when it is just the two of us, or when family is in town.  We save Nan King for our New York pals!
author: neil a.

description: I've been coming for as long as I can remember. Having grown up in Sausalito, I will be eternally grateful for my parents' extra effort in introducing this place to me as young kid. Hunan Homes is not distinguishable from other restaurants in China town based on its decor and exterior. However, I've yet to be disappointed by a meal and would not dare go elsewhere. This restaurant is a must.
author: Alexander M.

description: Wow! Thats all I have to say. I sat down for a meal here on a recent trip to the Bay. (Sorry Benny! Didnt get a chance to visit). They never fail to make it like home. If you love soup, you have to try the hot and sour!!! The staff is very friendly and helpful. I'm always a sucker for walnut prawns and these dont disappoint.
author: Manny V.

description: So many reviews have been written what more can I say. Good food, fast service, nice people. In town for spring break and have found yelpers to know what they are talking about.
author: Audra D.

description: This place might as well be called Sherlock Holmes because the taste has serious adaptations toward the English pallet with no remnants of authentic Chinese food.  Portions are very small.  The staff seemed a little shady and wouldn't give me a parking validation until the clock struck 5pm.
author: John D.

description: I have yet to find a Chinese restaurant to top this place.  Food is great, and the service is good and esp. FAST.
author: Rowzbud R.

description:
What's with all the tour groups? 

Went here for dinner with the Mrs. after recommendations from my Australian brother in law who got a recommendation from his hotel. After all the reviews we've read, we figured it should be pretty good. We walked in on a Friday night with no reservations at about 6 and were promptly seated. Hot and sour soup was very good. We ordered the curry chicken and hunan prawns. Downed them in no time flat. We were stil hungry so the waitress suggested we try the beef sizzling plate. Great dish! Overall, very good food and friendly service. But what's the deal with the tour bus groups? We sat there for almost 2 hours and we must've seen at least 3 groups of tourists with cameras swinging from their necks numbering anywhere from 12 to about 25 folks each. They all had this dumbfounded look on their face like they had never had chinese food before. They must have some huge cave in the back where they cater to groups as the front dining area isn't that big and it was consistently full all evening. Overall, a good night out for chinese, but with so many other options available, we'll chalk this up as good place to go, but we'll try other places next time. Don't want to get stuck in a rut.
author: Tom B.

description: it's good, they have a tofu, pork blood, intestine dish here thats pretty good and that's all i go for.
author: Sam K.

description: Hunan Homes, is a great restuarrant for Chinese food, that leaves you satisfied, and a joy in experiencing this place.     Hunan Homes, has a great selection of items, Theres so many good ones to choose from its hard to choose.    The portions are generous,   Prices reasonable.   Service is quick, and attenative.  Finding a good chinese restuarant is difficult, with so many to choose from.   You can't go wrong with Hunan Homes.
author: JERRY B.

description: I have been eating there for over 5 years now and the food is consistently good.  They are an amazing value considering that you get soup and oranges and fortune cookies all with your meal.  The food hasn't changed a bit since I first went and the waiters remain attentive and friendly.  Don't judge this place by the drab 70s' decor.  Best value for Chinese food in town!
author: Mark C.

description: i've been going to hunan homes forever..but recently they really disappointed me with their unethical business practice. we ordered a dish of cold jellyfish. we've had jellyfish many times, and we're chinese.. but guess what? when they gave us the dish, we could tell immediately it was "fake" jellyfish made of flour!!! when we asked them about it they tried to argue that it was real jellyfish, until the boss came out and quietly swapped it out with a plate a real ones.. can't believe it.. can you imagine if it was someone who's never had real jellyfish? would've gotten ripped off!! we will never go there again! DISHONEST!!
author: Chemistry S.

description: This place has been around for years and the food is still good.  They have the best potstickers and onion pancake.  Their chicken chow mein, pork and green cabbage rice cake, tofu, pork blood, and intestine hot pot is great, too.
author: Mary L.

description: Tasty, inexpensive, pleasant.  Try the squid in spicy salt.
author: Michael L.

description:
food taste = 4
price / value = 3.5
service = 3
environment = 3.5

it wasn't like the place blew me away, but the food is tasty and good.  service is ok and the place is clean.  very average.

to me, there are a lot better places around chinatown where the prices are much lower for lunch.
author: Bryce K.

description: Have gone to Hunan Home for a hearty and good priced lunch a few times recently. The food's good and service fast. I went for lunch yesterday and had the hunan smoked pork lunch special and unfortunately had a shard of metal in my food - it stuck me in the back of the throat. I'm sad because Hunan Home was a good lunch spot but it's now off my list.
author: J M.

description: Excellent Hunan cuisine.!  Being a Cantonese lover, I I love to try other things and broaden my horizons; after seeing and hearing about Hunan Homes for years, I finally tried them yesterday.  The pot stickers are crispy golden with a wonderfully seasoned ground pork, ginger, and cabbage filling.  The Hunan Homes bread, which should technically be a dessert, is crispy and greasless with an icing like dipping sauce that is sweet and creamy.  The chicken with orange peal is crispy and greasless, some pieces more tender than others, but still good with not too much badder in a light orange flavored sauce with slices of orange peal.  the steamed rice is firm not soggy.  The service is very friendly and attentive.  I just wished I would have asked about northern style dim sum as they may or may not still serve that on weekends.  So, for excellent Hunan cuisine at reasonable prices with friendly service in a casual atmosphere, Hunan Homes cannot be beat.  Keep up the good work guys.!
author: Brian S.

description: stumbled in here after my friend alexandria gave me a hot stone massage in her nob hill studio. i wandered into chinatown seeking the comfort of a chair, a table, and some food of my people. i've been hearing about this place since my extrajewishboss at wells fargo talked about it a decade ago, so when i saw it, i had to check it out. they were doing brisk business and quite busy, but i never felt rushed nor ignored. yay for great service! for some reason i decided to get the gringo-est of lunch plates - the general tso's chicken.  i liked how the chicken tasted like chicken and not fried batter in cornstarchy sicklysweet sauce like in most places. i'm down to try it again sometime for sure to add more stars to this review.
author: Winter R.

description:
I will begin by digressing into one of those moments of life where you sense a connection beyond tangible reality.  The year, 1996 and there was a charming elderly man who seemed to manage this restaurant (or at least the floor).  He often was at the door to great customers and he seemed to take particular joy out of the fact that I often poured gobs of their wonderful chili sauce onto the food on my plate.  One day, after eating, I got up to use the restroom before leaving.  Just as I was going down the stairs to the restroom, that man came over and said "follow me."  So, he lead me on a tour of the upstairs rear banquet room and was proudly describing it to me and finally to a small toilet tucked away in some corner.  He waited and then lead me back to my table after I finished.  Since this was a regular lunch spot for me, I noticed for the next several weeks I didn't see the old man.  Finally, I asked a staff person what happened.  They said he had been diagnosed with late stage lung cancer and had quickly died (he used to smoke outside the restaurant).  I was immediately touched that I had been given a special farewell from that man and of course Hunan Home always has a special place in my heart ever since.

Over the years, I have perceived changes in the food and ambience here and there, sometimes for the better sometimes not.  But overall, this is still one of the best choices in Chinatown and at this price level still worthy of five stars.

Eternal thanks to my little old friend for making Hunan Home a special place to me (now I need tissue to wipe away the tears).
author: Richard P.

description: i've got different categories of chinese food and a favorite for each -dim sum (koi palace), hot pot (spices II) and "regular" chinese food -stir-friend with rice type. hunan homes is my clear fave in the last category. their lunch special is the single best food to value deal in the city - the best hot and soup soup EVAR, entree with rice, oranges and cookies for about $5. it's not on the lunch menu, but be sure to try the squid with spicy salt too - it's awesome. the staff is very nice as well.
author: Erica W.

description: This place is the best.  I've moved to the South Bay and haven't been as often as I used to.  Going with a group is the best so you can sample a wide selection.  I have not had a bad dish or meal here and it is the cleanest Chinese restaurant I have been in.
author: Tim B.

description:
I have been to Hunan homes on and off since 1988 since I work down at the financial district.  I just went there today for lunch since it's been four or five months that I went there.  Believe me I had tried many dishes before, but I felt like chow mein this time.  I ordered the combination chow mein which includes chicken, pork and shrimp.  First, I don't know if it's me or the plate of noodles seemed less than a year ago.  It was priced at about $6.95.  That's pretty expensive considering that I could've gotten a whole lot more at another restaurant for $5.00.  Then I could not find any shrimp in my chow mein.  I even showed the waiter and he said that he could take my dish back.  No way am I letting my dish out of sight.  When I was done and we received our check.  There was no deduction whatsoever on it.  I had to tell them that I shouldn't pay full price when I didn't have shrimp in it.  I usually don't complain but it's the principle of it.  So, they just deducted 50 cents off of it.  Oh come on, that noodles dish has to be cheap to make since it did not have very much meat in it.  I don't think I'll be back for a while.  It used to be so much friendlier too.  

I still say that their hot and sour soup is the best in SF and their oranges are usually so sweet.  Their kungpao dishes are yummy and smoked pork too.
author: Lisa W.

description: This place was recommended by the concierge at our hotel. It's a hole in the wallish place in Chinatown. We made reservations through the concierge and our table was waiting for us despite a small crowd in the waiting area. We had lemon chicken, pork fried rice, curry chicken, and kung pao chicken. Everything was solid, not unbelievable. Total bill including beers was 70 bucks. Service was good and the food came out fast. I would go back.
author: Alan S.

description: i took my family here for dinner recently when they were in town. it was a fairly nice meal. the restaurant looked really clean and well kept. my 3 year-old niece loved the fish tank in front. she spent at least 15 minutes identifying all the fish a la Finding Nemo. must orders: mu shu pork, fried won ton, and honey-walnut shrimp. all three of those items were the best versions i'd ever tasted. the pork chow mein was aiite as well as the chicken fried rice and won ton soup. my only complaint was that the portions were a little small for the price of the food. also if you don't want to get stuck waiting forever, make reservations or get there before 6:30p.m.
author: Melissa A.

description: Haven't had one bad thing at this place. I only order off the lunch menu. Hunan chicken/beef, Kung Pao, Generals, all tasty. free soup. Under $7.00. jackpot.
author: J. B.

description: I came here with my husband craving wonton soup and jasmine tea. The restaurant had a nice cute mom and pop feel with pink table cloths and little crystal chandelliers. We were seated immediately, the service was very prompt and the wonton soup was DELISH! I was very pleased. When our moo shoo pork came, however, my husband was unpleasantly surprised by a one inch copper staple in his food... Luckily he didn't bite down on it too hard. We quietly pointed it out to one of the servers and they ended up taking it off of our bill in the end. Things like that can happen at any restaurant, and they handled the situation  well. The food (especially the soup) was very good, but honestly the flukey staple kinda dampered  the experience. I'm sure other visitors will love it though provided they font have a staple in their food, which I'm sure they won't. For the good food with good service at a good price, not considering the staple, I'm giving it 3 stars.
author: Tiffany O.

description: My absolute favorite Chines Restaurant in the city. This place is always packed during lunch time. In my opinion the quality of food and service is top notch especially when compared to the many other places I've been to in China Town. The location can be a slight problem if you cummute via public transportation but if you drive its actually conveniently close to an underground parking structure. The interior had been redone a few times since I first started going there but it has a nice big fish tank at the entrance with salt water fish and the tables are well placed with only the bathroom being a bit inconveniently placed downstairs opposite the kitchen. I highly recommend this place.
author: Richard N.

description: I love this place.  We sometimes go here once a week as the food is fantastic.  Just great Hunan food.  My favorites are the chicken chow mein, mu shu chicken, succulent bread, hot and sour soup, onion cake, smoked pork, and more!  I know you're saying some of these items are so basic, but they truly have the best food.  Service is straight forward and fast, but the decor is a bit old.  I have to subtract one star as some of the plates are still a bit dirty so we often have to ask for replacement dishes and utensils.  The food is definitely 5 stars - Get a new dishwasher and this place will be a 5!
author: Y W.

description: Based on Yelp we decided to try Hunan Homes.  We were not disappointed! We tried 3 dishes that many here at Yelp thought were outstanding. The hot/sour soup, moo-shu pork and the spicy, garlic eggplant.  All three were delicious! The hot/sour soup is exactly that.  What makes it different than other variations is that the soup is very hot (spicy) and very sour.  It may take a few tastes before you can appreciate/adjust to this significant difference with other reciepes.  The moo-shu was much better than most others. Not in the least bit greasy and discernable, dfferent flavors.  The eggplant was stupendous.  Perfectly cooked and again not greasy. Many times this dish is loaded with oil; not this one.  A couple of notes about customer service.  We had a reservation and arrived 10 minutes early but we were seated right away.  Also, the waitress forgot to add the two glasses of wine we had. I didn't pay any attention and paid the bill. She then told us we did have to pay which is of course, only fair. However, a gentleman that I took to be the owner said we didn't have to pay because it was their error.  How often does THAT happen!  I can't say enough good things about Hunan Homes.  We live in Marin and I only wish this restaurant was here because we don't get into the city too often.  Eat here without hesitation!
author: brian s.

description:
third review for yelp... 

this was the weirdest coincidence EVER!  I was searching for a fri night (02/26/10) chinese restaurant in anticipation of our trip to SF for Chinese New Year... I knew we DIDN'T want to try to eat in chinatown on sat night, so we planned on fri instead... found a restaurants.com cert and then checked against the yelp reviews... I was uncertain based on some of the yelpers, but went ahead and booked... made reservations for 8.30 on fri... here's the weird thing: when we walked in, I realized it was the same place that we'd wandered into three years past - now if I'd TRIED, there's no way I could have known that... and if I'd needed to remember the place, it wouldn't have happened... fortunately, we'd very much enjoyed the meal previously and so I was confident we'd like it again...

here's what we ordered:
- peking duck - very good!  crispy skin, moist meat, nice presentation
- mu shu pork - nothing special
- savory / succulent bread - we got the steamed and the fried... GOOD STUFF, but go for the fried!!! - but isn't that always the way??? fried is ALWAYS better :-)
- spring rolls - decent, not the best ever... personally, I prefer the Vietnamese method of frying versus the Chinese - crispier and less greasy IMO
- pot stickers - very tasty - nicely done
- hot and sour soup - great sour flavor, not spicy enough
- beef with green onion - good, but Ma's in Fullerton is better... tender beef w/ a good gravy.
- orange chicken (I know, I know, how honky can we get??? but the 'rents INSIST on getting typical honky-chinese rather than enjoying something off the beaten path like chicken feet... what can I do?) which was not spectacular, but not bad either - just very safe...
- spicy garlic chicken - again, we're white, so their 'spicy' is relative - I would have liked it spicier...
- Eggplant w/ spicy garlic sauce w/ brown rice - great spicing, very tender
- Prawns w/ honey walnut - NOT GOOD!!!! much too much mayo... again, Ma's in Fullerton is much better

this place did not disappoint and considering we were pleasantly surprised to have found a place we'd previously enjoyed... and with the $50 off cert, it was only $170 for seven people with a HUGE amount of food and multiple drinks (beers and wine).  Service was good once it got rolling, but it did take almost 20 minutes for our waters / tea to come out and for us to see a waiter to put our food order in.

VERY glad I'd had the presence of mind to call in around noon-ish for a reservation as they were PACKED when we got there at 8.30!

We'd definitely come back next time we're in SF, which will be next May :-)
author: FOXWOOD F.

description: so close and so great.  so far my favorite in chinatown.   now I just have a few hundred more places to try to be able to say it is the best in SF.
author: mike V.
